description:
This was the best Indian and Pakistani food i have ever had, almost 15 years ago when they had this location i remember everything was cooked at this location its was soul food, i remembered long lines friday and saturday night and cooks happy faces and great music, then they opened few years ago 3 locations and quantity damaged quality, i stoped coming here for some time until today, i come to this location that keeps my most delicious food memories in america, i used to live just to eat here.today, i tried nihrat beef shank slowly cooked in spices with ginger . It was one of the most delicious food i ever had, rice and vegetarian spinach it was soul food again. Nobody in san francisco can make Pakistani and Indian food so tasty i lose my self in this delicious taste of herbs spices and tender meat . Shalimar crew at this location is great old crew they renovated the restaurant it feel
Great to be here again. I encourage everyone to try this amazing dish 10.95 
Keep up the good work Shalimar we need you guys at your best because when you guys are at your best nobody can come close to you!
Best Indian and Pakistani food in USA, Thank you for such a great food today, god bless !!!
author: Nedim P.

description:
I'm sorry but I have to say it. These people are rude, very rude. Non considerate for their customers at all...

The hygiene is 00. If you going to Shalimar on Jones just be observant , very important don't get fooled by the smell of the barbecue chicken ....it smells the same everywhere....

The table are very sticky ,durty...you will notice it.. .
The dishes (plates, forks , spoons,knives....close look you will see that they are not clean.....)

The server : durty shirt (the old man) specially around the waist. His finger touching you food when he carries your plate... close look at his nails...discusting ....keep in mind he is not not serving food only  but he s everywhere from bathroom to kicthen....to handling food.....
The man cooking ....heavy dude ( doesn't give a f**attitude ) just look at him when he pull the tandoori from the oven ....he uses a dirty white towell to remove the meat from the iron stick .... you'll see it from your table ...
None of these folks wears gloves .....
Where is the SF health services???!!!.
author: Sahara Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here one night for dinner after reading all the raving Yelp reviews. I was excited to try the goat karahi dish and my boyfriend got the chicken tikka masala, and we ordered a side of naan bread. 

My goat dish was good - but not the best. It had a gamey flavor which I liked, it actually tasted a bit like lamb. But overall, I think it could've had a better flavor and mix of spices that I crave when eating Indian food. The mix of spices was good at best, but not overwhelmingly amazing. Same with the tikka masala. I actually enjoyed my boyfriend's dish better than mine, but I've had some pretty amazing chicken tikka masala dishes elsewhere so this was a bit underwhelming. Naan bread was yummy though.
author: Carina P.

description:
Pakistani food always hits the spot after a long day. This was close to the ice cream museum, so we walked here after. The food came out in about 10-15 minutes. The naan was not the same very thick compared to the other Shalimar. I specifically asked the guy to make the seekh kabob well done and it was not. There was this nasty taste/smell of beef. Other than that, the chicken was very good as well as the CTM. 
There are more locations of Shalimar that will not disappoint you. You have to try this food if you haven't yet!!!!!
author: Hafsah K.

description: For me this place is the best Indian place in the Bay Area (I think I was there more then 10 times). I'm not from India but I was there. It's a very simple non fancy place but it's all about the food! And 4me that what is all about!!! Btw the people is very nice there, and the place is normally busy and yes it's expensive at all!! Easy 5
author: Ben R.

description:
My friends and I ended up trying a bunch of the various curries here. The location is a bit hole-in-the-wall and the place didn't feel like the cleanest or nicest place I've been to for Indian, but the food was pretty good.

We tried the Brains Masala, which had an interesting texture, but I didn't really enjoy the taste or how it was made. The other curries were pretty strongly flavored and good at parts, but not the most enjoyable I have had.

The garlic naan is quite excellent though, it has a ton of garlic and you can taste the garlic pieces baked into the naan. It has the same effect with the onions naan as well, but I didn't enjoy that one nearly as much.
author: Tyler T.

description:
When it comes to Indian food nothing beats Shalimar! And the San Francisco location here didn't fail to disappoint.

Came in and sat down to pick out what to order, me and my friend order the chicken tikka masala, goat Karahi, garlic naan and shalimar chawal ( basmati rice)

Goat Karahi: one of the best goat dishes I've ever had! It was tender and the curry was not too spicy and had the right amount of flavor. Best part is that there wasn't too many bone pieces like goat usually does.

Chicken Tikka Masala: a traditional go to curry, it was perfectly creamy and spiced to perfection, mild spice and  is a must try!

Garlic naan: very fluffy and warm, not too crunchy and pairs brilliantly with the chicken tikka masala

Shalimar chawal: if u want curry you gotta get your rice fix and this is the dish for you! Not dry and and very much addictive 

Overall I would recommend Shalimar to anyone who wants to try some spectacular Indian food at a good price.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I had dinner plans on a recent Monday night with my friend and colleague, Don B, and I had one request... some kind of ethnic food.  He threw out some options walking distance from our hotel and we landed on Shalimar because he's a huge fan and he knew it would be fast and filling.

Fast and filling, it was... It was also pretty greasy and divey.  After placing our order (note - you do so at the counter) and helping ourselves to cups and a pitcher of water, we sat down and waited for our food to arrive.  We shared Chicken Saag, Chicken Tikka Masala, Okra and Eggplant, and I had rice too.  A lot of food but we're both good eaters and almost cleaned our plates.

Everything was moderately priced + heavily spiced and seemed very authentic (although since I've never been to India, I don't know that for sure).  Service was okay but not super attentive.  The place itself is super casual, cash only, and does not serve alcohol.

While I had a memorable meal with Don, I know there are tons of other restaurants to choose from in the city, so I don't know that I'll be rushing back anytime soon.  That said, if you find yourself nearby and craving a quick, Indian / Pakistani meal in a casual / no frills atmosphere, Shalimar could be for you!
author: Gabi M.

description:
No, thank you.
you can have it, it's all yours.

(my very first 1 star review)

the owner of this place should make a trip to DC and visit "Ravi Kabob" and "Kabob Palace" (Both in Arlington, VA) to learn how to make good Naan Bread & Karahi.
author: Rudy H.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant for many years. But I must say today was the worst food and service I have ever had at this place. Food was tasteless and old. Naan was as hard as rock they're ready made sitting next to the Tandoor, theyre just warming up and delivering to the table "see attached photo". Specially the Nihari was really bad taste sour. Bhindi was uncooked literally you have to chew and still can't eat that you have to throw it out. Try telling my server that bhindi is not cooked well, instead of taking it back, he simply told me that that's how our bhindi is. Worst of all the server saw me writing the review he didn't even let me take a picture of it. Very disappointed!! Will never come back here again
author: Muhammad R.

description:
Not here for the restaurant's looks. Here for the food. And it's really delicious. Check out who is the kitchen - it's authentic AF.  Even the service ;) 
Sitting in solo as a female I had no problems ( why should I) even tough I was the only one at 11pm with 20 other men around me. While it did make some heads turn (tons of Indian and Pakistani locals eating there) everyone moved on fast. 

Awesome food and felt like I was in a different world for a second. Which I want when it comes to an ethnic restaurant. 

It's not for everyone. I am sure the daytime is different but it's so so so worth it if you wan to have really good original and a very flavorful meal. 

( ps. It's not my first time here. It's probably the 5th i just wasn't  active on yelp back then )

Tips:
1. You will need to order and pay at the counter. 
2. Raw onions and jalapeños and extra spices are located by the chef near the fridge in a plate. You will need to walk up to it.
author: Zita M.

description: Best Indian cuisine in town , I craving to go there all the time best food ever, they should have location in peninsula love so much about the food.
author: Alan C.

description:
Walked almost 2 miles to have lunch at Shalimar because of the reviews. But when we reached, we had to wait for 30 mins for the order and that too with all the mosquitoes! The naans were dry and without butter, curries were too oily. When we ordered more naans, they came with butter but they were half cooked, you could taste the flour and garlic uncooked. When we got this to their notice, they said now you've already eaten!!
We had overall pathetic experience and never look forward to coming here.
author: Siddhi O.

description: The food here is delicious, great quality, and good prices! The interior is frumpy and not very attractive but that definitely doesn't reflect the quality of the food. You place your order at the front and pick your own seating. The service was prompt and efficient, and they kept the tables clean. I recommend this place to anyone that is looking for great quality authentic Indian street food at a great price.
author: Tootie A.

description:
I ordered the chicken tikka masala and beef jalfrezi along with some shalimar chawal, naan-a-akbar, and garlic naan. The curry were greasy, but delicious. It paired well with the fluffy and fresh naans. I have mixed feelings about the chawal.

Overall it was a very filling meal and I enjoyed it quite a bit.
author: Jason Z.

description:
The location is sketch.  Luckily we found a parking space right out in front, so we could keep an eye on the car.

The food was really good.  I found the portion to be a little small given the price and the location the ambiance (or lack of it) and the fact that it doesn't come with rice or naan.

That being said the naan was really good and so was the tikka masala and the lamb dish that we got.

You can get free chai tea.

I'm pretty sure it is cash only.
author: Ty C.

description:
Whoh, the goat karahi was super delish!   Suprprisely, the tandoori lamp chops were over cooked, a bit dry, but still amazing!   Garlic Naan breads were perfect!   Palak paneer was mushy and strangely had no favor.  The Shalimar chawal was the best basmati rice I ever had!

Will definitely come back to try out other dishes!
author: Ivory B.

description:
Horrible experience today. 
All 3 dishes ordered were not even mediocre. 
Ordered Nihari, the worst I have had in my life. Chicken tikka Masai was so so today and chicken boti was so so as well. Very disappointed as I have been coming here since early 90's. 

Even last time was mediocre.
author: Tintin F.

description: Service falls by the wayside but who eats middle eastern food for the service?  The food was fantastic.  We tried the goat karahi, chicken tikka masala, and garlic naan.  The naan was like no other.  Fresh, crispy on outside that provided a nice crunch and chewy on the inside.  Something you could only experience dining in.  The chicken and goat dishes were amazing.  The flavors popped and left me thinking about it all night long after the meal ended.  I will definitely be inclined to revisit Shalimar next time I visit.
author: Cindy S.

description: I've had a lot of indian food before, this one is a little more on the "cheaper" side of the map. The food is good, some bites felt way more spice-intense than others. Overall its a super authentic place and it's what you need if you really wanted to visit the closest thing to india in SF!
author: Bassel N.

description: This place has great authentic Northern India cuisine. The place is a whole on the wall but the food is amazing. I have eaten at Vic's in Berkeley and this place is hands down much better. The food is amazing, there is nothing on the menu that I wouldn't recommend. Their goat is rich and tender with well balanced flavors. I highly recommend this place.
author: sara C.

description:
I'm from North India and I can say for a fact the food here is pretty authentic for a fair price. The place smells like my grandma's kitchen back home. Takes me back every time. You can see them make the food too, it's an open kitchen.

With regards to what to order, if you're a food conservative, stick with your Chicken Tikka Masala and some Parathas (Garlic and Potato are pretty good)/Naan. If you're feeling good about those work your way to the other chicken curries they offer (maybe even work your way to the Brains Masala). Personally, I love me some Lamb Gosht, Chicken Tikka Masala, Potato  Paratha, Onion Paratha, and a Coke. Will usually get this and a few other dishes and will do it family style with a few friends. 

I love this place so much, I go back on the monthly. Straight up salivating as I type this review up. 

I will say it's kind of in a sketch area though, so I'd absolutely go for lunch there.
author: Tejas K.

description: This is one of my go-to places for super authentic, comfort food. I love this place, the service is great, the food NEVER disappoints and don't forget the free chai!
author: Amar K.

description:
Food prepared by this restaurant does not cater to vegetarians. They don't know how to cook veggies. Shalimar was not busy on Monday night and I ordered take out.
1. Okra -  boiled okra with tumeric for color was slimy.
2. Saag paneer - Boiled saag with paneer thrown in. No tarka or spices.
3. Garlic naan - tasted like plain naan without any noticeable smell or chunks of garlic.
Charge me rounded figure of $20 without receipt. Be sure to check the total of your purchases.
Will not return.
author: S R.

description:
I think the good reviews are paid for, otherwise there is not even 1 good thing about this restaurant.  Seeing the good reviews we went there. The place is shabby, and inside the restaurant it smells so bad that you'd feel pukish.
The staff was extremely rude, since we were tired we didnt want to change restaurants now.  Half of the things in menu were not there. When plates came, each of them was dirty. The food was ok, but very oily and we could see later very unhygenically made. Some veg options like kabuli chana and daal were bland. 
I wouldnt even eat for free here next time.
And dont even dare to use their restroom, you'd vomit.
I have never seen more pathetic restaurant in entire bay area,I've been here more than 7 years.
Management really need to work on the restaurant and teach their staff to behave better.
author: N B.

description:
One of my all-time favorite restaurants! When working in San Francisco, I have to visit once or twice a week. There are so many good dishes, I don't know which to recommend. Especially, because it's all authentic (Very Flavorful!)

Particular Favorites:

- Goat Karahi - Delicious goat dish "curry-like" made with a heavenly spice mix. Best with naan.

- Goat Biryani - Rice, slow-cooked with goat and spices

- Murg Tikka Lahori - Marinated skewers of Cornish Hen, cooked in a traditional Tandoor

- Beef Seekh Kabob - Small kabobs that go well with their sauces and onions in the hot naan

Enjoy!!!
author: Ali K.

description:
The small one block stretch on Jones between Geary & O'Farrell hosts three Pakistani/Indian restaurants namely Shalimar, Chutney and Pakwan that I decided to try, to find one that I could stick with on a regular basis. Shalimar was the first one simply because I ran into before the other two. Shalimar is located in the heart of the hood so apart from letting you know that you have to basically ignore panhandlers on your way here and back, I'm going to spare you other details.

My first visit was on a Friday at around 9 pm. The place was completely packed which did not matter to me as I wanted something to-go. After going through the menu I decided to get their specialty brain masala ($8.99) and a couple of plain naan ($1) to-go. To my surprise I was able to pay by card. I parked myself on one of the chairs at the entrance and looked around to see a really dirty restaurant. Without exaggeration this entire restaurant needs a good scrubbing from top to bottom. After what seemed like a long wait, but was only about 20 minutes I was on my way.

The brain masala seemed to have been hurriedly put together. The masala was definitely under-cooked and had the taste of raw spices coming through, but it was eatable. Overall a very average and nothing to write home about.

After my first visit, I've been back a couple of times and have tried the Chicken Korma ($.7.99), Chicken Saag ($7.99) and a bunch of lamb dishes all at or below the $10 mark. My experience has been mixed at best. At times when the food is cooked correct it's great. Other times you know that it has been put together hurriedly, especially when they are busy.

One major difference is very evident when you dine-in v/s get something to-go. When you dine-in the quantity of food that you get is drastically less than what you get something to-go. It even tastes better. So if you can deal with a dirty restaurant dinning in would be a better option here.

Price-wise Shalimar is the cheapest of the 3 Pakistani\Indian restaurants in this one block stretch. Chutney that is just across the road is about 15% more expensive and Pakwan that is one block down is about 30% more expensive. Quality of food wise it sits in-between Chutney whose food is better and Pakwan whose food is worse than Shalimar's.

Overall, this place can be hit or miss. What you get is not bad for the price especially when it is done right. I prefer to go to Chutney for dine-in but don't mind getting to-go from Shalimar. Considering the overall package of price, quality of food, service I feel Shalimar is A-OK at best.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Super casual and delicious dining near Union Square. Grab a table, order at the counter, and food is brought to you. Water is at the front and believe me you'll need it. Food is incredibly flavorful with strong kick that'll leave you sweating but wanting more.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I have been coming to Shalimar now for almost 20 years. They consistently have amazing tandoori chicken, probably close to the best I've ever had in US. It's also 5 dollars!
You really can't go wrong, very classic, simple, everyday south Asian food.
If you can get past the look of the space, you will not regret it. 
This review is specifically for the chicken tikka made tandoori style; cubed or a piece.
author: Naheeda K W.

description: My wife and I have eaten curry all over the world. This is authentic food. Don't come here for ambience. Come here for great Curry.
author: Richard P.

description:
Quick stop for garlic naan and mango lassi
  I saw tiny pieces of garlic sandwiched inside a giant slab of naan.  Hot, crispy, greasy naan.  Mango Lassi was refreshing, not so sweet.  Their prices are very reasonable.   Two items for 4.50.
author: Helen L.

description: After visiting so many Indian/Pakistani restaurants I have to say this is the worst one I've been too. The chicken biryani and chicken seekh kabobs we're spoiled and after telling the waiter he took the plates back and brought out "new" biryani .. which ended up being the same one all he did was put it back in the pan and marinated it with more spices and served the same spoiled biryani, very disappointing. Make sure to smell your food.
author: Iris K.

description: First time I ate here was over 10 years ago and I loved it. The food tasted quite yummy and I loved the range of customer and the funkiness of the joint. I've been back many times over the years, but I always forget to bring my own beer, next time I'll remember to BYOB.
author: Andrea Y.

description: While I love Shalimar-there are others that do not feel the same. This is your old-school Indian/Pakistani restaurant that has absolutely no Decour. The service is virtually nonexistent and the people taking you order are not necessarily the friendliest you'll find. You'll see flies buzzing around the restaurant constantly but I've always enjoyed the food and never gotten sick. Prices are still reasonable despite skyrocket in San Francisco. And you have to brave the tenderloin in order to get here. Went to San Francisco is more economically up-and-coming neighborhoods. If you can endure the atmosphere the neighborhood I recommend checking it out.
author: Robert C.

description: I love their rice plate and kebab! Big portioned plates. Customer service is okay just like any other restaurant around the neighborhood
author: Tsendsuren B.

description: This is a complete hole in the wall. If I had gone off of looks I probably wouldn't have eaten here. The owner reminded me of the soup nazi from Seinfeld complete with the sign that said We reserve the right to deny service to anyone. After my order he was like "Pay when you finish eating, go sit down".  I'm  glad I followed my nose instead. The smells coming out of this place had me hooked and I'm glad I listened to my nose this place was amazing. The best Chicken and Goat Briyani I have ever had. The Nan was thick crisp on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside and the portions were large. I love spicy food you can taste that doesn't leave your mouth numb from the heat. Will probably try to hit this place up again before we leave.
author: Cedric W.

description: So yummy, ordered the chicken sisig, langanisa, tocino and tapsilog. The chicken sisig was definitely my fave
author: Robert M.

description:
A real treasure of San Francisco.  We have been coming here for 20 years and are consistently blown away by the flavor and careful preparation of all the dishes.  I highly recommend the Chicken Tika Leg with a side of Raita and Naan. The curries are all amazing.

Shalimar, we love you, please don't ever change a thing!
author: David T.

description:
The other day I was chatting with my neighbor and he asked me what I'd done the night before. I told him that I'd gone out with some friends from Germany and that I'd taken them to this hole-in-the-wall Pakistani restaurant in the Tenderloin. His response was: "Oh, did you go to Shalimar?"

I quite enjoyed my visit here: the big open kitchen where you can see how your food is prepared; the total unpretentiousness of this place; in fact, the grittiness was what I liked most.

One of my friends was vegetarian and so we ordered a selection of vegetation dishes to share: everyone of them was good and we "licked" the plates clean with plenty of naan and paratha.
author: Uli B.

description:
This place is honestly some of the best Indian food I have eaten. Been coming here for a few years.

The location is pretty sketchy, however, come here in broad daylight or during commute hours and you have nothing to worry about. Further, the inside of the restaurant is fairly bare bones/old, but the food is VERY worth it.

Everything on the menu here is good! From the chicken tikka masala to their fire roasted chicken I would get anything and everything here.

Only downside is that this place accepts cash only. Regardless I would recommend this place 100x over to anyone that enjoys Indian food!
author: James D.

description:
Not sure how this restaurant has managed to meet health quality requirements. This place has one of worst ambience and environments especially on weekends. They stuff people on tables and even get large trash can at the table to clean and throw left over food and paper plates on the table. The service is super slow.

I have seen a lot of people visiting this place late at night after they've had lot of drinks. Also this place is really cheap in terms of prices. That might explain the good ratings. The food quality was also extremely poor. I was worried that I will get sick.
author: Rakesh G.

description: I've ordered here twice. All their dishes that are simply only seasoned meats come out perfect such as the chicken jalfrezi, murgh tikka lahari, seek kebab mughlai. The second time I ordered palak paneer and saag gosht (it was the morning right when it opened instead of night time) it did not come out good at all. It was as if maybe their someone new took over cooking duty for the spinach dishes no joke. The spinach and cheese did not seem fresh. Hoping it was not a batch from the night before or something since I had place my order right when it opened. It was lacking immensely that I was shocked that this was even the same place. In the future I probably will just stick to ordering just meats only here. I ended up ordering a palak paneer from another restaurant to go with my meat dishes. Also when I had called I had wanted to order the Fish Masala but the delivery menu said to call for availability but they did not pick up and it was maybe around the time they opened so I don't think they were even busy with customers.
author: Mark C.

description:
Decent Indian/Pakistani food and very affordable!

The restaurant is located in a somewhat sketchy area and the whole vibe is pretty hole-in-the-wall/dumpy, but the food in general is great. I came here in a group of 5 and we ordered several different kinds of meat dishes. I don't remember what exactly we had (one of those is called Chicken Karahi) but they were all delicious. Highly recommend doing family style instead of making individual orders. My favorite is probably their Garlic Naan! Make sure to get some if you ever try this place out. Most of the meat dishes cost around $9. Note that you have to order rice separately if you want it (~$2). It does not come with the entries by default. We spent about $15 per person after tax/tip. Not bad at all for dinner in the city.
author: Angel C.

description:
Been eating here for decades and is my favorite Indian/Pakistani food joint. And be sure, it is a "joint". You don't come here to be impressed with the ambiance, shiny service or to be catered to with big smiles and profuse apologies. You come here for the amazing food and it's affordability. If this sort of thing troubles you, then don't eat here.

The whole enterprise is very straightforward and pretty easy to figure out as long as you're not expecting someone to hold your hand. The staff are quite a friendly bunch but they are very busy and very focused because they work their asses off. This is a densely urban restaurant, not outback steakhouse--you only need to ask if you have a question. If you expect to be closely catered to with extensive directions and being shown to your table, then don't eat here.

Pick up a menu and stand out of the way while you decide. Know what you're ordering when you approach the counter, and be quick about it as surely numerous people are now standing behind you. Off to the right of the counter there's a fresh chai dispenser so you can enjoy a hot cup while you wait for your food, serve yourself. Enjoy your awesome food but don't dawdle, this isn't a hangout. It  usually very busy and other customers would like the table. If any of this puts you off, then don't eat here.
author: Travin T.

description: Best kept secret in San Francisco. All of it is so good and always take some to go. The staff is nice and the food is so authentic. I always order extra nana to bring home to Texas.
author: Moses D.

description:
Takeout review. Second review.

Naan - 4/5
Paratha - 2/5
Bhuna Gosht - 4/5
Murghi Korma Shahi - 4/5
Chicken Tikka Masala - 5/5
Malai Boti - 3/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
I had Goat curry and Lamb brain masala with Garlic naans and Lamb kababs. Goat curry is the best one I ever had in San Francisco. Lamb brain masala was good. Lamb kababs weren't juicy. Either they weren't fresh or over cooked. 

If you want to have chicken or goat curry with Naan in San Francisco, this is the place to go.
author: Subba R.

description:
This place smells so SO bad upon entering.
We ordered a beef nihari and chicken haleem- and everything was so tasteless and bland!
Never again sorry....
author: Tina L.

description: Can't beat San Francisco for great food!  Shalimar is Middle Eastern, but specifically Pakistani.  If you have had Middle Eastern food, but not specifically Pakistani food, you should go to Shalimar. Their chicken tikka, nehari, naan, and masala are delicious. It's is very small, so be prepared to wait nights and weekends. Order ahead, it's worth it!
author: Joe R.

description:
A flavorful onion kulcha and a good spice waft after making my way through several veggie dishes. Volumes are pitched at TandoorLoin-level expected hugeness; 2 portions of what have you plus rice and naan could easily satisfy 3 people.

Still, the food is not quite there in my estimation. The okra preparation came swimming in too much grease. Those inclined could pour off about half a cup of pure oil and not arrive at dry okra. And the daal masala came cooked down into mushy indifference. So it's satisfying and cheap and maybe nothing special.

And then they lose out due to better options nearby, being overrated by others, and inexplicable rudeness when I attempted to pay with American Express based on 1) the logo on their website and 2) the logo being posted on their door. Sorry for...paying? Oy.
author: James D.

description: This the worst food I have ever had. I usually don't  review abt food. But seriously this restaurant deserve one. Don't go there guys. Pathetic food and attitude.
author: Faraz A.

description: Staff is rude! Wish they know how to behave with customers. Food being good is one aspect but servers are worst!
author: Vijay B.

description:
This was my first time at this Shalimar location, and I'm kicking myself for not coming here more often. My husband and I dropped in last night on a whim and it was absolutely delicious. We got the Chicken Jalfrezi, Murghi Korma Shahi, Daal Masala and Garlic Naan, and everything was so freakin good. If you like saucy chicken dishes that go great with naan and/or rice, get the Murghi FOR SURE.

Get this straight, if you have never been here before- You are coming for the amazing food, the intoxicating way all of these spices come together and create these dishes... omg. You are NOT coming here for: The ambiance, neither outside nor inside, nor the friendly service. You will walk in, be confused, realize you have to obtain a menu from someone that works there, choose your food, walk up to the unofficial counter area, order your food, have the dude maybe/maybe not tell you that you need to grab your own drinks, then sit down and wait for your food. You will be brought a plate, napkin, fork and spoon. A person will bring you your food. He won't say much to you. You will get tears in your eyes from joy when you taste their complex curries. You will consider ordering more. You will scrape any sauces left in your bowl with your naan. You will then be confused as to whether someone will bring you your check or if you flag the guy that brought you your food down. You will pay, and be impressed at how little that meal cost you (yes, they take cards!) Your friend from out of town will compliment you on your insider's knowledge of great San Francisco hole in the walls. You will walk outside and be verbally assaulted by a woman only wearing pants and she will throw her bag of Doritos at you. You will decide it's worth it, and return to Shalimar the next time you get a craving for Indian food.
author: Liz M.

description:
Great place. Very simple, but probably best middle eastern food in San Francisco.
I tried chicken, lamb and beef dishes.
They all were excellent.
Food is not expensive, very reasonable.
Will go back there many times.
author: Ilya Y.

description:
This is hands down the best indian food I have ever had.

I usually get Chicken Tikka Masala and Okra, sometimes Goat Karahi and Mutter Paneer.
author: Johnny R.

description:
Avoid this place like the plague. 
They act like it's an inconvenience to serve people. 
And the. The food is dodgy. 
Make the walk to the one on Polk at pine. Much better, they are friendly and it's cleaner too.,
author: Ken M.

description: I highly recommend the chicken tikki masala if you can handle a little spice.  The service was a little slow but the food is worth the wait.  I saw other tables with beer, but they didn't sell any alcohol on the menu, so I assume it's BYOB.  Don't forget to get some of their tea!
author: Tung N.

description:
Someone highly recommended this place to me and I've had my eye on it for a long time since then. I finally got around to ordering some takeout from this place and I absolutely loved it!!

I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala, Shalimar Chawal, Garlic Naan, and a mango lassi. All were delicious, flavorful, generous, and went well together! 

I can't wait to order from here again!
author: Sofia R.

description: Hole in the wall in the tenderloin. You order up at the front, take a seat anywhere you please, then they'll bring you your meal when it's ready. You pay at the end up at the front. Prices are cheap, with everything being under $10. The flavors are spot on and the dishes have the perfect amount of spice, but ya too greasy for my taste. You can literally see the oils floating in the curry. Gulab for dessert at the end was cold and rubbery.
author: Lexi R.

description:
When my friend Harry said we were going to authentic Pakistan cuisine I couldn't wait! And since Harry is from Pakistan I was doubly excited to try something that a local would recommend.

My favorite dish is saag so I'm always looking for the perfect spices and spinach ratio. I also love mango lassi and both didn't disappoint.

We also ordered their chicken and onion dish, naan and yogurt dip. Forgive me if I can't name everything, I took a picture of the menu for reference then accidentally deleted it.

The chicken was tender and all white meat with some spices. Think grilled white meat chicken with grilled onions.

I loved everything we had, including the free hot chai tea.

If it wasn't in such a sketchy neighborhood with limited parking I'd be here more often.

Mad props for authentic reasonably priced food!
author: Jack R.

description:
The goat karahi and chicken Tikka masala are very rich and right on point, the garlic naan is fresh and serves its juice mopping purposes well.

Not a place you want to go for conversation though, not much seating and some pressure to eat and get out. The food is very reasonable for the quality you get.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I feel that they have the potential to make excellent food but I think the business is getting jaded over time.

The chicken jalfrezi came with a heap of oil (to offset it being several days old) and my garlic naan was doused with butter. When I politely asked if they could make a new naan with less butter the waiter picked it up, and when he thought I wasn't looking used a dirty napkin to wipe off the butter. At this point I asked the main cook to please make a new one instead. The main cook scowled and said"nope you should have asked for less butter to begin with I will stills charge you."  How was I to know he would use a stick of butter on it to even ask? 

I don't mind divey places, but I did get pretty sick afterwards and don't believe this place is sanitary and now with the bad customer service definitely don't recommend.
author: Michele Y.

description:
I am pretty stingy with my 5-star reviews, so if you want to get one from me, you have to knock my socks off.  Well, my socks are off in the gutter someplace on Jones St. tonight.  Shalimar is awesome.

My wife and I picked this place because the review ratings were high, and it was just around the corner from our hotel.  We knew nothing about the menu or the protocol to follow for such an authentic Pakistani restaurant like Shalimar.

When you enter the place, you know it's the real deal, because it is loud, the guys in the kitchen are working hard, and the wonderful smells of cooked meat and spices fill your senses.  A guy pointed us to a table and handed us a menu, but it wasn't real clear how things worked here.  Finally, we figured out that you need to go to the counter in the back and tell the cook what you want.  Also, it's good to note that you can go get your own water (and maybe even soda) and sauces from the fridges back by the kitchen.  And while we are talking protocol, it's up to you to go up to the counter again to pay the bill when you are done with your meal.  Now there may be some exceptions to the procedure, as we did notice that some tables were delivered their tickets, and water was sometimes delivered to some tables.

Now onto the food.  We ordered Chicken Jalfrezi, Nihari, Garlic Naan, and Shalimar Chawal.  Everything in this meal was nothing short of excellent.  Both the Nihari and the Chicken Jalfrezi were seasoned beautifully, and the chicken had a slight sweet taste to it.  The garlic naan was delicious as well, and the rice tasted great with the sauces from the chicken and beef.  Once we finished the meal, the spices and tastes were still dancing on my tongue for several minutes.  It was just great!



[  What would the world be like without rhetorical questions?  ]
author: Michael S.

description: The food was mediocre; not flavourful and not properly spiced. Wouldn't call it authentic either!
author: Muhammed I.

description: This is by far the nastiest, dirtiest, most crusty Indian place I ever been too! I found this place as I was downtown craving Indian food with my girlfriend. I ordered chicken biryani and the chicken tikka masala, the chicken biryani tasted old as shit looked like it been microwaved and the food came out fast plus the chicken tikka masala was so oily more oily then my forehead. I only took 3 bites, paid and left. Never ever coming back to this place ever again even if it was free!
author: Tommy L.

description:
Are you ready for a flavor explosion in your mouth?

The fragrant and exotic smells of Shalimar will make your mouth water for the deliciousness that is to come. You won't find reheated dishes in the microwave here and the Tandoori chicken is served fresh off the grill.

Go LUNGE for a table as soon as you see it being vacated or your wait could stretch out longer than 20 minutes. Order and pay at the counter, grab your utensils/plates/water and wait for your meal to be delivered to your table.

We all LOVED the moderately spicy Daal Masala. While considered a poor man's food, here it's made rich with a variety of lentils and cooked with cumin and coriander. Just perfect. Their chai is served piping hot and I absolutely love that it comes unsweetened! The Palak Paneer is some kind of special too. With a slightly golden paneer and soft spinach cooked in exotic spices, mop this one up with a big piece of Garlic Naan. Speaking of which is deliciously stuffed with garlic bits enough to drive the boyfriend away  ;-)

I wasn't impressed with the Chicken Tikka. Like Merica, I found it to be a bit greasy and the chicken was kinda dry. I prefer the creamier/tangier version which I found to be prepared much better at other places.

Nevertheless, the incredibly affordable prices and generous servings will keep me coming back for more. Plus, the sticky tables, divey atmosphere and pungent smell stuck to my coat (hello drycleaning!) is a foodie adventure I can't wait to experience again.
author: Janice C.

description: Best Pakistani restaurant in the Bay Area by far!Great food all around- best of the lot being Beef Seekh Kabab, Brain Masala and Chicken Tikka Masala!
author: Sam A.

description: The dishes were fabulous! I've had better garlic naan but it wasn't terrible. There were a few other diners but most orders were take out which was understandable. It was a bit cool inside and not a lot of ambiance.
author: TinaMarie B.

description: The food may be average to good , but honestly the quality of the environment ruins it for me. They're is sloppiness and hygiene is poor , dirty plates just thrown and piled and piled on display , the ground and wood on areas having stains and dried food from what looks like weeks never cleaned, utensils poorly washed which honestly makes me worried to eat if I'm putting that stuff in my mouth. They really did hurt themselves real bad with the maintenance and environment or else they would have been great. The make the food cheap which attracts people to come which they then use to give up on making the place presentable, hygienic, or give a quality experience.
author: Fatima M.

description:
This is a no frills kinda place but I looove it anyways. I've frequented this place many a night after the bars but I must say, the food tastes just as good even when you haven't had a few drinks in ya.

My go-tos: Garlic Naan and Chicken Tikka Masala. 

I've tried the Mutter Paneer (spinach and cheese), Aloo Keema (because i was craving a new dish that had potatoes in it) and the Brain Masala....yes BRAIN Masala....

These were all eh...the brain masala was a no-go for me. I'll just stick with my faves. 

Price is good! Portions are on the smaller side. Chai is free! You will also smell like food when you leave...

Don't forget: it's CASH ONLY
author: Emily Y.

description: This place serves authentic Indian food. Quality of the naan and chicken curry is really good. We also ordered Halim which was not as good as the chicken curry.
author: Rakshit M.

description: We came with tons of anticipation - they were amazing many years ago. We used to drive from San Jose just to eat here!!!! Came today with the whole family and food was just stupid and awful.  Little cleanliness would have helped too
author: The Food L.

description: Worst Indian food I have ever eaten! Everything except naan is pre-made. They just re-heat the food and give it to you. The food has got ton of oil in it. My stomach got upset right after having dinner here to the point that that I could not even sleep the whole night. A walk in the restaurant will also make you question the hygiene of the place. Safe yourself a hassle and do not go here.
author: Amay S.

description:
No frills, hole-in-the-wall Indian/Pakistani food. I got mango lassi, garlic naan, and bhuna gosht, a dish that consists of lamb, cooked with butter, garlic, ginger, and onions. The naan was probably the best naan I've had - perfectly warm and fluffy, great for dipping. The bhuna gosht was deliciously tangy and had a kick to it (although a bit greasy). As for the mango lassi, it was DELICIOUS. 

The restaurant is located on the outskirts of Tenderloin and is a bit dumpy inside. The ordering process is a bit strange - you go up to them to order your food, seat yourself and wait for the food to come, and pay afterwards up at the kitchen. My friend noted that dining and dashing would be wayyy too easy (disclaimer: not condoning that at all). Was it the best Indian/Pakistani dining experience I've ever had? No, but it was great considering the price. The restaurant is definitely very popular - it was packed when we went. Try it out!
author: Katherine Z.

description:
When it comes to Indian food, the tenderloin is lit af.

I was with 3 Indian friends and stood aside as they played tug-a-war between Shalimar and Chutney across the street. One is obviously cleaner and nicer than the other, but the other had a lot more people dining. We ended up at the more popular spot-- Shalimar.

The justification: "This restaurant has the most authentic North Indian food." Umm, sold!

We ordered:
-Chicken tikka masala (x2)
-Palak paneer
-Garlic naan
-Okra
-Seekh kabab murghlai
-Raita
-Shalimar chawal

I would give a play by play of all the dishes, but I was starving and the food was so good that I scoffed it down fast. The garlic naan looked a bit oilier than I'm used to, but it was still super bomb. It was piping hot though to the point that my friend who must have Satan fingers had to rip pieces for everyone. Once I got that naan, I scooped up all that saucey goodness off my plate and was in Indian food heaven. That chicken tikka masala and palak paneer were just so necessary. Mmm...

I need to talk about the okra. I have never ordered okra at an Indian restaurant before, but I loved it. I've met a couple of vegetarian Indians and, as with all vegetarian people, I've reacted like "Wtf why?!?!" Oh but this okra has made me a more understanding person. It was so flavorful in its plethora of spices. I could definitely see myself eating this as a main dish and nothing else; it's that good!

With the stamp of approval from multiple Indian friends, I'm definitely adding Shalimar to my Indian food rotation!
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: I alway look forward to come to this establishment and enjoy the food... every time I'm in SF I make sure to stop by your place north west frontier...
author: Bill C.

description:
We waited awhile at 9p on a Saturday night.  But it  cleared out at 10p.  You have to wait to be seated but then you go up to the cashier and order.  Then the waiter brings your food but you get your drink and desert yourself.  Then you go up to the cashier and pay after telling him what drinks you had (soda, water).  They take credit card. 

Food was good.  We had the potato pancake paratha, garlic naan, chicken biryani, saag spinach and chicken tikka masala.  Prices were not bad.  The tikka masala was very oily. The saag was good with the garlic naan. I would pass on the mango lassi.
author: Chris L.

description:
Grungy feel to this divey restaurant that serves up impressive, flavorful spiced up curry!  

I love their Shalimar rice and use the curry from any of the dishes that you pick from here (rest assured, their curry dishes do not disappoint), and it will be superbly delicious.  Garlic naan is of the essence as dipping for the curry. 

Their gamey goat karahi was rich with spices and kicks in with a tad bit of spiciness.  I adored it and cleaned every drip of sauce there was on the plate.  They offer butter chicken curry and lamb as other ogling options. 

Cash only spot.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Shalimar is the best Indian food in the city. The spice level is awesomely hot, but not overwhelming.  Shalimar is not fancy, it is just good food!
author: Emily L.

description:
Worst restaurant with dirty maintenance
Ugly service and poor communication 
Just only One person do both food service and Table cleaning without washing his hands.
author: Vamshi R.

description: I've only been there once since I don't live in San Francisco. If I did live in the city I'd probably eat there once a week. I went with my sisters and we tried their chicken biryani, sheesh kebab, tandoori chicken and their curry kofta with naan. Everything was delicious!
author: Sayam R.

description: Awesome food! The seekh Kabab's and malai boti was amazing. Service was great and fast
author: Habiba P.

description: Very delicious cuisine here. This place gets packed for lunch time and even more packed for dinner so hopefully you don't have to wait too long. Everything is awesome, Karahi, masala, lamb chops, naan, you name it. Good service and fairly priced. Yogurt they give you with your food is delicious as well
author: Sasan S.

description: Was on vacation to SFO and visited the restaurant numerous times. Not a traditional restaurant but absolutely delicious food is served here. Took a star off just for the ambience and service. A five star on the food.
author: Jinsi P.

description: Best Indian /Pakistani food ever in the US. If you want the upscale, no noise, super clean place.. don't bother. For me the food kind of covered everything else. You can just phase everything out and enjoy your food. Wish we had something similar on east coast :/
author: Vinod B.

description: I've been coming here since 2000, less recently, but I know I've been at least 40 times, and nothing, except for some minor wall decorations, has changed. Even the staff is mostly the same. The menu is large, seriously, it's a newspaper-sized thing, but if you drill down, you'll see a lot of the dishes are repeats for veg, chicken, and lamb. One exception though, is the brains masala, which although I haven't yet tried, I hear from the cashier that it is "delicious".  Other than the brains, anything you order here will be delicious, high in calories and full of flavor. I suggest the classes, for veg dishes, you can't beat the aloo saag, the okra, the chana masala (garbanzo beans.)  For those with sharp incisors, you can't beat the ground chicken kebab at $2.99/per kebab. You can also get lamb or even chicken on the bone, all cooked in a traditional tandori ceramic oven. Just take a look to the left of the cashier. Pair the dishes with an order of their rice, be careful because chances are you will bite into a full piece of cardamom, and also get their fresh garlic nan. The two sauces, often found in the fridge are great on anything. And their is piping hot milk chai in the ancient cooler, add sugar. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Brian J.

description:
I'm all about hole in the wall places with good food, but I'm not down with dirty/unsanitary restaurants.  

Shalimar serves up some great tasting food, but I couldn't help but be distracted from enjoying the food with how unsanitary the place is.  

Some issues I witnessed--
1) Uncovered food (desserts) in the drink cooler, just sitting out.  How many dirty hands open that cooler to grab things?  It's an open door for bugs/airborne bacteria to land in. 
2) The guy taking orders, answering phones, and accepting cash didn't wear gloves while handling food.  Saw him grab several kabobs off the long skewer and rip them in half to put on a plate BARE-handed.  
3) Busser wiped clean plates with the same rag he used to wipe the counter.  Seriously?
4) No gloves, hairnets, caps worn by anyone in the kitchen.  Is the health inspector on their payroll?  How's this place not shut down?

While the goat karahi flavor was really good, it was soaked in oil and had very little meat for $10.95 (mostly bones).  Also, I ordered a garlic naan that never came and the people were just rude.
author: John L.

description:
Stopped by for some late night grub since we had the munchies and this was in walking distance from my gf's place. I don't recommend walking around in the Tenderlion by yourself  because there are a lot of questionable people in this neighborhood.  Open until midnight and cash only. You order at the counter and pay at the end. They brought plates and utensils to us since they could tell we were sharing. Free chai tea by the counter so help yourself. 

The chicken tikka masala and garlic naan are all you need. The are tiny bits of garlic inside of the naan so be ready for some delicious garlic breath that's totally worth it. The naan is $2.50 for one piece but it's thick and filling enough for one person if you want to just be satisfied but not stuffed. We used all the naan to sop up ever drop of the tikka masala.  We also got a plate of palak paneer, a spinach dish with cubes of cheese in it. I'd skip this next time I wasn't really impressed. The rice was really good too. No pics cuz the gfs were hungry. As we paid to leave they were pulling chicken tandoori off of the skewer and that looked like it would be hella good. I'll have to consider that for next time but why chicken tandoori since it's cooked on a skewer ha a tendency to be dry so why mess with perfection when the chicken tikka masala is on point.
author: Lindsay C.

description: Best value for hot food in San Francisco.  $10 per person of normal appetite size and $15 per hangry wolf.  The lack of cleanliness must be overlooked in order to appreciate it: hence the 4 stars out of 5 rating.  The various fillings/flavors of Naan, biryani, curry and kofta are excellent .  They still accept Visa card payment which is out of the norm...
author: Lark A.

description:
Packed on a friday night. Go up to the counter in the back to place your order and then grab a table before anyone else does. There's no real system on finding a seat so you need to be aggressive (3 tables got snatched because we weren't sure how the system worked- and ended up waiting 20 minutes before finally sitting). You pay at the end when you're done eating.

Ordered: Chicken tikka masala ($7.95), bhuna gosht (grass fed lamb, $8.50), naan ($1), and shalimar chawal (basmati rice with spices and lots of flavor, $2).

Curries are less than $9 and overall this place is the best bang for your buck in terms of delicious Indian food. Don't forget to grab a cup of their (free) milk tea, sauce bottles, and a pitcher of water.
author: Lauren K.

description:
10/15/17 - 
So, I went to visit Shalimar because of all the great reviews! Well... it was just ok. When I arrived, it was packed. I was impressed. I was greeted, seated, and given a menu. Then I sat there.... and sat there... and was finally told by a customer that I have to go up to the cooking area to order. A-ha! Ok! I ordered the chicken tikka masala, the palak paneer and the garlic naan.
Everything was served in small to decent sized portions. If you're dining with a large group, I would recommend ordering double of dishes you like. 
So, how was the food? I would say the food was pretty good. I've had better. I've had worse. I wasn't wowed or overly impressed. 
The service wasn't friendly or welcoming. It was more matter-of-fact/ get in-get out. Don't expect service with a smile here. The interior of the place is definitely not dine-in friendly. Again, it's more matter of fact. The kitchen is open to the dining area making for a very warm dining experience. 
I won't be rushing back to eat here again. It was just ok and nothing really stood out. 3 stars.
author: Dottsy Z.

description:
When we came here to try the daily special, Brain Masala, I couldn't help but think about the legendary scene in the movie, Hannibal, when Dr. Hannibal Lecter saws open Krendler's skull, so that he can take a portion of his brain to sauté in a pan. Awful...uhm, awfully tasty! 

One of the highlights of our dining experience at Shalimar included the lamb brain $8.95, that had been handsomely cooked in butter, onions, tomatoes, and spices. This delicate dish was texturally pleasing and had a distinctive flavor that I can't completely describe. Minus its greasiness, this dish was good. Make sure to scoop up every bit of brain with their garlic naan, $2.50. 

In addition, we were thoroughly impressed by how moist and savory the Murgh Tikka Lahori $7.50, was.  The smoky flavor and the gorgeously charred exterior of the chicken leg were pleasing. So far, this was one of the more yummy tandoori charcoal barbecue items we've encountered. 

Other dishes we ordered included the daily special: Goat Karahi $9.95, (diced goat cooked in northern spices), which had robust flavor. I love goat and this dish hit the spot. Beware of its greasiness though. 

I was disappointed by the Chicken Tikka Masala $7.95, which was devastatingly greasy and watery in texture. I am accustomed to a thicker, rich, creamy sauce. Despite the fact that the chicken was swimming in a watery sauce, once I bit into a piece, it was noticeably dry. 

Preferences, preferences. My fiancé actually really liked the dishes from here, but I was completely turned off by how greasy the dishes were, especially the Chicken Tikka Masala dish.  How unfortunate. I think I'll stick to the dishes at Pakwan, and only resort to this place if we're really hankering for some lamb brain.

+ BYOB :)
author: Merica S.

description:
Food was just ok. Naan was a bit too greasy. The place was kind of unsanitary, which probably explain why I got stomachache afterwards. It unnerved me because it's the first time it ever happened during my many experiences of eating heluva spiced and spicy Indian food.
They do have a bunch of Indian customers though, so the food must be pretty authentic.
author: Jenny T.

description: One of those typical Moghlai Restaurants that you can find back in India. Raw and Ordinary interior, super crowded during the lunch time. The food is piping hot and fresh!!
author: Ketul D.

description: Ok i have some things about this place that had me stoked and yet felt let down in other areas. I am half Pakistani/Punjabi so I knew what I was expecting when I ordered. The haleem was a bit of a let down. No lemon wedge or fried onions (seriously?), the aloo paratha was an aloo stuffed NAAN! (That is unacceptable yo. We all know paratha is not naan!). The behari kabaab was yummy but sorta chewy. Now for the positives: the naan was overall yummy, the nihari SPOT ON, the tikka masala appropriate and lassi was perfect too. The chicken tikka leg left much to be desired for (not moist). Overall fair price and decent food but could be better!
author: Anisa M.

description: Great, authentic little hole in the wall. Order at the counter. Very rustic and flavorful food.
author: Sidra M.

description:
Shalimar is a staple of California Desi food. 

I wish they dedicated a little bit of funds to renovate inside. 

The food has always been consistent for me, the price point is unbelievable in SF, you will not find food this good at this price, anywhere. 

My usual order consistents of Tandoori legs, nihari, garlic naan, chicken sikh kabob and extra onions, lol god help those around me afterwards.

Service is fast and you legitimately feel like you're somewhere in Pakistan lol.
author: Amin H.

description:
Never mind the people making and serving the food look as sloppy as the food and the establishment itself, the flavors of each dish has the perfect blend of flavors and spices.  Goat biryani, chicken kofta, seekh kebab, garlic naan, tandoori chicken, and mango lassi.  Each item uniquely flavored.

Seat yourself, order your food from the newspaper menu by the counter, grab your water pitcher in the fridge, sit down with cheap dinnerware, and await the dirty finger lickin' goodness to be served. Straightforward Indian food that doesn't carry the westernized pretenses, though you also hope the food doesn't carry salmonella or listeria of some sort.  High risk, high reward FTW!
author: Bailey N.

description: Fantastic food! One of the best places in the city for Indian food. Great prices too! Highly reccomended!
author: Jessica V.

description: We have been going here forever now. Usually when you grow up eating a specific type of ethnic food, you don't want to eat the same thing going out.... however this place is an exception. Just like mom makes it. The best taste always, and owned by people who have brought to America a sample of some spot authentic cuisine.
author: Yo A.

description:
Disappointed,
The guy in the kitchen was mixing the rice n chicken curry,den added some colour on dat and says it's chicken biryani,,,

Checkout the neatness and observe d guy wen his cooking.
author: Sohail A.

description: Exceptionally good (goat and chicken tikka masala) and free Chai doesn't hurt. But quite oily so you shouldn't eat this everyday. The brain masala looks interesting but didn't try it.
author: David Y.

description: My favt restaurant for last 18 years or so. Love love it and it never disappoints. Try their nihari, Kababs, chicken tandoori and chops. You will be back.
author: Wasif I.

description: Best Pakistani restaurant ever! Haven't come across another that beats their taste. Their tandoori chicken and nihari is SO good. If your ordering to go, I recommend asking for extra chutneys (red and green one). The original location in sf is even better! I love u shalimar.
author: Kaval T.

description: Always enjoy eating Indian/Pakistani food here. In fact it's the only place I would go and eat Indian or else I would rather cook at home. Mind you, it's a little more rich than what you make at home, but the flavor and spices are always the right amount. Enjoyed their Bhuna Gosht/Goat Curry today. Will keep going.
author: Varun V.

description: I would give 0 stars if I could. The place was packed with. At 10:00pm I arrived and ordered tandoori chicken,Biryani and a few plates of tika masala and naan. I am of Indian descent but the owner who is  5'6 black hair with a little white hair. Wears a rinkled dress shirt a gold chain took our order. My family has been coming here for years and we got treated unfairly because we didn't order our food in Hindi. We sat for 45 minutes and we watched as a 3 gentleman ordered and in less than 15 minutes they received what we ordered.  We confronted the owner and politely asked why we have waited so long. He claimed the tandoori kitchen was closed. Once we expressed the unfairness he started cursing at us because we asked, How can it be closed when we ordered a little after 10pm and didn't received our food for 45 minutes and the gentleman that walked in received the same dishes we ordered In less than 15 minutes. It happened at least 3 times. I believe this was discrimination and unfairness we faced. I will pass the word along to my Patel side of my family and let them know never to eat there. I wish I could give 0 stars. May Allah judge you on your character on how you treat customers based on your assumptions. We ended up leaving because after the incident we didn't feel welcomed and it was at least almost an hour we waited. My father has been coming to Shalimar since his days as Taxi driver and after experiencing this discrimination and unfair business practice, I do not recommend this place to a friend. Word will get out quickly as the way we were treated was just wrong.
author: Moe C.

description:
Omg I am appalled n shocked that other reviewers gave this place higher than 1 star!!! The restaurant is SO dirty. Customer service is nonexistent. The food is nothing out of ordinary. Many of the items listed on the menu we couldn't order because they don't make them anymore.

The seating area, the plates, cutlery all looked filthy that we all lost our appetite. It's an embarrassment really!

We ordered chicken tikka, chicken karhai which a more like a qorma, beef seekh kababs that had a funny smell, plain rice that actually looked like biryani rice and naans. Only the naans were ok.

Even the free chai wasn't good.

Honestly, I wouldn't eat at any of the desi restaurants in the area because they all looked the same :(
author: S K.

description:
Unless you live in San Francisco, coming to Shalimar to dine can be quite an experience.  It's located in the Tenderloin (ruff and not the best neighborhood) and literally a hole in the wall.  This isn't the place for one to bring a date.  If you can overlook all this then this is the place to eat authentic home cooked Indian food.

You order and can prepay for your meal at the counter.  Credit cards are accepted.  The server will bring your utensils and food when ready.  I ordered the chicken tikka masala, chicken curry, palak paneer (spinach and cheese), and Shalimar rice.  The portion sizes of each dish were average, but together the four dishes were enough for the three of us.  The flavors of the dishes were different for me and I can't say that I appreciate them as much as others have.   The only plus to this place is that it is BYOB.  Overall it was an ok experience and an inexpensive meal.
author: Peter C.

description:
San Francisco, CA

Food 8/10.  If I knew any better it may be 10/10 given the level of authenticity.

* Chicken Tikka Masala - was suggested to me by Guy behind counter.  I was offended... Said "Are you offering the CTM because I do not look like a local".

Anyways I'm a sucker and ordered that.  Taste, not bad, the best I've had probably as all the others I've tried were probably not as authentic.

* Garlic Naan and Garlic Naan - Bomb.com I seriously think this his how Naan should be done!  Exquisite.

* Regular rice - almost bland, I really think it was seasoned very lightly to pick up the other flavors.

* Chicken - tender, well seasoned and fresh, like everything else.

* Mango Lassi - Almost frothy, not ice cold but really tasty!!

Tip:  Sauces GET Both located in the cooler.  Self Serve - The employees thought I was a regular asshole and didn't hook it up.  I had to grab it as if I was playing for keeps.

Tip: Complimentary Tea and Sugar are Awesome!!  I had 4 cups and was stimmied out of my mind!!!  (Caffeine high)

Note:  Surprisingly the food takes a while to come out after ordering - must be the Shalimar Secret / Way! 

Note:  American standards this place is a a divey dump.  I think it's just fine.  Also, don't expect great service you nerd.

Note:  This is the Taxi Drivers Go To aka this place is really good.
author: John C.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco . I am a little biased, I am Pakistani, but sometimes it is hard to find food this good. Now maybe this is not the right choice for your casual meanderer... don't expect stellar service, an easy to understand menu,or an ambiance that will blow you away. But what it lacks in nuances it makes up for in food. As an expert in Pakistani food, I will order the tikka masala here without guilt. I recommend you come here and try everything.
author: Ali H.

description: If you want the real deal hard core San Francisco food throw down Shalimar is what's up. The people who work here are slammed non stop. Which is evidence of amazing food. It was packed and we wanted to pick up and take home and while I waited I had free chai with a communal stirring spoon which just made me feel close to everyone eating there in a good way. Everyone made eye contact and smiled and was very nice. 48$ gets you four dishes rice nann and paratha!
author: Tricia G.

description:
I ordered the chicken tika masala, aloo paratha and chicken boti kabab. Tika masala is their signature dish. 
Food is little greasy but otherwise very tastey as usual. 
The Chai is very refreshing as well.. Chai is served free.
Aloo paratha was great.
author: Smartyr R.

description: Visited it for the first time last night with my family. I had heard a whole lot about it from family and friends. We went their at busy time. Restaurant was packed and their was only one server. Yes, just one server. So, obviously he was super super busy. Anyway, we luckily got a table and ordered at the counter. We ordered Chicken legs, beef kababs, Goat curry, brain masala, Palak paneer, garlic and plain naans. The tandoori items were amazing. Best tandoori chicken legs I have ever had. Goat Karahi was delicious and so was brain masala. Palak paneer and naans were good, I have had better. Overall, it was a good experience. Food was good and the only server was polite and really efficient. And we had tea in the end which was really good. Will definitely be back when I'm in the area.
author: Manbir K.

description: Rudest staff I ever met! They are so much unwelcoming. This is a Pakistani restaurant. There is a major hygiene problem  too at this restaurant. The biryani was the worst I have ever tried.
author: Garry T.

description:
No frills Indian is what you're getting here. 
We tried the chicken tikka masala, the saag paneer, and the garlic naan and all were very good. Portion sizes are decent and good for sharing.
author: Teryll H.

description:
I'm astonished by the fact that Shalimar has so many good reviews!! We walk in and I think to myself "Should we be even dining here??" The ambience is so bad that it gives a bad vibe to the entire dining experience, being in downtown San Francisco you expect more. We should have listened to our instincts and moved on to a different restaurant but because it was getting late, we anyhow thought of giving the place a chance with their food. Well, we were terribly wrong!!

Ordered Murgh Tikka Lahori for starters which was okay. For main course, we ordered Murghi Korma Shahi, Paneer Masala, Palak Paneer, few Garlic Naans and Onion Naan. You might at the least expect the non-veg dishes to be delectable but it was just not good! The gravy was so watery and there was nothing Shahi(Royal in English) about it as the name suggests it to be. I can't even start talking about the Paneer dishes!! The Paneer(Cottage Cheese) in both the dishes were so dried out and hard that it was difficult to eat them. Palak Paneer was really awful and I don't even believe they used Palak(Spinach) to prepare it. Seemed like Saag(Mustard Greens) to me!! Lacked salt and all other essential spices.

Hygiene seems to have gone on vacation at this place. We were first seated at a table which was not properly cleaned after the previous customer, we had to ask for it to be cleaned. The kitchen is quite open and you can see the chef's and other employees in the kitchen. None of them were wearing a hairnet. The restroom(just 1) was in a very bad shape with toilet papers on the floor and the floor was wet.

I'd never come again to this restaurant!!
author: Harshada K.

description: Shalimar was just awful, I mean just awful. Stay clear and away from Shalimar. Everything was microwaved. This Shalimar is nothing compared to what the original was.
author: Harris M.

description: Approximately 700 flies roaming the dining room, it looks like someone vomited on the menus.  No paper towels/broken hand dryer in bathroom. EXCELLENT FOOD!!! Did I mention the Tenderloin part? If I live through this experience I'll go back.
author: Devin P.

description:
Below average Indian food. The place itself isn't very nice, which is fine, I've had plenty of good Indian food in small, hole-in-the-wall places. Sadly, this was a hole-in-the-wall with equally unimpressive cuisine. We ordered the Chicken Karahi, the Palak Paneer, the Butter Chicken, and regular + garlic naan. The chicken karahi and palak paneer were both decent and flavorful, nothing standout. The butter chicken and naans were dripping with oil, and extremely heavy. 

I guess the best part was that the place was BYOB, so at least there was a couple bottles of wine to wash down the oily, heavy curries and naan. This restaurant is another addition to the scourge of mediocre, cheap Indian food which serve dishes with little resemblance to the delicate and vibrant flavors that can be found at plenty of other affordable Indian restaurants in and around the SF area. You'd be better off going to Pakwan or Rasoi, which offer food that is leaps and bounds better for only a few dollars more.
author: Sharath R.

description: the food is very good but the place needs some work. i recommend the goat karahi and nahari.
author: Mike J.

description:
Another win for cheap eats in the Tenderloin. This place is grimy like the neighborhood, but if you can get past that, you're in a for a real treat! 

Their chicken tikka masala isn't oversaturated with heavy dairy. Instead, it has a touch of creaminess to let the aromatic spices shine through. Love the chunky strips of fresh ginger in it. Pair that with one of their freshly prepared naans, and you've got yourself a meal for about $10. Their potato naan (aloo paratha delhvi) stuffed with spiced potatoes and brushed with butter, is the most amazing thing I have yet to put in my mouth. Their tandoori chicken is also another great option, flavorful and tender pieces of white meat.

They say they take card, but if it's closing time will only take cash.
author: Minh N.

description:
Had a dinner at Shalimar couple days ago. The food was ok, no service at all. You have to order at the front and they just deliver ur food. You basically grab your water... 
The place seems not clean and they don't care. The bathroom looks like a public rea
author: Chin H.

description: The food was superb. Quite authentic. I so wish the seating was nicer, but the food and attentive service made up for that.
author: D M.

description: This is a must when you come to SF! They also have additional locations in Fremont, Livermore & Dublin, California .  They have the most authentic South Asian Menu., specializing in Indian & Pakistani food.  It is a whole in the wall. They provide cook to order dishes that are SO fresh! While you wait for your food, they have a self serve Masala Tea station, where you can sweeten yourself .  We always get Naan, Punjabi Basmati Rice with saffron, tandoori barbecued chicken and Chicken Salan Curry.  They give a plate of sliced onions & jalapeño with your meal.  Prices are very reasonable!
author: Genelle S.

description: Been coming here for 16 years now and nothing has changed, the food quality is consistent and the recipes are still the same (unfortunately the nastiness of the place has yet to improve). The quality of the food found at this location is incomparable to other Shalimars around the Bay Area--it's definitely my favorite. Although the location isn't the best, the food is absolutely worth it!
author: Vinoo M.

description:
I saw the good reviews and had high expectations. Unfortunately, it didn't meet my expectations..

First of all, it has a truly hole in the wall feel, but almost too much and too literally--I felt kind of dirty eating there. The tables were old school, with slightly dirty utensils, and slightly weird tasting water (like lemon and dish water?).

The food itself was decent Indian/Pakistani food, but it was not amazing--compared to other Indian restaurants I've gone to, it isn't really a thing to write home about. I got the palak paneer and the murghi korma shahi. The palak paneer was definitely the winner between the two. Note that this chicken korma has bone-in dark chicken pieces, as some restaurants do.

They also have a strange service model: go to counter to order, they bring you utensils and cups and a pitcher of water, they bring you food, you go up to counter to tell them you're ready for the check, they bring you the check, you pay and leave. 

Maybe I'm missing something here, but honestly not sure what the hype is about this place.
author: Julia N.

description: Good Pakistan food hidden in Tenderloin area but still very close to union square . Strong flavor! Brain and tandoori are amazing. Highly recommended!
author: Xinyu L.

description: Amazing food.  You will leave smelling like smoke, but it's worth it. Order anything with cardamom
author: Adam P.

description: First and last time I'm eating at this dump. Ordered takeout chicken tiki masala. Got home and there was a quarter inch of grease on the top of the container. Poured the grease off and attempted to eat it. It was very bland bad texture and had peppercorns in it. Shit sucked. Garlic naan was garbage too. Never going back here again. Going to stick with Chutney across the street. Foods always good there. Only recommend Shalimar if you want to spend some time on the toilet.
author: Chris V.

description: This restaurant may not seem like the most tasty from the outside, but don't be mistaken it absolutely is! The food was outstandingly authentic and flavor packed. My family and I enjoyed each bite we took and kept ordering more! The service was prompt and pleasant. I would strongly recommend a visit to Shalimar for a cost effective and delightful meal!
author: Ganesh R.

description:
No frills but always delivers!

Remember numbers 6, 9, 20 & 22...you can't go wrong! The chicken tikka is delicious.
author: Nicole E.

description:
I try to eat here every time I'm in SF. 

Place is a hole in the wall, with no decor what so ever, but food is great. I usually get palak paneer and tika massala. Always have leftovers. 

Free tea with milk. Hits the spot, because some of the dishes are a little to spicy for me.

Cheap and delicious. Food comes out pretty fast too. 
Be ready to wait for the table, since place get busy around 6-7. 

Will be back again, when I'm in town. Definitely a must try .
author: Z P.

description: Lamb chops, chicken tandoori, brain masala, naan, spinach & cheese were all tasty! This location is way better than the Polk street spot. Pretty dirty tables and you may need to ask an employee to clean the tables and that can be annoying when they're busy.  Restroom is as dirty, so I suggest not to use it. You order and then pay after you eat. This place isn't intended for long sit-downs so please be curtious of others...
author: Noor S.

description:
Worst worst worst,I can't stress enough how worst it was,I wonder why the food inspection dept haven't raided and closed this yet!!!.picked this as it had 1200+ reviews,I wonder how people rated it.
Whole restaurant has millions of floes,untidy place,worst quality,worst service and even worst quality and taste.
If you have even a least concern on your health please avoid this place.
author: Esr E.

description:
Best Indian/Pakistani food this side of ... India or Pakistan.  Cheap.  Dive atmosphere that suits the TL.  Never ever disappoints.  We've been here over 50 times...maybe an even 100???  over many many years of great food and friendly service.  Price is right too.  

We usually get several vegetarian dishes, a chicken and a lamb dish, riata, naan...You really can't go wrong.

We always ask for the food to be extra spicy with little/no added oil.  No matter what we request, we are promised this -- and get whatever the cook on the line at the time desires...so, well, we can't special order, but it really doesn't matter all that much -- the dishes vary from greasy but good to OUT OF THIS WORLD FANTASTIC from time to time.  

Our faves:  Lamb chops, Tandoori chicken, saag aloo, channa masala, daal, raita...and whatever else strikes our fancy on any given day.

I used to bring in beer or wine for a couple years before I noticed a sign saying no alcohol.  Maybe it wasn't there before?  I still see plenty of folks bringing their own beer/wine to go with the food and nobody ever says anything to them, so, ummm...maybe it's not rude if I do so again???
author: Scott C.

description: This place is gritty but they really have the best Indian food I've had in the city. I've tried many things here and they've all been great. I was especially surprised by their tikka masala when I first tried it. It's quite different from the tikka masalas you'd encounter at other Indian restaurant, in a very good way. They don't skimp on the spices!
author: Chia L.

description: The only reason why i came here was because of the good yelp reviews. When i walked in, the first thing i noticed was the smell of this place (not a good smell either). The staff didn't even greet us and continued talking amongst each other for 5 minutes (we weren't even handed a menu yet). The food came out really fast, fast as in microwaved. The presentation didn't even look appetizing. There was also so many flies, it felt like a health hazard. I took a few bites and left.
author: Katie O.

description:
If you're looking for delicious, authentic food, this place is it! If you're looking for ambiance and service, go elsewhere...
