Shalimar has a diverse menu. Everything is made to order. The food is delicious (delicious doesn't do it justice). You order at the counter pub-style, they deliver the food to you, and you're then left to your own devices. If you need anything, you have to go to the counter and ask. 
I highly recommend this place.
author: Zak K.

description: This food is psychedelic. The range of spices are so powerful, they are a shortcut for you taste buds to the outer rim of the universe. Take a trip, blow your mind at Shalimar.
author: T B.

description:
My husband called it a religious experience. The naan is fresh and superb. 

Actually I almost don't want to review this place because it will become too popular...

I digress. Try everything on the menu. Try the chai. Be nice to the people who work there and they will be nice to you.
author: Brandina D.

description: Who care how dirty this place is, or how hard it may be to order sometimes. They are all really nice and the food is always good
author: Yas U.

description:
And your taste buds will never be the same again. Just give up now, they'll say. Don't even bother trying to look for another Indian/Pakistani place. It's useless, and it'll just make us cry, they say.

Poor little taste buds.

The garlic naan isn't bad, but the plain naan is the way to go, mostly because you're eating it with the curry, right? So the intense flavors just mask the garlic naan.

Go up to order, and enjoy the casual experience. The Murghi Korma Shahi is great, as is the Bhuna Gosht. Both are ~$1 more than is listed on the website. Both are also extremely oily and rich. A little goes a long, long way. And that's what that naan is for.

Get yourself some chai up towards the front straight out of the dispenser. It's like half milk, and really helps with some of the heat.
author: Andrew R.

description:
It is 4:36 am 9 hours from my dinner at Shalimar. I don't know if it is the spices from the food dancing in my stomach or the mixed emotions / reactions from our dinning party. Last night, we drove into San Francisco looking for another dinning experience. An old friend of ours was excited to introduce us to an Indian restaurant, he warned us that it was not fancy but the food was fantastic. 

Be prepared for the "total immersion" program. This restaurant is the "hole" of the Hole in Wall place. You get the whole experience of the Calcutta / Bombay by way of New York City Indian restaurant. It starts from the time you park your car with all the street urchins and panhandlers offering to take care of your car, to them escorting you to the door of the restaurant. Luckily, we got a table by the window so we could see them make faces and ultimately given a dollar for their troubles. 

The restaurant transforms you to a place in India, except for the crowd. There were girls in beachwear, Indian families with crying kids, tourists reading their Zagot guides, techies with their Google glasses and Indian Cabbies. We were 4 deep at the counter waiting to order. The menu is a large paper / newspaper / place mat. The items were so inexpensive, IE. tandoori items for $2., curries $7. After you order you sit down and clean your table. The floor has reminisces of the previous dinners meals. You get all you can eat marinated onions, jalapenos and Chai Tea. Paper cups, mismatched plastic plates and prison silverware are the table settings. A couple of flies buzzing your food is always a treat. 

The food tasted good and had lots of spices. The cuts of meat are a mystery though. We had some weird cuts of Chicken in our curries that I have never seen before. The Lamb chops were as tough as any wildebeest I have ever had. None the less there were lines out the door. The food is greasy but that is what the Naan bread is for to soak up all that sauce and flavor.

If you chose to dine here you need to come here with an open mind. Remember this is Mumbai without the 18 hour plane ride. Imagine you are spending Rupees instead of Dollars. And when you, leave your stomach will feel the same as if you were on tour of the Taj Mahal. 

Good:
Prices
Authentic Indian Flavor
Chai Tea
"The Experience"

Bad:
Cuts of meat
Location
Cash Only

Ugly:
Parking
Lack of Police Escort 
Rest Room
Floor Tables Chairs

Hey this place is not for most Westerners but they have Zagot stickers every where.
author: George F.

description:
My friend and I think we might be famous soon. You see, an Indian TV network was filming at Shalimar while we were there and based on the angle of the camera, we're sure that we will be featured prominently. If any of you see me on TV, please let me know.

In all seriousness, several of my friends have raved about Shalimar and I finally got a chance to check it out. It was a hot day and I was nervous that the restaurant would be too hot without A/C but it turned out to be alright.

The menu looks like a (dirty) newspaper and we ordered 1) Chicken Tikka Masala, 2) Nihari (beef shank stew) and 3) Beef Seekh Kakab. All three items were very good and went well with the naan and basmati rice we got. I also tried a cup of mango lassi and I would not recommend it. It was very foamy and light.

I like hole-in-the-walls but Shalimar could use a serious makeover or even a deep cleaning.
author: Yi Z.

description: Definitely recommended. Our friend was insisting from day one of the trip. Was worth it. Do not get fooled by the appearance. This is typical pakistani dhaba style. We had lamb chops, tandoori, bheja fry, goat bhuna and roti. All dishes were tasty and properly spiced. Lamb was little dry but it may be meat itself and not the preparation. Will visit again. Dont forget to buy a beer in the shop next door to enjoy with food .
author: Prashant C.

description:
"Dammit, the line is too long for Mensho" :sadface:
  
Luckily Shalimar is right around the corner from Mensho for others in similar dilemmas. It is a little confusing as you can pick any table, but you order at the counter and pay after your meal. There is free chai tea although a bit watered down.

Food was alright, but forewarn that the serving size for entries/rice are on the small side so you may need to do one additional dish. Grab plenty of naan!
author: Giovanni G.

description:
Gotta show some love to this hole in the wall in San Francisco! Pretty much my go to spot for "Desi Khana" (Homeland Noms!) whenever I'm in San Francisco.

My order staples are chicken "tangdi" (bbqed chicken leg tandoori style). Chicken biryani and both kabab. True to Pakistani cuisine, it's about 2x spicier than what you'd expect in your run of the mill Indian restaurant. 

I've rarely ever sat in and eaten here. Place is pretty much a disaster when it comes to ambience or even general hygiene. Very reminiscent of standards one might expect on the streets of Lahore or Karachi. 

Regardless of ambience etx. the food here is excellent. I have yet to discover a spot that delivers this level of yummy anywhere in NYC. 

Don't be put off by the interiors, come on in and give the chicken masala a spin, you won't regret it!
author: Monish D.

description: The smell just lures you into this small hole in the wall that doesn't look like it's maintained well.....But who cares cuz the food is good, lines were to the door, we got the chk + beef kebab and the beef wins hands down, the tandoori was real good while the Boti kebob was decent and could have had more traditional spices. The spice level is pretty high so beware. Definitely try if your close by.....
author: N And N K.

description: One of my favorite Punjabi restaurants.  Amazing authentic Punjabi food.  Non veg dishes are the best.  I would recommend the chicken tikka masala.
author: Manny D.

description:
Absolutely amazing. What ever else you do, order Chicken Tika Masala. The most tender big cubes of white meat chicken I've ever had and I've dined in 46 States and 25 Countries. It's in a rich Masala gravy. Some reviews deride the small amounts of oil in the dish, but kindly ignore them and mop it all up with your Naan. 

We had the garlic Naan but didn't notice any garlic chunks in it and the Chicken Tika Masala was so rich and flavorful that we might not have been able to taste any garlic so maybe we got regular Naan instead of garlic. 

As for the Naan itself it was a beautiful soft and white pillow with a very slight char on the edges. The Naan would rate a 10 out of 10. The best. 

We didn't find the place intimidating or confusing at all, as some have reported. And the various complaints such as a we bit of oil, etc. Get over yourself. Eat Stouffers at home or avoid wonderful ethnic hole in the wall restaurants and don't have any fun and adventure in life. Save the seats for those of us who love life!
author: Neil W.

description:
I cannot believe that I haven't written a review for Shamilar on Jones. I've been to the one on Polk at least a 100 times and I've been to the one on Jones even more. Last weekend I was near Sunnyvale so I went and picked up from there (I believe maybe the 5th time I've been there). No matter which Shalimar I frequent, they never disappoint. Everything I had was delish. I actually ALWAYS order the same thing... 

1. Chicken Tikka Masala
2. Nihari Curry
3. Haleem Curry
4. Few Naan
5. Shalimar Chawal (Basmati Rice). 
6. For dessert - two Banarsi Kheer (delish rice pudding). 

I always take my food to-go and the main reason is because I like to fry an egg and put it on top. There's nothing like eating the Nihari, mixed with egg yolk and naan. Shalimar, if there's one thing you could do to make your menu 110% instead of just 100% amazing, it's to add fried eggs as an option for those who wish to dine-in. 

Thank you Shalimar for never disappointing me. :)
author: Noneya B.

description:
This food. This food people... Just listen. Please.... Freaking amazing. It made up for the overpriced 'Michelin rated' place we went the night before (no I won't tell you where!). The food here is absolutely true to Pakistan and is delicious. Like... You will crave coming back. Yea the other reviewers are right in that it's kind of a dirty little hole in the wall. Yeah yeah I know the bathroom is nasty. Yeah FINE I agree the inside looks like ass. But you know why we are here? FOOD! And the kitchen looks clean and it's open so no it's not like the bathroom.

So come and get epic food and just wear gloves if you are so bothered. Oh... And guess what? It's cheap food. Like REALLY cheap. Wow!
author: John W.

description:
Opens at noon, arrived at 12:30 and all tables were already full. Waited several minutes (10?) before anybody acknowledged our presence and several more before we were seated. 

Unusual ordering system,  you have to go to the counter to pick up your menu and place your order. We also had to get our own drinks. 

Once food was ordered (chicken tikka masala and chicken kofta), it arrived very quickly.  This was not typical Americanized Indian food,  it was very authentic and enjoyable.  

Pricing was decent - two entrees plus an order of rice,  one naan, and one soda = $23.
author: Kristina R.

description: This place is extremely popular in the community told by how busy it was on a sat afternoon.  The service was two-fold: we walk in and as busy and loud from patrons, the only server/buser staff appeared to not speak English, so hard to understand how we were to order..... you walk up to a glass island station. The staff behind register super helpful giving taste of brain masala, very generous.  And it was really good.  When what I asked for was out, but I still wanted garlic naan, he suggested a better pairing than what I initially settled for.  So amazing! You dont pay when you order......and from the looks, I think you go get your own drinks.  The 1 buser guy must come back around to match ur table w remaining tags to pay. Would come back!
author: Dani G.

description: Food is warm and ok. But the restaurant/restroom needs to keep some health standards. I have had food at other Shalimar locations, but this place is the worst in terms of ambience. I ended up here only because they serve lunch after 3pm. That I appreciate. Please put some effort to keep the floor/table clean.
author: Moon P.

description:
Order your food, grab a seat, get water or a soda from the fridge, and someone should bring you plates, utensils and napkins. Eat and pay when you are done and someone will bus your table.

I had the chicken tikka masala and garlic naan. The chicken tikka masala had a more chunky texture than I'm used to with this dish but it was unpleasantly and extremely oily. It was really hard to get through the ring of grease. The garlic naan had plenty of garlic pieces inside and the naan itself was very soft and fluffy. Yet, I wish it had more crust for texture.
author: Maya S.

description: I lived in India for 4.5 years and love Indian food. I had already tried Shalimar from take out at friends house but this was the first time I went to the restaurant. The location of the restaurant is my least favorite (tenderloin neighbourhood) because it is a bit unsafe but we were hungry and at 10pm you don't have too many options in the city because it's too late for dinner. The three of us went to Shalimar and the place was pretty small and crowded so had to wait briefly  for a table. I must say, I wasn't impressed with the place at all because it was a bit dirty :( and having lived in Mumbai for so long, I don't like to be reminded of that but this is something you can expect if you want to eat this type of cuisine, I've had a similar experience in Santa Clara too at another Pakistani/Indian restaurant and I guess it's ok for once in a while eating out at these joints. We ordered dal fry (which was ok but I expected way more flavor from that dish) but also i'm biased because I get to eat Indian food at home all the time so perhaps i'm too demanding :P, mutton gosht which my husband (who is indian) loved it but i wasn't too happy about it and also because mutton is a not my first choice of meat or dish, tandoori chicken legs was probably what I enjoyed the most - succulent and not too spicy and shared tandoori roti, garlic naan and alo paratha - the garlic naan stood up and was soft and fluffy and some of our friends say it's just the way its served in Pakistan too so must be authentic. Overall I liked it but wouldn't say this was a great experience. Ah, and what can upset me most of all is not having fresh cut lime to pour on top of the food - they had this sad lime juice in a bottle instead :'(. Friendly and helpful staff and fast service but I  just can't get over that it wasn't clean enough!
author: Heliana M.

description:
It's confusing to eat at Shalimar for the first time, especially when you are alone without anyone who has been here before. You walk in and have a seat at any table. The waiter hands you a menu... then you are expected to order at the cash register. THAT MAKES NO SENSE. I felt hella dumb because I didn't know that, and no one else was in the restaurant ordering so I had no idea. 

Anyways, I wanted a lamb curry and was recommended the Bhuna Gosht over the Saag Gosht. It was quite tasty! I would have gotten the rice over the naan next time, or substituted for the garlic naan. I also ordered some Mango Lassi which tastes fresh. Would definitely recommend that! I'm not sure if this is supposed to be an authentic experience, but next time I'm just going to order something to-go because this place (and neighborhood) feels super sketch. Good food but overhyped by my friends who recommended this to me.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Essential stop for tea, snacks, and world-class dosas, roti and more.
author: Laurel S.

description:
Nasty!!!

This place is nasty. Don't come here if you don't like the smell of curry, sticky tables, long wait, crowded, unorganized, homeless sleeping outside, people shoving, dog or human feces on the sidewalk or the Tenderloin. Yeah, stay away from here at all cost. It's nasty.

Then again, there's Nasty and then there's Nasteee!

This one's the latter. 

My first visit here I was confronted with all of the above and almost went ballistic at the crowd, and some who attempted to cut in line. I was appalled at the lack of organization and it was a free-for-all attitude. But when in Rome, do as the Romans do. You have to quickly adapt to the situation in order to survive. It's fight or flight and I choose to fight. I quickly figured out that I had to be aggressive in getting the menu and placing the orders. Once I got the hang of it, I couldn't care less about the rest of the people and let my killer instinct set it. I scanned the room and quickly grabbed a table. 

You can't be Mr. Nice Guy here. Nice guys finish last. 

Do you want to know if a place is good, just scan the crowd as it was mostly locals with brave souls and native Pakistani and Indians that pack up this joint. Don't expect good service, don't expect anyone to greet and seat you, but do expect great, authentic food at very reasonable prices. 

I love lamb, and this place is lamb heaven. They make it in different ways, but the grilled Lamb Chops are out of this world superb and cooked to perfection. I would suggest that you devour these right away while they are still warm to enjoy the texture and flavors that oozes out from first bite. You also get different textures in one bite from the soft, medium rare in the center to the crispy, charred state that forms around the exterior. 

If you're the adventurous type, they also have Lamb Brains. Yeah...this one's nastee. One bite and your calories will quadruple and might require a bypass surgery. It's creamy, delicious goodness that you can slather on a Garlic Naan (more on that later) or mixed with Basmati Rice. 

The Chicken Kabob and Grilled Chicken are also fantastic. Both packed with wonderful flavors and aroma that is making the homeless person sleeping outside salivate in his dreams. Yeah, I'm cruel...but you have to be in order to get what you want. And I want this food in my belly and you better get out of my way when I'm hungry. 

And to go back on the Garlic Naan, there are Garlic Naans and there's Shalimar's GARLIC Naan. There's tons of garlic in here that could scare away Edward and all those Twilight groupies that could last for a week. You get a big chunk of garlic on every bite and oh it's nastee good. 

Yeah...this is a NASTEE place.
author: John G.

description: Small hole in the wall that serves food, plain and simple. I caught some bugs crawling along the floor which wasn't pleasant to see. We ordered garlic naan, onion naan, chicken tikka masala and one other chicken dish I don't remember the name of. Food was very, very oily but seasoned well. Garlic naan would be my favorite thing that we ordered. The portions were pretty small which disappointed us but it might be because we weren't ordering the right stuff off the menu. Probably won't return due to poor cleanliness inside the restaurant.
author: Diana F.

description:
I LOVE Shalimar. I always went in Fremont and recently discovered that one existed in Nob Hill.

Is it greasy? Oily? Unhealthy? Definitely.... but it's so damn good. 

DIshes here are hearty and delicious but inexpensive - dishes range from $6-$12 each. My favorites are the GARLIC NAN and the BUTTER CHICKEN.... those two alone will only cost you $11.

It's a grimey/casual cafeteria style spot. Don't expect a fancy restaurant by any means... I like it best for To-Go orders so your clothes don't absorb all the Curry scents from the restaurant!
author: Veronica S.

description: After not having any Pakistani food for days...it was soo good to have some Nihari with ginger with fresh naan and amazing zeera rice :)
author: Sana A.

description:
Thank you Yelpers for the intro!  This food is cooked with complete love and it is sooo dang good!!!

It was a bit hard to decide what to get because I like everything on their menu. I decided on the Murgh Korma Shahi, which is a chicken curry. It says on the menu I would love it. And the menu was right. The sauce was super flavorful and the chicken was moist. Energetically it was really really nice. 

Their nan is amazing.  It is made fresh and is plump and doughy. I like it that way. It was a little burnt from the oven, which I considered authentic.

Don't let the location (in the Tenderloin) scare you. It wasn't sketchy when I went in the afternoon. But do keep your phone in your pocket, as I was told there are "runners" in the area.

OMG how I love hole in the walls. They have so much more love infused in their food. Here I felt at home. In fact the guys are all relatives. I had to ask after listening to them talk. They are from Pakistan and are all related to one another.  It's really tangible when you walk in that they will take good care of your hungry belly. 

I'm in love.

UPDATE:  I dream about this place all the time.  Their food is magical!!!
author: AnneMarie W.

description: Really best restaurant in the city ...best... all the dishes that I had here were excellent specially goat biryani is the best of San Francisco..love to visit this place mostly...
author: Khagen O.

description: I'm Pakistani-American so I know authentic Pakistani/Indian food when I smell it. Right when you walk into the restaurant it smells like Food Street in Lahore. It is affordable and real Pakistani food. Their garlic naan and nihari is sooooo good! Go there if you want Pakistani food! The atmosphere is lacking, but in my experience that is always a telltale sign that it's legit food.
author: Saba H.

description: Best place for indo-pak food. Their quality is really good and the price is reasonable. Although the place is not for fine dining if that's what  you are looking for but for some good authentic  kabobs and curry with fresh naan this is the place.
author: Sal S.

description:
It's funny reading some of the reviews here from people who really don't understand Punjabi food.  In North Indian and Pakistan this place is the closest thing to what you would call a dhaba.  A dhaba is basically your equivalent of a food truck or road side meal.  You can always tell a good dhaba by how much food they are serving and how quick they are.  If they are getting you in and out then you know the food is excellent, safe and quality.  

My father who was born in Lahore when it was still India, he insists on going to this place every time he comes to town.  The food is authentic it is excellent and well worth it.  Look at it for what it is.  It is a fast food quick cheap place and worth every penny.

Tandoori Chicken
Beef Kabob
Chicken Tikka Masala
Regular Naan

You can't go wrong!
author: Aseem n.

description:
3.5 stars.

Shalimar is the perfect example of don't judge a book by its cover. This restaurant looks like it is falling apart. It was hot and poorly ventilated inside and there were tons of flies. But the health score is actually pretty good, and the clientele was legit. I'm going to India in a few months, so I guess this environment is a good segue. 

We had the lamb curry (bhanu ghost) and chicken korma. Both of them had really tender meat and were more stewy than I expected (not heavy and cream-based). While I loved all the spices in the dishes that gave deep flavors, I ran into a few really hard pieces that were inedible, which made the dish a little bit harder to eat.

Onion kulcha naan was very soft and doughy. Large portion. I am excited to try the garlic naan next time.

My favorite bonus: the free chai. It's milky and you can add sugar. It's piping hot, so be careful though. I had at least three (small) cups.

Prices are cheap. Menu is confusing though, because they have randomly written numbers on some of them, so we didn't know if that was just internal notes or updated prices (I think it's the prior).
author: Alice T.

description:
10 visits in a year, i guess its time to review this place. Located in Little Pakistani (Jones St between O'Farrell and Geary), right across Chutney and Karachi Classics. This is The Undertaker, Kane, Big Show, The Rock, Austin on desi restaurants in SF and the Bay Area, its a classic. 

I recently found out this place takes card now :O for the longest time they were all yada yada about cash and then i saw an uncle sneaking in a card. They don't advertise the debit/cc but as of recently (not sure how recent) they do take cards. They also had a few renovations to the place but the bathroom is still dirty, dirty enough to get ebola. 

Goat/Lamb/Chicken biryani is all good here. Better than any other place that makes biryani in SF. The portion is on the lighter side but you can't have everything be perfect. The chicken tikka masala is also better here compared to its rivals. The kebabs are meh, you get this clumsy, broken seekh kebab which looks like it took a beating. During its busy dinner hours you can expect to get fresh kebabs and tandoori options but during slow times they just reheat grill items (not surprised). 

The busiest times at this place is any day after 4 pm.
author: Daanyaal K.

description:
It's tradition for my family to eat at a desi food restaurant while traveling. And we were recommended to try this place. 

On the inside it looks really run down and is a small and busy space so I wasn't expecting much from it. There was a wait though. 

We ordered some basic things like chicken tikka and naan and nihari. I personally just felt like eating chicken tikka and naan that day. The food was twenty thousand times better than how the place looks. Everything was so warm and didn't seem like it was frozen before then recooked. The naan and chutney were the absolute best! 

Their service is really great too. Ask them for their recommendations!

Overall, it's a legit place to eat good Pakistani/ Indian food (says a Pakistani person). It's also reasonably priced!
author: Sadaf Q.

description: Location is a dive and not very friendly however food and service was excellent. We had chicken saag, tandoori chicken, rice and garlic naan. They also offer complementary tea. We would definitely return!
author: Damaris F.

description: Delicious pakistani and southern indian food right in the heart of the city. Great for tourists staying in down town, for locals looking to get some authentic south asian, and overall a well above-average, average-priced meal in San Francisco. Pakwan down the street at the corner is very tasty too but I'll usually opt for Shalimar instead.
author: Gabriel L.

description: Such a hole in the wall place. This place is amazing. Ordered the tikka masala as the counter. So gooood. Naan was decent as well. They also have bottomless free chai. There's not really any service besides ordering at the counter. This place can get packed pretty easily, so if you don't come early, be prepared for a wait.
author: Julie L.

description:
Sure, the formica's greasy, and some of the dishes are chipped. Sure, you feel like you need to wear asbestos underwear to use their toilet. Oh yeah...and it is on a particularly seedy stretch of Jones in the Tenderloin that isn't spotlighted in any of the guidebooks. But, damn, the South Asian dishes are good here. Good in a no-nonsense way with some surprising twists. In fact, I actually think the food is even better here than at their slightly more civilized location at the edge of Polk Gulch. I came here in the middle of a work day because I was finishing my shift at a work-related conference around the corner at the Clift Hotel.

I decided to take advantage of the remaining daylight and grab a late lunch at 3:30PM. As it turned out, nobody eats at Shalimar at 3:30PM, so I had my pick of the formica tables and rickety chairs. Even though I was seriously tempted by the Lamb Brain Masala (next time), I went for the more mainstream Tandoori Chops, four of them for $10.95, nicely marinated and accompanied by a few raw onion rings (see photo). Deliciously tender with a kick of masala spices and the bones quite gnaw-worthy. With them, I went for a $6.95 plate of the simply named Okra.

The dish was described most accurately as "ladyfingers" since they leave them whole rather than chop them as most Indian places do. They're cooked with onions and a big fistful of Shalimar spices sweetened by just a hint of ginger (see photo). Although it was oilier than I was hoping, there was no denying it was delicious especially when mixed with a $2 plate of Shalimar Chawal, a house specialty of basmati rice cooked in a rich stock of savory spices, onions and saffron (see photo). Stuffed. But I needed all that food to energize myself for the aggressive jog down the Jones Street hill. And oh yes, the restroom wasn't that bad.

FOOD - 4 stars...really good and unique Indian-Pakistani dishes served in a no-frills manner
AMBIANCE - 1.5 stars...well....
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pretty speedy and friendly when they're not busy
TOTAL - 4 stars...go during the day if you can, take a little more risk in the evening
author: Ed U.

description:
Service: Poor
Food: GREAT
Wait: No Problem
Will we ever go back: OF COURSE

Good food it was. Servers or Waiters, there were not
-Yoda
author: Chrissy W.

description:
If I ever make it to Jannah by Allah's mercy...I'm sure there will be better food served, however, as long as I am on earth, Shalimar is as close as it gets.
Shalimar is the spot.  Full flavor, the chai flows and doesn't run out (unlike some Indian places), hella good price.  Curries are super heavy and oily so don't eat chicken tikka masala everyday unless your trying to get fat.  Naan is perfect.  Kebabs are unbelievable.  The freshness is unrealistically consistent. The kitchen is a nonstop machine. 
Unlike every other desi food spot in SF, this place is not catered towards 1st world upbringing/privileged expectations, which includes but are not limited to: friendly staff, colorful decor, toned down spices, being formally seated, having a real waiter, etc.  don't bring a date here, this place ain't cute.  If your scared, go to church/synagogue; this place is straight out the balad.
author: Khalil S.

description:
One of the best place for biryani in bay area.
I recommend lamb biryani.

Note: 

They market as 'No frills restaurant'.
Thats true.
author: Vic A.

description: Hey hey hey HEYYYY Put cha lighter's up! Ganja's in the house  owwwwww! As you can tell from my accent I am from Dallas, Tex-ass! And it was not very easy growing up looking like this! Whether I was playing in my grandma's clothes or putting on a show for my well-organized alphabetically-ordered beanie babies  I was guh guh guh GAY! OKKURRR! But it wasn't until I moved to Los Angeles  that I discovered Marijuana, I mean I like to smoke, y'all I am just flying as high as your receding hairline! OKUr!  Marijuana really does help me calm down, so y'all, I went to Valencia where they film the TV show Weeds! Now, y'all, it's very dry, it's almost kinda like your vajoina! Can I get an amen?!? Now y'all, I am a treehugger because if it ain't green, HUH I'm not interested! OKCURRRRRRRR!
author: Xavier L.

description: Simply, cheap Indian food but v good taste. Person taken order was grumpy and the neighborhood is poor (a homeless lady came in mid-meal and started eating someone else's food), but the place was packed because in the end it is a v good meal at a reasonable price. The nan was a bit too think for my taste but the chicken saag and goat curry were both excellent.
author: Y E.

description: Ahhhhh, how I love Shalimar. Just what I want for a lunch in the downtown area. This is one $ dollar sign place. (I see it's rated as $$ on yelp). And given it is that level of cost, it's incredible. The palak (saag) and bengan barta are swell.
author: Stuart C.

description: You have to order the food at the counter. They do not have many menus to go around. The ones that they do circulate look like worn out newspaper. The chicken tikka masala was flavourful but did not have much meat. The restaurant did not look very clean. The mango lassi came from a mango lassi jug. The rice was colourful and really good. The garlic naan did not taste any different from regular naan. The prices were very reasonable.
author: James S.

description: Non-discernible small portions  (in hindsight grateful there wasn't a lot of it) pieces of what I hope was chicken. Fast service, however provided you are looking for speedy indigestion.   So maybe two stars in the moment, but one star as you realize this is gonna be a dinner that doesn't fade anytime soon and food should only be memorable mentally...if you know what I mean.  For $40+ bucks I expect actual food and good food.  Maybe I want too much from delivered Indian.
author: Darby W.

description:
This place is almost a hole in the wall. It's sparsely decorated and somewhat sketchy-looking (like most of Tenderloin). The service is fine but not great (sometimes you have to try a little to get their attention). But the food...wow, this is some pretty great Indian food!

Order the chicken tikka masala even if you know better, because it's actually really, really delicious. If you want more chicken, order the murgh boti tandoori, which is likely the best tandoori chicken I've had. Otherwise, try the daal masala if you like lentils, bhuna gosht if you like lamb. Finally, get some naan (it's only $1!) which is perfectly fluffy and delicious.

I'd recommend coming with a group of friends who don't mind sharing and ordering a bunch of dishes family style, so you can try everything. And the prices are great, so after a great filling meal you might be surprised (in a good way) when you get the check.

I wasn't brave enough to try the brain masala, but now that I know how good this place is, I might try it when I come back!
author: Brittany C.

description:
Stay away, fruit fly found in Dal

!! Stay away from this restaurant !! My craving for the Indian food led me to this restaurant in San Francisco. The place was very unhygienic, we found fruit fly in Dal we ordered. When we shown that fly to the owner, he smashed the fly right away and ignored us by saying its just jeera (cumin seed).

Unless you are looking for free flies with your food, I would strongly not recommend this place. This place is OVERRATED, other reviews are coherent with the similar feedback.

It is as well listed in just-say-no-to-these-places-san-francisco:
https://www.yelp.com/list/just-say-no-to-these-places-san-francisco
author: Saurabh A.

description: This is authentic Pakistani food. Their haleem was really good and their naans are only $1!
author: Maaz A.

description:
Shalimmmmmmmmar. 

Best late night spot west of Ben's Chili Bowl. 

Chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, regular naan. 12am breakfast of champions.
author: Rod A.

description: We had to go into San Francisco last night on business. It was getting quite late and we were craving Indian food. Unfortunately it was about 11 p.m. luckily I remembered Shalimar. A great hole-in-the-wall Pakistani restaurant that I used to eat frequent 20 years ago when I lived in the area. It was open till midnight and we headed right over. We ordered their specialty goat dish which I cannot pronounce or spell, the vegetarian eggplant, 2 garlic nan's, a mango lassi and all three desserts on the menu! LOL it was amazing. every dish was delicious. I couldn't believe that after 20 years this little hole-in-the-wall was still here in the food was still sooo good. The place was packed , the service was great it was a great overall experience. To top it off when the bill came it was about half as much as my usual place in the East Bay. Only downside it is in the tenderloin on Jones and O'Farrell but no worries there are so many people walking around you will be fine It looks much worse there than it actually is. Take my advice and go you will not regret it.
author: j c.

description:
The food deserves five stars, but the sanitation and service are seriously lacking. 

Though you sit at a table to eat your food, you still have to go up to the counter to order. Your bus boy, who will supply your table with water (appearing as a server) will not mention this to you. You'll be left to figure it out on your own. 

Also, this place is clamorous. A little hard to have a discussion with your party, as the heavily ethnic crowd provides a high-decibel background noise. Kind of feels like you're in Mumbai.

But again, four stars. The food makes everything else worth it.
author: Michael A.

description:
Indulge in gluttoney. Best indian/pakistani food. 

Prices are very reasonble.  quantity is great and quality awesome.  5 stars all the way. 

Mutten curry - delicious  around $8

Beer jalfrazi - awesom flavor and had lots of fresh peppers. Tasted good.

Garlic naan - they make naan in front of u. Naan is huge and flavorful. $2.50 one is enough for most people. Two is food coma!

Bhindi masala - ~$6.59 awesome. 

Rice was bit wet as i had guessed from previous picture.

Dont eat with rice if like biryani type rice. Naan is better choice.
author: TheHindu E.

description:
Shalimar. Everyone has heard of it.
And whether or not you have tried it or not, it's the household name for Indian food when it comes to the Bay Area.

They have locations all over. Fremont, Sunnyvale, Nob Hill, Tenderloin. I've been to all of those. But this location earns the most respect.

None of them have any standard of service.
All of them have questionable health code standards
All of them have the minimal amount of effort put into decor.
(For instance, this particular location used the previous tenant's sign, which features a martini glass, they painted over and simply paint 'shalimar' over it)

However, for the lack of attention and effort put into anything else you'd expect with a restaurant, they put directly into food.

Their food is always consistently good. The prices are always the same. Your taste buds will always be happy.

Plenty of vegetarian/vegan options and their rice is the best.

Forget service. Forget drinks. Forget cleanliness. Food is what they promise and they deliver.
author: Lanie L.

description:
Although in a slightly more dodgy part of town, this place is a little gem and worth visiting. It certainly looks authentic and the food is not posh by any means but sure tastes good.
The food was delicious, served quickly and well portioned.  Overall it was really good value for money. 
The staff also accommodated our large group of 8 people without stress or hassle.
Be aware that the restaurant does not allow alcohol. This wasn't a problem for our group but wasn't something we were aware of until we got there.
author: Tig H.

description: Such good food! The brain masala was awesome! So glad to find good, authentic Indian/pakistani food.
author: Pallavi S.

description: WOW What a hole in the wall! This is in the ghetto part of San Francisco. When you first walk in the place doesn't look nice, but the food is amazing!! This is one of the best Indian/Pakistani restaurants I have ever been to. They also have free tea, overall a great spot I will definitely be back when I am in SF.
author: Rihan K.

description:
The food was alright, but I've had better (I've had Indian roommates before and grown to really appreciate the culture through delicious Indian cuisine). Ordered the grilled lamb for $13, garlic naan for $2 and a coke for $1.

The lamb was okay, but it was a little dry and under seasoned. The naan was fresh and hefty in size. The place had a true "hole-in-the-wall" feel. 

What I think would help the place a little better would be increase ventilation because it felt kind of stuffy and super hot, which made dining in a little uncomfortable. I was sweatin' even before the spicy food came out!
author: Marino K.

description:
The real deal for tloin late night Indian -- definitely a league above its neighbors Pakwan, Naan n curry, etc.

Indian people: this is a goddamn dhaba, don't expect a Michelin star

Non-Indian people: this is like Carls Jr for Indian people, you know it's not fine dining, but damn doesn't it feel good once in a while.
author: Jackson P.

description:
Your first impression will be like...wth is this, but its food is amazing! It's authentic Indian food not the American version across the street. Once I tried their food I couldn't go back! Yeah it might look like a dingy place but it's the quality of the food we are talking about...

It's worth trying and if you really are picky about it just try the place across the street. It's the American Indian type.
author: Asma S.

description: The bartenders around the corner recommended this to us as their favorite local place to eat. The food was admittedly great, this would be a terrific place to get take away as the lighting and atmoshpere, well, to be honest was poor, not a fan of the stark and dingy look.. Food was fresh and authentic, though! We got there on the early side on a Friday night and got the last available seating, they must have something special going for them as the line was out the door and growing as we left.
author: Terri W.

description:
Oh boy. Let me tell you something about Shalimar. It's not the place to go if you're looking for a long, elaborate meal in a sparkling setting, where people serve you. 

But if you're looking for a joint with damn good curries and tandoori chicken, this is the spot for you. The bhuna gosht is the best thing on their menu. Have it with naan and cup of chai tea that they have. 

Just as good for takeout, too.
author: Glynnis M.

description:
BEFORE you go to Shalimar, here are some things you should know:

*It's Dirty.
*It's Divey.
*Tables are sticky and chairs are wobbly. 
*Mismatched dishware and bent silverware. 
*Sloppy drunktards everywhere.  
*You will get solicited by crazies in invisible stray jackets, junkies, and sheMANs.
*You will leave smelling like ass...FOR DAYS. 

Turned-off? GOOD. 

Please stay away from Shalimar so I can have the Lamb Brain Masala ALL to my gluttonous, fat f*ck self. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0OUFGCqvp84JMJH7pnFHgw?select=nUuPnJmgpFOPtWSwr_Ih-w
If pate and butter chicken (sauce) had a love child, the lamb brain masala would be it. Ridiculously good, the lamb brain's rich velvety texture melted in my mouth like a triple cream butter while the masala set off a trifecta of fireworks with intense bursts of spice, heat, and pure deliciousness.  Like Indian crack, the lamb brain masala was so BOMBTASTIC that I envisioned knocking out all the mofos with me just so I can have the whole plate to myself. *Muahaaahaaaa*

Did I mention that one 3oz. serving of lamb brain has 2128 mg of cholesterol (709% of your % daily value)?

Yup, stay away. FAR, FAR AWAY.  

OTHER NOTES:
*Authentic Indian/Pakistani food full of robust flavors.
*CHEAP EATS: most dishes are $6.95 and nothing is over $10.95. 
*Order the Goat Karahi and Nihari (Braised Beef Shank) which are just as good; don't order the dry Murgh Boti Tandoori (Chicken Tandoori).
*Order multiple orders of the Garlic Naan to mop up all the delicious sauces and curries.
*Many customers are native ones so you know it's legit.
*No alcohol sold on premises but we brought our own beers.
*CASH ONLY.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I love this place. The chicken tikka is very unique and amazing. They also have very fast service. 
If it's by enough that it's the best, their prices are lowest in the area.
author: Moawia E.

description:
I have been going to Shalimar with my family for the past 10 years.

I absolutely love this place - the food is phenomenal.

It is a hole in the wall - but - THE FOOD IS ABSOLUTELY AMAZING !

I recommend getting lamb chops, garlic naan, chicken leg, nihari, maghuz and a mango lassi - life is set once you have those in your belly.

If you want good Indian food at a good price - go post up at Shalimar and you will not be disappointed.
author: Kirpa W.

description:
This restaurant has a sister location in the Tenderloin, on Jones above Geary. Both have been in business for many years, and both serve very authentic, spicy Pakistani food. 

The Polk street location is cavernous, bare bones, and has a sombre feeling. Today there were many dirty tables and very few customers. I try to support it and when I go there it's because I crave it - specifically the Palak Paneer, spinach with cardamom and that special white cheese that never melts. Buttery and spicy, it is heaven scooped onto the fresh naan. Wash it down with the free, steaming hot chai.

Although they are not effusive with the regulars, I think it comes more from cultural habit than any kind of attitude. This place is now very unusual for the neighborhood. Its endurance will be a real indication of whether the city can keep some of its diversity in culture and businesses.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: In one word AWESOME!!!!!! This place never seems to let me down. The ambience is not that great but they make up for it with their awesome food
author: Aryan M.

description:
I swear to god I never had a bad costumer Service    Like this in my life . Food is not clean and tables are so dirty and they over charge costumers too.
I feel that giving them 1 star is not fair for them if there were below zero i would give it to them .

I feel so bad for coming to this restaurant.
author: Hesham A.

description:
I've been to the Shalimar in the Tenderloin and it was a drunken, mystical adventure. And that's from a guy who doesn't drink.

So when I was close by here in Nob Hill location and craving a heap of Indian food, I dropped in. 

Look, this is not fancy. It's street-level food. It's greasy, oily, hot, fresh Indian food. I had the chicken saag with rice and some garlic naan and I only ate about half, as the portions are generous and I wasn't crazy hungry. But it was just what I wanted.

I'm fairly confident there is better Indian to be had in this town. In fact, I know it. But still, if you want a really divey experience with a place that serves up random plates (the actual ceramic dishes they use are all different patterns) than you've found your late night divey Indian food match.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
This place is great! 

My friends and I were feeling the taste of Indian food and happened to choose this place because of the YELP REVIEWS!

We had no expectations and we're relying on our past experiences and yelp reviews for our food of choosing. 

The following foods were order: 

Rice(5/5):
-its just rice.... hahaha

Garlic Nann(3/5):
-Very oily. I wish it wasn't as oily as other places

Potato Nann(3/5):
-Very oily

Lamb Brain Masala (5/5):
-Personally, I was very hesitant to try this. I had my friends try it out first and then asked for their opinions. I was honestly scared. I had to  jumped out of my comfort zone to eat this and I don't regret it. Lets say that, we ended up ordering two plates. I hope that tells you something 

Chicken Tikka Masala (4/5):
-It wasn't over creamed like the others I had before. Nothing special, just the same ole stuff

Goat Karahi (4/5):
-I like spicy foods but my body cant really handle it. In my opinion, this plate was pretty spicy and had to grab a few napkins to wipe some sweat off my head. 

When eating these curry plates, I suggest to order rice instead. The nann will definitely fill you up faster. If we all stuck with nann, we wouldn't be able to finish the curry plates because its too filling. 

Parking was hard, so I'm guessing this is a only a one time stop for me. Other than that, I'll come by if I have another chance.
author: Allan W.

description:
Located in the heart of the Tenderloin, this is one of the dirtiest hole in the wall places I've been to in SF. There is a health rating sign on the wall which seems to have originally said "10", but someone drew into a "98". That was amusing, but the moment I stepped inside this place, I knew I was going to let a few things slide for the sake of tasty food (eg, dirty tables, chefs without gloves or hairnet/hats, crackheads panhandling next to me while I ate...)

I was brought here by a coworker originally from Pakistan, so I was already expecting a certain level of authenticity. Shalimar did not disappoint. Everything here was excellent and while I'm not an authority on Pakistani cuisine, it tasted authentic to me. We had about 9 people, so we ordered a lot. I can't remember every single dish, but we ordered more familiar items like saag paneer and chicken tikka masala, as well as an amazingly tender beef shank dish, and wait for it.... lamb brains. And the lamb brain dish was great. Their mango lassi is more sweet and mango tasting than yogurty, but I liked it.

As we started to get full and drift into a food coma state, a crazy dude ran in to the restaurant, leaned in to our table, and asked us for money. The Shalimar staff came by and told him to stop harassing people. Thanks Shalimar!
author: Amy M.

description:
I can't believe this place has any negative reviews. Shalimar is my sanctuary. I live to eat Shalimar. Shalimar is a way of life. My cat passed, then I went to Shalimar. I just got a raise, and then we all went. to. Shalimar. 

I haven't found and Indian/ Pakistani place that is better, even upscale restaurants. Sure it's not a healthy option. Walk it off. 

Ay yi yi! Their decor is on POINT! Try the chicken Jalfrezi. Obviously try the chicken Tikka Masala. Saag Paneer. Garlic naan etc.  

Overall this place is full of character and the staff is humble and honest. They aren't trying to be something else. Wouldn't recommend for a first date, you'll leave the place smelling like a smoked chicken breast. Though, every time I bring someone new to this place, they leave completely satisfied. and full. I hope it never shuts down, I plan on eating here for the rest of my life (In moderation, of course).
author: Wells F.

description: We end up going to this place each time we are in SF. Taste still the same after so many years. If you are not too particular about the service but are looking for good Pakistani food, then this is the place for you.
author: Rohit K.

description:
Most authentic dal and paneer! 
The naans are really fresh and light.
My to-go place.
author: Namrata J.

description:
So freaking good.

SF is full of great Indian restaurants so definitely go and explore but Shalimar is one of the best I've had. The place is small and smoky. When you go in, seat yourself at an available table and order in the front. Even though they've never asked me for my name, they've never gotten my order wrong. In due time, the magical delicious dishes will appear at your table.

The tika masala is so good. Garlic naan bomb. First combination curry was also delicious. I tried the saag last time and it was also totally legit.  The food there is spicy and has a tasty kick. I couldn't ask for more. Chai tea is self serve. 

On a cold SF night, nothing warms me up better than some spicy curry and a cup of steamy hot chai! 5 Stars hands down!!
author: Gloria C.

description: Authentic Pakistani food, the food in this restaurant is fantastic, full of flavor, authentic and served quick.
author: Z ..

description:
I should have known better.  Look, I've eaten at the one in the tenderloin and was not impressed at all.  My stupid friend says I must have had a bad experience, so he convinced me to come to this location.  Why I listen my pasty friend who doesn't like onions, garlic, or flavor I don't know.  What a waste of time.  This isn't curry, it's oil.  When someone leaving comments on how great the naan was, I rolled my eyes.  This is the crappiest cheap indian food in this city, yet it's raved about.  Everyone must be high or something.  And just like last time, I wore my food out and had to incinerate my clothes.  

If you eat at these dumpy places, and still think Shalimar compares, I'll buy your next meal at this dump:  Little Delhi (daal makhni, shrimp rasala...you won't be disappointed) or Pakwan (saag paneer is fantastic here!).
author: A A.

description:
I went there couple weeks ago but havent eaten. Before the place used to be wonderful and tasty . Nowadays , taste of food probably good. However , when i've entered the place , tables were messy and I did not felt that i'm in a clean place . Would like to recommend to the owner focus more about cleaning the place . 



It used to be one of the best indian restaurant in the city (by the taste of food) and maybe its still like that , however I won't eat when tables are messy and not clean. Especially , spoons and forks. 

Sorry.
author: Jay M.

description:
I love this place. In fact, I love it so much that I had my boyfriend cancel our fancy steakhouse reservation on Valentines Day to come here instead. Because how else would I share the love? 

Pros:
Delicious Food
Fast service
Decent prices
Free chai tea

Cons:
Smaller portions (also works as a pro when you want a little of everything)
Lack of air ventilation/kitchen exhaust (you will end up smelling like you have gone through the tandoori oven yourself)
author: Michelle C.

description:
I was dressed for a date at Ryoko's but we were quoted a wait of at least an hour. What's a gentleman to do? Reluctantly ask a lady dressed in sleek black and high heels if she's willing to take a chance on a super divey Pakistani spot just around the corner.

Zero hesitation from me ensued, aka: 'hell YES!'.

We walked in and were sat straight away. What came next was a flurry of fragrant dishes: insanely good garlic naan, a well-spiced bowl of daal, and real deal chicken tikka masala.

It may be a bit grimy and it definitely fulfills the definition of hole-in-the-wall; its low brow insides just might make you reconsider eating at Shalimar. But for the brave who summon the courage to stay: you're about to experience one of the best Pakistani meals you'll ever find in this city.

Believe.
author: Jelena Z.

description: Tucked away hole in the wall. A great place to go for no frills tasty food. The highlight was the brain masala. Would go when I am in the area again.
author: S T.

description:
The closest thing I've found in the US to an honest-to-goodness dhaba -- the Indian equivalent of a greasy spoon. Cafeteria-style tables, paper menus with curry splotches on them, and a harried-looking guy behind the counter who calls you "bhai-sa'b" (roughly, "bro-sir"). That's right, I got bhai-sa'bed in the Tenderloin. In fact, the entire ordering conversation took place in Hindi/Urdu, though I didn't realize this until a moment later. I've seen a couple of these dhaba-type places in Canada, but Indian restaurants in the US are usually not quite so casual, and everything normally costs about 50% more.

I suspect that the people running this place are Punjabi, and probably from the Pakistani side of Punjab. The default red meat here is beef (though there are a couple of lamb dishes on the menu), and there are a few classic subcontinental Muslim dishes like nihari and haleem, and biryani without any of that raisin-and-cashew nonsense. There's also a tandoor, with the usual array of naans and kababs. I like that you can get a single serving of kabab for a couple of bucks, rather than having to order a whole plate of them.

I got a chicken tikka masala, seekh kabab, and naan. The food was a bit greasy (OK, technically submerged in a pool of grease), but that's to be expected at a place like this. Not the tastiest Indian food you can find, but satisfying in a diner-ey sort of way.

I'm glad this place is here, and that it offers some dishes beyond the usual palak paneer and chicken tikka masala and naan that you get at every other Indian restaurant in America. (Yes, I'm aware that I ordered two of these dishes. I am hypocritical that way.)
author: Nath A.

description:
Don't expect someone to acknowledge you when you walk in.
You have to walk in and grab a menu near the register, order and find a seat.

It was pretty crowded but a seat opened up when we got there so we got lucky.
Ordered the chicken tikka masala, tandoori lamb chop, goat biryani, and aloo paratha delvhi.

The Aloo Paratha was kinda flavorless. Maybe we should've ordered the usual garlic naan.
Watch out for the bones in the goat biryani.
The tikka masala was just ok.  It was really oily.
The tandoori lamb chop was kinda dry but it was flavorful.

This place was decent but not amazing.
author: Heejin L.

description: Best paki food in San Francisco. Reasonable prices...Must try chicken tikka, behari, nihari, karahi and chai.
author: J S.

description:
Stopped by for lunch after getting a deep tissue massage by my new fond favorite massage therapist.  It's been a while since I last ate here and it's funny to see the same staff that's been there for more than ten years.

The best thing about this place is that they haven't sold out to the general dining public that prefer a more "suburbanized" Indian food, meaning, insipid, sweet sauce with meat that is deboned and neatly presented.  This place stays true to its core, the decor is very pedestrian, and dining hall smells like an Indian restaurant, self-serving chai, water, cilantro/tamarind sauce...  I had the chicken karahi, rice and they are as flavorful as I can recall.  The chicken was served with bone, which requires a little getting used to.  But everyone who cooks knows meat just tastes better if it's cooked w/ the bones.  So it's a compromise that I am happy to accept.
author: Jj S.

description:
Four stars for the naan hands down!

I shared chana masala and a potato naan with my roommate and the total was around $10.  The chana masala was good.. the sauce felt more like a gravy than the chana masala I'm used to, but it was nonetheless good.  

And the naan was the star of the show.  It was fluffy, had a hint of spice, and was very filling.  If I was really hungry, I could've eaten the whole piece plus the masala.  My other roommate ordered chicken tikka masala.  For $7.95, it was a small portion, and it didn't come with rice.  Though it was good, I thought it was overpriced.

This place is all about the food.  The decor is old, and the plates look like they all came from Goodwill down the street.  But the food is really good and I would definitely come back for the naan alone.

*Woohoo my 800th review!*
author: Vira P.

description: Wow. It might seem mundane to order chicken tikka masala at an Indian joint, but this one is righteous. The blend of spices and the well balanced creaminess of the sauce is as good as it gets. Paired with naan and a mango lassi to cool down equals a happy me. The chicken boti wasn't as good, but if you add some green sauce from the fridge it helps.
author: Nina S.

description:
Our time in SF was limited and the SF restaurant choices are  vast, so we decided to go to a restaurant only once, in order to try the next place on our list. 

However, Shalimar is so good that we went multiple times. It's just that good.  Yes, it's a hole in the wall.  Yes, it's small and can get crowded.  Yes, the food is oily.  And yes, your clothes smell like tandoori after you leave. None of that matters, just go. Just eat. And just go again.

Our favorites are the chicken tikka masala, chicken kofta, chicken jalfrezi, chicken boti, and the tandoori lamb chops.  Get some plain naan or some rice and go to town on that food.  And then relax and have a chai at the end.  Don't skip the chai, because it's great.

It's not a coincidence that when we moved from SF, we moved within 10 minutes of the Fremont Shalimar location.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
On any day of the week, this place will be busy. Busy in the sense, there will be about 1-2 parties waiting in front of you. There's nobody to take your name, tell you how long the wait will be, you just walk in and wait until a table clears up. 

Once seated, the place doesn't have waiters, you go up to the counter and order. The orders come quick but you'll notice is that there are many tiny details to the restaurant that make it look like it hasn't been cleaned since it opened. 

While your order is being made, look around, you'll see there's a container with chai, it's free. There's usually a cup with a few used spoons in it. Don't use these to mix your sugar in your chai, get a clean one from the utensils holder. The chai has this odd smell as if it was boiled too many times. I would recommend trying a sip or two, nothing more. 

When the food comes, it's going to be good. Order rice and naan for sure, garlic naan is better. The food is better than a few Pakistani places in the city but it's still nothing to crave every so often. If you're a meat eater, get the seekh kabob, it's good. 

Overall, this place is good to try, I wouldn't recommend it as your first attempt at Pakistani food. It is a little cheaper than some Indian/Pakistani places, but then, it's in the Tenderloin.
author: Muhammad U.

description:
After leaving the theater, my husband and I were walking around trying to find something that was open and delicious. We checked on Yelp, and after walking a few blocks we came in to this local favorite. 

The Nan bread was really good and the Chicken Tikka Masala was also very good. A little spicy too. The rice was also tasty. 

The restaurant gets really busy, but the service is fast.
author: Robert V.

description: In my extensive travels .including 6 months living in Karachi Pakistan...5 years Saudi Arabia..many years Liverpool. The need for the curry pulls me in like a Crack addict..it's a want .need .must have ....one thing about curry house food is if it's great ,all chairs are full and 50 % patrons are of the Indian/Pakistan Heritage...then go.. as Indian people don't tolerate crap ....the Garlic Naan bread the very best....Rice fluffy moist tastefully done....chicken curry is done the Indian way of bone in ...I'm not a fan of but meat scraped of with a spoon.....look next door Indian restaurant empty....Shalimar is a hole in the wall....but food and staff was 2nd to none
author: Wayne F.

description:
This place is not as good as the one in Fremont. It desperately needs a new paint job and a whole
Deep cleaning. The food is still very good. Naan bread is tiny compared to the one in Fremont as well.
author: Megan B.

description: After reading the reviews that raved about how good this place was, my friend & I decided to try it. Honestly, don't know why we walked in because everything we ordered was not up to expectations. The service and staff were really nice, however, the food itself is too bland and tasteless.
author: Nour A.

description:
My BBF (Boston Best Friend for all you unhip folk) is Indian, so when she was in town for a visit, she, her little sister and their bevy of Indian friends whisked me away to this place insisting that it was the best North Indian food in the city. 

While I love getting gastronomically schooled by people about their native cuisines, I think this place missed the mark. The food was tasty, but so disgustingly greasy that I could barely eat more than a few bites of each curry. Now, I'm Chiwanese (Chinese and Taiwanese for all you uncool folk), so I'm no stranger to greasy food. When I say it was greasy, it was gree-SAY! I mean, I love a big, thick, rich, creamy pot of chicken tikka masala or chicken kofta or chicken karahi as much as the next person, but it's usually not half filled with oil. Bleh! They mistakenly gave us an order of lamb tandoori, and that ended up being the best dish of the night for me by virtue of not being as greasy. 

Everything else was questionable--cleanliness, service....even pricing! Our itemized bill just listed, "Dept. 13" over and over and over again next to each price. WTF???
author: Josephine L.

description:
Shalimar (The name that just brings Indian/Pakistani inside the restaurant)!! However, I walked in and walked out with my friend at this location. The food might still be great but the cleanliness and hygiene was NOT at all present. 

Reading other reviews here, it seems like I was not the only one. We ended up going to Chutney across the place which seemed more reasonable. Shalimar seems to be riding on the name without caring much about the patrons.
author: Begum L.

description:
So this is my personal review. . We came here twice and ordered brain masala, goat karahi and chicken karahi. They use the same gravy for Brain masala and karahi.  Their Naan is the worst I had in all these years.  Very hard and never get it to to go because by the time you are home, the naan ia like a piece of rock. They don't have anything other than Naan as breads for the curries.  I wish they add more breads to the menu.  Will come back again.

FYI: The guys at the cashier have the worst attitude and they don't smile at all.
author: Rintu M.

description: A gem find. Lamb roasted in a tandoori oven are a must. Go in the evening hours. Somehow cooks do a better job.
author: Andy W.

description: I haven't been here since forever, but apparently my parents still come occasionally. I came here with them tonight, and it wasn't great. We ordered two tandoori chicken legs ($3.99 each pre-tax), two beef kabobs ($2.50 each), 3 naan ($1 each), eggplant curry ($6.50). The curry was so small! I couldn't believe it. It was also really oily, and it wasn't that flavorful. My naan was also not very good; the outer rim was very thick and chewy, but the middle was hard and not chewy at all. I was very disappointed; it was almost like eating a brick. Not enjoyable at all. Beef kabob was good as was the chicken leg. Good thing I didn't come here by myself; if I did, I would have only gotten the curry and a naan, and this place would be given 2 stars from my review. Self-serve onions, jalapenos, and tea; environment's okay, plenty of seating. Order first, find a seat, and they bring the food to you. Parking's pretty easy though the lot was full when we arrived (got lucky though and got a spot right as someone was leaving). Won't be a regular here; Chutney right near it is much better, and Pakwan is good as well.
author: Andrea W.

description: I guess it was alright. Not sure why the remarkable reviews here. The food was just okay for us. Super oily but definitely more affordable than other places though. We ordered for chicken korma, lentils and mixed ve
author: Mahak R.

description:
Cheap Indian / Pakistani food that's actually great...if you can deal with the sketchy cleanliness levels both inside and outside the restaurant and the homeless folks that sometimes join you inside and are then chased away.

Service is limited but quick and the whole experience is no frills which includes people standing in line staring at you hungrily waiting for your table as you come close to finishing.

Kebabs and tikkas are always good here as are the chicken curries.
author: Tabz S.

description: I can't say I'm an expert on Indian or Pakistani food but my boyfriend does enjoy Indian and was a huge fan.  We walked in starving around 9 pm on a Tuesday and it just happened to be across from Bourbon & Branch with a 4 star yelp rating, and it was not only filled but there were lots of Indian families eating there, so we figured we couldn't go wrong.  We ordered the chicken jalfrezi, lamb chop tandoori, onion naan, and chicken meatballs (forgot the name).  It was the right portion for the two of us, and it was very affordable (probably the reason for so many 4 star/5 star ratings).  Everything was definitely a bit greasy and not fancy, but it was good.  You walk up to the counter to order, and the place is a bit divey, but it is the Tenderloin after all.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Visited 03/29/2015.  This place has heavenly food in a bare bones environment staffed with efficient and friendly servers. A date who is not looking for 'fancy' will kiss you after her (or his) first bite. It's noisy and chaotic during lunch rush but the servers will take good care of you.   But here's the skinny on the food because that is the reason you will go there again and again:

Dishes look individual but portions are generally sufficient to share.  I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala, Palak Paneer, Basmati rice, and garlic Naan.  The Tikka Masala was perfectly spiced and had generous portions of tender barbecued chicken.  Just absolutely mouthwatering. The basmati rice was light and expertly cooked and just complemented the chicken. The Paneer was very thick and spiced amazingly, with huge cubes of cheese embedded.  The naan was so garlicky and buttery that it almost oozed out of the middle.  It was so rich it might better be an appetizer, with regular naan to soak up the sauces of the main dishes.  Oh, and Free masala tea! I saw beautiful Gulab Jamen in the fridge but was just too stuffed.  There is always next time! 

Prices are amazing considering this is San Francisco, and portions were generous enough we could have ordered one of everything instead of two. $21 total ( It is off the rich path around Union Square by just a few blocks but the neighborhood seemed fine to us, so out of towners nearby should try it too!   It is well worth it and will be on my to-do list every visit!
author: Noel J.

description:
Alright, so whoever is behind the counter& answers the phone is rude as hell.  This food is so good, monthly I humbly hand him over money and politely thank him as he hangs up in my face.  I work nearby & order take-out lunch.

So it takes 20 mins to get my food ready.  I'd gladly wait 2 hours.  Their Chicken Kofta meatballs are the best chicken meat balls I've had in my life.  Their beef Nihari is real spicy with packed with spices gravy.  And their Tandoori Chicken Leg is coated with red-spicy goodness and is the reason I can not eat tandoori chicken anywhere else.

So I have to spoon off half an inch of orange oil off the top of my togo container when I get back to the office, (I mix in the residual oil--you know an evil part of you is enticed by this!).  I've heard Shalimar is not authentic Pakistani food because the authentic version is more subtle in flavor.  Shalimar, maybe to cater to S.F. tastes, beats you over the head with spices, (whole cloves, peppercorns, fennel seeds, cardamom & cinnamon sticks in the food).  If this is the case, I love to be beaten this way twice a month.  I love Shalimar.
author: Johnnie N.

description:
Originally planned to eat at Lahore Karahi, but they were closed early for some sort of repair or something (went back to Lahore a few days later), so ended up at Shalimar, which is just around the corner.
Food was filling but not particularly good or memorable. Greasy and salty, but otherwise lacking.
Also, the place didn't seem very clean (the tableware felt greasy and the table clearly had been only cursorily wiped).
As I noted for Lahore Karahi, neighborhood seems pretty seedy, and sidewalks needed to be washed down. I won't be returning to this area next time in town.
author: Aris F.

description: A little hole in the wall that's not as cheap at it looks at first sight. The chicken tikka masala is only $8 but if you want rice and naan, you are over $15 with tax. The food is cheap, doesn't taste bad per se but out of 20+ Indian places I've eaten at its in the bottom two. And be prepared for very little chicken. Also, they didn't serve me water when I asked, the guy just pointed at the pitcher of water in the bottom of the beverage cooler.  After I saw another patron grab a styrofoam cup from the counter and serve himself I understood what to do. Then they have the nerve to ask for a tip, ugh. I give very few 1-2 star reviews but this place doesn't deserve your business. I'm shocked others have rated it as high as they have. Dine at your own risk.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Shalimar is essentially a soup kitchen for Indian food. You wouldn't call what they serve "food," as much as "grub": the stuff you might find if you wandered down an alley in the Fabric district of Manhattan and discovered the cafeteria where the seamstresses and cart-pushers eat their lunch. It's certainly authentic grub - probably very near what you would get from a street vendor in India - but it's not the kind of thing that you want to think about very much as you're putting it into your body.  

Another way of describing this place is that it's the opposite of a very conscious vegan restaurant, where the food is lovingly and thoughtfully prepared. The food is cooked in industrial containers and ladled out onto a paper plate before being plopped onto the counter. That may be exactly what you're looking for - it does have a certain no-frills charm to it - but again, it doesn't leave you feeling healthy aftewards. The amount of heavy oils and creams in each dish seems greater than what you would find in most Indian restaurants.  

If you are the type of person that would not mind eating a plateful of fried food, for example, then I think you will enjoy this place a lot. It is indeed tasty. But if you are pretty aware of things like bloating and brain fogginess, I'd recommend that you avoid Shalimar.
author: Evan B.

description:
I'm an Indian food junkie so I have been trying all of the Indian restaurants near me in SoMa.  
I'm also pretty close to the Tenderloin and for all of it's dirt and grittiness, one thing that the TL has to offer is a wealth of awesome and cheap ethnic places to eat.  Particularly India, Thai and Vietnamese.  

I went to Shalimar recently and came away happy.  The place is no frills, order at the counter and grab your own plates kind of place.  I had their chicken curry, garlic naan and paneer tiki masala.  The chicken curry was flavor full and had a nice depth to it.  The paneer tiki masala, was kind of a let down.  After enjoying this dish at other places (it's my favorite Indian item when done right),  The sauce was kind of thin (I like to creamy) and they did not give me that many cubes of paneer.  

What I loved about my meal was the garlic naan.  Their garlic naan is different that other places in that it's much denser and more pillow like (more spongy).  It also has whole garlic gloves backed into the bread.  It's perfect for sopping up sauce like from their curry chicken.  I will be back to try more dishes but right now, I give it our stars.
author: Joey S.

description:
There are already over 800 reviews discussing the food here so I will simply provide a few helpful logistics:

*Parking is available for $9 pre-paid (plus $2 tip, you cheapskates) in the rinky-dink garage across the street (ATM available)

*Order at the counter then sit your ass down

*Even though you ORDERED at the counter, you do not PAY at the counter, so keep your ass sitting down and wait for the check

*When eating with a group, an order including approximately 1.33 main dishes per person should suffice

*Beware of cardamom pods

*Including rice and naan, but excluding beverages and tip, expect to get stuffed silly for about $14 per person 

*No adult beverages

You're welcome.
author: Valeria R.

description:
I was in town from LA and you guys need to open up shop in LA. By far the best tasting on the West Coast!

Their naan was on point and their beef korma was pretty good.
author: Aazar J.

description: Excellent Mughalai food & incredible price  for the city. Good Nihari & Bengen Bhujia. Everything was cheap & rich but chaotic, just like how you may find it in some place like Karim's near Jama Masjid in Old Dehli.
author: Adam X.

description: Very affordable, cafe style restaurant in not the greatest part of SF. The portions are smaller than restaurants in Berkeley. The Garlic Naan is by far the highlight of the restaurant.
author: Sean M.

description:
If you're looking for glitz n glam, this ain't your place. Easy to miss, Shalimar is tucked into the slightly dodgy end of Polk. Was surprised when a friend and I walked in on a Friday night to see it not very busy. Large and substantial menu with very cheap prices. Order at the front and pay after you're done eating. 

Menus are printed on newspaper size sheets. Took them to the table to figure out what we wanted. I settled on chick peas and vegetables with rice and naan. The naan was amazing!! Soft, doughy, warm and melt in your mouth. The food was incredibly spicy. They gave us an entire pitcher of water with our food and we drank that whole sucker down. Also had to order some last-minute raita (cucumber & yogurt dip) to kill some of the spice. Wasn't a huge fan of the free chai they offer, though it was a nice gesture.

Def recommend for a super cheap meal and authentic (albeit spicy) Indian food. Our meal for 2 come out to $22!
author: Christine E.

description: The food was 100% great and the service was relatively fast and nice. the minus 2 stars is for cleanliness and tables was SUPER dirty and I had to call someone and say that they need to clean this mess. The food is good though if you can eat and sit on a sticky table.
author: Ross P.

description:
Chicken Timken Masala, Sarah Ghosht, Lamb Curry and Brain masala. ORDER THAT!!!! And you will not regret it! :D 

This place looks a little, O.o woah, but the quality of the food is authentic! Just so dam good I can eat it everyday!!
author: Nawaf T.

description:
This place is crazy hectic! It's some sort of cafeteria-style restaurant on steroids. We got take out because there were no tables (only about 10 tables). I got chicken tikka masala, my wife got paneer masala, and we got rice and a naan. 

The tikka masala had a good spice flavor. I like my tikka masala a little sweet, which this wasn't, but the taste was still undeniably tasty. 

The naan was fantastic. For one dollar, you get a giant, fluffy naan that tastes just right. 

The price was great - just over $20 for our two entrees, naan, and rice. The portions weren't huge, but there was enough for onr big meal. 

There's a lot to like about this place, but just be warned that this place feels like a foreign country when you come in to order.
author: Ross L.

description:
Whoever said the garlic naan would bring you to tears was right, but tears that it was the worst garlic naan I've ever had. Some terrible metal taste inside it.

Everything else was fine, nothing to write home about, and the basmati rice side was too spicey (hot) for me so I couldn't finish it. No other regular rice option to complement the rest of the meal.
author: Jessalyn D.

description: Can't go wrong with the saag/palak dishes, the biryanis, or anything tandoori. Decor is minimalist, but a recent renovation added a new floor that's a big positive. Often greasy, often loud, but always good food and a good deal.
author: Dave B.

description: After getting a recommendation to come eat here I was so disappointed in the food :( I was told the Chicken Tikka Masala was out of this world and unfortunately I was not happy at all and didn't even finish my meal. The naan was no where near the traditional naan that I am use to enjoying and eating. Sad it wasn't a good dinner and wasn't really looking forward to it being one.
author: D. D.

description:
This is by far my favorite Indian food restaurant. I use to live in SF and would visit this place so when I came to visit the Bay Area I had to stop here. I brought my Dad and brother and they loved it. 

We had: Lamb chops, tikka masala, palak paneer, beef jalfrezi, rice, naan, raita, and a mango lassi. 

I highly recommend to get the lamb chops. They are so good.

We came from out of the city so we drove in. There is a parking garage across the street for $10 an hour. FYI. If you can't find street parking.
author: Eric T.

description:
Food is tasty.

Very oily.  I am not sure about the hygiene in this place.
author: Dev. G.

description: Simple and yummy every time! I call in advance and since it is so hard to park there, they will come out to take your credit card and bring you your food. I love to pick up food here! Love it!
