author: Meredith L.

description:
Simple (no table cloths, self ordering, no frills) - GREAT food!
Went there for an informal meal with a colleague, based on Yelp info.
We loved all dishes we ordered - veggies and meat.
author: David M.

description: WOW ! We got the hint to go there from an Uber driver. Not fancy. Simply good , very good ! Food there. Take the garlic naan bread as a side !!
author: Arne C.

description: Great place for a cheap, casual dinner at the end of a long day.  Visited a few weeks ago on a trip to California for school and this was one of the best, most authentic ethnic restaurants I went to, which is saying something for San Francisco.  Their selection of food was good, and the free tea with dinner was a great bonus.  They didn't have saag paneer which I was a little disappointed about, but the alternatives we chose were good enough.  One piece of advice I'd give to the owners/staff is to make sure to keep the door closed when it's cold outside!  A customer didn't close the door all the way when they came in, and after a few gusts of cold air were blown over to my table I decided to get up and close the door myself.  That's not really something a customer should have to do.
author: Jenny C.

description: Exceptional North Indian food. Chicken Tikka Masala from here is the best I've ever had! Spinach paneer was also really good.
author: Trisha D.

description: Simply put, Go to this restaurant! Yes, it's in a sketchy area but it is worth the craziness. The food is absolutely amazing and the prices are unheard of, particularly for being in San Francisco. I always get the Chicken Tikka Masala and it is always awesome. I have also had the Lamb Brain dish and it was also really good, just not the texture I was thinking it would be as I was expecting more of a chunky / cubed sort of situation. Looked more like a bowl of soup. Sorry if that sounds disgusting, but it may be helpful to someone looking to try something "different". The Garlic Naan is amazing and the Basmati Rice is good as well. The service is not all that great here so don't come here in a rush. These guys appear to be crazy busy all the time and aren't too concerned about coming out from behind the counter to help you. Tip: If you're in a hurry, call ahead and get your food to-go.
author: Tyson G.

description:
This was some of the LEAST FLAVORFUL  Indian food that we've ever had....and you should know that 
 we are Indian so we are quite familiar with good Indian food both homemade and at restaurants. We ordered garlic naan, plain naan, onion kulchi, a beef dish, tandoori chicken and daal....all of which had NO FLAVOR. Even my first forays into Indian cooking when I got married 17 years ago had more spice than this. The one upside was that when I asked if there were nuts in the dishes we were ordering (my children are allergic), they very firmly said no and my daughter had no issues whatsoever ; usually at Indian restaurants they either don't know or don't care to be careful about cross contamination so tandoori chicken is usually the only thing that my daughter can safely eat.  So if you really  want something "different" than the usual American fare then go ahead and eat here - you won't get sick but you won't be eating anything with any kind of flavor that remotely resembles real Indian food.
author: Joyce T.

description: Man man man I cannot stop loving this place I love this place I love this place I love this place I love this place I've been coming here for over 15 years off and on Shalimar Fremont and San Francisco but for the past 10 years the San Francisco strictly I love the food I love the owner you cannot go wrong with this place is the best Indian food around....
author: Ahmad Z.

description:
This is a down-to-earth, simple Indian restaurant win amazing food.  For the past decade, every time I visit SF, I try to eat here.  The location isn't in a great part of town, but the food is great and cheap!   Don't expect heavy, creamy for at this restaurant.

The most recent time I went, the line was out the door, but luckily I ordered my food to-go.  I snuck past everyone at the door, saw all the tables and chairs full of patrons and headed straight to the cashier. I had to wait an additional 10 minutes for my food (how that guy keeps all the orders straight baffles me), but it was well worth the wait.  I ordered the chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, and 2 onion kulchas.

I would highly recommend this place for anyone looking for an affordable Indian restaurant in downtown SF without all the glamour and fanciness of the other restaurants in the area!
author: Mudit J.

description: Okay, I'm from Pakistan and I was craving for authentic Pakistani food. I ordered Brian masala, beef seekh kabab and naan. Too many cooks inside the kitchen btw. Awesome food, brian masala was amazing. Friendly staff and 5 star
author: Affan A.

description:
Very Very disappointing experience. The worst!!!!

I am surprised how this place has so many good reviews. The place was dirty. The utensils also seem dirty. Lot of fruit flies was there. I hated the food too ( No taste and too much oil).

Moreover, the neighborhood is bad. You will see many homeless people and drug addicts are moving around. I parked my car at 2 pm. When I came back, The rear window glass was broken and everything inside the car was stolen.
author: Niluthpol M.

description: I've been here a few times, and the food used to be good, I'm not sure what happened but it's not good anymore.
author: mariam n.

description: Smokey taste. Tasty smokey atmosphere. Order the menu. Jalapeño, onion, lemon medley a must for every dish.
author: Alexander T.

description: You wouldn't expect this hole in the wall place to be anything special, but I was pleasantly surprised! Great food for a great price.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I eat Indian food probably once every 2 weeks. And this was by far the most disgusting Indian food I've ever eaten. I ordered the chicken saag and couldn't  finish it because they left the inedible chili chopped up in the food to where I had to pick it out as I crunched (think fish bones), saag should not be crunchy.
We tried a salad but it turned out to be more of a flavored yogurt, the dessert was yuck too. 
I basically ate whatever chucks of chicken i could fish out of the dish and the Naan, but nothing else was edible. 
I've also never seen a place to not give you rice with your meal, maybe that's something i should  have paid more attention to, but still over all i couldnt finish it, very disappointing.
author: chrissy k.

description:
Two words : FOOD POISONING ...........
I felt I was eating pure oil smh and bad service
author: Edmar C.

description: Hands down best Indian food ever! My husband and I don't eat out much except for this place we go to at least twice a month.  You might be a little discouraged by the look of the place because it is a hole in the wall. But trust me it's the best Indian food I've ever had. And it's not expensive. I would highly recommend that you give this place a chance and you wont be disappointed.
author: Quinn S.

description: Very small plates. Not too great for vegetarians. Very oily food. I would rather have a subway over this. I feel this is overated, take this coming from an indian. Oh by the way garlic naan seemed it was frozen you can tell from the pic and taste too.
author: Kp P.

description:
October 18, 10:50 pm: I am utterly disgusted by how the cashier treated a Mexican customer who clearly spoke and understood little English. The customer was a dollar short of his entire order so the cashier said he would take one naan off the order but the customer didn't seem to understand and started walking away. The cashier brought out change, but the customer had his back turned around. As I notified the customer about his change, the cashier quickly put the change away before the man turned around and gave an "oh well" face. 

Shame on you for taking advantage of your customer and fellow struggling brother in this city. How can you hustle your customer, especially a minority, for a few bucks? Take a ride to hell. 

I will let anyone and everyone I know about this incident. I hope the few bucks was worth it.
author: Sora Y.

description: Great authentic food. Probably wouldn't have walked in here, if we hadn't been tipped off to give it a try.
author: Jan K.

description:
I was going to give them 3 stars due to the lackluster service but as long as you are aware that this is a hole in the wall type of place, then that level of service should not be too much of a surprise. And the place itself does have the appearance of questionable hygiene and cleanliness...

There are usually long lines here in the evening but we arrived for lunch with an almost empty restaurant (which soon filled up). Ordered the mango lassi, which was prob best I've had in a while. For food: garlic naan, chicken tikka masala, and murgh boti tandoori (chicken). The quality and taste of the food was really excellent, esp the tandoori. The masala was a little small but that's ok, it was pretty tasty. I'd love to try the other tandoori selection they have so of course we'll be back. I mean, we live just down the corner. 

ps. I love the comments about how scary/shady this area is.. you can tell they don't live here because they would know this is the tamest part of the TL LOL (Lower Nob Hill/Tenderloin border). But yeah if you're from the suburbs or a tourist this would be scary for you.. so ruuun!
author: Vol T.

description: Ambience is pretty poor. Had Bhuna Ghost, not worth it. Chicken tandoori seems promising. No beer but that's ok.
author: Ankur T.

description:
Shalimar is a Restraunt that when you walk in you say "hum do I want to eat here".  Located in a classic sf neighborhood parking is hard to find and the locals make getting there interesting.  There is someone just outside giving parking advice in the voice of darth vader.   Ignore the force. 

The food is awesome.  The chicken is tender and flavorful the biryani is to die for and the chicken makani is the best you will have.   We have tried all the locations and for us the quality and taste of the food here beats all their locations.  We had to get take out as our kids had to have it for dinner.  Now that is a statement.
author: Amber L.

description: Worth the walk and the slight wait.  I got there around 3pm on a Monday afternoon and had to wait for a table to get cleaned.  The food here was among the best Indian food I can remember. I had a lamb dish and tandori chicken.  You go to the counter and order the food and they bring it to you.  They have a pretty large selection too.  Not a fancy place nor is in a great part of town but I would eat there again.
author: Mark H.

description: Wow!! I'm very sad to say that, overall, this was the worst Indian food we have ever eaten. The chicken tikka Marsala was decent but the daal masala had very little flavor and garlic naan was horrible. I don't understand the high ratings unless the cooks just had a bad night.
author: Gary M.

description:
VERY RUDE PEOPLE, HOPELESS FOOD, DO NOT GO HERE.
There are plenty of options in San Francisco for Indian food. Shalimar is definitely not of of them. The servers are outright rude.
author: Karan S.

description: Lunch buffet is BOMB. I've eaten Indian food a few times but it was nice to be able to try things. Everything was very clean and flavorful and the staff was very nice!
author: Allie N.

description: Best Pakistani food ive had in a while! We ordered Tikka Masala, chicken biryani, daal masala and Nihari...everything was delicious. Naan were also very fresh. Very quick service, even on a busy Friday night. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!
author: Zara Z.

description: Wow! If it weren't for the incredible Yelp reviews, I would never have discovered this amazing 'hole in the wall'! The chicken tikka masala was absolutely incredible. It is by far the best Indian cuisine that I have ever tasted in San Francisco. The food was incredibly flavorful with a spicy kick. The garlic naan was equally as tasty and crispy, cooked to perfection.  The prices were incredibly reasonable as well. If you live in the neighborhood, I suggest getting take-out as the dining area is notably unpretentious.
author: William H.

description: This place deserves 5Million starts. Everything is fresh and so delicious.  Knowing its in the heart of SF, they should work on curb side for takeout.
author: Mareum S.

description: Ordered the chicken tikka masala and garlic naan, both delicious! The garlic naan had giant cloves of garlic studded in the bread (which as a garlic lover, I like)! Inside of the restaurant is pretty sketch and a wee bit dingy, but ordering takeout so u can eat it in the comfort of ur home is def an option!
author: Chase B.

description: I'm dreaming of the next time I'll eat here. It was so good I almost cried. Pair the garlic naan with anything. Dining area could use some sprucing up, but then it would lose its hole-in-the-wall feel.
author: Alaina B.

description:
HORRIBLE,

Worst service, food was okay... There is a better restaurant next door called Red Chili.. The food is better, the staff is nicer, and it is less expensive... ILL NEVER BE BACK!
author: Spencer R.

description: Nothing fancy, just great food and not trying to be anything else. Always a great place for grabbing some tasty South Asian food.
author: Sadique A.

description: Great tasting food, down to earth establishment. Minimal aesthetic and bold flavors with good prices. Saag gosht is tasty and the naan is hot and freshly made. Love the free tea. Let's keep this going.
author: AJ G.

description: First time trying this type of food, very interesting and unique! A little different for the GI system but well worth the adventure!
author: Nicolette R.

description:
As good as it gets taste wise. Total dive in a bad neighborhood but I didn't  care, I loved the food here. Once I came in and their back door was open: a pigeon strolled in and was pecking at the tub of raw chicken on the floor. I didn't even care - I loved the food that much. 

That said, I've gotten significantly ill after eating here, and more than once. I don't know if it's been from the intensity of spice or things like poor food handling (raw chicken sitting on floor = bad).  I'd hesitate before coming back now that I'm older and pickier....but a few beers could easily change my mind.
author: Michelle B.

description: Amazing food, cheap mango lassi ($2) and chai ($1).
author: Meiyi C.

description:
This place is unassuming but (or and!) the food is amazing.  Had the Chicken Jalfrezi, Basmati rice, and garlic naan.

No alcohol but that's okay.   Walk up to the counter to order and then sit down.  7 four tops and 5 two tops.  Fairly busy on a Thursday night at 7:30.
author: Miles M.

description:
The scene: Friday night dinner at Shalimar for 5. We arrived around 8:30. The wait was around 30 minutes.

WTF: There is absolutely no order whatsoever to arriving. There's no clipboard to put your name on, no host, no way to know when you'll be eating. When a table opens up, just go stand next to it and someone will come and "clean it" so you can sit.

Cleanliness: Don't count on it and definitely don't use the bathroom. 

More WTF: You order at the counter, although you wouldn't know it since there's no sign that helpfully tells you what your next step should be. You want a drink? Go grab it from the sliding fridge. 

The food: DELICIOUS. We ordered what we thought was too much, and then proceeded to polish the whole thing off. I will do my best to list what we had: tandoori chicken, chicken kofta, chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, chicken biryani, some kind of mixed vegetables, naan, and some other stuff I'm pretty sure I'm forgetting. 

And finally, more WTF (although at that point we should have expected it): You just go up to the register to pay, tell them what drinks you had, and then pay. Don't expect a check to be brought to you.

Due to its location, clientele can be interesting... but if you don't mind a dirty little hole in the wall, the food is totally worth it. For the rest of us, might I suggest take out?
author: Rachel E.

description:
I was walking home from a birthday party when I glanced into this hole-in-the-wall and stopped to see what the fuss was all about. At 11pm on a Saturday night, it was packed. A man walking out overheard me ask my fiancé "What is this?" and his answer was "fantastic Indian/Pakistani food -- trust me". So in we went.

Much to our delight, there were men preparing dough for fresh naan, and the tandoori chicken coming out of the kitchen looked delicious. We decided to snack on some baingan bhujia (eggplant), raita and aloo paratha bread. You can pour yourself some Kashmiri chai, so we did. Everything was fresh and authentic, and the staff were very polite. The bill came to $9.71 - a super deal.

If you don't mind a barebones atmosphere with great Indian/Pakistani food at a yesteryear price, then give this place a try.
author: Aleece G.

description: Best panner masala , good quality , very fresh ! Love the flavor and naan is super delicious here !!
author: Prayank J.

description: I am from Pakistan and so like folks from that part of the land know their food...tried Nihari, Haleem, Seekh Kabab and Chicken Biryani.....food was below average...Haleem was the worst! Tasted like Daal....Nihari was watered down! Seekh kabab order includes just ONE seekh kabab (below average)...chicken biryani was nothing special...maybe we just tried all the wrong things!
author: Hammad S.

description:
The best Indian food. Ever. God I love this place.

FWIW, there's a Nepalese place next door called Red Chili that sucks (average food, expensive). I'm only mentioning it in this review for you to cite if someone suggests you go there instead.
author: Noah P.

description:
Sketchy neighborhood to die for food.  I love Shalimar.  Bar none the best Pakastani/Indian restaurant ever.  Period.  Was so sad to move away from the Bay Area and to be without the tandoori chicken and their tandoori lamb.  This is how good it is- when I was pregnant, every three or four weeks I would send my husband up on a Southwest Airlines flight simply to pack me a cooler full of tandoori chicken and lamb- like 20 -30 orders.  Hand carry only.  I pity those poor people on the flight who had to smell the deliciousness of the tandori chicken without partaking in it.

So go there and order the tandoori chicken breast pieces. Dont' get the other pieces, get the breast. Ask for the tandoori lamb nicely.  Order naan and you're set!  Don't worry that you have to bus your own table or that you have to get your own drinks.  The food is worth it.  I don't order anything else but the tandoori chicken and the tandoori lamb.  For the last 20 years!

If you can't make it all the way to the city, they have a convenient location down south in Mountain View and less seedy.  

I now just go to random Pakastani joints down in Southern California trying to find a substitute but cry bitter tears in their poor versions of tandoori chicken.  Sigh.  But I'm heading up there in about two weeks...hmmmm chicken breasts.
author: Grace C.

description: I had a lamb curry here and despite it looking like kind of a dive, it was probably the best south Asian food I've ever had. I'm not from SF but I'd seek this place out for sure next time I'm in town.
author: Jay E.

description: Love this place. Has delicious food and great service. Today I got the chicken Tika Masala and the Naan bread. The kabobs are strange looking but wonderful.  I highly recommend it.
author: Scott S.

description: Hole in the wall joint. The food is delicious and reasonably priced, the surrounding area isn't the nicest, tho.
author: Valley G.

description:
Not bad. Nasty venue but the food is pretty good and fast.

Tandoori chicken is the bomb (and the standard comparator for me).

If it was Chutney's vs Shalimar, I'd probably go with Chutneys.
author: Julia P.

description:
Frequent this restaurant a lotttt - favorite place for Indian food. Basmati rice, chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, and chai tea on the house hits the spot every. single. time.

There's one other dish that I've tried here before, it's made of chunks of beef. Delicious, but really fatty haha.
author: Sabrina P.

description: My favorite - Goat Karahi and Chicken Tikka Masala :-)
author: Pratik J.

description:
I'm not really understanding the love for Shalimar. I dropped in on Labor Day with Anna D, as they were one of the few places open that day, and was a place highly recommended by her sister.

After sitting around for about ten minutes wondering when we were going to be served, we realized that we had to go up and order at the counter, after which they'd bring the food to our tables. We ended up ordering:

* Onion Naan - They ran out of the garlic naan, so we resorted to this instead. Not bad, not great.

* Chicken Biryani - Enjoyable, but I've had much better elsewhere (Aslam's, for example)

* Chicken Tikka Masala - So, this was one of the very hyped up dishes on Yelp, but I'm not seeing it. The flavors weren't decent, but the chicken was dry, making it just an okay dish.

* Bhut Gosht - Also not the best I've had, with lamb that was not as tender as I would have expected, but with alright flavoring.

Overall, average food. If I lived in the area, and with the low prices, I could see myself popping in every so often. But given that it requires a bit of effort to go to, I'd rather eat at one of the better restaurants in the area, and go elsewhere for better Indian food.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A  medium sized restaurant, with well-spaced seating arrangements, making accessibility into and inside the restaurant easy.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I can overlook the fact that the place is just dirty and ugly...but the quality of food was really bad. Worst palak paneer i ever had...under cooked and stale paneer pieces...not at all worth a visit..
And who packs naans in a paper bag for pick up orders...they were all wet and soggy by the time I got home...foil wrap is not rocket science!! Going on my places to avoid list..
author: Nikhil B.

description:
I've always had good food here.  Anything from the clay oven, but beware if you plan on going to the theater after eating here.  It's so filled with mesquite smoke the people sitting basically on your lap at ACT will assume you're working for SFFD.
Cheap eats for Union Square.
Oh yeah bring a pocketful of spare change.  The place is crawling with homeless.  I always give my leftovers away before I hit the corner. Grab extra napkins for this.
author: JIM M.

description:
I generally make a point not to reference other reviews, but I would like to direct you to this passage from the great Don B, who hails from Portland, OR: 

"Do you ever have one of those mornings where you wake up in a bit of a haze, and the first question on your mind is 'What the fuck happened to me last night and why does my shirt smell like Tandoori chicken?!'"

That is the man who took me to Shalimar. And when I say he took me to Shalimar, I mean he essentially carried me there after six too many cocktails at Rye, ordered for the two of us and stuck me with the bill, which I only know because I woke up with a Shalimar receipt in my pocket, and the aforementioned Tandoori chicken smell.

And as my memory slowly returns to me, the one thing I know is that I shouldn't be complaining, because this filthy little Pakistani spot slings some seriously delicious food. I'd eat here anytime.
author: Peter D.

description:
We actually came in here by accident. We were so hungry for Indian food and turned into the wrong restaurant. Pleasantly surprised that it was so delicious!!! The flavors were amazing! I had never tasted such a variety of flavors. I ordered the garlic naan and it was the best tasting naan I have ever had in my life! And the prices were so cheap! And it was open late! 

One of my main downsides was that it was a bit confusing. I was not sure how to order, pay, sit down, or take my order to go. Also they forgot to make one of the dishes that I ordered. The korma was also extremely greasy, but the chicken was fall off the bone good and tender.
author: Britney B.

description:
After fasting all day for an afternoon appointment to get some blood drawn, I desperately wanted some food that was fairly fast, cheap and filling. I'm not typically a fast food kind of girl, so I popped into Shalimar to see what I could get. 

There was a guy behind the counter who, focused on pressing some naan dough into place, barely acknowledged me, but oh well. I wasn't there to make new friends. 

I ordered the Lamb & spinach with a side of their freshly baked naan, which was the best part. The lamb & spinach was just ok. I managed to scarf it down even though I was surrounded by uncleared tables full of dirty dishes.

I was alive again! Still a little spacy, but alive! 

Now for the important part: As a lot of people do that are dining alone, I was looking at my iphone since I did not want to sit, staring into space. 

In the entire restaurant on this particular afternoon at about 3 pm, there were 5 people in the restaurant. Me, a guy in front of me, two guys behind my table, and the guy behind the counter. The guy in front of me finished at about the same time I did. 

I paid, left, headed out to tackle the next thing on my to-do list and realized I left my phone on the table! I rushed back and saw that my table had not yet been cleared, but my phone was gone. 

There were still the same remaining 3 guys in the restaurant. I asked the two at the table, "Did you see a phone on this table?" "No, ask that guy.", one of them replied, pointing to the guy behind the counter. 

I asked him. He looked right at me, wide-eyed and said "A phone? No, no phone!" 

I set my bag down and said, "Alright, I KNOW I left it right here, so either YOU have it, or one of YOU have it." It was clear I was not leaving until I got my phone back. 

The guy behind the counter says, "Oh, do you mean an iPhone? Well, yes, I found an iPhone on that table. Was that yours? Just one moment. " 

He knew it was mine. He goes to get it out of his bag. Within just a few minutes, he had scooped it up, turned it off and put it in his bag. Turning it off keeps the tracking from working so I would not be able to find it had I not returned immediately. 

What remains of the idealistic, small town girl in me would love to think that he had turned it off to conserve battery power, and that he stashed it away safely with the intent of tracking me down and getting it back to me, but well...YOU decide.
author: N B.

description:
We are constituted by God to be creatures for whom no meal should come easy.  We are made to till the soil, or to chase prey and toss rocks and spears in order to eat.  Sadly, our intellectual evolution has outpaced this simple reality, hence the problem we have with obesity and the many diet related diseases that now plague our entire species.  Luckily, there still exists a few restaurants that understand this basic deficit in the dining-out experience.  Kudos to Shalimar for recognizing that we were meant to struggle for our meals.  They very wisely placed themselves in one of the most difficult areas of San Francisco for parking.  Not only that, but they are also happily situated in an area that has not just-coincidentally been used by the producers of The Walking Dead for several of its more terrifying scenes.  As I ushered my wife and kids past and around the hundred or so human-flesh starved residents of this area, I actually did notice as we continued hiking upward toward the restaurant my hunger was growing at a measurable rate--apparently in response to the number of calories it required to simply get to the restaurant.  On the way there my 2 kids got to learn about law enforcement, deficiencies in our mental health care system, human anatomy, social injustice, the impact of the welfare state, and we were able to collect several samples of human scat for later research.  

But, once in the restaurant we were treated to the biggest surprise of all.  This was by far the BEST Indian food we've ever had.  I really don't know what else to say because any description I could give would pale compared to our tasting experience.  We chose a variety of items, and I wish I could say there were ups and downs, but everything was AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS.  I know that San Francisco is a beautiful town with some very deep wrinkles in some areas.  It is a testament to just how great this town is when even within the wrinkles there is beauty that outshines the best that any other town has to offer. 

Think I'm gonna risk my family's life to eat here again?  Oh Yeah!  Got my claw hammer ready, and we can't wait.
author: Anthony B.

description: It's the worst restaurant ever. I never want to eat here ever again. I had palak paneer and many other dishes. Nothing was good.
author: Jeevan K.

description:
It really pains me to give only 3 stars, but given how much the quality varies here each time I come here, I have no choice.

There have been times when I have walked away thinking this is the only restaurant in the Bay Area that comes close to some of the better Mughlai restaurants in India. And then there are experiences such as today. 

I came here craving tandoori food. Ordered seekh kebab and tandoori chicken. The seekh kebab was very dry and grossly over cooked. The tandoori chicken thankfully was ok. 

I also ordered the bhuna gosht. The curry was tasty, but sadly the meat pieces were not. Frankly speaking I had a bowl of fat and bones swimming in the gravy. Bottom line - I was highly disappointed.

So, why not a 1 star? Simply because I have had several great meals here as well. I still reminisce about the days when Shalimar first opened and I was ecstatic about the authentic Indian flavors. I seriously hope Shalimar gets back on track soon.
author: Ankur V.

description:
Hectic inside, really busy, good prices, good for take out.

Chicken tikka- really good!
Biryani- pretty good 
Tandoori- pretty good
Naan- okay 

Everything pretty spicy

Would come again for sure
author: Jon K.

description:
Great food, great service...needs a bit of a facelift in terms of decor and ambiance.

Chicken Tikka Masala excellent!

Free chai is a nice bonus.
author: Arman R.

description:
Shalimar is in the Civic Center/Tenderloin area, so don't expect fine dining. Its ghetto and thats what you should expect. I'm actually fine with it. Now, if Shalimar were in say, Hayes Valley, I may have a problem.

My current favorite spot for Indian food is Little Delhi. I like their butter chicken and chicken tikka masala. They also deliver so that's a plus plus plus in my book! However, I tried Shalimar because sooo many people say its the best spot for Indian food. 

When you come in, someone will direct you to a table. They'll bring you plates, napkins, and utensils, possibly a menu. Grab a pen, mark off what you want to eat, and then bring your marked up menu to the front counter and tell someone what you want to order. If water's what you want to drink, grab a pitcher and some cups :). Food will be brought to your table. I felt I should mention all of this because I was sooo confused as to how I should order my food, lol.

Chicken tikka masala- good. Flavoring is on point.. I don't know what authentic Indian food reallly tastes like since this is only the 3rd Indian joint I've tried.. but I imagine this chicken tikka masala to be MY version of what "authentic" would be. :D They could've given me more chicken though- I think there were only 10 little pieces and the rest was  just sauce.

Beef Jalfrezi- cut pieces of beef sauteed with onions, bell peppers, and tomatoes. GOOD, but greeasssy greasssy greeasssy! 

Garlic naan and onion kulcha- decent. I really enjoyed their rice though! MOIST!

Total for dinner? ~24bucks.

I still prefer Little Delhi... They deliver, their food isn't as greasy, I was able to pick my level of enjoyed spiciness, and they have BUTTER CHICKEN. :)
author: Chau T.

description:
My friend said this is the ONLY Indian restaurant in SF that his Indian friends can agree on. Even in broad daylight, its reallllly dodgy.

Dirty, reused stained menus, flies. In exchange, $2 lassis/naans/rice and $6-8 dishes.

Mango Lassi - Not too thick or sweet
Chicken Tandoori - Flavorful, juicy
Chicken Tikka Masala - Excellent, tangy, not too rich
Palak Paneer - Flavorful, not too rich, skimpy on the paneer
Bhuna Ghosht - One of the least gamey lambs I've had
Garlic Naan - Soooo shiny and soooooo gooood. You will stink for days but it will be worth it.

Definition of a hole in the wall? Dangerous? Kind of scary? Yes, Yes and Yes. Worth the risk for your health and safety? That's up to you.
author: Snuffles B.

description: One of the most amazing places to eat in San Francisco. I will miss this place the most. Awesome food reminds me of the dhaba setting in India. Try the malai kebob if you get a chance or the chicken tandoori leg.
author: Adi R.

description: The staff is very rude with customers, stupid and unhelpful. Their kitchen environment is very dirty. Surely one of the worst ever restaurants I have ever seen in US. NOT RECOMMENDED.
author: Muhammad A.

description:
I have been here numerous times and have not been disappointed. Don't be turned off by the lack of service or the sketchy location. The food is worth it!! Haven't tried all of the items on the menu, but what I have tried was fantastic. 

If you have never been here before, you should know a few things:

When you walk in, grab a menu by the cashier and find your own seat. Don't expect anyone to come and wait on you. That isn't going to happen.

You want water? Get it yourself. It's in the refrigerator at the bottom. 

When you decide what you want to eat, go up and order. Once again, don't wait on anyone. You'll be waiting a long time. 

As long as you know what you're doing, you'll have a great experience here. Don't forget to add the garlic naan!! Yes, you will walk out of this place smelling like curry for the next few hours, but it is well worth it!
author: Phillip G.

description: Taste of the food was perfect; Also the service was fast. Staff were friendly and they were trying their best to give customers fastest service. My order was goat stew (which wasn't as tender and fresh that I was expecting but still it was delicious) and my friend ordered chicken stew. The prices was inexpensive and the portions were good.
author: Shirin Z.

description: Best Indian food in SF hands down. It all started when I met an Indian man with a food truck in Sonoma. We were talking about how difficult it is to find authentic sag paneer and tikka masala. You see, it's not just a matter of dumping cream sauce into tomato sauce and calling it tikka masala! He told me I had to try Shalimar (especially because they served brains which was his absolute favorite!) Well, I couldn't get down with the brains but he was right- tasty, authentic Indian food right here in SF! If you don't want to schlep to the TL, try the Polk Street location. You won't be disappointed.
author: Micah S.

description: Skip Shalimar and go to Chutney. We go to Chutney often but wanted to try Shalimar as the two are often compared. Portions are smaller and more expensive at Shalimar and the food is just not as good. We ordered chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, rice, naan. The palak paneer was dry, chicken tikka not very flavorful, naan dry, rice not as good. Service was friendly.
author: Amber F.

description:
This is a hole-in-the-wall with AMAZING Pakistani food! We went to this restaurant several times while in San Fran, and twice just for the chai! If you want authentic Pakistani food and chai, this is the place to go. It's not pretty, it's in a questionable part of town, and it looks like a typical fast food joint, but there is a reason it is Zagat rated-it is delicious! 

We had the tandoori chicken, seekh kabab, and palak chicken with garlic naan which was absolutely delicious. 

We also had gulab jamun for dessert which was excellent, and several cups of their free chai! 

I'm hoping to go there again the next time we are in SF!
author: Sara A.

description: My go-to Indian food spot in sf. Chicken tika masala, rice and naan are all you really need, but everything on the menu is . Don't forget to get the complimentary tea.
author: Javin L.

description:
THE BEST INDIAN FOOD PLACE EVER! 
I admit they treated some other customers better but I don't mind because they were still very nice and the food is so BOMB. It's located in a sorta sketchy place and there's literally three other Indian restaurants within the intersection but this one is the place to go!
author: Jessica W.

description: Microwaved Biriyani, oiliest chicken tikka, dirty water and I could go on and on.. Sorry guys you need to up your game.. I can come over for the tea but then you should rebrand yourself to shalimar tea or something.
author: Nishank K.

description: The shalimar is a really good place to eat with friends.the is a little bit spicy,but it's delicious especially the chicken plates mmmmm.the service costumer is good also . I like the Indian food ,,,
author: Mohamed B.

description:
Staff are blissfully and pleasantly oblivious to what good service is but are polite and seem to remember about 95% of what you ordered.

Decor as others have mentioned, is Stasi-era Czech mixed with run-down once-was Taqueria external highlights.

Food is generally quite wonderful, but factors above can detract a little from the experience. 
Great people watching experience.
Still cash-only as of my last visit a few weeks ago.
author: Steve L.

description: Went here due to great reviews. Met a young white family at the entrance who also raved about it. But chaotic and unruly interior and so so food turned me off. Most of the patrons come for the non-veg entrees which may be good. The paneer masala, daal masala was ok.   Okra was bad. Aalloo Paratha terrible. Gulab Jamun cold. Plain yogurt excellent. Basmati rice was good. Would not come here again. Value peace and quiet at dinner time. Rough neighborhood. Ran into couple homeless folks hustling for money.
author: Caco F.

description:
Excellent food, very authentic and fresh. I asked for extra spicy, and indeed it was! Curry is excellent, even when I was in a suit on a rare 85 degree day. Yes, I did some sweating! 

Naan was the only thing that was not overly impressive, hence 4 stars versus 5.
author: Jonah K.

description:
Ok, so this location is a little sketchy on the outside...but the food is delicious! Have been to this one and to the one on Polk street. I really enjoy both!

Usual: Chicken tikka masala, side of basmati rice, and a side of naan. Does not disappoint!

I hear the garlic chicken is delicious as well!

Thanks to one of my very good Indian friends for bringing me here!
author: Coraline J.

description: This place is "slap yo mamma" good! Not much to look at & the service is what it is, but the food is an absolute dream. The flavors & spices are ever present. I ordered all vegetarian dishes; rice, bhindi, spinach & cheese & chickpeas,  Accompanied with the lightest naan known to (wo)man. The spinach had such a kick, but didn't lack for flavor. The chickpeas were the absolute best I've ever had on either coast. So soft, buttery and perfectly seasoned; I think I've died and gone to heaven. I will be back here every time I visit San Fran. These men "put their foot in it!" All phrases in quotes are complements of the highest level!!!
author: Scooter P.

description:
Shalimar is excellent- and I speak solely for the Shalimar in the Tenderloin. This place is authentic and their meat is done well. I particularly think their chops are the best.

Place is in the Tenderloin- don't go if you don't like restaurant that do not look their prime. This place is hole in the wall, cheap, service is not that great, etc. but worth it if you can handle that.
author: Tara S.

description:
I love this place!! Yummy. Both locations are excellent. Can't go wrong with the free
Chai tea. I always get everything to go. Wonder if they put crack or heroin in the 
Food. Can't beat the value..never had a bad meal. A word to the wise, you
will be singing Donald Byrds song slop jar blues the following day.
author: Michelle L.

description: Have been here a number of times while working in San Francisco. The food is solid and consistent. It is definitely a divey restaurant but so are many small places in SF. A great place to grab a tasty cost effective meal
author: Linda M.

description:
Heard a lot about this place. I have visited their other branch in Las Vegas quite a few times so was excited to give it a shot. Pricey but then again its SF, what isn't. Bad neighborhood, not that big of a problem. Its minutes on foot from union square. Took a long time before we were able to place order. Then waited another 45 minutes for the food to arrive. But that's usual at most restaurants which serve desi food. My only issue was the quality of the food being on the lower end of the spectrum.

We ordered a lot of dishes and pretty much all of them tasted just ok. Their naans are very thin and crunchy. Can't use them to eat a dish. Even though the restaurant say its Halal, I have my suspicions about it. The chicken didn't taste clean.
author: Jahanzeb B.

description:
This is my go to place for real Pakistani food. It's legit and it's a lot different from Indian Cuisine, so don't get ur shit twisted. Expect super spicy intense flavors. And don't get scared when u bite into a herb pod.. it's just part of the experiance . 

what to order
Chicken Kofta
lamb and spinach
Chicken tikki masala
Beef jelfrezi
Chicken Curry
Beef Kebab
Chicken Boti
Potato and garlic naan.
Chicken biryani (weekends only)


You love it here.. Trust me
author: Jackie N.

description:
This place is great. Delicious food, super cheap, and free chai!
We had the palak paneer, daal, naan (plain and potato). Everything was delicious and it came out quickly.
Only downside is the walk to/from the restaurant through the tender(est)loin.
author: Ariana L.

description: First timer... good food. Really good prices and incredibly fast. I really enjoyed the chicken masala.
author: Cliff S.

description:
Today we also tried the curried chicken and loved it.  The dal was not as good. And this was first time our order was messed up .  But  we all enjoyed it

Walked here from ACT where we saw The Orphan of Zhao......we liked it.  B D Wong was the simple physican..
author: Foodlover B.

description:
The girl that would *want* to come to Shalimar, that *would* come to Shalimar with me would be the girl that I would stick with. Would I find that girl that would want to dine out on a date here on a Friday night? Well two years ago I didn't have a hope so my date was Don B. Albeit a good chum, likely pretty huggable, and while his eye contact while splitting naan was strong, I found the girl. She was up to task to get in on this, and even considered a plate of brains (which we passed on). 

This is why I live here. This place is a ramshackle restaurant where it feels like the chaos of a foreign land's market. Somehow the guys that run this place have it under control, just enough. I can't take too many nights out where I'm waited on, and there are tablecloths. I can't take too many nights being surrounded by herringbone sport coats. Also, my wallet isn't as thick as most who dine out in this town. Most cheap Indian / Pakistani restaurants are a little vapid inside. Quiet, too tame. This is what I need. 

When dining here it takes a particular amount of initiative: get your own menus, point out your own table, move your own chairs, grab your own drinks, find the guy to order with at the counter, flag down your dishes, get your own silverware and napkins. Do all of this and you won't feel frustrated with the chaos. Peek over the counter to see the enormous tandoori, it's about as heartwarming as the fact that your date digs this place. 

Tip: eat this late at night, and don't pass out in your clothes or you'll wake up as a kebab.
author: Jon A.

description:
Terrible attitude. Really unprofessional about how they handle crowds. Food was decent.

The waiter "Noman" needs to be commended though. Attentive and respectful unlike the guy at the counter.

Would have been a 1* review otherwise.
author: Sanjay B.

description:
5 stars on the food!  Chicken tikka masala and chicken kofta we're fantastic!  Even the rice was solid with the herbs and spices that  they included.

BYOB I which is nice. I plan on coming back with a six pack next time!
author: David A.

description:
Best hole-in-wall Indian food in the Bay Area. I won't want to look this place up on the health inspection website though because I know I won't want to come here - so I just won't. I've eaten here more than 5 times. No food poisoning yet.

Besides, after lunch/dinner, you can pick up crack on the corner. What else could this place offer?
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: Omg! Needless to comment on the taste. Best indian food I've ever had! This place is barely decorated and pretty down to the earth!  But the price  and taste are way above the average which make up a lot to the cheap environment. I will definitely visit here again and very often.
author: Jeremy S.

description: This place needs to be closed down. The service is TERRIBLE! The employees are very disrespectful including the manager. The manager was very unprofessional towards customers, he had a bad attitude, he raised his voice a lot, he messed up our order, he kept slamming our cups and plates, he was huffing and puffing, cursing at us women, he tried to rip us off by charging us more, and didnt want to serve professionally. I felt very disrespected and felt like he was a fraud. AVOID! The food and service is terrible and this place or employees/manager need to be fired ASAP!
author: Katrina K.

description:
Shalimar is incredibly consistent. You can come up with your own version of "Spot it" to keep yourself entertained while you eat. Here are some of the things you should see during your visit:

1. A familiar face serving you. Yup, that "server" has been there for at least a decade. Not that one would expect Pakistani restaurants to lose their wait staff to the competition on account of the quality of their service.
2. Meat to bone ratio in the mutton dishes. Likely weighted in favor of the bones. In the restaurant's defense, they probably want you to keep sucking that bone marrow... 
3. An Indian family or two from the Punjab amongst the diners. You can spot them from their turbans. Preferring to eat at Shalimar than at an Indian restaurant (rarity)
4. Greasiness of the curries. I even overheard a few Chinese (possibly Taiwanese) customers find the food as greasy. They probably didn't appreciate that the restaurant holds diving competitions for the pools of oil on your plate.
5. Cleanliness. Noticeable, by its absence. The restaurant has probably not been cleaned since it opened.
6. Someone with beads of sweat on his forehead, declaring "the food is ridiculously good" or "they must put crack in it".
7. Confusion while paying. So, they've teamed up with Pakwan in deciding which restaurant causes more confusion. At Pakwan confusion revolves around when your order is ready. At Shalimar, it is when to pay (at Pakwan you pay upfront, at Shalimar you pay later)
8. An entire family of 6 eating heartily for less than $ 50. 

I am conflicted by Shalimar. Every now and then, I will have a good meal that will make me forget the pools of grease in some of the dishes and the seedy neighborhood. But, I still can't forgive them for tormenting the soul of my favorite Moghul Emperor, Shah Jahan, who built the greatest monument to love: The Taj Mahal. It is bad enough that the poor sob had to spend the last days of his life imprisoned by his son, but it's worse to have one of his beautiful, cherished gardens, Shalimar share the same name as this dirty restaurant. Trust me: you should never, ever use the toilet here. Unreal. Not in a good way!!
author: Atif I.

description:
1. Tikka masala: it has creamy and cheesy taste mixing with different spice.
2. Rice (not included in tikka massala): not typical white rice. It mixes with certain different ingredients. 
3. Mango lassi: the taste is amazing! It has smoothie-like texture with heavy mango smell.

Summary: the place looks a bit ghetto, but I would still give a five for price, service and quality of food. (I would also want to try lamb brain if I'm hungry enough)
author: Jane C.

description:
(See pic)

Review #1004.

Very solid 4 stars.

This is another very solid Indian and Pakistani place in the area.

The food here is fairly rich, quite spicy, more meaty and thick style. So if you are in the mood of heavier and very herb spiced, especially on a windy or chilly evening, Shalimar is definitely a great choice.

Nice and friendly service. Usually quite busy but I love it opens until 11:30pm and lunch time is less busy.
author: T L.

description:
I read so many good reviews about this place and it was a total disappointment. I am a big fan of chicken tikka masala and when I ordered and was ready to try it, the plate tasted like rotten and was super greasy. 
 NEVER COMING BACK!
author: Tania A.

description:
Not a place you would bring for your first date. This place is packed with people on the weekends, with tables and chairs kind of dirty. The place is kind of like a school cafeteria setting. 

The menu is gigantic, but not that many choices. Just grab a pen and start marking off what you would like. We had 5 people and our bill came out to be around $60. 

The prices and food are very decent. I especially like their Chai. When we walked out at 9pm, there were already another line of people trying to get in.
author: M C.

description: This restaurant has the best Indian food I ever had. However, the customer service is absolutely horrible. So if you do not mind slow and poor customer service, I strongly recommend this restaurant.
author: Fady B.

description: Bad and rude service , disorganized way to order and pay without a waiter but the food is delivered by a waiter to your table . They got my order wrong by getting a beef kebab instead of a chicken kebab and kept insisting they were right . Hygiene oft he place looks bad and you come out smelling like a bad curry . Will not go here again even those Hk the taste of their popular dishes alike Karahi chicken and biryani is good
author: Vin M.

description: Food was pretty tasty but the cracked out hooker, the sketchy walk to the back eating area and the abattoir of a bathroom makes this place a little too creepy for comfort.
author: Dina G.

description: Home away from home. My go to place when I crave spicy, greasy, Indian/Pakistani delicacies. I love their Chicken Shahi Korma, biryani and naan. The naan really reminds me of my home town where we still have those huge earthen oven and it is used for large parties and events. I have always ordered to go and it has always been a pleasure to warm up the food and just dig in. True Indian comfort food for me.
author: Deeba A.

description:
Shalimar is a great Indian/Pakistani restaurant.

Con:
Location (Tenderloin)
Atmosphere: Decent
Service: You can't wait to be seated, you MUST walk up to the cashier and order than find a seat yourself.  It's not necessarily a bad thing, but if you don't know it can be crazy and confusing.  

Pro:
Food!  The flavors are not tone-downed like some Indian restaurants for the Western palate.  They have Brain curry as well!  It tastes amazing, even though I know many of you will be turned off by it.  This place is as close to authentic it comes, if you can overlook some of the negative aspects including during the busy times the service can be bad.
author: Tin A.

description:
Shalimar was the first Indian Restuarant my husband and I visited after moving to the area and after reading the reviews we had pretty high expectations but were incredibly disappointed.

Apart from the fact it's in a really shady looking area the restaurant itself looks like it could do with a really good clean. It didn't look like it had a good dust and sanitize in a long long time.

We order our food and it arrived about 30 minutes later: Chicken Korma, Lamb Bhuna with Rice and Naan. 
The food was absolutely awful and I don't mean 'man that's pretty bad' I mean I wouldn't even call it food bad. Both dishes were very oily and runny (watered down). Almost like they had been made with curry paste from a jar mixed with water and oil. The Naan was also very dry.

The whole experience was just one huge disappointment. I simply cannot understand  how it can score 4/5 overall. Either it's purely based on price (it's cheap) or the city's population  hasn't actually had good Indian food because this is not good in any means of the word.

Since trying other local Indian restaurants in the area (Chutney across the road being one) and speaking to workmates of my husband we have discovered the better Indian restaurants are towards Sunnyvale and good curry hasn't (and probably never will) come from the City.
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
I wish I didn't gloss over another review that advised to go to the counter first and then take a seat... I was waiting for a good 5 minutes before I just decided to approach the counter LOL. On a street with at least 3 Indian restaurants (compared to LA where I'm from where you're lucky to find one within 5 minutes of each other in most areas), I just decided to pick the best rated one out of the bunch and went with it, and I don't regret my decision.

So, tapping into my adventurous side, I went with the Beef Jalfrezi, which I neither knew Indian restaurants serves beef, nor do I remember seeing Jalfrezi on menus in LA. It was very tasty, especially paired with the chutney (another thing you don't see in LA either) and generously sized naan.

The price was very good too; even just the main course and rice for one is easily $20 in LA for most establishments, but as I didn't eat much during the day, I got both the rice, naan, and 2 cans of soda (1 with food, 1 to bring back to the hotel) for only a tiny bit over $15.
author: Ed W.

description:
Really good Pakistani food. It's fresh, hot and just about the right amount of spice.

Make sure to order the grill items over the curries, you won't be disappointed. The naans is so fluffy and fresh--not chewy or too crispy.  The place is not fancy by any means, but don't judge a book by it's cover (or the inside...) but the food is good you'll soon forget where you're sitting.
author: Maliha Z.

description: Wasn't that impressed.. it was what you'd expect. Pretty stuffy in there but we got seated fast. It smelled weird. I liked the paneer masala and the nihari.
author: Sarah K.

description:
One of the best indian restaurants in the city. The food is authentic,fresh, quick and cheap. Not a fine dining option by any means, but great if you are looking for a quick fix of Indian food.

Highly recommend the garlic naan, chicken kadhai and tandoori leg.
author: Mayur D.

description: Good food and chai tea. Nan is hot and fluffy and the tikka masala is on point. All the standard indian dishes are up to par.
author: brandon f.

description:
My favorite Pakistani restaurant, hands down. I love it. Its filthy, and dingy, and always busy. In fact, if you ever walk around back to sit in the back dining room, you will truly see how filthy it is. But I haven't gotten sick yet, and I love the food.
I always order the nihari, the sikh kabob, the chicken tikka, and the mugus (brain). Its all so good.
author: Basil M.

description: Great food. Very reasonably priced. You don't get much in terms of "service" but the food is genuine Indian. Would recommend.
author: Nick P.

description:
This place is a total dive, but just close your eyes, ignore the complete lack of atmosphere and just breathe in and taste the awesome food!

We came here for lunch since I was craving Indian food.  It's in a slightly sketchy street block but felt safe (next to Dottie's) and the inside is dimly lit with some flies, but the food is fabulous!

We ordered a few different types of naan (you MUST get the garlic one... they layer fresh garlic in between the layers and top it with lots of butter -yum!), some of their tandoori meats which were wonderfully spicy and had one of their chick pea dishes.

One of the best lunches I've had at under $10 a person!

CASH ONLY.
author: Katie F.

description:
Good indian food and fare. Their mango lassi is my absolutely favorite! When our group ordered, they mainly ordered meat kababs which I hear are out of the world.

Good, cheap indian food. I would absolutely go back here again.
author: Akshaya M.

description: filled with spices! I enjoyed the garlic  naan and lamb curry
author: Thanh B.

description: Amazing Indian food and cheap too. I  definitely recommend my all friends whoever travel San Francisco.
author: Sunny I.

description: Been here a handful of times and I would say I've had better food here.  We ordered chicken tandoori, chicken tikka masala and naan.  The chicken tikka masala was not as flavorful as I've had before, tandoori chicken lacked salt and their naan was burnt.  Do not expect the staff to smile, not sure why but they're not very friendly.  If around SF I might give them another chance.
author: rose r.

description:
It was a cold and windy night. Not a creature was stirring (except some striped shirts and short skirts heading to Infusion). My group was starved and craving a gut-bomb of a meal... 

Following our noses, we quickly scampered through the TL and came upon Nirvana in the form of this cramped, smoky-haze-enveloped restaurant. Everything is deliciously fattening, but well worth the marathon you'll undoubtedly need to run the following day. 

You know it's REAL Indian food when the smell seeps through 3 layers of clothes and your fingers smell like garlic for a couple days. Yes, I would like to smell your fingers.
author: Calvin W.

description:
So, I tried the brain masala. Do I get extra points for bravery? I didn't like it much. It reminded me of liver and was sort of pasty. 

Luckily, there were sides of naan and rice to keep me entertained while others in my party had more common dishes like the paneer masala and the chicken curry. All these others I tried were spicy and melt in your mouth good. I also liked the free chai (it's hot and self-serve).

Parking is horrible. You'll probably find a place halfway up an Everest-steep hill. Have your driver drop you off next time, or opt for something other than your own car.

Do I regret it? Nah, but I think the order taker should have glared at me skeptically and said "No, little girl. Try the chicken tikka masala." But I can't blame him for my own foolishness. I'll order something with chicken next time.
author: Diane Y.

description:
When your Indian friend tells you he's taking you to the best place in town and then he orders for you, you just shut up and eat! I think the only time we piped up was to order more naan! 

Seriously, this was some of the best Indian food I have had. I wanted to order the chicken tikka masala just as a bench mark to other places we went but he also had a lamb dish and several veggie dishes- one being spinach and the other eggplant. Everything we had was wonderful and the naan was huge and delicious!

Some would argue the atmosphere is bland and there isn't much to this place. I would argue that you can't beat the atmosphere with the intense smell from the grills and the Indian guys running all over the place attending to different tables. The people- both employees and customers- really had to the feel here- lots of energy and enthusiasm!

Did I mention it's BYOB?
author: Christopher B.

description: I have no idea how this place works, but damn it was good, and decently priced. Extremely busy, but we got there during a break and were seated very fast. We had the tikka Marcela, biryani and a beef dish. The naan was very huge, but good.....Can't wait to go there again.
author: Troy H.

description:
I'm trying not to get Yelps in my eyes, and give this place 3 stars.  It's the symptom of "this place is rated so highly, I must be missing something..."

I had to shower when I got home, and frebreze my clothes.  It was a smoke factory that permeated all my pores and clothes.  The good news is that it seemed authentic to being in a third world country. Dirty, cheap, good.  It was a half hour wait I looked around for the health code score, but it wasn't posted; never a good sign. Definitely cheap.  Maybe $6/dish?  But they were out of everything we wanted to order.  Good?  Ok, maybe.   Really greasy.  Everything was pretty standard issue.  Maybe the meat dishes are fantastic, but none of the vegetarian stuff was extraordinary.  

Little Deli's right around the corner and super dynamite.  Check that place out and smell less.
author: Monica R.

description:
AMBIANCE: Read about this place on yelp and the girls and I thought we'd try it out. Yes it's literally a dirty looking hole in the wall with no decor, and an open kitchen. I used the restroom and walked by and saw a bunch of people just milling around a dirty looking kitchen. Needless to say there's no restaurant grade in the window, but if I had to guess I'd say...C or D. 

FOOD:  I've only eaten at a few Indian places in my own hood, and at a few functions, and I can tell you it's the best Indian food I've had. My favorite was the Chicken Tikka Masala and the garlic naan. The meatballs weren't bad either. The real winner was the MANGO LASSI! I've only had one other like it, and my aunt makes it using real mangos and carnation milk. It literally tastes like a fresh, sweet, ripe mango in the form of a shake. I couldn't stop drinking it!  I'm happy to say Shalimar's mango drink did not give me an upset stomach the next day. In fact, I think it even helped with the spicy food and settled my stomach a bit. 

    There's a lot of Indian food in SF, but I'd start here and work your way around town. 

TIP: Cash only, bring your own drinks if you can, otherwise you're stuck with canned soda, bottled water, and maybe some beers (can't recall if I saw alcohol in the fridge). 

SECURI-TAY: There's shady bums everywhere that like to converse about random stuff with you but they're also eyeing your pockets and purses. I was running down the street to get a few bottled waters from the car and this lady asked me for change. I politely told her I didn't have any and she said, "Nice Boobs!" I was wearing a hooded sweatshirt, but I'm not gonna lie I got a quick laugh and like 1.5 ego point boost. After we ate we ran into a few more bums and one was heckling us but said,"My you ladies are looking HEALTHY! Mmm, mmm, mmm, just a fine bunch and look at that ass!" Again, I laughed while speed walking to the car. I've roamed the streets of L.A all times of the day and night and can honestly say the bums in S.F are much more forward, scarier, and funnier.
author: Tamara T.

description:
Stopped by here one night with Coworkers after a company sponsored happy hour! We ordered family style and just shared everything. I don't remember everything we ordered but I contributed chicken tikka masala, jasmine rice, and samosas. 

The chicken was most excellent, though the portion size was a little small. The samosas were good, but not the best I have had, I felt like they could have been a little spicier. We also ordered several different types of naan, and they were all very good. 

The place was pretty busy so service was kind of slow, but it was very reasonably priced.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
It's official - Indian and Pakistani restaurants in the city cater to those whose taste buds have NO idea how Indian/Pakistani food ought to taste. No, Indian/Pakistani food is not supposed to be bland & Chicken tikka masala is NOT Indian/Pakistani. 

So, if you are giving Shalimar or Chutney or any other establishment 4+ stars based on Chicken Tikka Masala, you are not rating it fairly. (And I honestly don't know why restaurants even serve the pseudo Tomato basil bisque-y gravy with rubbery chicken in the first place.)

That said, here's my order of preference if I had to order food from the big 3 desi retstaurants in the city -  Shalimar, Chutney,  Naan & Curry.
We ordered our standard Shalimar order (back from our Shalimar Fridays in Dublin)
- Seekh kebabs - giant in comparison & grilled to perfection. Could use more salt, but that's a personal preference.
- Chicken Kofta Curry - the gravy looked anemic. It lacked the spice that should be associated with it.
- Bhindi - This shit was the bomb. The only thing that tasted similar to the Shalimar in Dublin. Reminded me of home :(
- Naan - The naan here is actually really good. Compared to a lot of other places, the naan was soft and fluffy.
Yeah the gravies ere oily, but you know, if you order take out, you can take that oil slick right off. If you are eating at the restaurant though, just make sure you run a few miles to unclog your arteries.
Prices were also fairly the same, across all their establishments. The kitchen was a lot cleaner than Chutney. 
That's all, folks!

PS: Remember , Chicken Tikka Masala is NOT from India or Pakistan.

PPS: they do accept credit cards.
author: Ranjani S.

description: Love this place.  Simple,  inexpensive, yummy, BYOB. I love the plain atmosphere,  like a blank canvas for your own mood.  I come here every few months.  All dishes are good, but you need a partner to share to large dishes.  Cash only.
author: Neal W.

description: The service was slow and the food was not even cook all the way!!
author: Waqas A.

description: Shalimar's food is really good.   This location is not as nice as the polk st location.
author: Michael E.

description: I tried Tandoori chicken and it was tender and well marinated. Biryani was average. The place is nice if you want to enjoy Indian/Pakistani delicacies.
author: Moazzam K.

description:
Excellent Desi Cuisine, great prices but don't come for the diggs.

Not exactly here for the:
atmosphere
friendly service

...but I am here for the:
Greasy curries
fluffy naan
fresh and hot chai

Tasty meal, great deal, Dehli feel.

RECOMMEND!
author: Rimi K.

description:
I live near Little India in Artesia (SoCal), but this was my first time eating Indian food in SF. After checking in our crappy hotel across the street, this place was a good first meal upon arrival!

Palak Paneer - WOW!  You can actually see the spinach! Usually palak is so mushy like baby food, but this was great quality. The paneer had a strong firm texture and was also full flavored.
Garlic Naan - Shiny from the butter and a generous portion of garlic pieces.
Chicken Tikka Masala - I inhaled this, but I'm sure it was good! ;)

What else can I say that hasn't been reviewed? Enjoy!
author: ReBecki P.

description:
We have been going here for years.  This place is hands down the best Indian food we ever tried. We have eaten at several Indian places between SF and San Jose and everything between, and this place hits it out of the park every time.  

The food is always consistent with flavor and portions, and freshness. I have tried everything on the menu at some point and have never had a complaint.

My all time favorite is the chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, Saag, chicken kabob, and rice. Now this review is making me hungry. So if you're in town and in the area, stop in for a bite, you won't be disappointed.

Parking can be a problem, but there are a few parking garages bear by. Don't expect a fancy setting inside the place, it's a jeans and t shirt joint, and it's always hoppin inside so there may be a wait for a table.
author: Zack K.

description:
The food is consistently good here. If you come here on weeknights before 8, you can avoid the wait. 

Chicken Jalfrezi is my favorite dish - I love the aroma of the spices and cloves. Naan is different here. It's more dense and not smothered with a lot of butter like many other Indian restaurants. 

Parking in this area can be scary. Just know the blocks where you can or can't park.
author: Saran R.

description:
If you're looking for great service, wonderful decor, clean bathrooms etc. This is absolutely not your place!!! Now if you're going only for the food guess what this is your winner.. I ordered the Nihari and Chicken Tikka Masala and they food was fantastic! I'm a nice guy and pretty much talk to everyone and like to strike up conversation which didn't work to well with these people. 

I'm simply trying to talk to my waiter like any normal person would and he looks at me like I have a giant lizard on my face or something. Dude haven't you ever tried being NICE to people it may help the business even more! 

Bathrooms dirty as hell, cockroaches yeah for sure I think one of the cooks was a cockroach. but again the food and Naan was some of the best desi food I ever had. Hole in the wall desi food place right here...
author: Steve R.

description: Cheap and tasty indian food. hole in the wall, home comfort food!
author: Doreen N.

description:
Major fail. Numero dos.

Apparently people either love or hate Shalimar...and after the stomach troubles I endured this past week, I'm clearly part of the latter group.

Friends ensured me this Jones Street location was the real deal and my previous lackluster experience at the Polk Street location was nothing to worry about. Clearly that wasn't the case.

Same menu, same dingy serving dishes, same lack of customer service, same dishes SOAKED in oil, and probably WORSE ventilation. My clothes reeked of masala and tandoori scents in the 30-45 mins I spent inside this place.

Needless to say, 2 experiences and 2 of the locations were not enough to sell me on this place.

P.S. C$SH only policy.

P.P.S. Not ideal for larger groups; the seating area is pretty limited.
author: Mansi A.

description:
A slice of heaven for any foodie.
What I love about this place? 
-every damn dish is awesome
-consistent in taste & quality
-no frill, just plain good food which tastes like a home cooked meal

my abso favs - bihari kabab, chicken kofta, sag-aloo-methi rouded off with chai & kheer.

A visit to the city w/o Shalimar pilgrimage? there better be a good reason for that.
author: Shaheen P.

description: Let's just say, if they serve Pakistani food in heaven, it's probably from Shalimar. The wait was long, but boy was it worth it. It's a complete hole in the wall, but they make damn good Pakistani food. The palaak paneer was amazing, the chicken tikkah masala was the best I've tasted anywhere (including any family members - sorry y'all), the malai kabobs were succulent. Everything was good. Very fair prices also. I've eaten Pakistani food in Chicago, Atlanta, DC, and NY and this is by far the best I've had.
author: Izzat A.

description: Keep in mind that this is a hole in the wall with Indian people coming, meaning it's authentic Indian and Pakistani food. I tried it with a friend before and he told me to order these things so we get the best experience. So, I decided to bring my honey here. We ordered brain marsala, chicken marsala, and naan. All of the food was very tasty and also spicy too. We both love the food.
author: Allan W.

description:
This place is so dirty, but that extra filth adds to the flavor. Not a date place but a good place to break your date in. This place is always busy. No reservations. 

Food: Curries and tandoories
Quantity: Plenty to share
Price: One dollar sign
Noise: Loud
Attire: Your clothes will smell like your food after. Just sayin'
Service: Little to no service. Have to tackle one of them down or just go to the front and order from the sticky newspaper menu. 
Parking: Meter...in the TL
Recommendations: Not so great place for vegetarian dishes. Tried palak paneer in 3 different occasions and found it too salty each time.  Definitely order meat dishes in curry sauces and the tandoori meats.
Freebies: Free Chai!!! 

Overall: 3.5-4.0
author: Annie T.

description: Very good food, but the restaurant and bathroom were very dirty.  Needs a good cleaning.
author: Doug B.

description: My first time here, it was confusing at the beginning because I didn't know how the restaurant works. Apparently you order in the counter but you don't pay rightaway. You pay after you finish eating your meal. I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala with naan and it was delicious, especially the naan. Price is cheap too! I paid around $11 including tax and tips.
author: Melinnie A.

description: This is in a really convenient location for me, so I have gotten takeout from here 3 times. I find I tend to gravitate toward Indian when I am alone and don't feel like cooking food. Anyway, the prices are reasonable and the portions are standard. An order of a dish and naan can feed me for 1.5 meals. I have tried their Chicken Tikka and Daal, along with their rice and naan. The Naan, like other reviewers have said, is pretty good, but I think that's about it. The Chicken Tikka Masala is so so oily, that whenever I get it for takeout there is an obvious layer of grease sitting on top of the actual sauce, it looks and tastes very unappealing. At first I thought that maybe it was a one time thing, but when I tried again for the second time, it was the same. The Daal is alright, though nothing special. I think I'm gonna have to start walking a but farther to try some other Indian restaurants.
author: Emily H.

description:
Move over Naan n Curry, Shalimar is here.

Shalimar is a great SF Indian eatery- casual, cheap, and oh so satisfying. Sure, be weary about the neighborhood. The location is not the best. But, who cares! Clutch onto your purse a little tighter and don't talk to strangers.

Trust me. Its worth it!

The food is awesome. We ordered the following:

*Chicken Tikka Misala
*Tandoori Chicken BBQ w/sauce on side- yum!
*Naan- warm, tender, & served piping hot
*Punjabi Basmati Rice- topped w/cilantro & savory spices

To end your meal, have their special house tea. It's completely tasty, warm, and not to mention addicting!

Shalimar is one of my favorite local hole-in-the wall eateries! If you haven't tried it yet, what are ya waiting for?
author: Joy A.

description:
People:

I don't understand the hype and positive reviews this place gets?

As warned by several others, Shalimar is a run-down, dirty, hole-in-the-wall joint in a bad neighborhood with horrendous parking.......and the non-existent ventilation there means you will fight to simply breathe, let alone avoid the permeating odors.  

I had the Goat Karahi for $10 and Chicken Tikka Masala for $8, neither of which was served with naan or rice or salad included (unlike many other Indian/Pakistani restaurants).  Since the portions were not large, I don't think the prices are a great deal. 

As to the quality of the fare, if it were excellent, then I could forgive the rest of Shalimar's many deficiencies.

Unfortunately, it was not memorable and only average at best.  The chicken dish was particularly uninspiring, with its bland curry and dried-out white breast meat.

Having traveled extensively through the Sub-Continent, I've experienced great South Asian cuisine.

Trust me.......this is NOT the place.

P.S. --  You can do much better at Pakwan (SF--16th St. location) with its fantastic Lamb Biryani. Or if in the East Bay, check out Viceroy Indian Cuisine in Berkeley, which has an exceptional all-inclusive lunch/dinner buffet for less than $10, starring a superb Chicken Tikka Masala dish.

.
author: Topeka C.

description: Shalimar doesn't pretend to be anything other than the dive'y authentic and great Indian food it delivers.   It's in tenderloin so that should give you some sense of what you should expect.  But, the food is authentic, tastes great and unpretentious.
author: Hema P.

description: Ordered chicken tikki masala. It had very little flavor. Taste like nothing. I asked for spicy but they only do it one way- without spice. The naan was crispy and not how I'd like it. Only redeeming quality was the cheap price
author: Silver T.

description:
I love this place and wouldn't be surprised if they put crack in the food because I'm absolutely addicted.

Definitely my favorite Indian joint in SF (I recommend taking out vs. eating in) and possibly the best Indian food I've ever had

Recommendations & tips:
- Chicken tikka masala (a little on the greasier side, but so tasty with a bit of a kick)
- Channa masala (a bit spicy)
- Free chai in the water cooler
author: Di W.

description:
This place is small and dirty, so what? 
Hands down they have the BEST, and most authentic Indian food you can find in San Francisco.
This is definitely a no-bullshit place. Their curries and Naan's are spectacular. 
The lamb curry and chickpea curry are perfect to pair with the naan and their Indian rice is also one of my favorites.
You can fill your cup with Indian milk tea as many times as you wish. 
I've been eating here with my family for so many years, and we've found that this place tastes the best in spices, flavors, and authenticity. 
I will be coming again and again to this place.
Highly recommend!
author: Veronica L.

description:
The food was delicious, no doubt about it.   The service was not super friendly, but I would probably do a take out order again with family.  With the wait generally imposed on customers I don't think I would sit down to eat here.  

Chaotic, loud, smokey aired venue.  The only thing that brings this review down is the atmosphere of the restaurant.   The food is stellar.

FABULOUS tikka lahori (per Jason B.'s review) and garlic naan!  So good!
author: Ali B.

description:
Always good. Always.

This is a meat eaters restaurant. Yes, they have veggie dishes which are pretty good, but the real deal here is the tandoori chicken and kebabs. The chicken tikka masala is the best I have had outside of India. The garlic nan is fearlessly real.

The service is not top-notch, but the staff is friendly and warm.

Shalimar really is the best, and they have been for years.
author: El Z.

description: Yum! Feeling a craving for Indian food, we decided to search on Yelp. Shalimar came up as highly rated, only one dollar sign, plenty of reviews. So we decided to check it out! And it didn't disappoint! We got takeout: chicken tikka masala, the korma, garlic naan, regular naan, and the potato-filled naan. Everything tasted delicious. Simple no frills place, plenty of seating inside, unassuming but totally delivers. I'd definitely come back.
author: Mary N.

description: 2.5 really. Not full of grease like others experienced but also not much flavor. As a quick Indian fix it is adequate but not for much more. I just had a tikka masala and naan. The food came out within 90 seconds, I kid you not. The curry was fine. The naan was too heavy and dry. It had clearly been sitting around for a while. Both were hot, though so reheating isn't a problem here.  I should say that I am really familiar with Indian food. Here is the thing:  They don't care. They don't care about the food, the environment, or the interaction. I'm ok with that as I read up, and went in with my eyes open. Having said that, I was still surprised by what a dump the place is.
