Oh, and I would go back if I was in need of an Indian fix and I happened to be in the neighborhood. I wouldn't go out of my way to go there, though.
author: Sarah L.

description: So I'd never had Pakistani food before and really like to try new things. So I walk up to Shalimar and order the Nihari and Naan. I'm telling you the truth when I say this is one of the best meals I've had in a long damn time. The curry sauce was so flavorful. The spices popped. The ginger was fresh as could be. The naan (which I've had before) was perfect. It was the best curry I've ever had, and it's not close. Take the walk. The neighborhood isn't the best, but you'll be rewarded. I can't wait to go back.
author: Jason N.

description:
- Locale destination -
It's in kinda ghetto area, though it's very close to Macy's. This area stinks and you see tons of homeless people. Nothing fancy decor. Obviously recycled paper menus. 

- Gluttony expedition -
Mango lassi: It's more yogurt than the ones I've ever had. Not bad.

Lamb boti: These lamb are well seasoned and soooooo good ;) I'm a lamb lover and love this ;) It's great with bites of onion ;)

Hakeem with Chicken: You don't see chunk of chicken but taste it. Lentil and berley were seasoned so well. Good curry ;) 

Garlic naan: You don't see any garlic on the outside - DON'T BE FOOLED. They put tons of fresh garlic INSIDE. I mean TONS. Good ;)

Seekh kabab mughlai: Lamb kabab. Very tasty and great seasonings. Even if you don't like the lamb nor the smell that lamb has, you'll like this. Great! Only one kabab, ok?

- Conqueror's deduction -
Great foods and price. It's a hidden gem in GHETTO ;p
author: Akiko I.

description:
Shalimar is as good as it gets. They serve really, really delicious vegetables, curries with healthy portions of meat, and great bayrani rice.  My group of friends shared four entrees, and we were all pleasantly plump by the end of the night.  Also, feel free to enjoy their complimentary tea at the drink station.  After tax and tip, the bill came out to $11 per person, which is unheard of in this fair city.  
Do not be turned away by the less-than-stellar environs, this place is worth the jaunt to Tenderloin.  Enjoy!
author: Andrew J.

description: Just got into San Fran and wanting a place to eat quickly. Found this place on yelp and decided to try it out. We walked past about 3 other Indian restaurants on our way that maybe had one or two people in them and then got here and the line was out the door! Still was seated quickly and out food was served moments after ordering. Plate size was a little small but the food was so flavorful and delicious. Chicken tikka Masala was the best! Dip some naan into the sauce and it's to die for! Recommended if you are looking for something quick, not fancy, but very tasty!
author: Megan E.

description:
This place is outrageous!  It is filthy - it has not been cleaned since they opened!  Careful on your way to the register where you will order as the floor is both slick and sticky.  And, when you leave you'll need a shower as you will smell like curry.  

Yet, it might be the best indian/pakistani food I have ever had!  Anything you try will be wonderful, but for $3 the 1000 degree tandoori made chicken is my favorite, spiced and flavored right thru!   

Don't forget to give a little to the needy on the way out!
author: Dax F.

description:
Total ClusterF*** inside this restaurant.  Everything from seating, to ordering, to paying, to even getting water, its just a big mess.  But somehow the staff here crank our to-go orders as well as dine-in orders.  We were seated right in the middle of the restaurant which gave us a constant chilly breeze from the open door and all the foot traffic from the people trying to place their orders, go to the restroom, get water and find their seats... not the best place to be located.  Plus this place is louder than an NBA playoff game.  Its very interesting to see all the action that is going on...

On to our meal...we didn't get our food till about 30 mins later than 3 other tables that were seated at the same time as us, which is not cool.  The one waiter just kept telling us "1 more minute."  

We ordered:

Chicken Tikki Masala - more tomato based, very tasty, enough chicken for 3 people

Palak Paneer - plenty of spinach, cheese was good but not cottage cheese crumbly

Tandoori Chicken - pretty good tandoori with onions

Basmati rice - seasoned well, but softer than most basmati rice

Garlic Naan bread - best garlic naan I've ever had, loads of garlic baked right in, the naan came out hot and bothered.

Tips: Be ready to order and order at the counter, and its CASH ONLY fyi.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place is the best. The food comes out a little different every time, sometimes has too much oil, is in the sleazy center if the loin, but it's the best Indian food for your $ in sf.  I felt vindicated when my buddy's mom (from India) told me it's her favorite in the bay area. 

Mutter panner is fantastic but they always seem to sell out. Saag ghosht also excellent. There are half a dozen Indian & Pakistani places in the neighborhood. Whenever I try one of the others I regret it. Long live shalimar
author: J D.

description:
Still our favorite! Went all Atkins low-carb high protein and found that I could eat a delicious meal and let not a grain of rice pass my lips. The LCHF among you should stick to the tandoori section of the menu, meat on sticks never lies!
Mt daughter was over the moon about the Tikka Masala and my wife again LOVED the chicken ginger. We stop here every time we're in town.
author: Richard C.

description: The food is amazing. The service not so much. I also don't like the fact that they touch the food with their bare hands. Please wear gloves.
author: Victoria E.

description: This place used to be legit, now it's not only not that cheap anymore, but the food lacks quality, has more bones than meat, and the rice would taste better from rice-r-roni. Ordered the chicken biryani and lamb curry with garlic naan. Meh.
author: Nancy W.

description: Went there around 7 pm. Place was small and crowded. Ordered naan, chicken haleem, mutton biriyani. Very few mutton pieces in the biriyani. I wouldn't say the food was great though. It tasted ok. Good place to grab a quick snack if you don't mind the average cleanliness.
author: Martin P.

description: Authentic Indian food! Not the cleanest looking place but the food is excellent and authentic! We had naan which was hot out of the oven and super yummy, crusty on the outside chewy on the inside. We had the chicken tandoori, which was flavourful and cooked just right, the beef curry was excellent...a must have, the Basmati rice is fragrant with carrots and I believe saffron infused as well, need this to soak up all the sauces. The chicken tiki masala, also a good basic curry, the lamb was a bit overcooked and dry, so pass on this one, but the mixed vegetables were good, but if you don't like your veggies soft, then pass on this as well, otherwise all the dishes are flavourful and not spicy at all. Good food for the value, no thrills, may be a turn off for some, but was also Zagat rated for 2011, so it must be worth a visit!
author: Shirley C.

description: My boyfriend and I absolutely love this place!! We take all of our guests from out of town here and they love it too! The best indian/paki food around! The beef nihari is our favorite and the naan is always soft and piping hot. Oh and the milk chai is super yummy and free!!
author: Taylor L.

description:
Yes, I do still love their naan, but when did everything else become such a grease-fest?  The chicken tikka masala and chicken jalfrezi had more more puddles of oil than curry.  So unappetizing.

Stick with the garlic naan and tandoori items.  Or better yet, skip Shalimar and try Little Delhli instead.
author: Joanne G.

description: Fresh and flavorful curries with nicely marinated kabobs. Goat curry and chicken kabobs were good. It is a hole in the wall kind of place. Service was fairly friendly and cleanliness was just ok. Overall worth stopping by for a bite if you are in the area. On a side note, Sabri Nehari in Chicago still remains my all time favorite.
author: Foodie K.

description:
The place is definitely a bit sketchy (both from the outside and the inside) but the food is absolutely delicious! 

We entered the restaurant, and there was a line, so me and a friend patiently waited while the people in front of us ordered. But even after we got to the front of the line, the person at the front ignored us for about five minutes before he finally asked us what we wanted. 

Once we put the order in though, the food came out fairly fast. We ordered the okra, aloo spinach, and chicken karahi - all of which were good but were dripping in oil. We also ordered the garlic naan and damn, that was delicious.

One tip - make sure you have cash for this place just in case their credit card machine is down.
author: Niharika R.

description:
Great little spot where they serve great, cheap and authentic Indian and Pakistani dishes.
I had the Lamp Spinach (wasn't called that on the menu), a side of Basmati rice and a mango lassi, which I'll warmly recommend. Big portion that was enough to feed me (a fairly big guy) for the night.

Not an exclusive place, but a really good place for everyday food with really high value for money.
author: Mads S.

description:
if you're trying to find a place that ACTUALLY serves AUTHENTIC indian/pakistani food, YOU HAVE FOUND THE RIGHT PLACE. Shalimar is by far MY FAVORITE Indian/Pakistani restaurant in California. Yes, I said it- IN THE WHOLE STATE OF CALIFORNIA. I have searched and searched for Indian/Pakistani food that would come close to comparing to my mother's home cooking, and this is the one place that has come pretty damn close.

Don't expect anything fancy or ritzy, and expect leaving the establishment smelling of smoke/curry. It's so worth it. I usually order the CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA, CHICKEN KOFTA (if you're into meatballs), OR, MY ABSOLUTE FAAAVORITE-- THE GOAT KARAHI. The Chicken Tikka Masala is delicious, and definitely a no-fail kind of dish for someone who isn't willing to take the risk of trying something new or unfamiliar. Not to say that it isn't completely worth the 8 dollars you'll spend. I usually order it with rice and naan (I love to dip my naan in the extra masala ;D). The Chicken Kofta is really good if you love meatballs and can tolerate spicyness. I usually order rice with that one. 

And then, there's the GOAT KARAHI. The goat meat is deliciously marinated and comes with little bones that you can suck deeeelicious bone marrow out of! If you've never had goat before, don't be scared! It's like lamb but a little tougher with random little bones to suck on. I usually order the Goat Karahi with rice. Sooooo amazing.

Did I mention that they have free chai? Dude. YES.

GO TO SHALIMAR.
author: Sarah A.

description:
verly clean for a 7-eleven. all the employees here are really nice.

the store is always well stalked and they always have what i'm looking for. 

the parking lot is a little small cause its shared with other businesses as well but all in all a great place to come to for a refreshment
author: Shawn S.

description: Avergae food.. Paneer masala was eatable with extra oil but tasted good... Worst part is the people are too rude... No sense of hospitality... We were waiting for 20-25 mins and no one even bothered to acknowledge...Will never visit ever again... Goodbye for ever...
author: Ekta B.

description:
This review is going to be on the food. If you are looking for 5 star service, this is not going to be the place for you. If you want some of the best stews and kabobs in the city, you should head to Shalimar. I've been coming here for over a decade and have only been disappointed a few times. The things that have disappointed me were either them running out of a specialty dish they were selling that day or a lack of a table because this place is PACKED most of the time.

Their prices are great, the food amazing, and the portions generous. All in all, this is a hole-in-the-wall that I will fare as long as they keep up their golden recipe of deliciousness.

Side note: Not much seating inside so if planning a larger group meal, maybe call ahead? Not sure how that'll work though.
author: Ashkan A.

description:
CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA and NAAN!!!! :D

I met Don B, the Portland CM, at the PLEY event and he told me whenever he's in town he'd make it a point to eat here!!

So this place has been on my bookmark since January! It's delish here!!! I got the chicken tikka masala!!! I wished we ate it here (and didn't get it to go). Super good and cheap food! Will definitely be back for more! :D

Sorry, there are no pics of my food. I actually ate it all before I realized I hadn't taken a pic yet. oops =\ haha
author: CeCe C.

description: Wtf? The people who are giving 5 stars to this place are mostly not from the Indian subcontinent and I believe  they definitely don't  know what authentic Indian food should taste like. Unhygienic, filthy, servers who don't  bother that you are even there, aweful look and taste of dishes. Okay you want to serve food that costs cheap to customers but at the  expense of cheap  quality. I went there only because of the reviews here which praised the place like anything. First when I  looked at the place from outside, it didn't appeal to me much. On entering I saw cutlery and paper towels lieing on the floor. Nobody to help us find a table. A huge queue waiting for long for their orders to be served at the counter. A huge ruckus made for a poor homeless lady who just wanted to get some food! You don't get such terrible experience or quality even at road side street vendors in India. I didn't expect this in a developed country like this!
author: Surbhi M.

description: My boyfriend struck gold when he researched Indian restaurants in San Francisco for our recent getaway to NorCal!!  Shalimar is LITERALLY a hole in the wall in a not so great part of town--some of the best places are always here!  I would've given them a 5-star if I hadn't had to re-wipe and clean off my own table.  The food was ridiculous!!!!! So good and very nicely priced! Again, the two of us needed a way bigger table for the plethora of goodies we ordered.   Get the Chicken Tikka Masala! So yummy with the naan!
author: Cuc L.

description:
When I walked in I had no idea what the shit was going on in this restaurant. Do I sit down? Who do I order from? There are a bunch of dudes walking around who seem to work here but nobody is helping me out. I flagged a guy down and told him I wanted to order which seemed to moderately annoy him but he scribbled down my order and asked where I was going to be sitting. I made a general hand gesture toward the only area where you can sit and he said ok.

I had little confidence that what I'd just ordered would get to me but I sat down. I then happened to run into some friends of mine so I joined their table which I thought would further decrease my chances of being located. My friends were Indian and they assured me that everything would be fine.

They were right. My food came to me exactly as ordered and it was amazingly good. I had the murghi korma shahi and garlic naan and it was fantastic.

I highly recommend this place and will be back very soon!
author: James R.

description: There are Indian/Pakistani restaurants and then there's Shalimar. This place doesn't LOOK like somewhere you'd want to eat (honestly I never do anyway... only takeout). But its as good as it gets for cheap, no frills, but not Americanized, sub-continent food. Yes there's a considerable amount of butter/ghee in it (but that's the case even at the high end places where everything is ladled with butter or cream), yes the Biryani can use some help, yes the naan is poor quality (at least the times I tried it), but the chicken and lamb curries are where it's at. Take out, make your own rice or buy Trader Joe's naan, crack open a lager. Can't go wrong.
author: Chintu P.

description: The food was amazing. Really spicy so be careful! The service was fast and there's free chai so that was awesome! Prices were reasonable, the only downside I didn't like is that the rice doesn't come free with the entire.. Whaat. Overall great!
author: Shubankan J.

description: This place is a dive but I was craving Indian and this place totally satisfied my craving. We shared a chicken tandoori, some naan, a chicken byriani some raita and a spicy chick pea dish. All delicious.
author: Debra R.

description:
SO FREAKING GOOD.  I don't know if it was because we were starving or because we walked here in the rain, but I was satisfied with the food.  We ordered the chicken biyrani, garlic naan, raita, palak paneer, and chicken tiki masala.  We wanted to try the mutter paneer because it's supposedly a favorite here, but they were out.

For you first timers, let me break it down for you.  If you're eating in, grab a table and don't wait for someone to take your order.  You have to grab a menu from the counter where you'll see the open kitchen and order at the counter.  They'll ask you where you're sitting and then they'll bring your food to you.  Don't ask for water, just walk to the refridgerator next to the kitchen and grab your own pitcher of water and cups or any other drink you want.  The service is really slow because it's so busy and the ordering system is really disorganized.  We have plenty of people who sat down before us get their food first.  Don't hesitate to ask about your order and you'll get it quick.  It really sucked for us because we got our dishes, but had no naan to sop the sauce with!  

The chicken biyrani was good. I loved the cooked slices of lemon in there and the tender chicken thigh meat.  Don't be afraid to eat the lemon, but beware of bones and random unedible spices.  Shalimar ain't fancy!  The chicken tiki masaal was good, but a bit too greasy.  I didn't mind it though.  It just made the naan taste better haha.  The garlic naan is good and they brush some garlic oil on top and it's so fragrant when you smell it.  I loved the raita which had cumin seeds in it.  Gave it a great spice.

I love me some dirty hole-in-the-walls!
author: Linda Y.

description:
This is a hole in the wall joint. With that said, you should come here only if you welcome these kitchens into your life.
Everything is tasty. 

My favorite dishes are the Nihari and Palak Paneer. There are so many aromatic flavors and perfect amount of spice!
author: Dee N.

description: Great place for cheap food. The tea was good. Had the lamb brains. Very interesting texture. Enjoyed the naan, and tikka masala. Yum!!
author: Michelle S.

description: Had the Chicken Tika Masala, basmati, and garlic naan. All delicious. The garlic naan is especially legit, so light and puffy.
author: Stephen S.

description:
There is absolutely NOTHING nice about this place. The food is pretty good though. It's not cheap and it's not expensive, I paid 10 bucks for chicken masala and rice, serves one.

The restaurant looks dirty on the inside and on the outside, I would never ever eat here normally but my bff who is a resident of SF swore by this place. We went during the day time, it's right smack in the middle of TL.  Hella homeless and crackheads everywhere. Don't come here for ambiance, you will only get depressed. I would never recommend anyone to go out of their way to come here, but if for some reason you are in the area and starving, this is okay to go to. And that is about it. If you are easily grossed out, stay far away.
author: Kiki K.

description:
I love the food here. I would love it even more if they weren't constantly out of the items I want. And I mean they never have the items I want. The things I order are awesome. The things I want, non existent. 
Thanks for nothing shalimar and everything!
author: Jake E.

description: Inexpensive price with delicious food! Great for take out as well! Will definitely comeback! The staff is friendly.
author: Mengze Z.

description: The typical "dhaba" type food as in India. The food is a bit greasy but tasty. The place is unassuming and seats max 30 people. We ordered the chickken tikka masaa, chicken korma with naan. If you want cheap, tasty and greasy indian food, this is your place
author: Soumyava D.

description:
Worth a stop.

Previously claimed the portions were not very filling: http://www.yelp.com/biz/shalimar-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:FUvalWhFeBr4C7yvjrFS7w

Lacking yelp proof came back for a second visit. Not surprised to unknowingly order the same dish as the Jones location.

Marinated chicken breast was still just $4.50. Spices and lemon juice gave this tasty dish an extra kick. $1 for a massive naan made the whole thing a massive deal.

Food was ordered and ready to go in less than ten minutes.

Consider this yelp proof that the Polk location is indeed worth a stop.
author: Jason B.

description: Yes! Yes!  So much 'yes.'  Wife ordered murghi korma shahi, I had haleem, got some basmati rice and ngan.  Nothing short of perfect.  If we lived in SF, we would visit every week.
author: Chris J.

description:
Love their food, but I wish they would really try harder on decor and the service.

Great plates to order: the chicken tikka (bbq chicken) moist and delicious!
author: Karen S.

description:
Truly excellent okra.  Very good chicken tikka malsala.  Don't get the eggplant it's not worth it. 

Neat tea dispenser with very strong tea. 

Scary neighborhood.  Prostitutes making out with their johns is a common sight outside the door.
author: Di Yin L.

description: Worst Pakistani resturant I have ever been to , and I have been to many in different cities in the US . Poor hygiene , inattentive service , half burned bread . I would rather throw money in the drain than ever go to this resturant again .
author: Sohail K.

description:
I'm a UC Berkeley student. My friends and I often drive to the city just to have dinner at shalimar. 

Makes us feel like we are at home!
author: Rick P.

description: Definitely one of the best Indian restaurants in the city. Been coming here for years and have never been disappointed by the food. It's flavorful and really authentic you can smell it from outside. The only problem I have about the place is it's location not the best but for this food and these prices it's worth it!
author: Ashley B.

description:
In a city that is saturated with Indian/Pakistani restaurants, it can be hard to stand out, but Shalimar really does stand out - purely based on the food they serve. 

Area/Decor:
The tenderloin area isn't the best place to want to go out to eat, its dirty and full of homeless people outside so walking into the restaurant can be a bit intimidating for people that don't know this area well. The restaurant itself isn't fancy either, the decor is barebones, canteen-style.

Food:
This is where Shalimar really shines. The food is really, really good - and probably the only reason I go here. The Sindhi Biryani is hard to find here, most restaurants do basic Biryani but this place really does a good Sindhi Biryani. They also do a very authentic Nihari and Haleem. They also offer entrees that a lot of other Pakistani restaurants don't. Their food has a very home-cooked taste to it, and the food is never too oily or rich. It IS pretty spicy though.

Price:
The prices are pretty good compared to competitors. The servings aren't HUGE but the food is rich enough that you don't need a lot. I would say the food is worth the price when it comes to quantity/quality.

Service: 
The staff is fairly friendly, the food comes out fast and I've never had any problems here.

Oh, and be prepared to walk out of here smelling like food. The kitchen is open and so all the wonderful smells saturate your clothes and hair pretty easily!
author: Sarah D.

description: When it comes to the food, this place is great. Awesome Indian and middle eastern flavors at really reasonable prices. Although I've sampled some of the other options, I always come back to the standard classics of chicken tikka and garlic naan. The decor and location aren't the best, but you'll forget about that once you taste the flavors.
author: Jon M.

description:
My first time there was yesterday and it will be the last for sure
I tried their lamb briany and it was horrible the rice was dry and no taste to it and the meat was black burned and hard it feels like it was sitting there for couple days at least 
Any other Indian place in the area waaaay better than his place.
author: Murad A.

description: Looking at this place you wouldn't have high expectations but it was really good! The chicken tikka masala is a safe bet, but tasty, and the lamp chops were also good. The real high point is the naan. I've had many, but this is one the best! It is very soft and you can tell that it is fresh. The mango lassi is a must-try. Overall, I would definitely come back!
author: Roofia B.

description:
Had been a while, but good lord why did I wait so long - the Northern Indian food her is outstanding!!  Great dive place/hole-in-the wall, but SOOOOO worth it - the Naan is perfectly cooked, fluffy and just the right elasticity, the chicken tikki masla is rich, savory, and perfectly spiced, the Saag Panneer is silky and creamy and the Lamb Chops are...well....perfect!! :-)

Don't wait, just go - the only reason I hesitate on a 5 star is that it is a bit rough on service and decor - wish I could add a 1/2 star - food is 4.5 stars while place is 2.5stars....but we do go for the food (mostly)!!
author: Richard D.

description: Better than fancy indian restaurants, Shalimar is both amazingly delicious and super cheap. Not the prettiest place and the location is, well, the Tenderloin, but you can't have everything in life, can you?
author: Katalin G.

description: Armpit of a place in the middle of the SF Tenderloin Crackden. I walked in and immediately wanted to walk out as this place honestly looks like crap at first glance and my first assumption was that I will be on the crapper all night if I eat here. My brother insisted that I try it and sure enough, it was some of the better Indian food I have ever had. I guess the moral of the story is not to judge a book by its cover, even if it appears to be as ominous as this place.
author: D K.

description:
Sososososo good.

I love Indian food. I love Shalimar.

The service is not that great. The restaurant-- not really a great atmosphere. You will smell like Indian food for the rest of the night if you eat there. But the food is top notch. 

My number one go to restaurant in the city when I want Indian food.
author: Erica W.

description:
amazing! My fave is the chicken tikka masala (like a butter chicken) and my hubby's fave is their seekh kabob (spicy ground beef kabob)....and some fresh soft naans ...and you have a heavenly meal!! 
tip 1: it's kind of a small hole-in-the-wall type place and the lines can get pretty long since it's such a popular spot... so try to have like late lunches/early dinners to avoid the crowds! :)
tip 2: their kabobs taste great with both chutneys - red (sweet/tangy) and green (minty yogurt) - mixed on on top - delicious!!
author: Sofia M.

description:
What you'll get here is flavor.
Rich, uncompromising, complex and delicious flavor.

What you wont get here includes but not limited to: waiters in tuxedos, fancy plates of irregular geometric shapes, tablecloths, distratcting interior design, cucumbers in your water, or the need to get reservations prior to arrival.

Another spot introduced to me by Aaron V.... another hit.

Highly recommend palak paneer (best one i've ever tried), garlic naan, and the chicken tikka masala.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Almost everything has already been said.  Yeah it's dirty, yeah there are junkies hanging around outside, but yeah, the food's good.
I thought the service was actually pretty good.  We over ordered and the guy came over and told us we should probably only do 4 pieces of naan instead of 6.  I thought that was pretty nice that they weren't just trying to make money off of us.  
The garlic naan is really super garlicky - I would rather the garlic be cooked a little more.  The chicken tikka masala is delicious - that's pretty much all I ate :)
author: Michele S.

description: Ate here every single day while I was visiting San Franscisco. One of the most authentic Indian food I have tasted in United States. Will definitely recommend it to everybody. Murgh shahi was my favorite. Will eat here every time I'll visit San Franscisco
author: Abhishek A.

description: Got the haleem from here and have to say the worst haleem I have ever tasted. I asked for chicken haleem and all I got is potato paste with some weird tasting masala and small pieces of chicken(if you are lucky to find one). VERY DISAPPOINTED
author: Tharun K.

description:
This place has decent food but one of the worst services I've ever experienced. The employees could care less about the customers. We got our food but no spoons to take the food out and half the plates we needed. It took 3 tries to get spoons to eat our food with. It was also a dirty place which is unfortunate because the food is actually pretty good. 

If you don't care about the environment or cleanliness of a place - def go here for the chicken tikka. One of the best I've ever had.
author: Sidra M.

description:
I had the Lamb with Spinach and the butter naan. It was filling and satisfying and the serving was the right size for one person to be full without being uncomfortably stuffed. However, what threw me off was the atmosphere of the place. It was self serving, sort of like a cafeteria where you had to pick up your own plates and food. I would be fine with that except that I encountered certain customers that made the dining experience very uncomfortable.

Pros:
Satisfyingly flavored food. Good portions.

Cons:
Not very clean. Slightly expensive considering that it was self serving. No atmosphere to speak of, come here to eat, and get out.
author: Longwen C.

description: Shalimar has been around for ages.  The food is always good and price is great.  Not the best atmosphere but if that is not the biggest factor then I would recommend it.
author: Robert G.

description:
Best in the city!

Been coming here for 6 years and counting. This spot is way edgier and better than the one in Polk. Be warned that this is a completely stripped down, absolutely no frills place. I like the fact that only locals come here, and a ton of cab drivers.

If you want to be pampered with ambiance and friendly staff service, and be able to still smell decent after your meal, this place is not for you.
author: Kevin N.

description: Food had authentic taste, although the biriyani was not like the biriyani in India (coming from Kolkata, I am really fond of the Lucknowi school of biriyani, and I haven't found a restaurant in US which can match the taste). The chicken tikka masala and other side dishes were very spicy, so if you are weak in heart or stomach, please be careful. The lassi was great. I won't complain about the not so welcoming location or the shabby interior, very often in India, the old and authentic famous eateries don't try to score with their decors. But I can't see how it would do any harm if the people who work  here portray a little more hospitality.
author: Sayak R.

description:
Awesome Awesome Awesome food, and for great prices.  For sure one of the best food joint in the city.

The kabab and chicken legs are def. the bomb.  the only bad thing there is the neighborhood and parking
author: Mike S.

description:
Sometimes, places that are crowded, dirty, and ethnic don't deliver on their promise of delicious food. Shalimar definitely did not deliver. 

We had a sampling of biryani, murghi korma shahi, aloo keema, and chicken tikka masala, as well as some garlic naan. All the Indian food was bland, greasy, and had no distinguishing flavors across any of them. 

The garlic naan was almost inedible. The garlic was stuffed inside the naan, and it was soggy and almost raw at points. Not a great experience.

I won't be back - this was quite possibly the worst Indian food I've ever had in the Bay.
author: Linh L.

description: The food is only so-so. The lamb chops, which have been rated so high, were over cooked and marinated with a dry rub that tasted chaulky.  The service was absolutely horrible and the back room near the restrooms smells foul. There were about 7-9 men behind the counter cooking or just standing around while the only male server was rude and forgetful.  Avoid this restaurant and just keep walking and you'll find a number of other Pakistani/Indian restaurants.
author: Erika M.

description: My wife and I are pretty adventurous.  We're up for any obscure hole-in-the-wall dive if it promises authentic, high-quality ethnic food.  Unfortunately Shalimar disappointed in all respects.  We walked through a cloud of flies around the front door, some of which joined us for our entire meal. I had to give back some of the silverware because it was still dirty. After all that the food turned out to be meh, at best. Tandoori was ok. Okra was bland and kind of oily. I get that it's in the Tenderloin and everything.  I make allowance for that.  But these guys have got to get their act together.
author: Franklin F.

description: The service isn't great but the food more than makes up for it. Order at the coubter. They bring you the food and the check.
author: Stacey B.

description:
DELICIOUSNESS - this is not your ordinary Indian/Pakistani restaurant.

The lamb chops were amazing and I don't like lamb. Not at all game-y and tender without being rare. The goat curry was goat-y but not in a bad way (again I hate goat) - very flavorful and yet goat-subtle at the same time. 

The dal was good - but nothing out of the ordinary. The garlic naan was also delicious.

The free chai is delicious and the rice pudding is yummy.

This is a great restaurant - not your typical over sauced curry restaurant. 

It's truly worth stepping over the crack heads and drunks to get to the delicious food. 

oh, and the interior was cleaner than I remembered - didn't go to the bathrooms, but the restaurant itself was clean and functional.
author: Madison W.

description:
This is my new favorite Indian place. Recently, my girlfriend and I stumbled upon Shalimar and we fell in love with the place. 

The food is amazing. I crave it almost every day. It's unbelievably fresh and the spices are great. I've had several experiences with them, and the level of spiciness (for the same dish) varies by chef from very little heat to eye-watering, belly-burning fire. Even though I can't really tolerate spicy food, it doesn't really matter to me. The food always tastes amazing and feels substantial and authentic. 

To be clear, I would never eat-in again. The tables are disgustingly sticky. There is one waiter who brings your food out, but the experience is largely self-service. The smoke billowing out of the cordoned off kitchen is thick and dark gray. I have asthma, so sitting there for 45 minutes was a suffocatingly hellish experience. My girlfriend has runner's lungs though, so her watering eyes, coughing, and general face-shielding really put the smoke cloud in perspective for me. Never. Eat. In. Moreover, there aren't a lot of tables and there's isn't any sort of organization, so the dinner rush coming in just hung out in the aisles between the tables and circled patrons who seemed to be leaving soon. Four separate couples hovered around our table for ten minutes while we were finishing up. Not awkward or rude at all, guys. Not at all.

Get takeout and be prepared to experience deliciousness like never before.
author: Jen H.

description: OMG this food is yummy! I am not sure about the place itself so if you can eat at home instead of the location itself... do it. I ordered spinach saag and chicken haleem  with onion naan. The food was incredible! If I can learn how to prepare spinach like that, I would become be a popeye.
author: Magda G.

description:
This place is amazing on so many levels. 

The Location 
If you're feeling brave this place is smack in the middle of the SF Tenderloin District. There will be gauntlets of crack heads (during the day they are harmless) and there are...NO STARBUCKS *gasp! 

The Atmosphere
This place looks sketchy as hell but it is clean, warm and smells awesome. The guys who work there are incredibly nice as long as you're nice to them. 

The Service
You order off of a huge newspaper style menu at the front and the food is brought out to you. You grab your own chai tea by the register along with any sauces that might be missing from your table. There is no alcohol in there but as long as you are low key about it you can BYOB - just keep it classy and drink your beer that you bought at the liquor store down the street (keep it local!) out of a clean Starbucks cup (suck on that corporate America).

The Food 
Now according to several sources this isn't 100% authentic but whatever - it's awesome, it's cheap and it's delicious. Be aware that they cook with real whole spices here so they WILL end up in your rice and sauces and if you bite down on one of those bad boys you're gonna have a bad time. So take a second and pick out any visible offenders. 

Favorites (if I spelled it wrong it's because I'm writing this review from distant memory as I haven't been there in a few months)
-naan (always naan) 
-Chicken Tika Masala (the spice level is pretty tame) 
-Chicken Tandoori
-Yellow Lentils (these can get real spicy)
-Palak Paneer 
-Chai tea for DAAAAYS
-The beer you brought in a Starbucks cup 

So seriously, get the F out of Union Square, stop being such a yuppie and go to this place.
author: Hanna W.

description:
While I have been to their Fremont location more frequently, this was the first Shalimar I ever visited.
The hearty food is full of delicious, robust flavors. I love a meal that's so good it truly feels "homemade" & that's def. what you're getting when you order here! Loved the piping hot chai dispensers, too. Very creamy.
Minus one star for being insanely crowded, and a little dirty!
author: Shianne D.

description: This place isn't bad but its below average compared to other Indian places I frequent.  The service is poor and the food was about average.  As others have mentioned its definitely dumpy inside which is fine if the food is outrageously awesome but for us it was just average indian fare.
author: Trent K.

description:
If you want good Indian food follow your nose, and don't let your other senses fool you. Is the floor a bit dirty? Yes. Are the menus frayed and tattered? Often. Is that a bum peeing on the wall outside? Quite possibly. 

Just ignore all that, close your eyes, and concentrate on what you came there for: exquisitely spiced curries, beautiful Biryanis, and that lovely feeling of inner peace that comes from drinking three chais in the span of thirty minutes because it's cold outside and they're complementary. 

I've never had a bad experience here. The counter staff is quiet and sometimes a bit terse, but I wouldn't describe them as rude. Besides, are you there to chat all day or are you there to shove curry in your face? Close your eyes and dig in.
author: Aaron Y.

description: Seating is a bit difficult but the food here is amazing. Always hot and fresh. Chicken tika and tanduri chicken is great. I haven't tried anything bad here. The naan bread is awesome also
author: Ahmed K.

description:
If you like Indian food served up in a dive-like atmosphere, this is the place for you. Everything we ordered was fragrant, full of flavor and amazingly good. 

It's a great scene late night; lots of Indian men engaged in lively conversation. This place is legit.
author: Lee H.

description: This is TL ethnic food at its finest. Perhaps the best Indian in all the city. It's cash only and I'm pretty sure it's BYOB. At least I've never heard otherwise. Lock yo car and hide yo wife first
author: Martin R.

description: Great dive atmosphere.  Friendly waiter.  Sketchy neighborhood.  Phenomenal food.
author: Phil G.

description: Great authentic food! Make sure to order a piece of their fresh nan and a plate of their house rice, both under two bucks! We went with their king of all curries dish, Murghi Korma Shahi, which of course did not disappoint. We will definitely be back again. Speak up and be open to a new experience of dining! (Tip: Order at the counter and pay after you are finished eating!)
author: Cindy G.

description: I went there for the first time yesterday, that would definitely be my last! I usually don't write negative reviews, but in this case I couldn't help myself. This place is filthy!!!! disgusting!!! I am surprised the health department hasn't shut them down! However the food OK. Nothing too delicious! But the place was soo dirty and there were a lot of insects!
author: Deniel P.

description: I've been eating here since moving to SF in 1999. Consistently the best causal Indian food in the city. I think the location in the TL is by far the best- something about the gritty TL goes nice with the spice.
author: David P.

description:
I've actually woken-up from wet dreams craving the na'an from this place. 

I can't claim to be an Indian food expert but I know I love that tandoori chicken and the spicy mystery meat shaped like a sausage. The staples of rice, palak paneer and lentils are delish. 

The place isn't the cleanest in the world (the bathroom is straight out of a horror movie) but the food is fast, hot, well priced and good. When you leave the smell of tandoori will linger on your clothes and in your hair...turn on for those of you who are into that kind of thing.
author: Jade W.

description:
Filthy.  If this bothers you, stop reading now and go to a different restaurant.  There are many cleaner restaurants of similar quality on the same block.  Hell, there are many cleaner restaurants in every third world country that I have visited.  The poorest slums of Lahore likely have cleaner restaurants with better service than this place.

The food is actually quite good, which is the only thing (besides the slumlord pricing) that saves this place from zero stars.  I mean, I really love delicious food, and I find delicious food at third world prices to be near irresistible.  That's what led to my rather flawed decision to patronize this hovel.  Oh, and I guess we saw a "Zagat Rated" sticker placed crookedly on the window.  

Now, normally, I can easily ignore flaws in service, decor, courtesy, cleanliness, etc. in a restaurant when the food is excellent.  When good food is also cheap, I hardly notice the above problems.  But not this time.  Where to start...

The filth.  We aren't just talking cheap diner sort of filth, or even third world country filth here.  We are talking full on retch-inducing horror movie filth.  It coats the walls, the tables, everything.  When we sit down, some annoyed looking guy (the owner? a vagabond?) comes over and without speaking or even acknowledging our existence, literally body checks us as he pushes his way to the table to wipe it with a cloth that looks like he stores it in his ass.  That was clue #1 that we had not chosen wisely.  Unfortunately, we decided to "keep it real." 

This is where it turns into the next Chapelle Show episode of "When Keeping It Real Goes Wrong."  We aren't sure if you order from the annoyed looking guy with no concept of personal space, or from the counter, as there is no sign or other indication.  We find some paper menus and look through the choices, all of which sounded delicious and were priced quite low.

When the dude with the dish towel in his ass didn't come back, we decided to approach the crumbling plexiglass counter.  There, he magically appears and looks quizically at us while holding a pen.   We order a few things and then he says "No." and grabs our menu to cross off several things.  Apparently, they were out of those items.  We then order other things, which apparently were acceptable.  My poor brother and I both order a mango lassi, which turns out to be bad decision #23 that night.

We go to grab a soda we had ordered from the fridge and to our surprise, we find the "Lassi Vat."  It's a large dirty plastic bin without a lid, filled with mango lassi with a soup bowl floating in it.  The annoyed dude comes over and reaches into the lassi with his bare hands to fish out the soup bowl and uses that to pour lassi into two plastic cups.  These are brought to our table for us to consume.  Bad decision #24.

Eventually, some food arrives.  I am confused as it doesn't look like the Jehangir's favorite lamb chops or the chicken korma or the palak paneer that we ordered.  We ask the annoyed guy with the ass towel if this is our food and he points at all the dishes and names them.  We remind him that we didn't order any of those things.  He looks more annoyed, takes them and leaves.  My brother asks me if it is because we are infidels that the service is this bad.

Eventually, correct food arrives.  Some of it.  We inquire about the rest of our order and are ignored by ass-towel guy.  The food is delicious, however, and we think that we've finally justified the 37 bad decisions up until that point.  

This is when keeping it real goes wrong.  While eating the chicken, I notice there are shards of bone in it, as if it had been violently hacked with a meat cleaver, paying no attention to the bones.  Unfortunately, I notice this while chewing when a thin shard of bone penetrates my lower gums, causing an impressive stabbing pain.  After a startled pause to figure out what the hell happened to my mouth, I carefully use my fingers to remove it, and note the wonderful flavor of my own blood.  Awesome.  That just happened. If the inevitable food poisoning wasn't enough reward for keeping it real, an oral abscess would really top it off.

After about 15 minutes of applying direct pressure, my mouth stops bleeding and the remainder of our food arrives.  It's also tasty, though eaten more carefully.

A large arabic family arrives and sits near us.  My brother wants to see if they experience the same awful service, or if they are treated differently from infidels.  An older woman in the group looks around after sitting down, sees the table, and eyes the annoyed ass-towel dude approaching her and pretty much loses it.  In broken English she tells her family that it is too filthy and they must leave.  Good decision #1 for them.

We finish and leave, so I can spend the rest of my night in the bathroom.  Does San Fran actually have a Health Department?
author: Matt J.

description:
Ever since I reviewed neighboring Lahore Karahi I've been inundated with challenges swearing Shalimar would easily trump my experience up the block. Walking home on a rainy evening not too long ago I thought of Shalimar... "Tonight... You."

At entry the experience was much the same. Very busy, very aromatic. Simple setup, cafeteria like, with the kitchen and all the related hustle and bustle clearly viewable from anywhere in the restaurant. Many cooks moving seamlessly through the small kitchen like an intricate dance, it was a busy night, always a positive sign.

I skimmed the menu and honed in on the mill juli sabzi, the exact dish I raved about from Lahore, and concluded what better way to really compare than to get the same dish? I took my order with rice and onion kulcha and hit the road. 

I headed homeward with excitement to compare apples to apples, or I suppose in this case sabzi to sabzi. I inspected the food and delved right in, first the rice. Rice and breads are canvas to the Indian/Pakistani culinary arts, too many places slack and think you won't notice when in reality bland rice will sap flavor from the dish instead of complimenting it. I sampled some by itself and found it good and authentic, complete with a stick of cinnamon and bay leaf, but honestly it wasn't AS flavorful as I'd hoped. Don't get me wrong the rice was solid, but comments from the rabid Shalimar zealot coalition had me anticipating my jaw to be blown clean off the hinge with rich flavors.

The main course again, a satisfactory dish but just not nearly as epic as I'd been lead to believe. It was a bit oily for my preference which can drown out individual flavors that would normally work so well with the spiced rice and subtle breads. I clearly recall sitting in my living room staring at my bowl, wondering what I must be missing to reach such moderate conclusions on food others find phenomenal.

I would come back and likely will, I had my eye on a few other menu selections. Frankly though the end result was food that was 'good' but not great, service  'polite' but not friendly or speedy, and taste buds 'content' but not enthusiastic. I reckon that's a three star review if I've ever experience one, don't you agree? Sorry Shalimar fan club, I tried my best..
author: Justin N.

description: Great meat consistently, Free Chai is really nice treat
author: Vadim M.

description:
Unreal. Saag out of this world. Cheap too. Free Indian chai tea. Real robust flavors. Wish LA had real Indian food like this. 

Chicken Tikka so good you will slap your mother. Love it
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Stumbled here last night on my bus ride home. I jumped off the bus to hit the taqueria on the corner but the smell of my homeland called to me.

Shalimar has damn good food for such a good price! I had their Bengan (eggplant) and it is very tasty, albeit not healthy at all. I will definitely be back on the nights where I feel like cheating but we Indians/Pakistanis need to make things a tad healthier.

Also staff was super friendly and kept chatting with me and making sure everything turned out well.
author: Raina B.

description:
Imagine a third world prison - the heavy scent of arm pit, the daily beatings, the inch-thick filth covering all surfaces, and sanitation equal to that of a 12th century french latrine.  Now imagine the guy that delivers your daily beatings also serving you delicious food.  Welcome to Shalimar!  Unfortunately, this is an accurate depiction of my experience.  Here's a rundown:  

- We were given the wrong food twice
- When we got the right food, it was thrown at us in true "prison meal time" style
- Our drinks were scooped out of a dingy vat kept in the back
- Our table was "cleaned" with a rag that was most likely purchased in 1948 and then never washed
- Our cups and plates were encrusted with unidentifiable bits of something that was perhaps hopefully at least semi-edible
- Walls, tables, windows, floors, and most everywhere I looked were yellowed and filthy from what appeared to be years of neglect (Robert Irvine would have taken one look and said "No bloody way")

Shalimar is directly across the street from Chutney - a great restaurant I visited a year and a half ago serving excellent food without any of Shalimar's "charm".  Avoid the health risk and go to Chutney (or any other place for that matter).
author: Jeff J.

description:
I moved away from SF six years ago, but my mouth still waters thinking about the lamb chops at this place.  Add some dal and you've pretty much described my favorite Indian meal in the city.   

One time on the way to the bathroom, I though I spotted meat marinating outside in a plastic pail (like one you'd buy at Home Depot). I'm sure it just added to the flavor. 

I think Pakwan may have slightly better veggie dishes, but between the two I usually choose Shalimar.  I still haven't found any place close to this in Orange County.
author: Ivy W.

description: Not the cleanest kitchen/staff in the world but the food is good. Would I go back?  No. If you disagree with this review,  go in there and observe the kitchen staff and chefs how unclean they really are!!!  Thanks!
author: Adam T.

description:
Tastes great.

Then I spent the night throwing up until 6AM and missed work the next day.

Ask yourself if possible food poisoning is really worth it.
author: Elinore E.

description:
We went on a Saturday evening and it was a wait to get inside and there was some confusion on getting a table.  If you are looking for service and a quiet dinner, this is not the place BUT if you are looking for great Pakistani food at reasonable prices, go for it.  You'll see some confusion, a mixed crowd, people running around and a few screaming kids but that more like urban Pakistan anyway, right?

Food was great but naan was not fresh so they exchanged it.   Have some chai before you leave.
author: Kelly W.

description:
Chicken Korma Shahi was pretty good. It was very different than anywhere I have had this before.
I loved the chicken tikka here. 
Service is good enough. 
Garlic Naan stole the show for me! it was just awesome!  
PS: Garlic naan is always good...but this one was wayyy better!
author: Harish Kumar S.

description: Yes total dive.  But the food was very good.  Was great to grab an inexpensive meal before the Theater.
author: John T.

description: More adventurous than I typically am, but it came highly recommended by our hotel concierge as his favorite restaurant.  It was tasty!  Rich and complex flavors, spices I've not experienced.  Great to explore something different while visiting the city.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is one of the first places I ate at when moving to SF about 5 months ago, and it is fantastic!  It's a total hole in the wall, but the food positively sings with spice, complexity and flavour.  I had the Mattar Paneer with rice.  Rather than the boring, creamy, mushy and flavourless peas and cheese that some places provide, this dish had firm paneer and peas bathed in a richly-spiced, multi-layered sauce for which the colourful rice was a perfect vehicle.

I also had very nice service here - fast, friendly and laid-back.

Yes it's dingy and not in the greatest area (though I've always felt safe there), but it's cheap, totally delicious and friendly.  Highly recommended.
author: Sabrina B.

description: The eggplant dish (bengen bhujia) is excellent. MURGH TIKKA LAHORI (tandori chicken) is solid -- very tender. One of the first indian places that wouldn't give me a stomachache afterwards!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Shalimar VS Lahore Karahi in a fight to the death... who wins? Well, if you ask my buddy Aaron, Lahore doesn't even come close. Myself, on the other hand, sees this feud as more of a friendly sparring match where both spots come out the victor. 

Apparently, Shalimar was one of the first Indian/Pakistani eateries to set up shop in the Tenderloin, and if you know anything about the 'Loin (besides the junkies and pools of vomit), you know it's home to plenty of fantastic restaurants of this variety. For setting the bar, you have to throw these guys props.

They have wacky stuff like lamb brains that you can order, but if you stick to the simple stuff, you'll be blown away. The saag is outstanding, the chicken masala is some of the best I've ever had, and their naan is incredible. Best of all, it's CHEAP! Like Lahore, the prices are in the $6-$8 per dish. A total steal for food of this quality.

It's always good sign when folks of world descent pack a restaurant serving food from their native land. Much like observing a sushi place where much of the clientele is Japanese, Shalimar had a fairly high concentration of Indian people enjoying their grub. When you see that going down, you know you're in for a real, authentic treat. 

Beware - the city recently cracked down on BYOB restaurants. Shalimar used to let you imbibe freely while eating, but no longer.
author: Ruggy J.

description: The food is great but this place needs a renovation SO BAD, like come on by doing this more people gonna come and enjoy their food more. Thats the only reason im giving it a 4 star because they need to step up their game on the renovation interior and exterior.
author: Mario L.

description:
So we basically go in there, order, and then get rudely ordered to go to the front of the store to wait. We waited. And waited. And waited. When we go to get our food, the same guy bumps in to us (again) rudely telling us to go back to the front of the store, even though we were literally picking up our food in front of him.

The food itself was pretty lame. Greasy as all hell, the naan wasn't cooked all the way through, and there was nothing special about how the chicken tasted. On top of that, I'm probably gonna be up at 2 am crapping that sloppy mess out all night long.

In retrospect, I would say that the combination of the food and customer service was an experience strong enough to make me want to slap all the Indian people I an think of. So, I'm about to embark on a three hour return trip to go to my parents house just to hit them. Possibly get something as authentic but actually good, too. And then carry on in the morning with whomever else i can think of.
author: Ashwin B.

description: This place is amazing!  As a preggo, I cannot begin to tell you how much I have craved the deliciousness that is Shalimar.  This is not a glamorous place - heck it's in the tenderloin - but man, it is tasty.  Their Chicken Jalfrezi is the best I have eaten in San Francisco.  Fresh garlic naan?  Yaaaaasssss!  Their Palak Aloo Methi is also great as is their chicken tikka masala.  Basmati rice - good but hey I'd rather use the naan to soak up all the curried heavenliness.  Oh and their mango lassi - the best mango lassi I have ever tried.  The place is not where you go for 5 star service but rather for 5 star flavor, if that's a thing.
author: c c.

description:
The food is fresh and tasty.  Great venue for casual dinning with friends or colleagues that you don't need to impress.

The decor is minimal and alcohol is not permitted.

Most dishes are between $6 to $10.
author: Rob D.

description:
Do you ever have one of those mornings where you wake up in a bit of a haze, and the first question on your mind is "What the fuck happened to me last night and why does my shirt smell like Tandoori chicken?!"

I thought so. 

Seriously though, while I definitely remembered everything that happened to me last night, the most memorable part was the fantastic Indian meal I had in one of the most unsuspecting places in the Tenderloin. 

Shalimar is a tiny, dirty, filthy hole-in-the wall, serving up some serious, and I mean SERIOUS Indian food. Nice pungent, greasy chicken tikka marsala. An amazingly thick, chunky, and delicious saag. Some whole-lentil dal that's tasty if not surprising, and a fantastic set of naan. With prices ranging from dirt-cheap to slightly less-dirty, and served up in cheap plastic plates that have seen many moons. The mise en scene was that of an Asian night market, filled mostly with locals, where you get the best of blue collar food at even-bluer-collar-prices.

We were shepherded into Shalimar by a local who claims it's some of the best Indian in the area, and I am tempted to believe his assertions. As we sat in the little space sipping beer from discrete paper cups (they told us no more BYOB, so we hid it) we watched them pull giant skewer after giant skewer of seasoned chicken from the oven, the pungent smoke hanging thick in the air. Doused in a thick red curry, that same chicken descended upon my palate like rickety speedboat full of Somali pirates descends upon an unwary container ship navigating dangerous waters. Quick, sneaky, then POW! My taste-buds have just been held ransom, and the only thing that will save them is a combination of garlic naan and more tikka marsala. 

I unfortunately found this place on my last night of a week in The City, but Shalimar has instantly become my new go-to Indian when I am in the area. I fear that I have been permanently ruined on Portland Indian food now, since none have come close to the filthy brilliance dished up by Shalimar.
author: Don B.

description: If you can get past the no parking, the one way streets, tourists, dirty hotels & hostels, drug addicts, drug dealers, derelicts, prostitutes, that seedy feeling that someone is following you and actually find parking- this place is THE BOMB!!! I find myself always coming back after a few month of naan and curry. This place; no comparison. I'm salivating as I type, sorry bout it gotta eat now!
author: Roxanne O.

description:
Previous review still applies. Love this place for what it is: great food, bad location, poor ventilation, floaties (see below), etc. Although the service has markedly improved, maybe since the staff realized that service = tips in SF.

I just wanted to write an update to turn all y'all on to a SECRET MENU item: lamb shank. It is served in the same sauce as the bhuna ghosht (I think), but it is a whole shank of lamb, braised to perfection, to the point where the meat is positively falling off the bone. Mm mmm mmm.

Oh, and watch out for random floaties in your drinks. This place definitely doesn't rate too high on the health board's list, so just be on your toes. I've experienced a floatie or two in the pitchers of water and the mango lassi (they replaced it.)

I think the cooked food is very safe, though, so don't let it turn you off on the place, since it's so worth it. If you're really concerned about it, just BYOB. The sign on the wall says "No Alcohol" but that is so they get the benefit of the doubt from the health board when they come pay a visit.
author: Josh K.

description:
Four stars for the food,  knocked down one star for cleaniness.

The garlic naan is one of the best I've had.  We also had the palak paneer, channa masala, rice, and another paneer dish in cream sauce (paneer masala).  The food was tasty, but overall appearance and unsanitary conditions were hard to avoid.  

Not sure if anything in the restaurant is cleaned.  Restroom was filthy, without soap or towels.  Not sure how the staff washes their hands.  I assume a lot of restaurants are this dirty behind the scenes, but its just harder to witness it first hand.
author: P S.

description:
Place:  It is always suitable to enjoy the Indian food in the lively place. The tables are too small for our order, but they are clean.

Price: Very reasonable price. 

Products: I don't really know what is the authentic Indian food, but I am really enjoy them.
author: 春枝

description:
I was bummed after my last trip here.  I had always like Shalimar more than Pakwan (the one on 16th) as they were two of my faves but upon returning this last time I found the fare here at Shalimar was not as good as before :(

I need to go back to the Polk street location though since that one was also a step below this original spot IMHO but maybe it's now the flagship?
author: Gene X.

description:
The food was fantastic - absolutely delicious.

Less great was the total chaos inside. Thankfully, I was with a regular who took charge and got us a table (it looks like it's first-seize, first-get when it comes to tables), ordered for us (unclear to me whether one can order at the table or if you have to go up to the counter), and settled the bill (again, I think you have to go to the counter).

Given how good the food is, I don't have a problem with the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere.
author: Bryce K.

description: The worst hospitality experience in San Francisco. We waited at the door for 25 minutes waiting to be seated. Nobody greeting, welcomed us into the restaurant, or even have us a menu. It's surprising how many other restaurants in the same neighborhood being busier still manage to be more welcoming. I would not recommend this place at all.
author: Deepa G.

description:
So I've been going to the one on Polk for years and never knew there was another one on Jones until I was dragged there last weekend (I wanted to eat at Lahore Karahi). 

But I was pleasantly surprised... I like this location more, even though it's smaller than the Polk Street location. It's cleaner, quieter, and the food is just as good. I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and Garlic Naan (my favorite combination) which had the perfect amount of spice. My date ordered the lamb brains on a dare from me. It was interesting---the texture and taste reminded me of curried frois gras.

Lesson learned: trying new things or new things in different places DOES pay off!
author: Dani D.

description: It's still the best in the city...12 years later!
author: Michael E.

description: Simply the most authentic Indian of all Indian restaurants. Their chicken is 100% Natural, Grain fed and farm raised unlike the 99.99% of other Indian restaurant who get their meat from restaurant depo to save money. As a San Francisco Cab driver, trust me I have tried all of them. Don't waste your time and money anywhere else.
author: 4thesakeof P.

description: Pair the food here after a few cocktails at Bourbon and Branch and you are GOOD TO GO!! I love everything my friend Jerome orders - chicken tikka, some chick pea mixture, paneer tikka, and naan bread. Plus they have complimentary warm chai tea to wash it all down. Reasonably priced for dinner, and they do their best to get the food out quickly. Just do not wear your favorite clothes because it will make people either hungry or run in the other direction from you.
author: Thomas L.

description: Food was mediocre. We went to this place after reading the reviews, and coming from NY/Va (East coast), this would be rated disgusting. As recommended, we tried the mix kebobs, chicken tikka masala, goat curry, biriyani, onion naan, alu naan, mango lachi.. and some other items off the menu. Simple words- people need to try some real quality pakistani food!
author: S Z.

description: Delicious food don't miss out! Awesome authentic tasty food! Good value for money! You can create you own meal! Choose tandoori chicken, kofta .. Etc. Then add rice & bread! Their mango lassi is nice. The tea is for free
author: Doaa E.

description:
This is a Caro five-star for SURE.  I am all about good prices and quality food and that's what this place delivers.  Get naan and chicken tikka masala and pat yourself on the back for making such a good decision.  done.

[[also recommend getting to go.  it is byob which is cool.  but getting it to go is even better.]]
author: Carolyn N.

description:
Shalimar is my new favorite Indian place in the city. It has no pretension. You have to go to the counter to order your food and the decor is...hmmm...let's just say plain.

However, the food is just really good and not expensive at all. 
I go there for lunch often. I've tried the okra dish which is one of my favorites, as well as the chicken masala (the chicken masala has to be their signature dish because I see everyone getting it every time I go), I've tried their beef kebabs which I find perfectly spiced, and a veggies dish with cauliflower and carrots, which was good but not exceptional. 

I intend to try everything on their menu at least once so more reviews are to come...
author: Cemeldosce M.

description: Once you walked into the restaurant no one is really there to welcome you or tell you what to do. Its super busy, and you have to flag people down to ask where to garb a table. Once you grab a table you can then go over to the ordering counter which is also seems like there peeping station to order your food. Food was ok, but the whole experience was very confusing. I would not desire to eat there again. I have had a lot of other places that had good food.
author: Sami S.

description:
Yes, it is all true.  Shalimar is filthy with zero customer service, impossible to park and in a super shady neighborhood.  The first several times, I'd say, I would over-look all these problems because the food is amazing, rich and flavorful, I phone in my order, double park and run in with my cash ready to take out.  It is also really really cheap, like $10 for chicken tikka masala and garlic naan.  

However, a couple of weeks ago, I busted my diet and took out my favorite dishes, chicken tikka masala, goat and garlic naan, looking forward to a yummy and fatty meal.  Alas, it was completely disappointing, the flavors were off, the meats were over-cooked and tough.  It was hard for me to imagine this crappy meal came from the same resturant that I thought had the best Indian/Pakistani food in SF that I 'm even willing to overlook a number of health code violations!   

Not sure what happened, but inconsistency in a restaurant is a deal breaker for me.   The roller coaster ride in quality of the meal is like a roller coaster ride of emotions in a relationship, time to breakup....
author: Rosalyn C.

description:
Shalimar is in the sketchy part of the Tenderloin where there are many down-and-dirty but delicious Indian restaurants. Shalimar certainly holds its own against its immediate neighbors, including Pakwan and Chutney's within a block.

I ordered the Chicken Jalfrezi, a "special" that was printed on their menu. It tasted very good, but it was incredibly greasy - there was literally a pool of oil at the bottom of my dish after I skimmed the good stuff off the top (see my pictures). My boyfriend ordered the chicken kofta, which is like malai kofta but with chicken (obviously). I'm not a big fan of ground meet, but the sauce was good and he was satisfied. 

I really liked the garlic nan. It was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, and it was breadier than nan at other places.

As you would expect from this part of town, it's a pretty bare bones space and it's kind of chaotic inside. You order up at the front with their oversized paper menus, then they find you at your table once your food is ready. But, surprisingly, we got the right food relatively quickly.

Presentation and diet aside, Shalimar tastes great. I'll probably be back since I have little self control.
author: Adam B.

description:
I come here for the curry.
Serving myself in no hurry.
Tell you all won't be sorry.
Every time I eat and carry.
Don't you be shy.
C Indian kids sayHi. 
Drink a cup of chai.
Lick my plate B4 bye.
author: Abel Y.

description:
So cheap, so delicious.
VERY GREASY!  But if you are ok with grease, it's some of the best Indian food in SF.
Tikka is great, Tandoori is great.  The nann is amazing - and you will need to it sop up the greasy goodness.

Take it to go - it's in a shady area
author: A S.

description: My favorite Pakistani restaurant in San Francisco recommended to me by some Indian friends 14 years ago. It hasn't changed in all of these years. The chicken tikka masala is a must along with the bengen bhujia
author: Mondher B.

description: For the prices (~$8-9 per person), I was expecting much larger portion sizes. I actually left hungry after ordering a vegetable dish and one naan for myself. The food was decent and seemed more home-y than your usual Americanized Indian place.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Got the saag ghosht, not that it was inedible but the flavor of the spinach really took over and the lamb was meh.
author: Justine L.

description:
Visiting SF and  disappointed as a friend raved about this place . I had Bhuna gosht , it was oily and very spicy( not in the right way )I also felt it was salty.Naan was cooked to perfection and the Lahori kabob was yummy . It is very bland looking place and service is blah ... The guy forgot my order and asked me again after 10 minutes what I ordered. Also curry came first and naan came after 5 mins :),they forgot. I drafted this review waiting for bill, I guess I will remind them :). Also there is a sign which says no alcohol but guy next to me bought his own corona so they are discreetly BYOB . For now 2 stars but maybe I will come back to give a second chance.

Better Indian/Pakistani places in SF for sure!! Try Pakwaan I gave it 4 stars based on my dinner there.
author: Sudhir D.

description: This place would've have gotten five stars if it weren't for the seating area. Other than that great food. Their Biryani is a must.
author: Krishan S.

description: Best authentic Paki/Indian food in my opinion.  Super fresh, quality ingredients, what more can you ask for?
author: AJ K.

description: I've travelled the world and this is the best Indian food I have ever had. Incredible price   Plus the service is great. The food though is just something special. At one point I would eat there 5 times a week!! I know that sounds crazy but it's the truth. Order the goat curry, garlic naan and saag chicken. See for yourself!!
author: Amit D.

description: This place has great food and at amazing prices. The tikka masala was extremely well done. The dhal masala lacked some salt and some flavor but was nice. The stuffed naans were really good too. Will I go there again? Definitely!
author: Arvind G.

description:
Ok, so if all I cared about was food, I would give this place 4 stars. However, if I haven't been to a place before, first impressions - especially about the service - matter. 

When we first stepped in for a late lunch, we weren't quite sure how things worked here. It wasn't clear how to order - at the counter or do we just sit down? But where is the menu? Ok, it's folded to the side in a mess of a pile. There was also no acknowledgment that we even walked in. Once at the table someone came by with plates and water and made no eye contact whatsoever, which we noticed seemed to be the style here. Then, we see our food come to the counter. Do we get it ourselves or is someone bringing it over? We saw someone else pick up their own food and no one ever really gave us direction, so I go to grab our plates only to be yelled at by the guy on the other side of the kitchen. I couldn't even understand him clearly, but I eventually got the message. Feeling like an idiot, I sit back down and 3 minutes or staring at our food on the counter, someone brings them over. Oh, and I also ordered a mango lassi, which was still missing after we got our food. I was giving them the benefit if the doubt that maybe they were out and had to prepare a new batch in the back. But, nope, 10 min later I saw some guy take a jug out of the fridge and pour a glass (only 3/4 full). Maybe it was being chilled? Ok, probably not. 

I get it. I love hole in the wall places with "flavor" & "character", but not places that make me feel like an idiot. I mean, now that I know how things work if I ever go again it will probably be better, but the way this place made me feel probably is enough make me not care if ever eat that tasty lamb dish. 

A simple "we'll bring it to you when the food is ready" when ordering and perhaps putting the menu display over the counter or at least a sign that says "order here" would have go a long way here. Just a thought.
author: Maria M.

description:
This place looks like a worn down cafeteria inside. It's in a seedy neighborhood to say the least. It also has some of the best Indian food I've ever had.  

Their curries are excellent, chicken tikka masala and channa (chickpea) masala are my favorites.  Garlic naan is packed with flavor.  In fact pretty much everything here has plenty of spice and flavor.  

If I had one gripe it's that the saag spinach curry is more chunky and less puréed than I like.  But that's just a personal preference, I know others who go crazy over the saag.  

I ate lamb brain here and I loved it!
author: Matthew B.

description:
So after months of hearing about Shalimar this.. Shalimar that.. I finally last night made it through the doors and actually ate at Shalimar.

I am no Indian/ Pakistani food novice.. so I know what I want in my food.. when I am the one to actually order it.. but as I wasn't the person who ordered anything last night.. it was a bit of  a walk on the wild side for me.

As of last night I can now say.. proudly.. I have had Haleem and Eggplant.. and I think maybe Lamb Curry..??  But if it was Lamb.. first time I ever went back for seconds on a Lamb curry.

Everything wasn't over spiced and neither was it SO spicy it over powered the flavor of the food.

My group and I basically took over the place.. we were like 20 people in the place.. that was at least 2/3 the seats of the entire restaurant!

This place isn't fancy.. it doesn't have mood lighting and it sure isn't a place your going to propose to your significant other.  The tea and water is mostly self serve.. the tables are Formica from like the 1980's.. you leave smelling like a wood fire and grilled meat.. which I don't mind because the price is right and the food is pretty good.

I'll be back... especially since I know this spot is right across the street from Bang Sun.
author: Alicia A.

description: Absolutely excellent!  I lived in India for 5 months. This is the best food I've had since then. The place has a depressing decor, and you essentially have to serve yourself. But the food is superb, & I can't wait to go back!
author: Rob S.

description:
Curry can be either super greasy or super tasty. Shalimar has the latter.

The mom and pop feel can be best experienced in their Naan, hands down some of the best in the Bay. The attention to the bread transfers into the rest of the meal.

Great, great stuff.
author: Haz O.

description: Shalimar is my favorite place in the city. Really awesome food and great price. (Of course it is busy -- great places tend to be!) My family has been eating there for 15 years now and Shalimar never disappoints.
author: Emma D.

description:
Cheap, tasty, authentic Indian food.  Free Chai tea.  What more can I ask for?

I guess cleaner looking space would be nice.  But for what they are, I can live with it.

The funny thing is ... their other location on Polk is much more spacious and appears cleaner ... but I still come to their original location on Jones as my favored location.
author: Winnie C.

description:
We came here because it was walking distance from our hotel. The seating is self-service and they won't let you order until you've secured a table. We came at 8:00 and it took about 30 minutes to get a table and another 30 minutes to get our food. There were a lot of groups, so if you are a table of 2, it's really difficult to get a table. There were a few 2-party groups who ended up joining together to get a table. I usually rate an Indian restaurant on how well they make chicken tikka masala and this was good, but not great. The ventilation is horrible, you'll definitely end up smelling like smoke since the grill is only separated by a counter from the dining room.

Overall, it was an ok meal, but I wouldn't come back here again.
author: A C.

description:
2.5 stars 
As much as Shalimar is hyped, the food is here just ok - no better than Naan N Curry, maybe not as good. 

If this were anywhere else it might warrant three stars but there is NO excuse for having just ok Indian/Pakistani food when Lahore Karahi is just down the street which is probably the best in the entire city and costs about the same. 

Tried it twice, the last time my stomach hated me after eating here - another reason for not going here again.
author: Ben B.

description: Honestly I din liked it at all .the food looked and smell better thn it tasted..we had chana daal that had no spices or flavor , chicken tikka ..seekh kabab , nehari ..
author: Reema S.

description: I think the only thing that deserved a 4 star out of the stuff we ordered was their goat karahi. The meat was cooked so nicely and the curry was superb. I also ordered channa which turned out to be too bland, garlic naan which just had chunks of garlic in it which i didnt like and gulab jamun at the end which were cold :-(...
