I just assumed all restaurants serve the gulab jamuns hot. Anyways, would prob just order their meat dishes if i end up going there again.
author: Manpreet R.

description:
Overdue review (like almost all of my more recent and future reviews).

Came here again last weekend again... the cousin and I had a nice-postwork dinner here, where we more than adequately recovered any lost calories... painfully so.

I've ordered a number of dishes here, and none have disappointed. The one I do remember from my last visit here was the lamp chops. Fantastically tasty... must have again.

Disclaimer: Make sure you don't wear clothes that you can't throw in the hamper immediately upon returning home... their ventilation system isn't entirely top-notch... but it has nothing to do with the food. Trust.
author: Victor C.

description: I'm not sure who's giving this place good reviews. Went with friends, but I should have trusted my gut. I gave the place a chance didn't say anything. We ordered, and then I saw one cockroach. After the second or third one I asked our group to leave. I understand that some bugs are inevitable, but for god's sake buy a roach trap or something. Maybe I'm a little picky, but I think that is well below what I would consider acceptable. They do present some level of health risk.
author: Chaz W.

description: Cheap ($6.95 and $7.95 for curry)--great tikka masala because white meat chicken was actually baked in tandoori oven first and the other one...king of curries..was just okay with chicken thighs with bone.  Naan was fresh, large and round..$2.50 for garlic...probably best to get regular for $1.  Very smoky and kind of a dive bit that is part of the authenticity? Lots of Pakistini folks eating in there.  busy at 10pm.
author: Sandra C.

description:
Freakin' Awesome!!! 

Take it from a guy who grew up eating this kind of food. This is the "go-to" spot for Pakistani grub in the city. Even my parents are crazy about this place. And let me tell you, if you knew my parents... that's all I'd need to say.

Don't let the "bootleg" exterior deter you. The food is fantastic, prices are cheap and the Chai is actually "on-point."

Side Note: Don't mind the crazy, some-what psychotic bums frequenting the streets around this place. Sure they look crazy, but they're generally harmless. More entertainment than anything else.
author: Jimmy B.

description: Best food you can have. Goat karahi is best. Service is excellent and very fast. Staff is very friendly and always happy to serve.
author: Aditya P.

description: Review #1000. Had dinner from here last night and it reminded me of the food I had in Lahore, Pakistan -- fresh, authentic, delicious, amazing. Go.
author: Sam P.

description:
The smokey campfire smell is one of the best things about this joint. The Chicken Tikka Masala was one note and the chicken was overcooked yesterday. The naan was the worst I have had in the neighborhood and the cost with a side of so-so rice $10.20 equals no good value here. Service? Almost hostile. 

Chutney, across the street, is much better and for a lunch special Pakwan is very good. Both these places give you free Chai Tea. All of them give you bad attitude. Lahore and Tikka Masala both have owners who are very nice and the food is good, too. 

This joint is only good if you need to smell like you've been camping.
author: Tom A.

description:
Awesome halal food, had their chicken sheekh Kabab and Shalimar chawal! It was yumm..
The prices are very reasonable.
author: Asma F.

description:
If you are going to stop in here (to eat or pickup), make sure it's the last stop of your day because a minute spent inside will leave you and anything you brought with you smelling like a campfire.

The three things that I would come back for and don't mind smelling smokey for are the delicious tikka lahori (lightly marinated chicken breast cut butterfly style), the seekh kebab mughlai, and the naan which has been unique in my experiences as it has a thin crispy, cracker-like crust. As for all of the curries that I've had from here so far, they aren't lacking on taste but they also aren't lacking in copious amounts of oil either. Somewhere beneath all the oil you'll find the curry you ordered.
author: Erich D.

description:
What these guy are short on personality they make up for in taste!

It's family run hole in wall type place that consistently puts out delicious food. Don't expect ANY extras here! Just tasty Indian/Pakistani at a fair price!

Open late!
author: Robert M.

description: The best indi/paki food I've ever had. It is a loud, not so elegant hole in the wall in a shady neighborhood with the best food. Come for the food flavors and authenticity. Don't come for customer service, clean environment and credit cards-----cash only foolz!!!
author: Toothfreek P.

description: We went here with big hopes. They would not sit us for 20 minutes. No one even came and talked to us. After being ignored such, we left the place. Would never go here again
author: Sushant T.

description: I love Shalimar It is super authentic, overflowing with personality from a bygone era. It's a florescent lit fast paced inexpensive restaurant with news print menu and a BYO brown bag policy. The food is GOOD. There are only a handful of late night restaurants in San Francisco and Shalimar is one of them.  I always seem to find parking within a block of the restaurant which I think is something of a miracle.
author: Jorindajoringe L.

description: Oh. My. God. Delicious! I normally love CTM but the brain masala here is amazing. Goat curry was spectacular and the lassi was nice and smooth. Service was also much faster than expected although the place was packed. Highly recommend!
author: Abubakr E.

description: Cheap, delicious, authentic Indian/Pakistani fare! Cafeteria style and definitely a hole in the wall, but I LOVE these kinds of places. The locale is a bit shady, but whatever; the FOOD is WORTH IT!! The 4 of us stuffed ourselves on naan, lentils and chicken tikka masala for like 30$!!
author: Maria G.

description: the food is great but boy is it filthy! I'm an easy guy and nothing turns me off more than seeing a dirty kitchen, aprons, hands etc....this place has so much potential if they decided to just paint the damn place and get some clean linnen so no real stars for me other than 2 for food
author: sofiane b.

description:
Great food.  Very old country feel to eating in this restaurant.  I continuously return for the excellent dishes.  
Be warned, there is no fluff here.  The restroom is yuck, so if  you have to use it, it is dank.  Every time I come to the restaurant the bathroom is always jacked up, the toilet even backed up and all I did was #1 LOL.  The biggest warning is there is no ventilation, you WILL smell like the essence of every dish in this joint.  Your hair, your clothing.  I always come home undress immediately and put everything in the washer.  Having said that, enjoy the food.
author: Dawud H.

description:
Sooooo good. The naan was fresh and toasty and hot. We had the chicken jalfrezi and the beef kabab between the two of us, with some chai to wash it down. The total - about $11. It doesn't get much better  than that :)

The employees were ribbing my Pakistani friend every time she went up to order, but it's all in good spirit.
author: Victoria D.

description:
Found this place by recommendation from a friend who lives in Fairfield. I asked about places to eat, specifically Indian food and he said, "If you want really good food and don't want to spend a lot of money, go here."

He was right. The location is not the best (tenderloin), parking can be hard, and the locals (transients) are off-putting. But the food was great! The menu is pretty basic, and the atmosphere is a bit dirty, get past all that and sit down and enjoy some great cheap indian food served FAST and simple.

Bring cash and an open mind when you come here, oh and don't forget to order plenty of naan to go with your entrees! 

P.S.- BYOB.
author: Mikey O.

description: The food is really great - reminded my in-laws of Lahore's food! However, don't expect a clean restaurant/bathroom/overall environment.
author: Iqra M.

description: Its no frills ambiance is half the charm, and the food is great. While most restaurants serve impossibly large portions, Shalimar's portions are perfect.  I had the eggplant curry, nann and a mango lasso for less than $10, and I was perfectly satisfied.  At these prices you can try a few dishes.
author: Adam D.

description: It's a dive. It's in a sketchy neighborhood. But it's so delicious that it's become one of my favorite restaurants to hit when I'm in SF. One day I'll visit Pakistan and be able to report back if it's authentic. Meanwhile I rely on the reviews of the friends, colleagues, and people at conferences I take there who've been to predominantly Pakistani countries like England, Scotland, and even Pakistan. They say it's as good or better.
author: Pero D.

description: Amazing food, they have a lot of authentic choices. Prices are great. The only down side to it is the rusty ambience
author: Evelyn Z.

description: Good place for a quick meal if you're in a rush and looking for something super cheap.  Love all the different Naans they have.
author: Edgar C.

description:
A literal hole in the wall.  Like a dirt wall.

The food is good, and from what I've gathered from the locals, it's also pretty authentic.  I found it interesting that the entire establishment is run by men, but I didn't find it interesting to see hair attached to the top of mint chutney bottle.  I watched it sway from the draft of the open door like seaweed at the bottom of the Indian Ocean.  This place is in dire need of a feminine touch.

However, the food is good.  And cheap as balls.  We got mounds of food for 2 for about $20.  I was hoping to get a fish curry, but they had no fish that day.  This kinda thing urks me, especially if it's on the regular menu and not just a special.

The naan was about the size of a frisbee. The temptation was great, but I refrained.  We all have to grow up sometimes.

The masala tea was kinda balls.  

It's a great place for cheap bites with comfortable friends.  Don't expect to fall in love here.

And then my Indian food coma commenced.
author: C J.

description: The food is ok (though not amazing), but the space is neither comfortable nor clean-looking (though much less scary than the Tenderloin location). After ordering I try to stay focused on the conversation I'm having with my dining companion to avoid thinking about the environment I'm in. For a more comfy (and tasty) experience I prefer Lahore Karahi. These days I don't like stress served up with my daal, guess it's a sign of old age!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The prices are very reasonable and the naan is very good. I came here yesterday with two friends, and we paid a total of $24, not including tip (more on that later). 

The curries are very flavorful. We ordered chicken tikka masala, daal masala, and the buhna gosht. The most notable was the bhuna gosht, which had lamb cooked in all kinds of spices (I pulled out a few cloves from my curry). The lamb tasted quite a bit like beef, to be honest, so I loved it, but I couldn't really taste the lamb. My favorite part of the meal was dipping the naan into the curries. Their naan tastes unsalted and was very fluffy and delicious on its own, even without the curries.

I would give this place four stars for just the food, but I'm taking away one star because of the service. We threw down $30 for our $24 meal and asked for change, so we could leave a tip (I thought a 25% tip was pretty hefty for a place where you order at the counter). The guy looked at us funny when we asked for change, and then gave us back a 5 and a 1. Clearly he was hoping for the 5 back. I almost didn't give it to him and wanted to leave the $1 on the dish, but I was in the company of good friends and didn't want to make a scene, so I just took the $1 and left the $5. In my opinion, people who work in the service industry should know to leave behind lots of $1 bills for change, so they can be assured of having a good tip, as opposed to none, which I've done to some bartenders who decided to give me big bills back.

Other than the awkwardness come tip time, I had a positive experience and would come back. Don't wear anything you care about here, because it will all come out smelling like food (well, maybe you're into that sort of thing).
author: Angeline P.

description: Food is very good, prices very reasonable...interior is very bare bones and basic...so this is a place you go strictly for the food! Overall, good experience !!
author: Vic R.

description:
First and last time here, all in one visit.

Flavorful Indian spices, but my paneer tikka masala had a pool of oil on the top and contained hardly any paneer & my boyfiend's chicken dish was filled with bones [big pieces expected because he was forewarned, but we're talking lots of extra random fragments--sketch!] Very poor meat to bone ratio on the hunks, he didn't even finish it.

The service was... awful. Seat yourself wherever. One menu tossed on the table 3 minutes later. 5 minutes after that we were finally told to go to the counter to order. No drinks were ever offered. No food quality check-back. Had to get up to ask someone for dipping sauces. Felt like the guy was angry at me when I got up later to ask for waters. Finished eating, plates all neatly stacked and waiting.. waiting.. waiting.. The guy walked by our table 3 times, never took the stack and never offered our check. Up I go again, time number 3, to the counter. Ugh. 

A less than 20% tip has never been so deserved in my book.
author: Sarah S.

description: Authentic amazing been coming here for years love this place wish it was closer to my home
author: Ilya P.

description: LOVE this spot, but the ordering system they have in place is a little odd. Food was just what you'd expect - tasty and complex in flavor.
author: Rob J.

description: The food here is amazing (especially the naan and the goat curry) and the prices are cheap. An awesome place to stop for lunch on a day trip to San Francisco.
author: Alex S.

description:
Shalimar is the gold standard by which I measure all Indian restaurants.  It's can't-stop-eating-no-matter-how-full-you-are GOOD!  And you can fill your belly 

What is amazing here?  Glad you asked.  I have never been a huge fan of palak paneer until I had it here, where you can tell it's actually made with spinach instead of just green mush.  The okra is gonna change your life.  And the buttery, garlicky garlic naan shimmers like sunshine and happiness.  I have never had anything bad here.

Be prepared to smell like Indian food when you walk out of here, but you'll be reveling in the delicious afterglow and you won't notice until you get home and start getting hungry cause you're smelling it on your clothes.

To sum it up, I heart Shalimar!
author: Linda L.

description:
Only gets 3 stars because of the location. I'd give 4 for the food alone though.

While waiting for friends, there were 3 crack deal and 5 weed deals and I wasn't sure if I was standing in dried vomit, dog pooh or human pooh. Probably all three.

I've heard of Shalimar before. They apparently have a small cult like following for how good the food is. 

Only problem is it's in the Tenderloin. 

Have to say some of the best Tandoori I've ever had. Wasn't over cooked, wasn't over spiced/marinated. You could actually taste that it was cooked over a flame.

I'm curious to try out their Fremont location
author: Leo V.

description:
Was in town for work, and our concierge directed my co-worker and me here, and we were not disappointed.  We both had chicken tiki masala and naan (plain and garlic).  

We didn't know that rice wasn't included with the meal, but we really didn't need it, after using the bread to soak up all that delicious sauce (if I was at home, I would have licked my plate).  It was a little on the oily side, but delicious nonetheless.  Calvin W. - I'm happy to report that my fingers smell delicious.  LOL 

Only negative - we didn't realize that it was cash-only until we went back up to the counter to pay.  Glad it was only $17 (with a soda and a bottled water to drink)!!
author: Becky S.

description:
yay! I'm a fan~ Like the rating, i love this place!

Taste awesome food with less less less money!!

We ordered :
 
- 2 kinds of Naan Breads: Onion Kulcha ($2.00) and Garlic Naan ($2.50). They are definitely my favor. - (5 stars!)

- Chicken Kofta ($5.95): Love the meatball and the sauce. Meatball is totally solid, and the sauce is very match with naan!

- Fried rice ($2.00): Can't believe this plate is only $2.00!!! No kidding~     I suggest to eat with chicken kofta.
author: Rock C.

description:
I came here yesterday for lunch with a friend from San Jose. They have one down there and he really likes it. 
He says this one looks different. To me it looks really run down and kind of dirty. The bathroom is super dirty. =[
We sat down and I was super confused about what we should be doing. All the Indian restaurants I have been to you have to order up front and then sit. We sat there for a while and this guy brings over this menu. It is like a newspaper. Cute! 
We ordered two chicken curries, a naan, and some rice. There was barely any chicken in either dishes and half of our naan was burnt. I liked the rice though.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I've ordered take-out from Shalimar at least a dozen times, and love love love their food. I am not a fan of the dining room, but I like the way they somehow round-down to the next lowest dollar for pricing, and how they always get my order spot-on right.

One tip: when you get take-out, you'll have to prepare a couple of containers of the green sauce and the red sauce (I don't know the real name, sorry) yourself from the fridge, or you won't get any.

I live across town now, and I do miss Shalimar.
author: Greg J.

description:
0MG.
the best. sent me to heaven instantly.
Ive been going there for 15 years,  
best food.
author: Jennifer T.

description: My friend suggested this place because of all the great reviews, so we decided to give it a try. It's not in the best part of town (the TL), but i didnt want have that turn us away; afterall, sometimes the best food is in dive places. When we first walked in, there were a lot of flies in the air (shockingly, still didnt deter me). They brought our food out (missing one of the dishes I ordered) and we started to dig in. The rice and naan were really good, but to be honest, none of the other dishes were all that great. The prices were good, but again not great. I felt like there are better places in the area to try instead of this place. Not to be mean, just the truth.
author: Tyler L.

description:
I love Shalimar!

Shalimar was recommended to me by a couple of Indian friends. When I get that sort of recommendation, I can't resist. We've been four times now, making trips to SF primarily just to go to Shalimar.

Authentic and fresh Indian food, and very affordable. Their Naan is outstanding, and I've yet to have a dish here that I didn't absolutely love. 

Generally people trust me to order when we go to ethnic restaurants. Apparently for a white bread dude, I have good taste in ethnic foods. Shalimar makes me look good, because often I guess and everyone still likes what I order. Even my daughter loves this place!

My only complaint is that the place is very dirty. Only use the restroom if you must! But I've never been against eating at a dirty place if the food is excellent, and Shalimar lives up to its reputation.
author: TJ D.

description:
Prior to our SF visit, we were told Shalimar is the place for GOOD Pak food. So it was on my to do list. While I did not think I could drag my family around looking for Shalimar without some major pushback (group consisted of teenagers, high maintenance tween and tired hubby), after our touristy visit to Union Square, I found this location fairly close by according to my iPhone....and decided to walk to it. The walk was fun as we got to see a diff side of SF.
1st off, Shalimar is not a fancy place. Not a date night place. 
Flagged a guy to get us a table as we were exhausted after the walk (ppl from the East Valley dont walk that much).
Menu had all the standard stuff - tandoori chicken, nihari, mutton chops, biryani, Korma, Karhai, Naans, etc.
Ordered 8 dishes for us 5 (ppl from the East Valley don't have many great Pak food options and get excited at places like Shalimar). Everybody relished the dishes - Mutton Chops, Seekh Kebabs, Nihari, Karhai Chicken, Tandoori Chicken, Magaz (Brain), piping hot naans, Mango Lassi, Chai. Can't recall the dessert we ordered but it was inhaled pretty fast.
The walk back to the trolley was going to be easy as we were stuffed and we could walk off some of the calories we'd consumed. BUT....the area at night looks a bit tough - blessed are we that a very kind SF Native (he happened to be walking along our path and noticed the fear in our 10 eyes I think) walked with us and helped us find a cab to our hotel. 

Bottom line - this is a simple looking place with some very good food! You must try it!!
author: Ayesha S.

description: The location is a little dicey but the food is pretty awesome.  It's cheap and filling.  Reminds me of my curry places in NYC or London.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
At first glance, this is the kind of place I'd never set foot in.  It's filthy and dumpy and the decor is framed posters on the walls, banquet chairs and chintzy-ass tables.  Worse yet, there's poor ventilation so the place was full of smoke from the tandoori oven.

BUT - the place came highly rec'd from an Indian friend who is a caterer and pretty darn picky about his food.  He warned us about the appearance but assured us that the food was fantastic and DIRT CHEAP.

The rec'd was right on the money!  I stop in for some tiki masala every time I'm in SF.  All the entrees we ordered were $6-7 and amazing.  The garlic naan is a little slice of heaven!  Everything is fresh and served up quickly.

Go in with an open mind and a light wallet and you'll leave with a full belly!
author: Scott G.

description:
Not the best and not the worst Indian food I've had.

My mistake was ordering the Chicken Tandoori. At the time, it was very dry and was very hard to chew.

However, the tikka masala made up for it BIG TIME! I don't know what they put in these sauces, but even crack doesn't even taste this good :).
author: FJ H.

description: No doubt... Every time I've come here it's not a disappointment!!! We had lentils today first time and boy I almost finished the entire plate by myself!!!
author: Abby E.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall with some of the most delicious Indian food I've ever eaten.  As has been said, the location and cleanliness of the place are questionable (my host warned me about that ahead of time) but staff is very friendly and it has a good atmosphere. 

So, so tasty.  We had the lamb chops...cooked in the tandoor and deliciously salty and tangy...The eggplant was to die for.  It was one of the most delicious dishes! We also had the "king of curries" and it was a very subtle flavor; chicken just fell off the bone.

Price was awesome, and we took our time without feeling hurried or rushed.  I would definitely eat here again!
author: Amy H.

description: The food is excellent!  Lines out the door.  We were lucky enough to get first class treatment.  The staff was attentive and accommodating.  This place has been around for a while now.  Humble setting...great tasting food!
author: Rachel H.

description:
Grungy atmosphere but great food if you don't mind that.
If you're on your own and want to try a few things, they'll make you a custom plate.
yumm
author: Ric S.

description:
The chicken tikka masala I ordered here was a little greasier, less creamy, and spicier than the type I'm used to, but it was still good. But the naan was totally fantastic. Crunchy yet doughy, and none of it overly charred. You can even see the butter glistening on top. I could go for another piece -- or three -- right now. 

The place is dive-y, for sure, but I didn't see any cockroaches on the wall as another reviewer mentioned. 

Anyway, you should go here, and here's a how to guide:

(1) Walk through Tenderloin. Do your best to ignore the pervasive smell of pee. Tell yourself it's part of the charm. 
(2) Arrive at restaurant
(3) Have one friend immediately scout out a table. Hover if necessary, sit immediately if there's anything open even if it's still crowded with dirty plates and half-finished cups of free chai tea. This is crucial because the kitchen will not cook your food unless you have a table. 
(4) Go up to the counter/kitchen and make your order. Make sure you place an order for your table scouter friend too. Make sure you order naan (I'm not sure if I've made this clear enough) 
(5) Sit down, drink tea. 
(6) Eat. 
(7) Pay with cash at the counter/kitchen
(8) Go to the Davies Symphony Hall and attend a piano recital reeking of curry 

Part 8 is optional, but the rest are not!
author: Ada T.

description:
Between the 2 Shalimars, there's a reason why this one has a half star more, it's better. But...as far as Pakistani Indian goes, this is still not the best around. We did take out, and ordered the usual suspects - bengen, naan, aloo paratha, the paneer masala, chicken (again no fish...) While better than it's sister restaurant, the spices were still missing, and the naan was not fully cooked. And I will never understand why Shalimar does not serve Samosas!!!

So in the tasting contest that was started between my boyfriend and I, Shalimar comes in at 2 stars, and the other restaurant which will be reviewed next comes in as the all time favorite...
author: Laurence B.

description: I practically raised my kids on this food....literally we had at least once a week.  Been going here for over a decade now.  The guys always gave my son a mango lasse and let him watch them make naan fresh.  Dont come for the ambiance come to eat.  Favorites are chicken meatballs, chicken boti or typically called tandoori ,lamb saag, the garbanzo beans and the beef nahiri? The guys usually know so I might have spelling wrong but its stewed beef shank that literally falls apart.  Food is spicy and since some dishes aren't cooked in that facility you can't order levels of spiciness so if you dont like spicy beware.... Free flowing unsweetened chai my favorite.
author: Nins D.

description:
Have been to this restaurant a few times. This time the food taste has slipped considerably. The chicken tikka is bland. The channa dal is not tasty. The karahi chicken is not desi enough. Taste wise it matches the surroundings. BAD   

DO DOUBLE CHECK THE BILL. When I double checked the bill, found out that they never gave us the murgh boti tandoori. But  they insisted that it was served to us.
author: Faisal H.

description: Been eating at this joint since college and not much has changed, food wise, which is great. Spicy deliciousness.
author: julia b.

description:
The food at Shalimar is very good but the atmosphere is not really my style (not meaning to be snooty, I swear!). Plus, I'd rather eat Indian food for dinner than for lunch (because it's so filling!) and didn't really love the dark walk through the TenderNob to meet up with my friend at Shalimar and also the dark walk home by myself... 

Maybe take-out from here would be a good idea? The food is made pretty quickly too so you could just walk in to order and then take your grub on the road to somewhere a little less noisy and less bright...
author: Meghan P.

description:
Back home (and I'm including the UK in this) there's nothing that goes together as well as pints and a curry. So when bumbling around in the Tenderloin at 9:00pm wondering why all the Vietnamese sandwich places were closed, imagine my happiness at ending up at an Indian restaurant.

It's solid Indian food that, for me, hit the spot after skulling a few pints at Whiskey Thieves. Lamb chops were excellent, the chicken jalfrezi tasty, and the chicken tikka was decent. Their chana masala was pretty underwhelming, though. Prices were remarkably reasonable (although the lamb chops were a tad pricey for what you get.)

That said, I'm frankly in shock I partook in the brain masala. That's right, brains. Brains! Braaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaains! Hnaaar! (They were okay - tasted like any nondescript curry, with a slightly odd texture.)

Also gotta love the free chai tea - which was spot on - and even their naan (normally eaten at a minimum to preserve stomach real estate for curried goodness) had me coming back for more.

I do have to knock a star off for the bathroom, which was - I have to say - one of the worst holes in the wall I've ever had to urinate in. And lemme tell ya, I've drained the weasel in some pretty unsavoury WCs. Although I suppose it is the Tenderloin, after all...
author: Gary E.

description: My roommate and I had a hankering for some good Indian food and trusted our good friend, Yelp to give us some advice. We ventured over to the Tenderloin and spotted this somewhat hole-in-the wall. I ordered the chicken tikka masala, plain naan, and mango lassi. The chicken tikka was good at first-usually the dish has a lot of milk/yogurt and is creamy. But, this time I could taste the spices and it was a nice surprise. There were little pools of oil which I was not a fan of and it started to taste a bit mediocre after awhile. The naan was fluffy and warm and the mango lassi was also quite delicious. The service was poor at best, which would normally be fine except we felt outright ignored even when going to order and pay. They only take credit card for $10 or more so make sure you have cash beforehand! A good try but I'm having a hard time accepting it's 4-star rating.
author: Salma R.

description:
Best Indian food in the city! Shalamar is a little hole in the wall place with and open kitchen and excellent food! 

Bring cash and be prepared to wait a few to get a table.
author: Jen E.

description:
Food doesn't get much better (or cheaper) than this. The okra is to die for, and everything seems is exquisitely spiced.  Excellent nan too.

However, if you're the kind of person that doesn't like a fluorescent dining experience, or cracked out panhandlers in the vicinity, or corny pastoral paintings of old Pakistan, then don't come here.  To me, this ads to the charm. But the bottom line is the food is outstanding.
author: Avi B.

description:
Those who read my reviews know I have a bit of a "crusade" against what I call "San Francisco Popular" places - meaning, places too famous and more popular than they deserve to be.

And hardly any of them are a better example of that than Shalimar. Except its popularity really defies logic: the place is in the middle of the homeless cloaca of Tenderloin, it's a true "hall in the wall", stinky, extremely basic, with dirty bathrooms and being Pakistani, they don't even serve alcohol...Oh, you might say, but surely all that doesn't matter before their wondrful, authentic, delicious food?

Wrong.

I am an Indian food connoiseur, even if it comes with a "Pakistani" label like Pakwan or Lahore Karahi. I have to say, Shalimar disappointed me on every count of every dish I ever ordered there. Curries are extremely greasy. Chicken tastes like it doed of natural causes. Lamb is sinewy and tough. Rice looks like it came from a yesterday's vat. Even nan tastes too sour and is not crispy like in other places. 

So, what gives? And more importantly, why do Indian people keep saying "Go to Shalimar"? I suspect it's because they don't want you to discover the places they actully do go to. Because I, for one, do not have any logical reason why anyone would choose Shalimar over any of the other Indopakistani places in the neighbourhood.
author: Evg R.

description: ths place is in a not so desirable neighborhood. The food is great. I have been to the restaurant for years and love their chicken tikka masala and lamb and beef shish kabob.
author: Min L.

description:
Intensely smoke, bright lights, and snail-service didn't take away from:
+delicious garlic naan 
+Murgh Korma Shahi (king of curries, obvi)
+awesome yellow lentils.  
FYI:
+BYOB (we asked for a bottle opener) 
+chai tea at the counter 
+all the extra sauces you would want at the counter. tenderloin field trip!
author: Katie H.

description:
Usual Indian food spot for me is Pakwan in the mission but happened to wander into the "dangerloin" area and decided to try Shalimar as comparison.   Quite an experience and thankfully, food made the trek worth the trip.  Shady characters looming -- fight between some customer and a cook while I gingerly scan the curry coated paper menu.   Ordered my usual of Chicken Leg Tandoori, a veggie dish (Okra), lamb curry, naan and rice.  For $23, it was flavorful and satisfying.  As good and totally comparable to Pakwan.  Flavorful and lamb meat was tender.  

It got crowded by 7pm even though it was a weekday.   Portions at Pakwan may be slightly bigger for about the same price.  One negative for Shalimar is the mini masala teacup for 50 cents--pakwan charges a little more but you can refill as many times.  

Pakwan will remain my go-to Indian food fix becos the mission area is more pleasant than the tenderloin....
author: Anna C.

description: Amazing authentic Indian food. Loved the Roti's and Naan. Very cheap and good bargain for the good except the place and ambience could be much better.
author: Mahek C.

description: I have been coming to this place for over 10 years. Mind you, I have tried Indian Pakistani food all over the Bay Area and keep coming back to this place. Its not much of an atmosphere and service is basic. Where they shine is their food and fresh naan from the oven. My favorites are the chicken tikka masala, chicken meatballs, meat kabab and brain masala. Mixing a side of onions with lemon on the side completes the meal with the warm nan bread. Its a pretty affordable and hearty meal one can get in downtown SF nowadays.
author: George Y.

description: Appetizing Aromas + Divey Tenderloin Digs + Chaotic Counter + Flavorful but Dry Chicken Tikka Masala + Fantastically Garlicky Garlic Naan + Rice + $12.50 = A TASTY TAKEOUT TUMMYACHE  ;P
author: Amy C.

description:
Cheap but SO greasy and terrible atmosphere. Naan was slightly dry, as well. Best thing that we had was the rice....

BYOB is a plus.
author: Maggie J.

description: Always solid food here. Sure it doesn't look like a fancy restaurant and the Tenderloin is sketch   but Shalimar always delivers in quality. Order the Lamp chops and Chicken Tika Masala, you pretty much can never go wrong.
author: Yelper H.

description: My trips to San Fran aren't complete without eating here. It may be loud, smokey and chaotic, but it's all in the good interest of it's mouthwatering food! if you want the true pakistani bbq/grill experience in the states, this is the place to be! I keep it classic - go for the tandoori chicken (topped with fresh lemon), raita (mint based yogurt) and a hot fresh naan. A mango lassi goes great to cool off the spicyness
author: Amna A.

description: My friend and I came here on the recommendation of her aunt.  Don't expect much in terms of ambiance, as the restaurant looks like a cafeteria in need of some personality.  Perhaps that is part of its charm.  (Not if you're a germaphobe though.)  The food is served on mismatched dishes, but who cares?  It is fantastic.  My friend's goat karahi was tender and flavorful, and my lamb brains were well seasoned - a bit greasy but that is probably inherent in the meat.  The naan is wonderfully made in a tandoori oven.  As with many Indian/Pakistani places, chai tea is on the house.  A perfect complement to the meal, especially on cold days.  Try a bit of the digestive that is also by the register (green grains and licorice candy) after the meal.
author: Christina G.

description:
After hearing a lot of good things about Shalimar, I was glad to finally make it out to this tenderloin hotspot to try it for myself.  We went on 4th of July at about 9 pm at night, which I would assume would be a relatively quiet time to have dinner.  I couldn't have been more wrong.  Even at that hour, Shalimar was completely full; every table was being used, and we had to wait a good 15 minutes before being seated.

One thing to note about Indian restaurants: you will usually leave smelling strongly of Indian food.  Shalimar is no exception.  In fact, the restaurant is so small and compact with no barrier between the kitchen and tables and seemingly no ventilation, you will undoubtedly smell like Indian food for a couple days after eating here... not that that's bad or anything...

I was a little overwhelmed when we arrived because of how crowded it was.  I was also confused because there was nobody to seat us and there weren't any waiters.  Everybody was hustling and bustling around and seemed to know what to do.  By watching other people seat themselves and make their way to the counter to order, we figured out what to do.  They have these huge menus that you essentially circle everything you want to order.  You then take the menu up to the counter and hand it to the chef who asks you where you're sitting and then tells you to take a seat.  

The wait seemed a bit long, but that's understandable for being so crowded.  However, I would definitely recommend having more than 1 server bringing food out to the entire army of hungry patrons.

When our food finally arrived, I was impressed with the massive feast before us.  Between the three of us, we ordered tikka lahori (tandoori chicken breast), murgh korma shahi (chicken curry), aloo palak, sindhi chicken biryani, a ground chicken curry (never seen this at an Indian restaurant before, 2 orders of plain naan, 1 order of garlic naan, and rice.  

Everything tasted decent; however I had a lot of trouble getting past the amount of oil resting on top of all the curries.  It was literally just a puddle on top, more than even the cheesiest of pizzas.  It was kind of gross!  Now I've seen oil on Indian food before, at Naan & Curry, but never at a more authentic/ non-fast food Indian restaurant. 

Aside from the unfortunate visual disappointment, the food was quite tasty.  We especially enjoyed the tikka lahori which was spiced and cooked perfectly.  The chicken breast was nice and crispy on the outside, while still being tender and succulent on the inside.  All of the curry's tasted fine.  I would skip the chicken biryani.  It didn't offer much more than the plain rice and the chicken looked and tasted like it had been sitting out for a while.  I will compliment the garlic naan; it was great.  It was packed to the brim with yummy garlic cloves.

Although I left satisfied, I'm not sure if I would come here again.  I've been fortunate to have found other much better tasting Indian restaurants in the bay area.  Don't get me wrong, the food didn't taste bad.  However the location is pretty seedy, it's very crowded and thus service is slow, the curries are way too oily, and bathroom stinks like no other.  I have a fleeting suspicion that my expectations for Shalimar were so high because of all the positive things I've heard about it, that I was ultimately disappointed.  Therefore I would advise to try it for yourself.  Just don't go in with any expectations...
author: Timothy C.

description: Spices used in food are not good quality. This street food of Pakistan. Hygiene is something to worry about. Restroom can't even enter it so smelly.
author: Sean S.

description: The halem was very bad they add indegrident daal in haleem no were in the world you have like this worest halem  in the world will be available here very bad taste
author: Vineeth R.

description: As many other reviewers have pointed out, this is one of the best Indian restaurants in SF. The food here is consistently delicious and high quality. I especially love the vegetable biryani and the garlic naan. Plus, the location is quite convenient if you're going to a show in downtown SF.
author: Diana G.

description: I love this place. I've ordered from here twice already. The chicken karahi and goat karahi are magnificent. It's amazing how tender they are able to make the goat. The saag gosht (lamb) is also very good and not gamey at all. I have not tried the veggie dishes yet but plan to on my next visit. The place is a dive so I would recommend carry-out vs dining in. This is by far my most favorite indie/paki place.
author: Mai C.

description:
With so many good reviews already for this place, there really isn't anything this asian guy can tell you more about the Pakistani food here that hasn't been written.  So let me tell you about the area this restaurant is located in.

A few blocks due east from here we've got the major hotels and the Powell bart station which is a high traffic area for shoppers and tourists alike.  So why is it that every time I walk pass the intersection of O'Farrell and Taylor heading toward this restaurant that I start to feel like one of the following will happen the closer I get to this restaurant:
   1. I get mug.
   2. 1 + a homeless person ask me to help out a brother and I awkwardly pretend I didn't hear him in fear that by giving him something, it might egg him on to harass me.
   3. 2 + I get a good whiff of urine all around me because this area seems to be a mecca for homeless people.

Seriously, the block pass O'Farrell and Taylor is SO different from the immediate area to the east of it.  Even in the broad daylight, I don't feel safe there.

So if you do decide to come here, go in a group and enjoy that janky urine smell in the air together knowing that you won't be bothered if you travelled in a large enough pack.

Oh, also, don't forget to try the chicken tikka masala and garlic naan.  It makes walking here all worth it.
author: Victor C.

description:
I found this place very calm and clean. The food is simple and awesome, The menu is good, you can have many choices, so u can easily choose one of them. very Delicious food in short.
So i"ll come with my friends again to enjoy this beautiful place. And please don"t hesitate to come here and enjoy this place. The prices were reasonable and service was awesome.
author: Hidayat U.

description:
Came in for dinner - and immediately was in disarray. When entering - there are no clear instructions of where menu's are located; where to order etc. 

Afer figuring out the process - I proceeded up to the counter to order some curry; naan bread; and a diet coke and waited for my order to arrive. 

Food arrived - portions appeared to be a tad small; but tasty. After eating, you walk up to the counter - pay your tab and leave.
author: Brian D.

description: Good quality food. We tried their Chicken Tikka Masal and Nihari. Both were to our expectation and would certainly go back when I am back in town.
author: Ray D.

description:
I'd rather go to Chutney's across the street even though Shalimar's chicken tikka masala is spicier and tastes better. Probably all that grease.

I'm reading these reviews and half of the people are saying there's free chai, and half (like me) are saying you have to pay for it. What the hell? If there was chai somewhere, why did you hide it from me? It was on the menu though so I'm pretty sure it wasn't free. If that was the case, what the hell? What Indian restaurant charges for chai? 

Also, their menu is pretty limited, but they do have a better Indian/Mexican ratio than Chutney's. They ran out of garlic naan, and the dude made me deliver the bad news to my friends who already ordered some, and who got mad at me and refused to believe. What the hell, why would I lie about that?

Anyway, mid-meal I see them bring in a huge partially filled tub of some greasy sauce. Seriously, half of it was radioactive-looking grease, like the kind I just slurped down. I'm fine with them taking that ish out of the restaurant, but why are you bringing it back in?!

I'll probably come back one more time though, to get me some more antibodies.
author: May C.

description:
Place is SLAMMIN on a Fri nite! Be prepared for loong lines, but it's allll worth it. And they keep it movin quick so you won't have to wait for too long. One of- if not The best, hole in the wall places in the city. 

The guys that work here are soo nice and accommodating. I went with a large party and they literally ran around putting together tables and trying to make us as comfy as possible. They also managed to get our rather large order straight in the midst of the madness. 

My top pics: saag paneer, mutter paneer, CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA, garlic naan, chai- TRY THEM ALL!! Stuff comes spicy, so if that's not your thing, beware. 

Tab INCL. tip: $100...for 8!! How is that even possible these days?!?!

Shalimar, thank you contributing to one of my cheapest nites out in SF.
author: Shree R.

description:
Not your typical Indian food eatery, but so so delicious. You won't find your typical chicken tikka masala or sag paneer here, but some other really delicious interesting dishes. Greasy, but so so good.

The ordering process is unclear, we ordered at the counter, while others were seated and were served on, but service is otherwise very friendly.

Garlic naan - super garlicky
Okra - yum!
Chicken Karahi
author: Uyen D.

description: I don't expect service from a "hole-in-the-wall" type of restaurant because they make up for lack of good ambiance with good food. That is not the case here. Place was dirty. Food was not served hot. Multiple Items listed on the menu were not available. When asked if they were out for the night was rudely told don't worry about it, they are just on the menu for looks. WTF? Food was ok, not good or great. Go across the street to Chutney for better food that's served hot and you are treated with decency.
author: A G.

description: Unpretentious, unbougified restaurants with authentic cuisine are a rare commodity in a city like San Francisco and I was hoping Shalimar would deliver... Unfortunately I was very disappointed. From a taste perspective, the food was not anything special....the dough for the naans is not made correctly and the curries seriously lacked flavor. Taste aside, there are a number of glaring hygiene concerns that were validated by the fact that my meal destroyed my stomach (for multiple days, and I have an strong Indian stomach...straight up Delhi belly). Finally, the man at the counter was downright rude to me!!! The waiter also rudely rushed me through my meal because a group of his friends were waiting for a table to eat at and the place was full. Nothing more uncomfortable than eating while being glared at aggressively by four burly dudes not so secretly making fun of you in Urdu....that's right smart guys...I understand your language.  *mic drop*, get it together Shalimar...
author: Anish T.

description: My favorite Indian food spot in SF.  You step into the Asian subcontinent at Shalimar invariably.  The interior space & vibe seem so authentic that even if it isn't, you will still believe you are in Calcutta    Try the veggie combo plate with a round of garlic nan.   Shalimar will take you to nirvana !
author: Roland C.

description: Wonderful food at a great price! It doesn't get better than that. The neighborhood is a little dodgy, but it's worth it.
author: D H.

description:
The food is  SO GOOD. 
But the restaurant is SO DIRTY.

This locale is not for the faint of heart. 


Jones is um, colorful, to say the least, and, the flies in the windows do not help, but, I'm telling you, the Murgh Boti Tandoori is TO DIE. 
The spices are perfect, the chicken is so tender, and the portion size is perfect. 

There were six of us, and the service was fast, the waiter was helpful, and the dishes (including two types of naan, haleem, palak aloo methi, chawal, and chicken and beef seekh kababs) were delicious and generous. 


Be ready for cash only!!!!!!
I will go again, but, perhaps get take out. 
De.Lish.
author: A. H.

description: A little hole in the wall, that can't be beat for the price. first time here, and won't be my last
author: rae m.

description:
Dining at Shamilar is truly like entering an alternate universe. On my first visit, I was lead through a dark, wet alley into a small back room where a TV sat atop what looked like a dresser. From the TV blasted programming in a language I do not understand. The menus, delivered upon newsprint, provide your choices. And when the food comes, you will be more than pleased. You will sing out for the glory of it. You cannot find better or cheaper Indian food than this.

On a recent visit, we brought our own beer, which was definitely a plus that enhanced the dining experience. After all, beer and curry are just a very nice combination. They'll even hand you a bottle opener!
author: Miriam W.

description: food is very very good !! ambience is poor though ! but who cares when you have lip smacking food !
author: Ankita M.

description: I'm going to be one of those people who writes a review for the simple fact that I received shitty service when I was in. The food is great, no doubt about it. I brought some friends out to share the experience because I've always enjoyed it in the past. This time the people just seemed so uptight! When we went to pay we had 5 separate cards from 5 people. The guys were barely responding to me and mumbling to each other. One guy said "1 card!" under his breath like he was disgusted. I know how it works- they didn't want to split it because it costs them money! Long story short I stuck to my position and basically told them no, it needs to be on 5 cards, give us separate bills if you have to. The main guy gave in, shoved everything aside like he was pissed, slammed down a calculator (5 people for $100), and got to work. They didn't seem happy yet the did it. So it was definitely NOT true when they claimed they could NOT do it! Likely will not be coming back amymore.
author: David L.

description: Pretty good but not very clean and not good location. Popular place ..gotta love the spice ;)
author: Rate I.

description:
This place has grown on me over the years.  There is a plethora of Indian/Pakistani food in the city but, Shalis stands on it's own.  

Shalimar asks nothing of you.  It is unpretentious and doesn't pretend to be anything more than a hole in the wall.  The lack of cleanliness, the hobos staring in from the windows, and the smell of masala on your clothes are all part of this spot's charm. 

I'd recommend their Tandoori Chicken and Nihari - but everything here is good.  Bring cash and dont wear anything that you want kept smelling fresh.
author: Aasim K.

description:
Getting my hunger on
with my girlfriend gone
I went seeking some naan
like M Night Shyamalan

I took a turn of the street
hit with a smell of smoke meat
and a friendly greet,
this place is effn sweet!

A quick peak at the veggie menu
and Shalimar was a new favorite venue
cause I need not be a billionaire
to eat better than slum dog millionaire

Using my nan as a shovel
my taste buds were quickly pummeled.
Not to be hasty,
 but with a dish this tasty
it's gunna be hard to beat
this palestinian treat.

After this mili juli zasi dish
remains only one wish
which is a kiss
from thee who initiated this.
author: Kai F.

description:
Service is nonexistent, but the food makes up for it.  I like that the prices are cheap and the portions are big enough to fill you but not humongous like most Indian places.  The Haleem ($7) is especially delicious although the amount of meat in there was statistically insignificant, as my friend said.  Garlic naan ($2.50) is also a must with the delicious pieces of minced garlic baked into the middle of the bread.  Mmmmmm... salivating now.

So go in here and take initiative with menu, seating, ordering, or you'll be waiting forever.
author: Liz L.

description:
At places like this you really don't care about the service or ambiance...just great, authentic food (byobooze), smoky, spicy dining room and a belly full of awesomeness.
If you order the garlic nan, you can smell as the fleshy dough is charred just before they bring it out. Then, you peel it apart and there's chunks of fresh garlic in there-joy!! Perfect for a rainy San Francisco night!
The items on the menu are limited, not your typical 8-page Indian restaurant menu, but you don't need much to be completely satisfied here-everything is delicious!!
author: Virginia D.

description: This place is IT for Pakistani food.  Brain Masala rich and deelish!  Tandoor Bohti was the best.  The queen of Tandoor!  Can't wait to go back!
author: John W.

description:
"A pot. A pot belly. Pot bellies are sexy" says Fabienne from Pulp Fiction.

---  Oooo, methinks I can become sexy by making more trips to Shalimar! ---

"No. Pot bellies make a man look either oafish, or like a gorilla," replies Fabienne.

--- D'oh, says I. ---

Whatever the case, I made it down to the Tenderloin again and had to continue my quest for curry.  The first object of my desire was Lahore Karahi (http://www.yelp.com/biz/lahore-karahi-san-francisco#hrid:Uo6Df7_UewhaxQvRbpM6aw), which knocked my socks off.  So the standards were high, but I heard good things about Shalimar.  It was on.

I happened to be here between lunch and dinner, so it wasn't too packed (I was almost worried it would be closed and called beforehand, but they were good to go).  So their menus are basically little Indian cuisine newspapers, with their tasty food the story of the day.  I went with my standard:  

chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, and mango lassi.

MC Shalimar was throwin down the mad beats & representin'.  The masala was bangin'.  I found myself hovering over it like a naan-armed custodian.  I was using my naan to clean up every speck of masala on my plate.  The mango lassi also went down pretty tastily.  

So yeah, between Lahore & Shalimar it's certainly a tough battle.  I'd personally give the edge to Lahore Karah only because I declared their naan fit for sainthood all by themselves.  But yeah, Shalimar is also good all unto itself.
author: Corey G.

description:
Ok, so maybe this isn't really the place for a first date, but the food doesn't leave much more to ask for.  There's a decent choice of food, and the it's definitely delicious.  It is a total hole-in-the wall dive, though, so do all the usual (check your water, try not to look at the floor, focus on your friends)

Everything's pretty good.  The Tika Masala is amazing, and so is the Tandoori (not dry, perfectly spiced/marinated), but my favorite is definitely the garlic naan.  With garlic, and butter, and all of the different curries to eat with it, nothing can go wrong!

Prices are super decent, and if you go with a small group of friends and eat in family style, everyone (who isn't a slow eater) is pretty much guaranteed to come out satisfied.

Oh one warning--try to wear clothes you don't mind getting the Shali-scent on.
author: Emilynne A.

description:
Words cannot describe how profoundly disappointed I was with Shalimar.  i have been coming here since high school, and it has been progressively getting worse and worse.  Maybe it had something to do with the inspectors coming in and requiring the place to be clean?  Don't get me wrong, the place is still a dump, and not a place you'd take your parents, but it used to be the best Indian food in the city.  

Tonight's meal was horrible.  Everything was super oily and they butchered my favorite dish, the lamb chops.  Not only were the lamb chops almost meatless, but they were fatty and barely edible.  They weren't nearly as spicy as I remember, and the rest of the food just did not make up for it.  

It is truly sad.  I used to love this place.  Not anymore  :(
author: Adam E.

description:
What can I say about this place other than that they serve the best Indian food I've ever had in my life...

Well, I ate at Shalimar a year ago while visiting SF, and it truly made an impression on me and my stomach.  A year later, I returned, and I consider myself an adventurous eater, so I don't like the go to the same place twice.  But Shalimar lured me in with their savory curries, tasty sausages, tender meats, and flavorful sauces.  I don't regret eating there again.  I think I will actually make it a point to eat there every time I go to SF.  Shalimar and Sotto Mare, for their cioppino.  Done! :)
author: Christy K.

description:
This is pakistani food.
Flavorful, Moist and Scrumptios chicken, flavored with spices , limes and it's BBQ'd in the tandoori tradition, just $3.50 for the leg/thigh. The flavor is amazing.   A big Frosty King Fisher would have been Nice.
 The $1 naan bread has a light crust on the bottom and puffy and sweet. The Channa (garbanzo beans) was tender and tasted fresh cooked and was dee lish too with its varied spices. The most striking thing about their food is the freshness and spices like i've not tasted before and my tummy Tiger is still smiling. 10 bucks for lunch is reasonable for high quality Indian/Pakistani food. Decor: eh..dive. 
 NO A/C. Service: crude. 
Location: sketchy.
Location: some down and out people circulate outside.

cool indian/paki beats. Good customer service. From FiDi , take the 38L up to Leavenworth and walk one street back to Jones, then walk south on Jones 80 feet and you are there. To get back, just walk down one street to O'Farrell , turn left walk 80 feet and cross the street and you can pick up the 38. Been back two more times, and the chicken leg, while cooked thru was dry; well, its only $3.50 , but could have been more juicy. sorry  moving down to 3 stars.
author: Bert K.

description: I have eaten at indy/pak places around the country, and this place defines it!  Clean...no.  Delicious...YES!  It does not get better than gruppy old men cooking you the best blend of spices you have ever tasted.  As someone else pointed out, you will stink when you leave,  but that's part of the charm!
author: Matt H.

description:
Went here for lunch today. I followed a friend here. He recommended it. So glad I followed. This is one of the best Indian restaurants that I've been to. Definitely cannot judge this restaurant by it's cover.
I ordered Lamb Chops, Chicken Massala, and some naans. All was great.
author: Patrick Z.

description: I love this place! Fantastic Indian food with just the right amount of spice. Classic example of a hole in the wall restaurant with great food.
author: Cori B.

description:
The food isn't great enough to justify a trip to the Tenderloin. The tikka massala had floating puddles of grease but at least the  chicken was moist. The best part was the garlic naan. They use real garlic and it was piping hot when it came out. 

I doubt I will ever visit again as the whole restaurant is dirrrttty. Authentic food doesn't have to be dirrty. The bathroom is the dirtiest bathroom I've ever been in. I went in to wash my hands, but realized that my hands would be dirtier after coming out the bathroom than had I not gone inside.  It makes me wonder about what kind of sanitary practices they use.
author: Melissa M.

description:
The first time I ate here, I was blown away by the chicken tika massala. Not usually a fan of chicken tika, I found it tender, perfectly spiced, and not super dry like you would usually find. The prices are very reasonable for a good meal, and they offer free tea. Cash only, so don't forget to bring cash. Surpassed my expectations, for looking like a hole-in-the-wall place. I couldn't believe my friend said this was his favorite Indian food place when I went in, but understand now. They also had this really good vegetable dish. Really humble, but entirely delicious.

The 2nd time I went in, the chicken tika was more dry, and a not-as-enjoyable experience. Not sure what was different, but I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt. Try it and tell me what you think.
author: Julian K.

description:
The food is yummy! A little greasy but so nicely flavored! And the nahn is amazing, plus free chai tea.  We often eat here for a fast dinner, you will smell bad after but well worth the food!!
Going nowM
author: Kate C.

description:
Lucky us found a parking spot right in front of Shalimar. Even before we parked, a crazy dirty druggie stumbled upon us aggressively panhandled for money. I know we are in Tenderloin, but I was still a bit surprised at how dingy Shalimar looked. I know Naan N' Curry isn't exactly spotless, but at least it didn't have flies distracting me while eating. 

The food, however, is solid. I can't order outside of my comfort zone. So we got two naans, chicken tikki masala and saag paneer, and mango lassi. There was a protruding wooden box thingy near the door that was perfect to place the baby car seat. Not sure if it was by design or by coincidence. 

All the dishes were very tasty. Service was a bit slow even though there weren't that many customers. I guess that's what happens when your food is popular. Looks and service don't seem to matter all that much anymore.
author: Candice B.

description: The food is fantastic, authentic and deliciously seasoned. The atmosphere is extremely casual and not at all catered to American style. The service is not particularly friendly and it is dubbed 'self serve', though there is no buffet and that is totally impossible. SO: go with hungry, avid Indian food lovers who are ok with no service or ambience, and are content with happy mouths and tummies. Or just get it to go. Oh, the newspaper style menu is a funny read too. Yum!!!
author: Sophia D.

description: This place is amazing. I felt like I was eating at a restaurant in Pakistan! It's that good. The workers looked straight out of Pakistan and that's an indication of authentic Pakistani cuisines.
author: Humzah L.

description: The food was very good and south Indian style. It was also very cheap, two of us ate for under $20. The decor of the establishment is very plain,  but represents the authentic simple food you are getting. I would definitely eat here again.
author: Shane L.

description: This place is a shithole but the food is absolutely amazing.  I used to come here a lot in the late 90's and then I moved out of SF.  I came back recently and I swear to god it was still the same old surly dude taking orders.  Nothing at all had changed.  Don't expect any type of service.... You go to the front and order.... Then they bring it out in a rush.  Kick ass tandoori and naan.  The basics, but really good.
author: Anne K.

description: Best Indian and Pakistan food I've ever had. Customer service sucks, decor sucks, but well worth it in the end.
author: Vinh H.

description: This place holds a special place in my heart.  I used to come here about 13 years ago when I was living in San Francisco for school.  This place serves the best Indian food I have ever had.  The menu has hardly changed and every time I visit San Francisco, I make sure to go here.  If you go here, you are going for the food and not the atmosphere or decorations.  Everything is excellent.  I miss the food already.
author: Arash Z.

description: This place is fantastic! Everything we had was very tasty. The only complaint I have was my confusion about how to order, though I am probably more to blame than the restaurant for that.
author: Savi E.

description:
Yes, it's dirty and to prove it the help-yourself-pitcher-of-water I grabbed was keeping afloat what looked like someone's leftover finger crud. The second pitcher proved cleaner but if I had my brita filter I would've dunked it in just to be safe.

I had been here years ago before Yelp was cool and I had tastebuds that  could differentiate between a McDonald's burger and an In and Out burger. We made the journey into the seediest part of SF tonight (and probably of many other towns anywhere) to try what a Pakistani acquaintance from NYC claimed to be the best Pakistani food in the USA.

The food is good I will concur. We had tikki masala, bhuna gosht, and palak paneer with a side order of naan and basmati rice. If the tables were clean, I probably would've licked the food off the table. I'm no connoisseur of Pakistani food but goodness this stuff was finger licking good. 

I will say advise against getting this food to go since it probably loses much of its essence sitting in a Pagoda logo To-Go box while sitting in the front seat of your car. Plus who wants to eat soggy Naan. Don't do it. Just deal with the lunatics and eat there even if it means you have to lose your paneer because you see someone peeing on your car.
author: C L.

description: I love this place dont let the painted yellow walls fool you this place is authentic awesomeness
author: Michael S.

description:
YES.

North Indian/Pakistani food, just as dank as authentic should be. A lot of meat, but a side panel in the menu for 6-10 vegetarian dishes. Hot naan, bottomless chai, SOLD!
author: Jen N.

description:
yum ! whenever im downtown, I go to eat here. i think as long as shalimar exists, i won't get to try any more indian/pakistani restaurants in union square. The food is authentic pakistani - it is at par with restaurants in pakistan even.  Their meat is halal, and always marinated all the way through ! yummm... my mouth is watering just writing about it. They make their own naan bread and is served piping hot. I love their chiken tikka boti, and haleem. The Nihari is also amazing. We tried the brain masala, and it wsn't that good - it was beef and not mutton like we expected, so I guess that's our fault. 

The place itself is very basic, and hardly any waiter service. You have to go to the counter to order and to pay. But in the end, with food this good, nothing else matters !
author: Novaira M.

description:
We have been going to this restaurant for many years and given that this place is a hole-in-the-wall , we have never expected a good customer service from them.  We go there basically for the good food.  However our experience last week was so horrible that we have decided not  to go there any more.

We were a party of 7 with three adults and four kids.  We got there around 5 pm when the restaurant was not that busy.  After ordering the food we waited for over 40 minutes and our food was still not ready.  By this time the dinner rush started and people started lining up for open tables. 

Finally the helper (the only person who brings food, buses table, etc) brought our food.  We noticed our naans were overcooked and burnt.  I asked the guy to take the naans back but he simply refused and ran back to the kitchen.  The kids were hungry so we removed the burnt parts of the naans so they could eat.  On top of that the "aaloo paratha" we ordered didn't show up until we were done with the food.

We ordered chicken tikka, naans, aaloo paratha, and curry.  The food was not that great and none of us enjoyed it especially after eating the burnt naans.  I went up to the counter to pay the bill and told the cashier about the naans.  My intention was to let them know about our bad experience and nothing else.  However I was completely shocked by his response.  He immediately said that we should have returned the burnt naans right away and that people use this trick to ask for discount.  Shocked by his inappropriate and rude answer, i told him that we did ask the helper but the cashier didn't seem to care.   He then mumbled something and then rudely threw the cash register receipt at the counter and said he took out one naan from the bill.  Wow, really?? Instead of just saying sorry or a simple apology the cashier basically assumed that we are trying to trick them into giving us some sort of discount.  This is unbelievable.

We left the restaurant feeling completely disgusted.  This is a very popular restaurant and I am sure they didn't care if we never went back there, but they should learn how to deal with their customers.  No business does well for ever and if they continue to maintain this type of nasty attitude who knows if they will always be this popular.  Even one star is too much of a rating after this experience. We are not going there any more.
author: Aamir W.

description: I usually don't post reviews but my love for all things food coupled with a disappointing experience at this place prompted me to post some. First of all, I grew up in northern India, so trust me when i say I know what north Indian food should taste like. This place offers absolutely nothing like that, despite their claim. First of all, the servers are straight up rude, won't respond to you unless you excuse yourself multiple times to get their attention. After the initial struggle of finding a place to sit, we order our dinner (you have to walk up to the register to put in your order!). My lamb bhuna was a bland mixture of watery curry mix of some sort with precooked chunks of lamb. Nope, that's not how mom used to cook. Rice was an oily amalgamation of long thick rice with rice color. Big fail again; I asked for basmati rice, not whatever you had available. Paneer masala was worst I have ever had (after living in places like Texas, LA and Seattle). The only good thing was the naan because it was plain, simple, made in an actual tandoor (indian oven) and felt like home-Either. The place does not feel very hygienic either. And to top that, a homeless woman walked in (probably looking for something to eat in a freezing cold night) and these guys practically manhandled her, dragging her out by her arms and legs. You couldn't give the poor woman some bread/curry and let her walk out on her own? It's Christmas night tonight FFS! This is the most over-hyped place in SFO. Either the yelpers on here don't know what Indian food should be like or they have a very poor taste in patronizing an establishment that is worth the vote. Top 50 place in America? Yelp needs to hire better reviewers, especially for Indian food, particularly in SFO.
author: Dj L.

description:
Some background:

Lived in Delhi for 5 1/2 years; know my way around the galis of Nizamuddin, Old Delhi and Mehrauli. Consider myself a connoisseur of mughlai cuisine.  Worked and travelled all over India (IMHO, the best non-veg curries are in Amritsar) and searched for the best street food wherever I travelled in the sub-continent.

***

Summary: if you want to have fairly 'authentic' (for SF) mughlai food (including something of the dhaba experience to boot) then go to Shalimar.


Reviewers: most goras are clueless. If you wrote "I had the CTM..." Hey, you just outed yourself whitebread. :-)

About the Oil-slick: get used to it. Authentic mughlai cuisine is all about that.  Places that don't have it... I avoid them, they're compromising themselves for the weak of heart and stomach.

Cleanliness: to John B R. "Indian pork chops" yeah right, in a halal muslim joint? Others--oh well there's always Chipotle. Anyways, man-up and grow a pair.

The Food: I have low expectations when it comes to Indian fare here. So I was pleasantly surprised by Shalimar. They serve nihari and other more obscure (at least in Americastan) Mughlai khanna.

We ordered the  Saag Gosht, Nihari, Chawal, Dal, Naan and I made a special request for Tandoori Roti. The nihari was fairly close to the versions I've had in Delhi, though doesn't hold a candle to Haji Noora's: http://eoid.org/2006/11/06/haji-noora-ki-nihari/

The beef was very soft--of the correct consistency--showing that it was stewed for a very long time under low heat, as it should be. 

I had to ask the guys for the requisite garnish of chopped chilies and lemon wedges, since they didn't serve them with the dish. And I had to go and ask for a plate of onions and jalepenos (something they give to their regular south asian customers automatically, it seems.).

The saag gosht, daal and chawal met my expectations and were quite good. The naan was okay, not wonderful, but good. 

The big disappointment was the tandoori roti. This everyday staple was akin to a dry cracker; far worse than any you would get from even the most basic roadside dhaba.
author: Tak N.

description: This is a hole in the wall joint....super easy on pocket and quick service. The best kababs I ever had in bay area... Chicken Tikka Masala is my favorite. deducting two stars as food is oily here...
author: Astha S.

description: I have been eating in this restaurant for two weeks now. I have tried lots of items from menu and virtually all of their food tastes delicious. Some may find curry items little spicy compared to surrounding other indian restaurant. But I will always remember this place for its best chicken tandoori, either legs or breasts. Best chicken tandoor in the town.
author: Krishna L.

description:
The food is the best food I've had in SF yet. 

I just recently moved here and I remembered going out to eat here from three years ago and had to find the place. I am so happy I did- the food is still amazing and incredibly well priced.

I would give it 5 stars except for the fact that this is the kind of place where you go for the amazing food, but not for the decor or service. 

Also- it is in a bad area so for those you not from here, I recommend only going during the day.
author: Apryl S.

description:
Care to have diarrhea?  Then come to Shalimar, where they run out of your favorites so you're stuck ordering Indian pork chops that oddly resemble pig fetus, all while paying way too much for the portion size!!

Shalimar--- when you're here, you're fucked.

"Fist her? But she's my sister!!!"
-Jake Gyllenhaal
author: John B R.

description: This place has been open since FOREVER! I always smell the cooking while walking home. I always saw the crowds outside, waiting to get in. It took years before I even stepped foot inside, but once I did, I regretted not coming here sooner. The location is smokey and dingy. The lights are all fluorescent. There's this grimy cafeteria charm. Oh, but the food is far from cafeteria food! Yum! Yum! Yum! Halfway in, the whole table began removing layers of clothing. It was getting hot! Loves it! My HAPPY METER after eating here is definitely high up there...but it gets FOUR stars only because Chutney's right across the street BLOWS MY PALATE!
author: Helen L.

description: total dive spot with some tasty food. Unless it's late night, I would actually recommend going across the street to Chutney.
author: Blake N.

description: The best Pakistani restaurant in the city.  My favorite are the lamb and the lentil dishes.  I am always satisfied when I leave.
author: Felix C.

description: The Pakistani restaurant that started the revolution back in the 90s is still going strong. Incredible barbecue items especially the chicken tikka and the piping hot naans. The curries particularly the beef nihari are great. Hi on Spice and Low on decor  but still a great Pakistani restaurant
author: Umair K.

description:
Not quite the Shalimar Gardens of Lahore, Shalimar of SF is nonetheless an exotic destination worth visiting.

I enjoyed my food here, but was not really into the hectic, aggro vibe of this place. We practically had to strong-arm our way to a free table despite having entered the restaurant well before those who tried to challenge us for it. I'd understand if we were in New York or France, but this is San Francisco, people. We're supposed to be more aloof and cool about these things than that. We tend to know what lines are and how they work, at least for the most part.

I CAN say that I was impressed with the food and the ambiance -- once we sat down, that is. We ordered daal (lentils), chicken tikka masala, lamb of some kind, rice, naan....and definitely something else but can't remember due to brain damage. It was all really tasty, hearty, but not very spicy. The sauces that they have on the tables (tamarind and yogurt-cilantro/mint(?), I think) do the dishes some real justice. Try them out!

A good place to eat Pakistani/Indian if you don't mind fighting for tables and touring through the Tenderloin.
author: Nicholas F.

description:
This place is always I mean ALWAYS busy! You'll know it is good when they get so many customers!! 

Cash only and one of the best food you will be able to eat for a reasonable price.
author: Aylee G.

description:
Everyone rants and raves. I have yet to be impressed.

Although cheap and decent food for indian food I have had better. Service isn't much to speak of- since its an order upfront-wait for your food place- and never see anyone again.

I ordered a mango lassi- and afterwards all I wanted was a glass of water. I walked up and asked one of the guys if I could have a glass. They nodded and told me they'd be right there. 10 minutes pass. No water. And within those 10 minutes no one had come in so it wasn't like there was a huge crowd where they were distracted. I asked again and the guy gave me an annoyed look and finally came with the water. Was I asking too much?

Also in other places I either get complimentary salad or tea. This is not to be found here.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Very authentic "dhabaa" (by Indian definition, tasty food in a shabby looking space) style food. Absolute best! 

I love the lamb curry, palak paneer, chicken curry but the best dish to get is sheekh kabab. Their garlic naan is the most unique in the world - they stuff garlic inside the naan instead of dabbing on top! 

Free "tasty" Chai which tops it for me! 

Take Cash only.
author: Sangeeta N.

description:
Tikka Tikka Tikka....Masaaaalaa...Masaaaalaaa...Masaaaalaaaa...sounds
like some tribal encantations and it will really put you under a spell because it's so freaking good. Ok that was kind of corny but you get the point.

But thank you Shalimar for introducing me to the wonderful foods of Pakistani/Indian culture. I will admit that I was a bit afraid to try new things, especially something as foreign as Pakistani, but Shalimar opened the door for me and I will forever keep coming back.

Ok, first things first. It's pretty much located around the TL (Tenderloin) and it's pretty damn ghetto at night (being straight-up honest with you). You'll get your occasional homeless guy/gal asking you for change and this WILL HAPPEN for sure. Although it's pretty ghetto, it's not dangerous at all as it's pretty much downtown so there's a bunch of people and stores around. 

The store itself? It's pretty ghetto, Pakistani-style, which is what I like to see. None of that Americanized food that caters to the American crowd but it's straight-up what you'd probably see if you went to Pakistan (I'm assuming). It's crowded, humid, dirty, and you'll end up leaving smelling like lamb....I LIKE!

The service is pretty quick and simple. They don't suck up to you like waiters are supposed to do (because they want a fat tip) but rather ask you what you'd like to order, deliver you the food, and collect the bill. As simple as that. One thing I didn't like is that you have to fetch your own water from the fridge (and your own cups). We kind of waited a while before we figured this out.

The food? We ordered:

1. Chicken Tikka Masala - favorite dish. You can smell the aroma of the different spices used in the dish and it tasted the way it smelled.
2. Saag Gosht - no idea what this was beforehand but ordered it because everyone else seemed to be ordering it. It's basically lamb + spinach. Eh...it was ok.
3. Basmati Rice - colorful rice! Goes well with the curry/naan.
3. Three regular Naans - Get the Naan regardless of whether it's regular or garlic and eat it with your curry/rice.
