Total Price/Person (plus taxes/tip) = $12

Money well spent on Dinner.
Total price
author: David W.

description: Mango lassi is nothing to write home about but everything else I got was delicious and authentic North Indian/Pakistani.
author: Russell B.

description: Yummy! Enough said! & I'm picky about taste lol FYI sit yourself and ask for service
author: Angie O.

description: The food is fantastic. really one of the best i have ever had. However the location is really bad (like prostitutes and dirty massage places next door or down the street) plus it seems like they are breaking a bunch of health code violations. The service isn't so great either. They have a strong loyal customer base people like my uncle who go there for breakfast lunch and dinner. I personally just want better service and and a cleaner restaurant to eat at. Despite all of that I would still go to eat there and bring friends. The food just is that good.
author: Sarmad N.

description:
We came here to Shalimar to have lunch and bid farewell to one of our coworkers.   This place is not near my office by any means... A solid 15 minute fast walk will get you there, but that's certainly a good way to open up your appetite...

We ordered all kinds of food but my yardstick, as always, is their Chicken Tikka Masala, and it was very very good...   Shalimar certainly deserves 5 stars as it's clearly great Indian food in the City.   That said, it got talked up so much to me by coworkers that I nevertheless felt slightly disappointed...    That, perhaps, was simply symptomatic of the company with whom I shared this meal.   Face it, however much you like your coworkers unless you're truly great friends the meal won't carry the gravitas it would if you shared it with people you truly love.

Anyway... Chicken Tikka Masala and Basmati rice... Fucking hey yea!  And the Naan they served was piping hot, too... and we got an obscene amount of food for $13 a person, tax and tip included... So yeah boyee... I'll certainly be back!
author: David O.

description:
S o it's not the cleanest place in the world
H ad difficulty, too, figuring out how to order, get drinks, pay, etc.
A side from those shortcomings, the food was awesome
L oved the curry's flavor of the Chicken Tikka Marsala
I t went great with the huge piece of Garlic Naan
M ight be a lil' tough, but the Tandoori Chop was tasty and not gamey
A ll went down well with the milky Mango Lassi
R emember: order at the counter, self-help take-out boxes, cash only
author: Anthony N.

description: not oily like most other pakistani/indian joints in SF. tasted home-cooked. got Goat Karahi, Chicken Karahi, Shalimar chawal, and Naan. SO SO SO delicious and well-made. it's in a dingy area and not too glamorous inside but the food and fair costs absolutely make up for it.
author: Shilpa D.

description: I ordered the Murghi Korma shahi chicken dish (first on the menu under chicken dishes). The guy who took my order recommended it.  I almost thought it was some kind of joke but the chicken covered in the sauce was 90% bone parts of the chicken including chicken spine pieces.  I tried to just eat the sauce on the rice but the sauce had bone shards that I bit down on and had to spit out. I had to leave without eating any of the rest.  It was a horrible horrible lunch experience and I'm going to have nightmares about that chicken for a long time.   Worst Indian food I've ever tried in the US.  Truly inedible and I want to throw up just thinking about it.  In addition the employees were not friendly or welcoming at all.
author: Sally B.

description: Cheap, good, Pakistani food. Good Naans, Lamb Chop, and Okra.  The Haleeem could have used some more bite.
author: Harry C.

description:
How good is it? Just take a look (smell) at how disgusting the bathroom is! Does it stop anybody from eating here? Apparently not - there's often a wait for a seat!

I was talking to a South Asian couple who told me they've been driving up from South Bay for 15 years, and spending $20 on parking each time, just to eat here. (And there are some really good Indian restaurants in South Bay, too.)
author: Adam Z.

description:
The best chicken tikka and tandoori chicken anywhere, including India.  Also excellent kebabs.  The other food is delicious but also needlessly greasy, so much so that I usually get only the "dry" food.  My pat down technique works for some disher better than others.  Patting down involves repeatedly degreasing the food with napkins, each time being careful to peel the napkin slowly from the corner.  This removes the oil but keeps the good stuff in the plate.

The Polk location is less sketchy than the Jones location.  They also have a location in Fremont and Sunnyvale.  Of all, I find the Sunnyvale location the best.
author: Sanjay M.

description:
Best Indian/Pakistani in town! This review is solely based on the food. 

My favorite must orders!

- Potato Naan - soft pillowy and piping hot! the potato naan is stuffed with potato crumbles, no where else makes it the same
- Goat Curry with Ginger - don't be scared it almost like beef with a slight gamy aftertaste
- Chicken Tikki Masala - sauce packs heat, but is also sweet and hearty
- Beef Brisket - fall off the bone succulent

They use to let you bring in beer freely, now there's a no alcohol sign. Since beer and Indian go hand in hand, How do i get around this you ask? they have a "don't ask don't tell" kind of policy. pour your beer in one of the cups they provide and as long as you keep the bottle under the table your good to go.
author: Maggie L.

description: four stars for the great food,. me and my husband eat here every time we visit SF.   They offer garlic bread nann, curry, veggie plates, and their chicken is amazingly soft and tender. !! ****
author: Jewl B.

description:
Service: 4
Food: 3
Price: 4

First things first, this is a good place to get decent food after most restaurants close, and they deliver.  That said, it's not the kind of place you go to for service or ambiance--you're looking for cheap, good food, or at least I was when I went.

Bearing that in mind, service was fine (friendly and prompt).  Price was okay, although not exactly cheap for takeout / fast food.  

The food was good, not great.  Given the positive reviews this place has garnered for its food from lots of other folks, I'll focus only on what we ate when we went.  The channa masala was tasty, spicy and well cooked.  The rice pilaf was well flavored, but served a little cold.  The garlic naan was delicious (in itself a great snack or meal).  The chicken curry, though, was a let down: it wasn't well cooked or seasoned, and it was more bone than chicken.  I think chicken curry is a good litmus for an indian restaurant, so that's what discolors my opinion about this place most.

Overall, Shalimar is probably a better bet than any comparable takeout Indian restaurant open late, especially in the area.  But for the money and quality, it's not all it's hyped to be.
author: Naveen A.

description:
4.5 stars.

I've only tried Shalimar once (we got take-out on 03/08/10 from the Jones St. location) and all the luscious flavors are still fresh in my memory. We were aiming for Lahore Karahi initially but it's closed on Mondays so we ended up looking for an alternative: Shalimar it was (and a good one at that).

For 3 people, we ordered:

* GARLIC NAAN - $2.50
* ALOO PARATHA - $2.00
* CHICKEN KOFTA - $6.95
       - [5/5 - Very well seasoned, amazing blend of spices, great texture - soft but not mushy.]
* CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA - $6.95
       - [5/5 - We LOVED this version of chicken tikka masala so much, the 3 of us attacked & conquered this dish before we got to everything else.. The only thing wrong with it is how few pieces of chicken there were (pretty much the same amount you get at most places).]
* ALOO KEEMA - $6.95
       - [4.5/5 - Very good, smelled great, tasted yum.]
* DAAL MASALA - $5.50
       - [5/5 - I LOVE DAAL. And this is some GREAT yellow daal.]
* CHUTNEY - $0
       - [5/5 - Okay, yeah, chutney's free. However, since I always NEED chutney with my Indian food, I have to mention - their chutney was YUM!]

I like to stick to the safe things when I'm trying out a place I'm hesitant about.. Next time, I'm trying the Brain Masala and the Tandoori Chop. 

P.S. I still think of you with deep affection.. and await our next encounter with a hunger you can't squelch.
author: Asha S.

description: The food was outstanding, great flavor and very fresh. Service was sparse with self service ordering. The ambiance was authentic based on my time in Pakistan.
author: Clifford C.

description: Great food. At first glance the location and the actual place seemed sketchy to me, but the food more than made up for it. Delicious! They do not have a license to sell alcohol so bring your own. Luckily in the tenderloin there are liquor stores everywhere.
author: Andy G.

description: Awesome restaurant. Sketch neighborhood which justifies the cheap prices but food is unbelievable.
author: Karan K.

description: I go to this restaurant all the time.  It is in the Tenderloin so obviously the facilities aren't the most cleanly, but the food is delicious and the atmosphere is very relaxed.  Walk in, grab a table, order at the counter, grab a pitcher of water and some tea, and wait for the drool-worthy Pakistani food to arrive.  Don't let the homeless people on the corner fool you, this place is top notch.  Grab some beer at the corner store (BYOB) and relax.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Shalimar is the jam.

Try the chicken tikka masala and the garlic naan, and bring your own beer.  I docked them one star because the masalas tend to be a bit more greasy than I like -- but that's just my personal preference.

One piece of advice: This place has a distinct campfire+food scent that will definitely stick to you. Don't wear your bedazzled jean shorts here if you don't want them to smell like delicious Indian / Pakistani food for a while.
author: Justin S.

description:
Tried the Chicken Karahi with a couple yelpers recently and its flavor had me drooling.  Only downside was that the chicken came in lots of bony little pieces, which was probably quite authentic, but constantly pulling bones out of my mouth isn't quite in sync with my western sensibilities.  My buddy's Tandoori Chicken wasn't quite as flavorful, but it did come in more reasonably-sized drumsticks and chunks.

My visit's highlight: when I asked if there were any available side veggies, I was offered a sliced raw onion.  I don't think we need to worry about these guys selling out to the masses...
author: Geoff D.

description: Shalimar has been one of my favorite local places to enjoy Indian/ Pakistani cuisine since 1995. The food is simply delicious and the atmosphere is very predictable. Though the restaurant is located a short distance from Nob Hill and Union Square, you might as well be dining at a roadside joint in Lahore, Pakistan. Recommendations:  Saag Gosht, Daal Masala, Garlic Naan and Shalimar Chawal.
author: Michael O.

description:
It is hard to beat this delectable mix of aromatic flavors for the price. It is not always the most consistent in terms of taste, quality and freshness, but it is almost always good.
Hint: If you enjoy the sultan chicken, try it in the Chicken Saag, and get it in spinach, thereby getting a vegetable with your meat.
author: Lance X.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times and cannot talk it up enough.  Expect gritty unassuming ambiance, friendly service, but more than anything, the food is outstanding.

I have taken people here who thought they didn't like Indian food, and they were equally blown away.  I can't recommend any one dish, just get what you want and hopefully you can try a few dishes and share.

Sitting outside and BYOB is great as well.  Cheap food too.
author: J P.

description:
I order from here to go on the way to class. The food is excellent! Rich and tasty, you really can't go wrong with any item on the menu. I always get the chicken tikka masala and sometimes the dahl. 

I am only rating the food, the surrounding area is a bit iffy and the inside is so so, but the food is what's important!
author: Erik R.

description:
Who hasn't been to Shalimar? 

Cheap... Spicy... and if you want alcohol you can BYOB... Sounds like my friend's xboyfriend! Oy' ve!

The hole in the wall that everyone knows about!

Date Rating: 4
Pick up Scale:2

Strong Suggestions: Bring some antacids if you need them... this place is going to light your mouth on fire! Yum yum yum!
author: Megan C.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Location: Tenderloin (I don't mind it)
Ambiance: Third World (so you get to travel without leaving SF)

Take a walk on the wild & grimy side!  I may be touched in the head a bit, but I drove 6 hours with only a 5 min rest/gas to get to this place on time for lunch. A total dive, don't use the restroom either, just go in, order, eat & enjoy, leave.  A good friend got me introduced to this place and I'm eternally thankful. I've had everything on the menu in my 3 trips to this place.   All chicken dishes, tikka masala & korma in particular, are great. There is a rice dish with caraway, and lots of naan, the kabobs are great.  Just take a chance and order 4 things and enjoy...yeah, also, don't worry about the calories, you'll burn them off running from the local muggers!
author: Darius S.

description:
On the recommendation of a couple of folks, I decided to take my husband out to Shalimar for dinner. Now mind you, I'm no foodie nor one to go to expensive restaurants. I didn't go to Shalimar expecting ambiance. In fact, I fully expected it to be small and squalid, cheap, and likely minimal customer service. But I will gladly take all of that if the food is good. Shalimar was all of these things except one: the food was just as terrible as the rest of the experience. After wading through the expected tourists and panhandlers in the Tenderloin to get there, the place was full, but quickly emptied out. We got seated and were given a marked-up paper menu, then realized after deciding on food and sitting there that we needed to go up to the counter to order. Then we sat back and waited. And waited. Even though the number of employees working likely exceeded the number of patrons in the restaurant, we still waited for over a half hour to get our food. I made a special request for a knife to cut into my tandoori chicken, which was way overdone and rubbery. Rice was lukewarm; the chickpeas, meh.They were out of the lamb dish my husband wanted to order and the lamp chops he ordered instead suffered the same overcooked fate of my chicken. By that time we both smelled like the inside of a tandoor oven and tried to pay up and get out of there, but apparently for this (cash-only) transaction, you have to wait for the indifferent waiter to get to your table to reconcile the bill.

To top it off, on the way back to the car, we nearly stepped in human excrement on the street. A product of the neighborhood, but definitely epitomizes our experience dining at Shalimar.
author: Megan K.

description:
Great Mutter Paneer, rice, and Masala Chai!
It's definitely not the cleanest restaurant in the world because it has an open kitchen so you can smell all those raw fish and meat when you get close to the counter or get a cup of chai, plus it's located at Tenderloin, but if you want cheap and delicious Indian/Pakistani  food, this is it.
Another plus is that they gave me a cup of free chai when I walked in the next day and wanted nothing but a cup of masala chai.
author: Michelle N.

description: Grubby little place where the air is thickish with curry oils and it's the classic Naan n' Curry setup. No free chai though. Curries are  nice with big chunks of meat though both of the things we ordered tasted exactly the same. We couldn't even tell what was chicken and what was lamb. Meat kinda just falls apart and is a little stringy from overcooking. Strange. Naan was tasty, though a little too crackery for me. I like doughy plus singed. Nice alternative option if you give up hope at Dottie's next door.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Dude. I LOVE Shalimar. Last time I was here, people literally almost go into a fist fight over a table. You know it's good when people are willing to throw punches.

I loved everything I had there.. and the prices are GREAT. Dirty, I know... and service can be improved...
author: Mary C.

description:
I came here like two months ago so the details might be a bit fuzzy. 

I love Yelp because I love going to places like this. A hole in the wall with not so great service or decor. The food however was superb and decently priced. 

I got the Butter Chicken and Garlic Naan while my friend ordered the Chicken Tikka and some roti. We were both really happy with the food.  Its in the Tenderloin so you might want to go with a friend if you are considering this place. 

It wasn't the best Indian/Pakistani Food I've had in the city - but it was definitely the best value for money. 

Definitely plan on going back sometime soon.
author: Rohith S.

description:
This quick n dirty Pakistani restaurant belongs in the heart of the dark, seedy Tenderloin. I personally haven't been to it's nearby contenders, but after eating here, I can vouch for the quality of it's food.

I ordered saag ghost and garlic naan. The entree was nearly entirely spinach, which normally I don't care for, but the oily goodness alongside the fresh garlic naan was heavenly. For a moment, I wished I could keep eating, without the constraints of health and diet. I've only been here once, but based on this single experience, I feel safe ordering anything else here.

I ate half of the saag ghost and one garlic naan, which is one sizable serving. I then ordered another garlic naan and boxed the other half to take home. I later found out the delicious garlic naans are $2.50, and my bill came out to $13. I don't regret it all.

Come here if you're craving South Asian meat and curry dishes. Again, this is not a pretty sit-down restaurant where you take your time drinking and mingling. It's a place where you grub. You order at the counter, sit down, and prepare for destruction. The destruction of food and your stomach.

On some nights I can still hear a voice in my head chanting in a cultist Temple of Doom tone, "Sha-li-mar! Sha-li-mar!"
author: Rahil P.

description:
This review is based on trying this place out while I was staying in SF for a music festival. I pulled up Yelp on my phone to search for places near our hotel that were cheap and had good reviews, and since I haven't had Indian food in a while I figured I'd give this place a shot. 
I looked up the menu online ahead of time and once I figured out what I wanted I headed down there to order. Ordered the beef jalfrezi, chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, onion kulcha, and a box of rice. It was on a Thursday night, the wait was just like the guy at the front said (about 15 minutes). They actually accept cards so that was nice (I was expecting to pay cash). The reason I knocked 1 star is definitely for the cleanliness of the place...it really has a grimy feel and you can see the kitchen past the register and that doesn't look very organized either. Also the waiting area is tiny, and as more people started to come in we went outside and there are definitely some seedy people roaming the streets but overall were harmless. 
Now the food itself was really really good. The chicken and beef were both SO tender and juicy. There was quite a bit of sauce but it was perfect for mixing with the rice and dipping the breads in, mmmm. There was also so much food that my boyfriend and I had a hearty dinner and then still had enough for lunch the next day. I'm sad this place isn't closer to home because I would definitely want to come back and try more items here.
author: Vita S.

description: As again no surprise and shalimar stands out compared to all other restaurants in north cal. Can do better with adding more space and making it family friendly.
author: Zak M.

description: I was so happy when we walked in to see that we were the only non-Indian/Pakistani diners in the restaurant.  It gave us a feeling that the food was authentic.  We were certainly not disappointed.  It is not fancy at all but if you want a very good Indian/Pakistani meal, this is the place to go.
author: Carlos G.

description: I used to think all Indian food tasted the same, but Shalimar proved me wrong. I had to follow the pack of Yelp wolves and get the chicken tikka masala that definitely did not disappoint. My suggestion: make an Indian taco consisting of garlic naan (and trust me, the garlic is plentiful and amazing), chicken tikka masala, and a shit ton of the cilantro sauce and you will indeed reach nirvana.
author: Jerome C.

description:
This is one of three of my favorite Indian restaurants in SF.  Guess what?  One of the others is a Shalimar as well.  ;)

What can I say? They offer magnificent food at GREAT prices with friendly service.\\

They were very accommodating even tghough they don't take reservations. I showed up with 10 of my friends for lunch and they made room for us without making the place feel crowded..

We'd get loud and it didn't seem to bother anyone - it was a birthday party.

Important notes:

They only accept cash
They do not take reservations

You can order mango lassi by the JUG!  =D
author: Anita J.

description: One of the best food places in the city, the only reason I come to this place is because Indian food usually tends to be heavy and stays with u for a long time, but the food here is so light and u'll never feel bad(calories) if ur eating in limit. :)
author: Parikshit T.

description:
My very first taste of Indian/Pakistani food was here and I was hooked since.  Coming from a Cantonese background, I didn't experience food with to much bold flavors growing up.  So when I find new cuisines with so many kinds of spices and flavors I go all out.  I tend to go on these binges where I eat that particular cuisine until I get sick of it.  I tried many Indian places and although other places are good (and some bad) Shalimar  is may favorite.  The garlic naan, chicken tikka masala, bhuna khost (lamb) and the palak paneer (spinach and cheese) are my top pics here.  You can ask for this marinated onion and jalapeno thing that goes well with everything. 
Highly recommended!
author: Mike K.

description:
So delicious I don't even think about the calories.

It is worth the trip to the Tenderloin, but I have to admit, it is a little too divey for me.
author: Sarah C.

description: Great food! Best lamb chops, chicken, and mango yogurt drink ! Very authentic and tastes great , only thing is that the dining area is old and needs new furnishing , they should offer more seating area since there were a couple of times when I went that I just had to get it to go, but the great tasting food makes up for it.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
I don't think that I'm the best judge of Indian food considering I enjoy the boxed palak paneer from Trader Joe's but nonetheless, here goes my take.

This is another hole in the wall joint that I'd heard raves about for months since I became a loin dweller. I had been wanting to try it for a while but it's rare that I feel like ordering Indian food since it's so heavy. I finally found my excuse when my friend and I walked back from that lame excuse for a Yelp holiday party  (or as I like to call it, a really long line) and decided to swing by and get take out from Shalimar.

We ordered the chicken korma, palak paneer and onion naan. The naan was the best part for me. The chicken korma was a close second but the palak paneer was a little too oily for me. They did a pretty good job of keeping it mild even though when I asked them for less spice they looked at me like I was an alien.
author: Julia N.

description: 5 stars for the food, but the place is little dirty,dark and rundown.
author: Sumalatha R.

description: Not my favourite spot. The food was reasonable and the staff was nice and welcoming which was cool, but I can't say I "get it". Maybe I'm missing something here cause everyone seems to love this place! But I wasn't a big fan. I found the curries a bit runny and the naan was a bit overcooked when we went. Also the neighborhood was not the greatest and the vibe felt kinda grungy. People seem to love it there but I've definitely been to much nicer Indian spots in the city.
author: Mike J.

description:
This place looks really bad from the outside. It looks even worse when you go inside. It smells terrible. Customer service is almost nonexistent. The food, however, is AWESOME! 
Goat Karahi was the first thing I ordered at this place. One year later and many many many more visits and I still haven't tried anything else. Yes, it's that good.
author: Arash Y.

description:
This place is cheap but the food is SOOOO greasy!!! There was a half-inch layer of grease in our takeout container. Yuck.

Also, the area is superrrrrr ghetto and the whole restaurant is filled with smoke from the kitchen. I was in the restaurant for about 2 minutes and feel like I have to shower again just to get the smell out of my hair. 

On top of that, the cashier is freaking rude.
author: Cece L.

description:
Awesome food. That pretty much sums it up. 

Other bonuses:
* Fast service
* Relatively simple menu
* Free tasty chai (unsweetened)
* Authentic
* Sufficient water pitchers were supplied to our 10-person table.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Saag Gosht, Tikka Masala, Free Chai Tea, Mango Lassi, Garlic Naan...There are so many yummy dishes to choose from here, you won't be disappointed. I remember first coming here with my dad maybe 6 or 7 years ago and it has remained a reliable source for awesome Indian-Pakistani food. 

The place is smaller and not very posh or clean, but that's what is so endearing about it for me. I can just relax, eat incredible food, and be on my way.
author: Erica H.

description: My new favorite Indian spot in San Francisco.  Utterly delicious!
author: Dave R.

description: I eat so much I blow up later. The lamb... The lamb... The lamb... Look out the back door and see the empty lot full of burnt pots and pans. Such a great way of getting rid of those sort of things. Went once with 2 hot lady models. No really... It was a different time. And they took us (it is all Pakistani bad ass men working there by the way) to a secret private room that looked a lot like a generic motel room, down the alley. I am not making this up! Anyway... I try to go here every time I am in San Francisco, I eat alone now. So alone... Did you know that English military officers created Chicken Tiki Masala because they were colonialist bastards and they wanted a dish that used tomatoes but they say it tomatoes if you catch my drift. Anyway... It is really good there too and I am fascinated with the tandori oven. Feel lost your first time eating there? The chaos overwhelming? Just go with it. It is good... Tip: Don't talk politics.
author: Rock P.

description:
Another favorite Indian restaurant. Their kebabs are mouth watering! Bhuna Ghosht, Baingan bhaji, chicken kofta, karahi chicken are absolutely amazing! The free tea is pretty good too. The cooks and everyone are very friendly and helpful.

The only thing that sucks is their restroom.
author: Mrinalini K.

description:
EDITED: 12/18/06

So, I was a little disappointed with the service I received tonight.  For some reason, they didn't remember my order...so they served all of the other people who were behind me in line...  But, it is Shalimar, and I have a soft spot in my heart for Shalimar...and it's mostly because we really wanted some more chicken tikka masala sauce.  So I made my friend go up to the counter (ok, I didn't MAKE her, she wanted some too!) and ask for more...and they generously obliged.  Yay!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Shalimar...  Shalimar.  The conveniently located Nob Hill restaurant...  I was little concerned it wouldn't be the same as the location in the 'Loin, but there was little difference - and that's a good thing.

My standard meal is chicken tikka masala and saag paneer.  I know, not really that inventive or different...BUT then I can compare restaurants across the same dishes...!  As always food is good, and service is good...well, it's me.  But you go to Shalimar knowing that you get your own water, silverware, whatever - no big thing.  The food is reasonably priced and oh-so-tasty.

And the best thing about this location is the outdoor seating...  Just in case you are planning on going out after your Shalimar meal, you won't smell that strongly of Indian/Pakistani food...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Shalimar, Shalimar.... you bring me memories of the best of London curries.  Was quite worried after moving here last spring that I would never be able to achieve that combination of great curry at cheap prices.  I am so happy I found you!  Also tried Naan N' Curry but they do not compare.  The dive atmosphere only enhances the curry experience.  Too bad it doesn't put off more people.

The aubergine and saag paneer are the best I've ever had.
author: Jean K.

description:
Yum. Nothing to complain about. Yes, it's incredibly oily, but my goodness...totally worth the calories. I ordered the (lamb) brain masala, palek paneer, lamb with spinach curry and 3 orders of naan. 

The brain masala was SO GOOD. 

The first time I ate it was about two years ago, when my bf dragged me to Shalimar. He ordered the brain, I said, "Ew. I'm not eating that. You're going to have to finish that on your own."

"Okay."

The food came. I began sampling everything, and because I have an abysmal memory, I forgot he had ordered lamb brains. When we were almost done, I remembered, "Hey, didn't you order brains?"

"Yes."

"Where is it?" *nomming on some naan dipped in curry*

"You're eating it."

*Stops mid-chew*

Turns out the brains were my favorite dish, the dish I kept going back to. I was horrified for about 2 seconds, then got over it. It's cooked, obviously other people were eating it and were still alive. Why worry? The sauce was sooo yummy, and the brains had a creamy consistency, perfect to pair with the plain naan.

So when I ordered for pick up today, it was the three items listed at the beginning of this review along with the naan. Everything was spiced perfectly, everything tasted wonderful. The portions are HUGE. I had trouble finishing one naan and barely made a dent in the other three orders (yes, I thought I would've been able to finish this all myself). 

So now I have leftovers to heat up in the microwave and smell up the whole office tomorrow. My colleagues are going to love me and Shalimar.

Would've given five stars if there was a little less oil/grease....
author: Evelyn C.

description:
A lot of my friends LOVE Shalimar. Especially those from the Bay Area, they've grown up with Shalimar being a staple. Me, I'm not a big fan. I know, blasphemous right? Well, I'm not a huge fan because I went to the Jones loc twice when I first moved to SF and it was so dirty...and the food was mediocre. 

THEN recently, I found my Shalimar staple. I'm a fan of Shalimar's chicken breast piece bbq tikka with naan. Simple and so good..and that's the menu item I return for. Shalimar is still pretty dirty, but theyve got a friendly staff and as long as they keep making my tikka right, I'll be coming back for it.
author: Shafaq C.

description: The food is very good.  Again, this was my first time eating Indian and Pakistani food.  I was surprised I was able to handle to the spiciness.  Maybe I am getting immune to spicy food.  Anyway, I ordered their chicken tikka masala and naan-a-akbar.  Their naan-a-akbar seems like pita.  Their food was delicious, ambience was okay, and service was okay too.  I was disappointed that they only accept cash.  Boo!
author: Carlene R.

description: Really good and authentic Mughlai Indian food. The place does not rank really high on hygiene and would surely not be an appropriate place to go on a date. But if really good and spicy Indian / Pakistani food is on your mind, then this is the perfect place. Their tandoori chicken is really good and compares with the best ones I have had in India. Shalimar has surely one of the best Indian foods I have had in the US
author: Rahul K.

description:
Best Chicken tikka masala I have ever had! Loved it! The place is nothing fancy in a stinky part of town, but the food is great and the price is too!  The rice was very good too, the naan was ok. I will be back!!!  ps easy parking on street.
-Chris B
author: Chris B.

description:
I don't know why there's always a line of people (today there were 2 lines!) at the cafe next door, but THIS is where it's at!

But I'm always relieved as I walk up, that I don't have to wait in THAT line for the other place.

Okay... so the food: Pakistani action. And it varies from good to great. Along with Pakhwan in Fremont, this is the beat Pakistani food I've had in the Bay area.

Cleanliness: This is the holiest of the hole in the wall places! I always wonder whether my hands were cleaner before or after I used their restroom to wash my hands.

That said, I've never had any tummy trouble here.

I'm taking 1* off because of their ventilation. Every time I go here, I end up with the unmistakable fragrance of smoke and grilled meat all over. They have what appears to be decent exhaust for the grill, but it isn't working well enough - there's often this cloud in the air. On a recent visit, I propped the door open to clear out the place, and the guy claimed that it would make things worse. It didn't. That did clear out the air.
author: El Huron I.

description:
Two words: Tandoori chop

It's the most expensive thing on the menu but you have to order that. You won't know what a real lamb chop really is until you try theirs. You may see some cockroaches running around the restaurant once a while but don't let them deter you from trying the best. They are just part of the decor\pets.
author: Hinling Y.

description:
Shalimar was the only Indian restaurant my husband and I visited during our stay in San Francisco.  The food was okay, although they didn't have everything they offered on the menu and it was early in the evening.  The na'an was the best part of the meal.  I had the plain na'an and my husband had the garlic na'an and though it was great.  

The place is DIRTY.  I was afraid to touch any surface in the joint.  My daughter wanted to use the restroom and I told her she'd have to wait until we got back to the hotel.  The seating area is also very small.

There was only one man busing and taking orders from the restaurant.  He was unfriendly and not very helpful unless you knew what you were doing already.

The food is okay, but I am sure there is better out there.
author: Pam F.

description: The best part of Shalimar?  You can get food to feed a small army for under $20.  The naan is amazing, and the biranyi rice (is that how you spell it?) is so incredibly good.  I just hate eating here . . . I'm always scared of what I am going to see crawling under the table, and I seriously am scared about putting my elbows (or any other part of my body) on the table . . . disgusting.  Highly recommend "take out only."  By the way, they seem to have received a passing score from the health department so maybe the "image and impression" of filth is worse than the reality.
author: D H.

description: We didn't even get food. It's not like we could have, what with them ignoring us. It took them a while to come and clean the table we had sat down at and give us menus. We decided on what we wanted and closed our menus, the universal sign that we were ready. The waiter didn't come to our table and didn't notice us trying to call his attention when he would come close to tables around us.  We did everything short of getting up and going up to him to tap his shoulder. It wasn't particularly busy, and we could just see him standing around near the kitchen. We waited around 8 minutes after having closed our menus and decided to call it quits and try the Indian restaurant across the street. There's no way I'm going back.
author: Jacob A.

description: The best part about this place is that it's on my favorite cross street - Ofarrell and Jones!
author: Omid F.

description: I've been going to this restaurant 4 x a week for the last 3 years. The chicken tikka masala + aloo naan is my staple. Nobody does it better IMHO. The food is very authentic. I feel like I am walking into Pakistan when I step into the restaurant. In the heart of the Tender loin, it has a "hole in the wall" feel but charming in it's own way. Easily one of my top food choices in the city. I would recommend to anyone.
author: Nivay A.

description: ahhhmazing food. their lamb chops grilled and tandoori chicken was awesome. really really cheap place. but great tasting food
author: Foodie J.

description: If you want Indian food that tastes authentic, eat here. The goat curry reminded me of mom's. Just don't expect to be wow'ed by the decor. And don't forget to get a cup of chai in the corner!
author: Kevin K.

description:
This is the place for authentic indian and pakistani food, featuring delectable Tandoori charcoal barbeque, traditional curries, the most amazing garlic naan, specials such as brain masala, (lamb brain cooked with butter, onion, tomatoes, and spices) goat karahi ("khyber pass region delicacy where no feast is complete without this dish" featuring diced goat cooked with northern spices, herbs, and tomatoes), and Bhuna gosht "relished by punjabi stalwart soldiers" (grass fed lamb, cooked with butter with a hint of garlic and Ginger over a bed of onions, brought to simmer in Pakistani spices.)

Help yourself to the vat of chai, and polish off your meal with a bowl of kheer.  Three people can happily eat here for under $40.  Average price of a dish is $6.95.  Don't let looks deceive you, as this is as "hole in the wall" as it gets.  Decor and cleanliness are at the bare minimum, the bathroom is frightening, but I will fly to San Francisco just to eat here.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
If you've ever wanted to know what eating at an Indian "Dhaba" by the Grand Trunk Road feels like, go here.

Since other people have not mentioned it, I'll recommend their daal. It has a homely feel to it and is close to the real deal. Ginger chicken and chicken jalfrazi are the best in non-veg curries.

I see people complaining about the hygiene and cleanliness, but I think that is their charm - I felt like I was back in India when I first came here.

I didn't like their goat curry, so I take off one star.
author: Awesome P.

description: All of the food here is really good, but the curries are the way to go! The curry dishes are extremely flavorful and the meat is always fall-off-the-bone tender.
author: Neil R.

description:
The food is off the hook best, one of the best places to eat.  Take the price out and location out of the factor of anything, the food is awesome.  One of my most favorite places to eat.  
Adding back in the price, well sheit .. it's cheap as fuuk and even better to go with a group of people to have many different selections to keep it cost effective and not waste or have to take food one.
Location, well you get a lot of interesting people walking around.  As well, the missing start on my rating is due to the fact after eating here, I always the smell in my clothes due to poor ventilation.  
I love this place and here all the time.
author: James H.

description: Amazing food. Its a hole in the wall and you somewhat have to serve yourself but I think thats what give this place character. I have been going there for years!
author: Saleem B.

description:
I've being going to Shalimar since 1997. To start, this place is PAKISTANI people! Notice the posters that say Lahore and Karachi?!I've brought numerous peeps here from India/Pak, UK, Aus/NZ and even they all admit this is some of the best curry they have ever had!

Recs: saag gosht, chicken boti, seekh kebab, bhuna gosht, daal masala, and chana. Their naan just doesnt get any better.

To the peeps who b*tch that the place is nasty inside, especially the bathroom; OK, fair enough. It's not that clean inside. But the food is all VERY fresh and the kitchen looks good to me. 

Extra star for whom I call Osama who is occassionally there...the long bearded butcher who always seems to have blood over his shirt from chopping up chicken in the "backyard"
author: dan s.

description:
From what  I can remember, the chicken tikka masala was delicious! My friend and I were ecstatic to beat the crowd. The sauce was buttery and flavorful, I bet they use ghee to make it buttery. The rice was good too, but how can you not cook the rice well? The chai was delicious.

What really stood out on the menu that was the brain dish! I was really intrigued, but I suppose not enough to actually order and try it.
author: Nance H.

description:
OMG! The best Pakistani food I've had EVER. I grew up a vegetarian and have tried multiple Indian restaurants. I haven't had food this good. The meat was succulent, the spices were right. 

For specific recommendations, the Nihari, the Tandoori chicken and the ever elusive chicken biryani. With a side of raita, I sit back after my meal with a satisfied sigh.

If you are looking for a fine dining experience, this is not the right choice. It is a small, hole in the wall that is guaranteed to leave you wanting more.
author: Meera V.

description: The chicken tikka masala is decent, but way too oily! Everything else- totally overrated for the amount of calories consumed
author: Romita J.

description:
Shalimar is my favorite place to satisfy my Indian food cravings. I haven't found another place (yet) to knock it off the top of my list.

I love their Chicken Tikka Masala and the Palak Paneer. But what makes the meal even better is their fluffy hot naan. Mmmmmm. Excuse me while I wipe the drool off my chin.

With the dishes averaging $6-$7 and $1 naan, you really can't get a better deal. Great food + cheap prices = very happy foodie.

However, while the food is excellent, the actual restaurant is a bit of a hole-in-the-wall.  The other locations are a little better, but overall you have to completely ignore the surroundings. Ordering things 'to go' is the best solution.

Whenever I want some curry, I head to this place and stuff my face. And to note, I can't even handle spicy food! But for a taste of Shalimar, I arm myself with cup(s) of milk/lassi to counter that heat. It is just that good.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I definitely like to talk the talk and walk the walk when it comes to being in the know (through first hand experience!) about good, cheap eats in the city, but last night, I was forced to come clean and sheepishly admit to a group of people that I had actually NEVER been to Shalimar before!!! 

Having heard so much about it, I thought I was really in for somethig special. Well I have to be honest and say that my paneer tikka masala (they call it something different on the menu but its essentially the same thing) was just too greasy for me. Now, I know that paneer tikka masala isn't exactly a light dish to begin with, but it does generally tend to be quite delicious, so it's a gamble I'm willing to take. This was just tooooo much though. I only ate a very little bit of it, due to that.

What I DID really like about Shalimar, though, was the experience of ordering the food (we took it to go). It's cash only and i was about $5 short. The guy behind the counter heard our discussion about finding an atm and said, 'it's cool, just bring it by next time you come in." Wow, what a kind gesture. And my BF still swears by their chicken tikka masala. He is a loyal Shalimar customer and I don't think that will be changing anytime soon, so I'm sure I will have upcoming opportunities to try other dishes.
author: Shannon R.

description:
I give out very few one star reviews, but there was a cockroach floating in a pitcher of water we requested. When we gave it back, he didn't even pour it out in front of us, he just set it down with the rest of the other pitchers...

The prices weren't anything special, and the food was pretty decent. But the roach was enough to keep me from coming back.
author: Matt F.

description: The food is really good! and the service is friendly and fast. It's a downtown restaurant, so don't expect suburban cleanliness.
author: Graham B.

description:
I have never been so scared to order food in my life!
I was staying with a  friend at the SF Hilton, and we decided to venture out and get some Indian/Pakistan food. After walking 2 blocks I saw Shalimar, and I made the call to go in. 
The place is truly a hole in the wall, the walls are bare and white, the chairs and tables don't match, and I couldn't tell who were the patrons from the staff. ( I kept seeing this women walking back and forth with pitchers of water, only to later realize that she was getting water for her own table and that it was self service.)

I didn't know where to order, so I watched on as some other people came in and headed to the counter. We followed and stood next to them, and as soon as they order I asked if they had food to go. The waiter said "yes", and that he would be back to get our order. When he came back he handed me the menu, and I soon handed it back to him, and told him to choose a couple dishes for two people. 
He proceeded to do so, but son realized that this is a cash only place. We headed to the ATM and back, and with in 10 minutes our food was ready.

I couldn't tell you what I had, but I think it was a chicken curry dish that was hot and spicy, and a lamb dish that was savory and sweet. Along with that we had some rice, and naan bread. Everything was spiced perfectly, and it was very aromatic. We got back to the room and ate with our hands. It was an authentic Indian dinner in our modern hotel room!  .

The 1st  bad thing about this place is the location, it's not the best neighborhood. Secondly, somehow when you order your food, it gets to your table, I don't think I am used to self service and waiter service at the same time.
author: Alex F.

description: It's dirty, rather filithy, but the food is cheap and filling. We did a taste test between Shalimar, Chutney, and Nu-Lahore's Chicken Tikka Masala.  Shalimar's was the greasiest, but gave the largest portions and IMO was the tastiest.  Dining hours listed are wrong, I was able to grab food late afternoon between their lunch and dinner hours.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
There's quite a difference between the Shalimar on Polk and this one on Jones. The one on Jones is so much more better (in terms of food) despite the location and the cleanliness. 
The Nihari (tender beef stew) is our favorite here.
author: Samyuktha K.

description: Simply awesome food. Hands down the best Indian food I have had outside of England and India. Only knock is that the food can be kinda greasy but all in all, can't beat it.
author: Akhil C.

description: Tasty food, authentic cuisine, although their tandoori meats should be a little less dry. The place is quite dirty, but it's worth it because of their food quality and because it is probably the only great Pakistani restaurant in the city of San Francisco. Opens till late hours. Their garlic naan is actually filled with garlic chunks, unlike at other restaurants. Authentic Pakistani clientele fills the busy place day and night!
author: Raymond F.

description: Great hole in the wall spot my friend introduced to me after some drinks at Jones.   We got 4 dishes and some naan to split between 4 girls.  The total bill came to about $35 which isn't bad at all but the portions were a bit smaller than some other places.  I liked how there was a kick to all the dishes.  No ambiance at all but service was nice although kinda slow.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I like this place a lot. The food is great. However I do have a few issues:
1. It's not the cleanest place I have ever been too.. I don't know, maybe invest some of your profits in some bleach a mop, vacuum, dustbuster, something to clean the floors. A coat of paint wouldn't hurt either.
2. The bathroom is something out of a 70's horror movie.. it's scary as hell in there. There are micro-organisms living in there that have yet to be scientifically classified. Enter at your own risk.
3. I order the onions and jalapenos EVERY time I go there, and EVERY time they never bring them, I always have to ask 2-3 times. It's like they don't want to give them to me.

Other than that, the food is AWESOME!
author: doug c.

description: This is my favorite indian/paki food. I have been going here for years. Its also there original spot that first opened up. You can beat the quality and prices.
author: Ray L.

description:
Mughlai Cuisine traces its roots to the Mughal Empire in medieval India.  This is probably the most popular cusine in North India and Pakistan.  And I have to say there are very few places in the world who do it better than Shalimar.  Karim's in Old Delhi is one of them.

Clearly no one goes to the Tenderloin for clean streets and ambience!  You go there only if you really like the food.  And when you are there you have to try the naan.  That's the best thing they do.  They also make excellent kababs (tandoori chicken, lamb chops, sheekh kabab).  But they do some other things very well too, like haleem and nihari.  Some days of the week they have karahi chicken /goat - again something you don't want to miss. And I always get their spinach (aloo saag) too.  This is by far the best Mughlai food in the Bay Area.
author: Kaushik D.

description:
Came here for lunch on friday with my coworkers. They've always told me how delicious this place was. We came here at 11:45 and it was empty. We were the first customers! The place is much more fancier than NnC, so that was a plus for me. 

We ordered the chicken tikka masala, spinach with potatoes, lamb curry, a couple of pieces of chicken tandori, naan, and rice. Everything was delicious! The tikka masala was def. a lot more tastier than other places I have tried. Naan was piping hot and fresh, so fluffy and delicious! Basically everything was delicious...and nothing was left behind. 

Delicious cheap Indian food, but you'll def. come out smelling out like curry after eating here. Its probably due to the lack of circulation in the restaurant. Kinda weird that you get paper cups to drink water from...a little on the ghetto-er side for me. But overall, I'd come back here for lunch again, or come here for take-out!
author: Betty S.

description: How can I have never written a review for this place? This is our go-to spot every time. When the line at Dottie's is too long, when you need to sober up from Bourbon and Branch, when you've smoked too much hookah at Nile's Cafe, when you're hitting up downtown, seeing a play or wondering the city, this it the late night spot or good afternoon spot for the munchies. Affordable yummy food, quick service, love it.
author: Naomi K.

description:
I usually go to Shalimar on the other location. But after we went to do duplicate the keys@ brownie hardware and then we decided to have some Indian foods for our lunch. I would say this location is good.

We got Chicken tikka masala which was very tasty, Saag Gosht was ok dish to me but Garlic Naan was pretty yummy, ton of garlics.

This location is bigger than the one on Jones St. and it's good if you want to come as a group.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: I need to contradict some earlier good reviews.  I am a fan of Chicken Tikka Masala, and often use this dish as a standard from which to judge Indian restaurants.  I consider this dish a delicate and sophisticated blend of spices that, when done well, makes my taste buds resonate with pleasure.  This was most definitely NOT the case with this restaurant.  I found the Chicken Tikka Masala to be harsh in flavor and greasy in texture.  Given the numerous other Indian restaurants nearby, I would recommend looking elsewhere.  That said, you can't beat the price of this restaurant, and I did find the tandoori chicken tender and well-flavored.
author: Chris P.

description: Thank you Shalimar, my life would be so bland without you! Add the potato nan to your curry, so delicious.
author: Jamie Starr X.

description:
Rockin good Indian Food!!!  Spartan, and I do mean Spartan surroundings, no amenities to speak of, but the food is awesome!  My co workers told me about this place and the meat dishes are superb.  They serve the tandoori type dishes on skewers and all the meats are so juicy, it's so much better than the dry overcooked versions you typically get.  They also serve goat, which is done in a stew style, again very tasty.  Naan's are fresh and vegetable dishes are equally good!
This place is very spartan so don't expect table cloths and other amenities.  You're lucky to get our food and silverware!
author: Ron T.

description: Best Indian/Pakistani food in SF. Cheap prices, shabby looking restaurant, definity not touristy, but why is this place still running? All the locals go there. Most meal times this place will be packed. I would recommend the Lamb curry and their garlic naan is also very delicious
author: Howard K.

description: I live to eat. Some of my co-workers flew down from seattle and took me to this place. It has THE BEST kababs ever. The biryani is as good as it gets but the kababs :) omg!! chicken tikka, chicken seek kabab and some other chicken leg kabab.. i wish i could get this food delivered to my place everyday!
author: Shon S.

description:
Shalimar used to be great. I live in the neighborhood and have the great pleasure to sample some of the best of this cuisine available anywhere. I just tried Shalimar again. The place was filthy but when the food was great, I could overlook that. The service was rude- again that could be forgiven were the food at least delicious. Sadly the tikka masala was more oil than sauce with bones and mediocre flavor. The chicken biryani was cold and not fully blended with spice.
I never write negative reviews but this place had been so good for so long it appears as if they suffer from success syndrome. They should refocus their efforts and work to regain their status... especially with so many other great places around.
Meanwhile, I'll be at Lahore K or Pakwan. Heck, even Chutney across the street from them is better.
author: Tod T.

description:
This Is my favorite Indian/Pakistani restaurant in town and I have tried a lot of them.  There is nothing bad on the menu.  May I suggest the lamb bhuna gosht and the chicken curry. 
I have to warn you it is nothing fancy and you may have to dodge or step over a couple of crack heads to get in the door but its worth it.  Don't go there for the atmosphere go there for the great food, I do.  
Almost forgot, its byob.
author: Veronica L.

description: It may not look like much and yes it's in a sketchy neighborhood but I've been eating here for about 13 years now and it is hands down the best Indian/Pakistani food you will get in the Bay Area!!!
author: sunny s.

description:
Shalimar....I don't know if I love you or hate you....

Let's start from the beginning...

Location: one the worst in town. I would never go there by myself lol!

Decor: non existent. Except for the inspection score that is proudly shown-off. 70/100!!!! Is it anything to be proud of?

Atmosphere: the place is always packed and busy. You can see a majority of men. Sometimes big family groups. Never first date couples though!

Service: you order at the counter and the waiter brings the food at the table. I always have the feeling that they never understand me but so far they always got my orders right!

Cleanliness: the inspection score is probably over-rated. I am always afraid to get sick whenever I go there. I have never risked drinking their tap water!

Food: the tandoori and naans are fresh, the curries come from huge plastic buckets. From the crowd of customers they have, I assume they are fresh too...

I definitely recommend the chicken jalfrezi. Perfect balance between the chunks of chicken and the bell peppers.
If you feel adventurous, they have brain masala...Never tried it though.


In conclusion: this place is recommended if you don't care about frills and much hygiene. The only reason I go there is for my husband who absolutely loves it.

A plus: open late and during Holidays.
author: Anastasia M.

description:
There's no one at the register, whichever cook isn't cooking, takes your order. If all are cooking, you wait and adore the wonderful atmosphere, small and crammed with a giant intrusive mirrored wall on one side and a plain off-white hospital style wall on the other.

Despite the ridiculously crappy service/space, I'd eat from here (not IN here) any day. The tikka masala is probably the best I've ever had.  Very rich, greasy, creamy, spicy and tasty all at once.

For take-out it's probably your best bet for amazing indian food in the TL.

For dine-in it's probably your best bet for 40 year old indian guys wearing shirts from the 80s in a restaurant that hasn't been cleaned since the 90s.
author: Mack D.

description:
The best authentic Indian/Pakistani Food you're going to find. The experience itself is quite authentic as well. No, you don't have waiters that respond to your every whim. No, there isn't a waiting list. Yeah, you have to order your food at the counter, get extra silverware yourself if you need it, grab your own jug of water from the refrigerated shelf. But Shalimar isn't supposed to be the kind of restaurant where everything is strictly organized. It's supposed to rough around the edges, similar to the neighborhood restaurants you find along the streets of India and Pakistan. Classic, authentic Indian/Pakistani food is considered that which is consumed by the majority of the population. Most restaurants in these countries reflect the fact that the majority of the populations in both India and Pakistan consist of working low to middle class individuals/families. The working class mentality (working hard, placing tremendous emphasis on brotherhood and nationalistic pride, putting in the effort to get what you want out of a situation, not used to being waited on hand and foot, etc.) permeates through the very framework of the establishments that these individuals frequent. The owners of Shalimar figuratively picked up the experience and delicious food of the local restaurants in Pakistan and India, and brought it here to share with all of us in Northern California. 

Taking all of this into account, I once again stand by assertion that this is the best authentic Indian/Pakistani food you're going to find in Northern California.
author: Amber K.

description: Favorite place to go for Indian food! Super delicious and authentic. :) FREE CHAI TEA TOO! Minus one star because the restaurant is dirty :/
author: Koki I.

description:
Read everyone else's reviews about Shalimar's fantastic and inexpensive food, BYOB awesomeness, complimentary chai and cool newspaper menus. I couldn't agree more.

What I love about this place is that if you walk into their restaurant with your dog in tow they will promptly tell you to beat feet. One of the last few times I was here some a-hole comes strolling through the dining area with his mutt wagging its tail about 18 inches from people's food; he was cut off before he could reach the counter and told to kick rocks by one of the employees in about 0.6 seconds. I almost stood up and started a slow-building round of applause like in the climactic scene of a feelgood coming-of-age movie. I am unquestionably a dog person, but I find this revolting--why do people think it's OK to do that? If I wanted fleas in my food I'd have your mom do my cooking without her hairnet.

Exceptions: Blind people with seeing eye dogs, but if you're blind you definitely are not reading this so, really, NO EXCEPTIONS.
author: Trav W.

description: Ok, all I have to say is go early and get the goat stew..... If you don't go early, expect to wait because it's a small place with maybe 8-9 tables and a line out the door.  If you don't get the goat stew, you're gonna be mad at yourself and asking "what is that, that's on everyone else' table that smells so good"
author: Chans G.

description: The place itself is kind of a hole, but it doesn't even matter because the food is SO amazing! We almost always get takeout anyway. Not much else I can say, but this is by far my favorite comfort food. Best Indian food in SF.
author: Marianne G.

description:
Tandoori Lamb Chop - taste & smell very good but abit dry
Saag Chicken - good
Naan - good
Basmati rice - good
Chai - good

Price -- $22
Cleanliness -- cleaner than eat in India and didn't have diarrhea after the meal
author: Manda W.

description:
DIRTY! 

I really didn't want to come here as a friend of mine swore by it and dragged me down I remember telling him umm...i don't know about that place it looks very dirty so we get there its packed got a table and just when i was feeling comfortable and was about to order I look up at the wall beside us and there it was 3 COCKROACHES looking at me I instantly got up and walked out I'm sorry i cant eat here as my friend STAYED see you later buddy how can you eat somewhere with roaches gather up so nonchalant in the open begging at the side of your table for some food (matches the area its in tenderloin). I couldn't tell you how the food was nor will I ever be able too, and for those of you who like this place and are oblivious to its flit next time your there take a moment to look around i dare you, but if you don't mind dining with the worlds oldest creatures be my guest. 

For more info on cockroaches and the disease they have go to www.planetcockroach.com this is NOT A JOKE you should be very concerned about what these little critters carry.
author: Nader F.

description:
Pros: The food is great, customer service is wonderful, and the setup to order food is different than any other place I've been too. They serve the meals as entrees, so bringing friends or family is a must. The price to eat there is very cheap, but the reason that it is, is that it will add up once you start ordering

Cons: The only reason why I am giving it a four is only because of it's location. The location is horrible with homeless wondering around even outside the restaurant. Be prepared to bring cash or else you will be running around outside traveling to each ATM hoping you won't get robbed or begged on. I had to go through two ATM's until I found one that actually had cash outside the restaurant.

Overall: Other than the location, the food here is top quality for a good price. If your going with friends or family, you will spend around $40 or more. Also, don't forget to bring cash.
author: Brian S.

description: Absolutely fantastic.  Stopped in late for dinner and enjoyed a great, authentic indian meal.  I wasn't really sure of the process when i walked in, so - as a heads up - just grab a menu and a table and order at the counter when you're ready...and enjoy!
author: Waylon C.

description:
Absolutely fantastic food at great prices. Some of the best Indian I've ever had, including fancy sit down restaurants.

This place would get a 5 if its employees weren't such gigantic assholes to everyone.
author: Phatalie J.

description:
Alright, I don't care too much about hygiene, a 66 on the health report doesn't scare me away.  I've been blessed with an immune system. However, the big buckets of food I saw being wheeled in out of a van that came from Lord knows where at 6:30 pm on a Saturday almost did.

The food is good, it's not Lahore Karahi good, but it is good and although I'm not desi, I'd say authentic, judging from much of the happy clientele.  I liked the haleem, but they only had beef and I wanted chicken (or much, much better, lamb, but that wasn't even on the menu).  The spice is right and the naan, the mango lassi, the channa, all good.  Plus it's HALAL.

The look, feel, and service reminds me of developing countries, so if you want a really cheap way to pretend your visiting India or Pakistan, go here and sit next to a table speaking Hindu or Urdu.  Close enough.

My favorite part was when the Shalimar employees laughed and clapped when I left my date after a tirade on his old (lied about) age and his age discrimination and the problem of older single Muslim women looking to marry.  I think they had my back, but maybe I was just daydreaming that part.
author: Cara J.

description:
If you want authentic Punjabi food this is the best place in the city. If you want the Americanized version of Indian food this is not the place for you. 
Get the chicken tikka masala, naan, seek kebab and the chicken biryani..I am Indian and I can tell you guys it doesnt get better than this when it comes to North Indian/ Pakistani (Punjab area) food.
author: Kaushick N.

description: Best Indian food ever. It's best to come early when the place first opens up or else you'll find yourself waiting a half an hour to an hour for a table.
author: Arthur K.

description:
The location is crap (to say the TL really scares me would be a grave understatement) and the place is the definition of a hole-in-the-wall (it's hot, crowded, and the floors could use a mopping or eight).  But it really is the best damn hole west of the Indian Ocean!  I've been to Shalimar a couple times now, and both times we had delicious meals.  The 35-45 minute wait to eat here proves that this is a gem!!

The Shalimar folks have a little system down where you order after your wait in line (and the long wait will allow you to fully decide on what you're going to order).  Then you find a seat, you eat, and lastly, you pay.  I'm not sure why it's done this way, but it works and is pretty darn efficient.  

Be sure to try:
- saag gosht (lamb) - $6.95.  The lamb is melts-in-your-mouth tender and comes with lots of spinach!
- beef jalfrezi (spciy!) - $6.95.  Be sure to order some chawal with this to soak up the oil and spice.
- paneer masala (cheese) - $5.95.  It's cooked cheese so it's guaranteed to be delicious.

When I came here last weekend on a Friday, my bf and I got two curry dishes, the Shalimar chawal, and the garlic naan.  All of it came to $20 even.  

And now I am considering erasing this entire review as I'm reluctant to let the secret out....
author: Kira K.

description:
I think I prefer the Shalimar on Polk street more. They did not have OKRA dish at this restaurant and it's harder to find parking. 

The chicken karahi that I ordered also did not taste as good as the dish from Polk Street.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Grease grease grease! But don't let the grease fool you! This place is superb! Love the chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, chicken biryani and the kabobs! The price is right also! Perfect combination! You can bring your own drinks! Service is ok and decor is horrible, but don't go here for that. Go here for the food!!!
author: Edgard P.

description:
Shalimar makes Naan n' Curry look like McDonalds. 

You know you are in good hands because: 

1. It's an Indian restaurant that Indians actually go to eat. 
2. 3 out of 15 tables are vacant at 6 p.m. on a Thursday. 
3. You clean up the stuff you normally ignore, like spinach. 
4. You find yourself thinking about every plate three days later. 

I am fairly new to Indian food. My friend and I had chicken tikka masala and beef jalfrezi, then saag chicken and bhuna gosht two days later. I didn't know what to expect, but the flavors blew me away. My friend kept marveling at the whole grains of cardamom in the tikka masala's cream. 

I would have liked a strong cup of Darjeeling, but then the experience would be too perfect. :) 

By the way, the naan was very fulfilling. It wasn't until I got home and started eating the food my mom left for me when I realized how full I already was.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
I went to this place with a group of co-diners, one of whom is from India. He offered to recommend and order a few items, so we said sure. Chicken tikka misala, the standard naan bread, and a few other items were ordered.

I'm not the sort to back away from spicy food ("too spicy" is an oxymoron, IMO). Due to what I think is my obvious nationality (skin color somewhat akin to snow), I've found the staff in establishments that serve potentially spicy food will tend to "mild it down." I encouraged them to serve it full strength.

Damn, that stuff is tasty. Still not overly hot to the taste, but deeply flavorful; much more so than the food in other Indian/Pakistani restaurants I've been to.

Like soooooooooo (insert 50 more letter "o"s here) many other good restaurants, this place is a total hole-in-the-wall. Totally unassuming exterior. You could walk right by it and either not notice it, or just dismiss it outright as some dumpy greasehole which you wouldn't recommend even to your worst enemy.

The interior decor is, um....lacking. Oh, Hell: there's no polite way to put it: it's ugly.

Fortunately, the food is quite the opposite. If you want food that has lots of flavor, is quite authentic (yes, my friend from India confirmed this), and which has a touch of attitude, this is the place for you.

Those of you who seek trendy dining or a place to be seen: move on.
author: Tim B.

description:
Fantabuous Food!  

First things first, if you see a free table, grab it.  Send another person in your party to get a newspaper menu close to the cash register (don't wait in line for a menu).  Pick your pig out food, stand in line, place ur order.  Food comes to your table and you pay when you're done.  We chose:

Chicken Tikka Masala was as good as I had in Africa.  Buttery, hearty and very tasty.  Not a drop of sauce left on the dish when we were done.

Murghi Korma Shahi with chicken, saffron, yogurt and other spices.  Outshined by the tikka masala, not because it wasn't good.  I think if we ordered it alone, we'd be hanging from the ceiling in food glee.

TANDOORI CHOP - 4 nice, big, lean pieces of chops in the best marinade evah!!!  Bbq'ed right in the tandoori oven.  Another reviewer mentioned how pricey this dish was.  Where in SF can you get four deliciously marinated lamp chops for $10.95?!??!?!?  It's more expensive at Safeway raw.  

Rounded out dinner with basmatic rice, garlic and plain naan which are the best naans I've ever had.  Made fresh!!  Mango lassi and free chai tea to go around.

We even ordered two Murgh Tikka Lahori for lunch the next day.  Felt like Shalimar #2 in my own dining room.  That is some daggone good chicken!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Definition of "dirty ethnic restaurant," and I mean that in the BEST possible way. You get the feeling that they have a touch of pride in the 73% sanitation score they got from the SF department of health.

If I haven't scared you off yet, then you are in for some great Indian food. And prices are Tenderloin-errific, easily get out the door for under $10.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I've had better Indian.  The naan was a bit crusty in the middle.  The chicken was dry.  The lamb curry, while the flavor was good, had a thick layer of gooey grease that made my stomach curl.

They also charge for chai... boooo.  There are just too many delicious places to try in this city for me to dwell on mediocre.
author: Blu n.

description: I've been to many Indian restaurants in the city, and by far this is one of the best! But make sure you arrive early, this place is always packed. I love this place because you can BYOB!
author: Timothy H.

description:
Great cheap Indian eats!  The garlic naan was awesome with garlic baked into the naan -- yummy.  Tikka Massala and Saag Chicken were very good.  It's a bit of a dive, but the food is great -- perfect for a quick bite to eat.

I was a bit confused about how to order.  Seems that you just wander on up to the counter and order.  Find a table, food is delivered, and then pay at the counter.  Grab your own water pitcher from the fridge.
author: Brad B.

description: I've actually not experienced better because I don't eat Pakistani all that much so I have no bench mark. That being said, the food was tasty and I survived it in one piece. I say that because on the way out I noticed the Health Dept. rating was 77 out of a 100. Wow. But I must say I have eaten at quite a few hole-in-the-walls, a couple are favorites, so that doesn't usually bother me all that much. But I do think that it's strange that so many small places like this don't think much of cleaning.
author: cyndi L.

description: Ooohh Yeah and then some. Tasty authentic greasy Pakistani deliciousness served in a dive of a restaurant in the Tenderloin. I was a big fan and would recomend this to folks who are down to earth, like spice and enjoy eating with a utensil toolkit that is at a minimum pieces of bread in hand and at a maximum a spoon.
author: Mo A.

description: Definition of hole in the wall. No decor. Flies buzzing around. Chairs n tables look dingy and sticky. No customer service. They Messed up an order. Only saving grace was delicious tikka massala and freshly made naan but the Garlic naan was half bread and half undercooked garlic. Looks like 10 cloves of garlic in one naan. Wayy over rated place.
author: Kasey H.

description: This place is a total, scary mess. I mean, I recommend avoiding the restroom entirely except in the case of an absolute emergency. But what can I say? The food was excellent - the naan alone was the best I've had, ever. I ate there two days ago and I'm still thinking about it.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Yes,
shalimar is cheap OK Indian food, if you want a quick bite in between bars or just on your way somewhere this is the place, if you want an experience this is NOT the place.

Good food.
Dirty place.
BYOB, great.
Patio, good.
Drunk people, OK i guess.
author: cecilia k.

description:
This restaurant serves delicious Pakistani-Indian food. It looks like a hole in the wall, which it is so don't expect any fine dining. What you will get is a friendly cashier who will take your order (super cheap prices!) and a server who will bring it to you from their counter. 

I had the tika masala with rice. Don't forget to order rice (separate but still cheap). The tika had wonderful flavors of ginger, curry and star anise - a little oily but still great flavor. There was plenty of chicken in it as well. The rice was nice and fluffy. I love this place - it's like Indian comfort food.
author: Steven H.

description:
We came here after downing some drinks across the street and so, buzzed and happy, Indian food seemed like a beyond brilliant idea.  

When we walked in, I noticed two things that attested to the awesomeness of this place:

1.  You know a place is legit when it's PACKED at 9:30pm on a Monday night.  There was a line to get tables, AND a line to order.  
2.  You also know a place with ethnic cuisine is legit if the percentage of customers who are of that restaurant's ethnicity is greater than 75%.  Lots of Chinese folk in Chinese restaurant = Legit.  Lots of brown folk in Indian eatery = Legit.  So this place was definitely legit.

Some other awesome points:
+ AFFORDABLE!  Entrees are about $6-$7 each.  
+ TASTY!  We got chicken tikka misala, bengan bhujia (eggplant curry), and the chicken kofta, all of which were so flavorful and superb.  Set my mouth on fire, but I actually enjoyed it all, which signals mad props for the food because I normally shy away from the spicys because it makes me OMG DIE.  Their naan is also fluffy and fantastic, and the garlic encrusted one was great.
+ FAMILY-FRIENDLY!  My friend says that sometimes you can measure the awesomeness/legitimacy of a place by the number of kids running around.  It was like 10pm, and this place was still packed with giant families with kids.  Loves it.  
+ LOCATION!  The location is not crap, and honestly, the TL isn't as scary as people say it is.  You just have to keep to yourself, and you'll be FINE.  Plus, there's really some stellar eats here, including this fine joint!  It's so close to so many watering holes, which is very convenient, and I noticed the other night that there's a hookah bar right next to it too.  Nice!

A couple notes: Like Naan 'N Curry, you order and then it's self-serve.  No-frills eating is great.  We were a little confused with the ordering system at first because it seemed like there were several lines, so for other n00bs, just letting you know that the line by the door is for waiting for a table after you've ordered, and the lines by the counter are for ordering and paying.

Final word: I still have a soft spot in my heart for Naan "McD's of Indian Food" 'N Curry, but this place is really freaking delicious too. 

So many choices for good cheap eats in this City, and now another great place!

This is gonna make decision-making a lot harder.  Sorry, I know that's probably the most privileged complaint ever, but there's some truth to it.
author: Vivian C.

description: Oh Shalimar how I miss thee so. My insatiable longing for you burns deeply and cannot be satisfied by any other. Until our awaited reunion is fulfilled I will weep silently at thoughts of your unwavering perfection. Alas, even this terse review is tenderizing my hollow heart.
author: Clark D.

description:
Would a spicy Pakistani joint inspire so much loyalty if we didn't have to pick our way over the supine Tenderloin bodies to pass through its doors?

I love Shalimar. Unconditionally. The chicken kofta with only two balls. Sikh kabob cradled in fresh onions. "Rice-for-two". And have you tried the gulab jamuns? They're off the hook.

I tried convincing these guys to expand into Mexico. Although we were unable to come to agreement on terms (i wanted to add toilets with seats, they wanted me to put up all the money) a lifetime love-affair was born.
author: Lola S.

description: Best indian food in the USA. Waited 10 min to be seated, and the service was a little chaotic. But the food and prices were amazing!
author: C J.

description: Don't go here if you are looking for fine service or delightful ambience. DO go here if you are looking for delicious food in an atmosphere that may well be what you might find in a small cafe off a side street in a Pakistani town (though this is sheer surmise on my part as I've not been there). We had Nihani, Palak aloo methi (both of which were new dishes to us), garlic naan, basmati rice and some Masala chai (which reminded me of the chai we had in India some years ago). Anyway, it was all delicious and there was plenty of it. It appeared to me that we were the only folks in the place who didn't appear to have at least one forebear from the subcontinent. There were some lively conversations going on in a language other than English but there was no difficulty making our order understood. (Note: You order at the counter and pay there when you are done but your food is served by a waiter who looked as if he wished he were doing something else.) We finished up with a couple of favorites, gulab jamom and kheer, both delicious and not too sweet. Prices were very reasonable. We will definitely come back.
author: Harry N.

description: It's no surprise that the best restaurants you find are by accident.  This little hole in the wall is located in the least pleasant neighborhood in San Francisco, but you know what, now there's a reason to go to the tenderloin.
