Visit if you can -- if not for their great food, at least for the dramatic ambiance outside their doors!
author: EastBayVintage x.

description: The best hole in the wall Pakistani restaurant in San Francisco. Nehari is top notch as is the Barbecue Chicken. There is always a line here and it is always packed so you will have to wait around sometimes. Since the kitchen is behind the counter, the restaurant gets quite smoky at times. Service is not applicable since it is all self serve.
author: Faisal L.

description:
best divey wholesome indian/pakistani place.
been eating there for 3 years and haven't once been disappointed... fresh saag, good tandoori meats.. goat karahi, lamb korma, chicken jalfarezi are excellent, friendly people... I've take friends there on multiple occasions and everyone emerged happy and well fed :)
its totally worth way more that what they charge you...
author: K K.

description: Indian food is not really my favorite, so it was hard for me to tell.....however one of the people I went with said he had had better in the past and that he would probably not return....as for me, I probably would not go out of my way to go back but I also would not say no if a friend really wanted to go there to eat.
author: Shawn O.

description: Ya. Real good FAST Indian food here. Sucks that they don't take credit cards though. The menu has a wide selection, and you won't be disappointed with the options. Don't expect it to be super high end or like a sit down restaurant.
author: John M.

description:
Wow- fantastic find for the late night, I've-been-testing-the-limits-of-my-liver- dining options in the Tenderloin.  

This place introduced me to new pakistan/indian food horizons with their brain masala dish.  Paired with the Chicken Jalfrezi, chana, lamb chop tandoori, naan and free chai and you simply can't go wrong!  The food was quite good with prices to match.

I would recommend avoiding the bathroom and the raving homeless guy outside (unless you have some extra naan for him), but other than that- it a must- experience place in SF.
author: Tracee E.

description:
Super tasty food! 

CASH ONLY! NO BOOZE!

You definitely leave smelling like a campfire, but it's pretty much worth it. We had a feast for 7 people and the bill was $70! Pretty hard to beat the price point considering how tasty everything was. Don't expect amazing table service or even table cloths, you get a pile of plates and silverware along with paper napkins and then just dig in family style. It wasn't the most incredibly food ever, but definitely well above mediocre.
author: Clay T.

description: I don't have much Indian food experience on my hands since the only places I've been to were buffets. However, in comparison, Shalimar was pretty decent. I give it only an "a-okay" because it wasn't all that clean in there. The flavor of the food was good, although some sauces were really oily. I really enjoyed the Murghi Korma Shahi.
author: Alysha K.

description: Good Food like to go here when we in city and lovet hat place... good service.....
author: Boris M.

description:
Ask Britney and her sis, it's cool to slum it sometimes.

Worried we would be over-dressed for this place, we decided to take it up a notch.  He wore a nice suit, and I wore a flowy chiffon dress.  I had heard that Shalimar was in the Tenderloin, and as we drove across town, I tried to keep from noticeably wringing my hands the way I do when I get nervous.  While he concentrated on parking, I quietly removed my debit card and ID from my purse and tucked them down the front of my dress, figuring that if someone stabbed me and stole my handbag at least my identity wouldn't get stolen.

As we entered the restaurant, I noticed that we were definitely dressed too fancy.  A Rhea Perlman look-alike took the runner-up "best dressed prize" with some sexy Jordache jeans and a Ted Nugent tee.  I noticed Rhea glaring at me and feared for my life.  "I'm too young to die," I thought.  We bonded, however, when I removed cash/debit card/ID from the top of my bra.  As one (seeming) streetwalker to another, I had unknowingly just passed the prostitute initiation test.  This earned me some street cred.  After this, we were allowed to enjoy our meal (relatively) glare free.  I'm not sure if this was a good thing, because the food made me violently ill the next day.  

Good place if you hate your life (or your wife) and want to die by gunshot or food poisoning.

+1 star for showing me how lucky I am to live such a comfortable life.
author: Janney B.

description:
First off, the food was really good! Don't get me wrong there. If you just want good Indian food, this is the place. What we didn't like: the naan bread came in a basket that had no napkin in it, so it was bread on plastic. When was the last time that was washed..? Let me back up though. We arrived, sat ourselves, and the server came over and threw one "take-out" menu on our table. It had stains on it. We could barely understand his English as well.
We read online that they offer free chai (tea), so I asked him about it, and he told me to help myself to it. I got the chai, and waited til it cooled a bit. It was watery and pretty flavourless.
During our visit, a homeless lady walked in, argued with an employee, and then the employee executed a very loud whistle with his fingers at her. The whole room went silent. Weird.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Shalimar's a mixed bag.  Here's the contents.

1. Pros

   A. Five of us ate a shit-ton of food (it's a technical term) for $65.

   B. Their BYOB policy meant I could have Newcastle with my naan.

   C. While I am not aware of exactly what everything I ate was, it was all pretty decent.

2. Cons

   A. At the beginning of the meal, they brought a plate of what was essentially onions and what I think we decided were sliced jalapenos.  Obviously, to add to dishes as we saw fit.  I tend to like my food spicy, so pay attention to what I'm about to say: the sliced jalapenos tore my ass up.  I had to beg for some yogurt sauce to kill the fire before my eyes popped out of my head.  I was sweating like a whore in church for the rest of the meal.

   B. While we had a LOT of different dishes, each of the individual dishes was actually pretty darn small.  Like, no more than 3 people could split a dish and have more than a bite or two apiece.  Almost like Indian tapas.

   C. When you bring us something like 12 plates of food, it's probably wise to bring more than one plate of rice.

   D. When I left at 10:30, I looked around and realized that almost none of the other patrons were wearing pink-striped, French-cuffed shirts with matching ties and a suit.  Note to self: greater situational awareness is probably needed unless you'd like to get stabbed some day.
author: Ben P.

description:
Do NOT judge a book by its cover.  Obviously hidden in one of the worst parts of town, Shalimar makes it up in its food.  If you don't have the stomach to eat here, have it to-go.  

The mili juli sabzi is strikingly spicy.  The chicken tikka masala is marinated and swimming in a rich, yogurt sauce.   The bengun bhujia is eggplant whipped up tender and spicy.  Dishes run from 4-8USD a plate. So indulge is some inexpensive and filling Pakistani/Indian food.
author: Rochelle B.

description:
It absolutely blows my mind to see you kids rate so highly this filthy and abominable place. Seriously, four stars? What are you thinking, San Francisco? Every time I'm taken here I have to literally sweep the insects off the table so I may set down my plate, which swims and splutters with enough oil to lube a Hummer. I believe some people are confusing 'cheap' with 'value'. Though the two can and do coincide, they are certainly NOT the same thing.

I don't know how it has come to pass that city inspectors have not shut this place down. Do not be mistaken and assume I have a snotty, picky attitude, because I love hole-in-the-wall ethnic eateries as much as the next pseudo-foodie. But apparently in the quest to appear urban and hip, certain desperate individuals are willing to quite possibly risk their long-term health by slopping up this gastronomic swill. I cannot believe for a second that anyone who gargles this grease down actually enjoys it, much less looks forward to future helpings.

The only reason I may possibly conceive of someone wishing for Shalimar is if the poor sod has been constipated for days, and seeks to remove their intestinal blockage. Shalimar will easily do this in a matter of hours - honestly, how many of you after eating here went home and gave your own sudden impromptu recreations of the infamous 'Tubgirl'?

Two stars only for the naan and tandoori chicken. Anything with a sauce should be negative one.
author: Buster P.

description:
So Shalimar isn't the classiest restaurant in the world, nor is it in the best neighborhood.  So it's in the Tenderloin.  So the place is really shabby.  So everything is served in scratched up plastic plates and bowls.  So it's self-served.  So the bathroom is absolutely disgusting.  So I saw a drug transaction right outside the window as I was dining.  So my friend wouldn't let me walk here or back to BART on my own.

But it's still good.  It's still good.

I've been hearing about the wonders of Shalimar for quite some time, yet it wasn't till I took my friend out for his birthday dinner last week that I actually tried it. From their menu that day, this is what we ordered:

#25 Palak Aloo Methi
#33 Paneer Masala
#11 Naan -A-Akbar
#15 Shalimar Chawal
#4B Banarsi Kheer (rice custard!)

I like ordering by numbers!  Everything was delicious, albeit the curry dishes being a bit too salty.  The naan was warm and fluffy and the rice was perfect.  The rice custard was unnecessarily too sweet, though still delicious!  It was exciting and thrilling, yet scary, to eat because there were all sorts of mystery solids inside, all sorts of nuts and pods.  And guess what?  Everything cost just $17.85.  Super cheap!

And their green chutney sauce, was AMAZING.  I'm a condiment whore and when there are LARGE squeeze bottles at my disposal, I go to town!  Actually, before I went to town, I went to heaven first when I saw how many full bottles that they had in their fridge.  I used it on everything except for the custard.  And when I had nothing else to use it on, I squirted it into my spoon and drank it like soup.  So good!  I ended up eating over half the bottle on my own.

Compared to all the other Indian restaurants I've been to, this one actually has surprisingly good service.  Plates, utensils and napkins were brought to us, and when the food was brought out, each plate was introduced instead of just tossed onto the table.  I can dig it.

So if you're brave enough to trek out to the Tendernob, Shalimar is where you'll find cheap, delicious Indian/Pakistani food with some seriously AMAZING chutney.
author: Debbie L.

description: Excellent food. Excellent prices. Lots of vegetarian options. Definitely take a walk to the back of the restaurant outside to have a unique/bizarre view of a combination of back restaurant eating rooms and people watching tv on their bed.
author: Tracy H.

description:
I love the food they serve in Shalimar-The taste is awesome, though it is on the greasier side. I've never seen rats, though I've been there at least 10 times.
Why only three stars? Well, the place is very crowded, smelly, loud and I have suspicious thought that this isn't the cleanest place on the earth.
author: jamila u.

description: This is a greasy spoon. Food was good but not spicy enough for me. They serve no vindaloo. Rice had a type of clove in it that tasted like cardamom. Nan was good but greasy. Lamb was tender and sauce had a good consistency. Recommended for those not too picky about their location. No beer or wine is another neg.
author: Michael T.

description:
Now, I'm sure all of you have either eaten here and written a review, or still eaten here and still recuperating. I would contribute 5 stars for Shalimar if it wasnt for the oil. A dark, translucent, thick, consistent layer of floating oil on the top. 100% punjabi style.

Hole-in-the-wall has always been a SF pride, and Shalimar wouldnt turn you down on that experience. Food can be pretty fucking good sometimes, especially the kabobs. I wouldnt endorse the friday biryani ritual. Also, most veggie dishes are pretty standard and doable. 

Word of advice: Get a couple of dark beer's while savoring on Shalimar. You'll need it to soak all the spices down.
author: Sav B.

description:
Shalimar, a diamond in the rough, a temple of gluttony, a purveyor of fantastical gastronomic aphrodisiacs. Or simply, the place that serves the best Pakistani/Indian food this side of the planet. I love food and I have a special place in my heart for Mughlai food - the lavish cuisine invented by Mughal chefs, through careful assimilation of ingredients and craft of Arabic, Mongolian, Persian, Portuguese and Vedic schools, to please the keen palate of Kings who considered their food to be as much art as the Taj Mahal. That very cuisine, in one of its finer forms, by way of globalization, is being dished out at less than 5 bucks a plate, smack in the middle of our beloved Tenderloin. 

Don't pay heed to the misguided folks here who are comparing lesser places like Pakwan and Lahore Karai to Shalimar. It's insulting at best and blasphemy at worst. Shalimar stands tall, offering its magical repertoire, with in-human consistency to anyone who brings dollar bills and a growling stomach.

Everything on the menu is worth trying, though certain dishes will bring you closer to Nirvana than others. One of my favorites is the Chicken Kofta, the ambrosial balls of minced chicken in a piquant curry, quite unlike anything else I've come across in my illustrious career of devouring Mughlai food. Then there is Nihari. Nihari is a beef stew from Pakistan and rather hard-to-find due to the holy status of the Cow in certain parts of India. It's sinfully good and sinus-blasting hot. Originally a delicacy, this is one of the many Mughal dishes that is cooked overnight to imbue that mouth-melting consistency and deep spice flavor into the beef. I like to eat it last, on its own, with rice and nan, because its distinctive aroma is best appreciated solo.  The only acceptable accompaniment is a plate of cool raita, which serves well to pacify the peppered palate.

The nans are brilliant. They are best if they are straight out of the oven. Order them as you go and if you feel your nan has been sitting too long, just order a new one. Be stingy with rice, use it only to finish off the curry in dishes like the Kofta and Nihari which are brimming with it. Most of your carbs should come the wonderful nans.

Another delight of note is the Tandoori Chicken. This is a whole leg of Chicken, marinated in yogurt and dry spices and slow cooked in the wood burning oven. It's deliciously tender, mildly spiced and fastidiously observed by the chef to ensure it retains its original juices. Tandoori Chicken makes a perfect appetizer. However, since it's slow cooked and in high demand, it might turn up after the other dishes, which is fine too. But, please, hold the leg in your two able hands and bite into it with your teeth! As the adage goes, "eating Indian food with a knife and fork is like making love through an interpreter."

The Tandoori Lamb Chops are the Lamp equivalent of Tandoori Chicken. These are every bit as succulent and substantive as their Chicken counterpart. I tend to alternate between the two.

I often order Haleem, a hardy dish made out of wheat, lentils and beef which has the consistency of mashed potatoes. Haleem has a very mild flavor, and it stands out due to its mostly pure Persian heritage. It's comfort food, Pakistan-style. The palak (aka spinach) dishes, chicken and paneer, are well executed, though they don't make my soul sing. People swear by them, so perhaps you'll enjoy them too. The subji (mixed vegetable) is quite good and nicely rounds up the diet.

For the devoted foody, or the simply adventurous, the menu also offers Brain Masala, as in lamb brains lightly fried in onions, tomato and spices. I order it from time to time, usually out of alcohol imbibed bravado. The taste is rather hard to place, somewhere in the vicinity of cheese or scrambled eggs, but with an undertone of something quite complex, perhaps a mammalian brain.

There are, of course, other delectable items on the menu, but I won't call them out because I don't believe they are as inspired as the wonders I mention. Please do try them however, as they still leave a lot of what passes for epicurean in the dust.  Whatever you order, you can be certain of one thing: the talent and the love, that the merry-band of unassuming lads behind the counter pour into every dish, will stand out, clear as day, unsmirched by the cloying pretense of high-food or the hubris of gourmand chefs.

Oh, and remember to BYOB.
author: Vipul V.

description:
DON'T FORGET TO B.Y.O.B.
There's a convenience store just down the block where you can buy some beers if you forgot to bring your own from home.

Here's the rundown of the "system" so you don't look like a moron.
1) B.Y.O.B!  Be sure to bring your own opener ;)
2) walk in, and get in line.  Seat yourself when a table opens up.  In order.  Try not to get into a fight....
3) Go to table as soon as you see one open.  THey will bus it soon.  Note the table number.
4) Send your representative(s) to the main counter where he/she/they will order your food.  Be sure to know what you're doing, or the guy will get surly and impatient.
5) pick up some cups, plates, and silverware for your table
6) BREAK OUT THE BEERS/WINE and wait for your food.
7) after you eat, you ask for the check and pay at the table.  I'm pretty sure it's CASH ONLY.

About the food, well, what can I say that hasn't been said already?
Top notch authentic curries and pakistani food.  The tandoori chop here RAWKS.  But I must say, Lahore Karahi, in my book, is giving them a run for their money.  Try to get here for Goat Curry night ( I think Thursdays?).... awesome stuff.

5 stars for the food.  -1 stars for the "ambience" or lack thereof.
author: Fong L.

description:
Shalimar does not need another review but my meal was memorable so here you go.  

I read the reviews and wasn't sure what to expect other than THE BEST INDIAN FOOD AND DIRTY BATHROOM IN SF.  I actually went to the loo before leaving my house so I wouldn't have to use the one at Shalimar.  

I'm in a bit of a food coma so in no particular order:

-I had dinner with my significant other who is Indian.  He frequents Shalimar often so they recognize him.  It's Saturday at 7pm, the place was packed when we walked in. . .the SO and the host (owner?) start talking to each other in Hindi what sounds to me like a lot of shouting.  A table is immediately cleaned off for us.  

-Shalimar is dirty.  One of the guys who works there wiped the table off with a rag that must have been soaked with oil, ghee, who knows but I sat down and rested my elbows on the table and they sort of stuck.  So I rubbed whatever it was on my elbows to moisturize, got some napkins and gave the table another wipe.  

-Smoky smoky smoky.  My eyes were burning.  This place is smoky!  The grill was smoking off the hizzle and literally we could have all used a pair of goggles.  At one point, a lady (Indian) got up from her table, opened the front door and stuck her head out for a few mins.  No, she did not walk out of the restaurant, she stuck only her head out.  I smell like grill right now.  

-Eating at Shalimar is messy.  I'm not so crazy about eating with my fingers.  I had to let that go tonight at Shalimar.  You know when people shake a champagne bottle and pop it open P. Diddy style while partying and spray it all over everyone?  My SO was just about doing that with the green chutney sauce, sure it's good but is that normal? 

-Extreme eating.  Totally extreme eating.  The food here was really good.  I couldn't stop eating the naan and yogurt sauce with the green chutney sauce.  We ordered some saucy homemade cottage cheese thing, grilled tandoori chicken, daal, lamb.  It was all spicy but not so spicy that I can't taste anything now.  It was still spicy, my nose was running, my eyes were watering (from the smoke), our table was unbalanced and the water pitcher kept slipping towards the edge, plates were stacked, children were running around waving cell phones in the air with funny music playing on them, people yelling from the front of the house to the back. . .this meal was extreme.  

-The SO spent the better part of his childhood in India.  He says that Shalimar is the bomb.  Watching him eat at Shalimar was fun.  In all the chaos of Shalimar, he was calm and looked right at home.  That is saying something.  I felt like I was watching a movie happen around me.  Is it always like that at Shalimar?  I don't know but I do know that it was the most eventful meal I've ever had.
author: James M.

description:
When she was 5, my beautiful niece sat on my grandfather's lap, looked up at him like she was about to win a prize, pointed to his belly, and said, "I know what that is... You're gonna have a baaaaby!" 

Never have I been more proud of my niece than I was at that moment, and never did I better understand my grandfather's reaction ("that's it, Dorotha, I'm going on a diet!") as I do every time I leave Shalimar, preggers and shamed.

If you like exotic spice and third world decor, you'll find no better place to partake in such taxi-stop delights as chicken botti, chicken kofta, saag gosht, and chickpeas, all with a little aromatic rice and naan.  And if that's not enough exotic spice for you, just jingle the change in your pocket as you walk out into the Tenderloin.  You'll find some more coming your way.
author: Nom D.

description:
I love it when I find hole-in-the-wall joints; that's my disclaimer before I start this review.  But really, this is some seriously good Indian food.  Who needs ambiance or even good ventilation when you can get reasonably priced (downright cheap for San Fran standards) food?  My clothes still smell of tandori smoke, but I would come here again and agian if I could.  

The cooks at the restaurant and even some patrons eyed us suspiciously when we came in; perhaps tourists don't frequent this place much?  If they don't, it's their loss.  Be prepared for 0 service.  We had to go get drinks from the fridge in the front of the restaurant ourselves.  I will keep getting my own drinks as long as they keep cooking their perfect lamb chops and paneer!  I will be back everytime we come visit!
author: Lisa J.

description:
Trekking through the concrete jungle called the Tenderloin there is a hidden treasure lurking beneath the vomit, crackheads, drug deals and lost souls....it is a place called Shamilar, and it will fill you full of warm curries and hot, fresh naan breads.

Beware the crazy lady posted out front and at all costs, do not enter the bathroom. Make a point of relieving yourself BEFORE setting upon your journey and you will be rewarded with culinary delights of the finest order.
author: Serena Q.

description:
Yeah, yeah, yeah.  The food here is good, it's cheap and they let you bring in your own alcohol.  But you can figure all that out from the other reviews.  

Gas rating: 500
It is clear that many types of food give me gas.  Some experiences have been so memorable that I still refer to them by title such as the Broccoli casserole incident of 2005, or the garlic-fry incident of the 2006 Giant's-A's game.  But this incident my friends will go down in history as the gassiest I have EVER BEEN IN MY LIFE.  

Obviously Indian food is going to give me some gas.  I'm not naive.  We were having girl's night out, and there was some talk of going dancing afterwards, and I knew this wasn't a good idea.  But we were enthralled by the idea of bringing our own wine so I went along with things.  

But then...it happened.  One of the girls' ordered garlic naan.  And I loooooove me some garlic.  There was an incident over the summer where I consumed half a head of roasted garlic, and after two days of excreting garlic gas and sweat I vowed to moderate my garlic consumption.  But this night, the garlic spoke to me.  It said - you're with the girls.  No one's trying to hook up tonight.  We'll all be gassy.  You're going to have gas anyway, it's Indian food.  Might as well indulge.  And indulge I did.

Words cannot describe what happened to me for the next 12 hours.  We went out dancing and within an hour, it became clear that I was not fit to be out in public.  Every time I took a sip of beer, out would come a noxious, floor-clearing burp.  I tried doing walk-by burpings where I would burp and then leave the scene of the crime, but really, there are only so many places you can go in a club.  I couldn't dance, I couldn't have a conversation with anyone and I couldn't sit in a corner for fear that the air would become so foul they would call a haz-mat team.  So I left.

Little did I know, the burping was only the beginning of the cycle.  Several hours later, as the food traveled downward...so did the gas.  It was girl's night out so we were going to have a slumber party, but for the sake of slumber and friendships, I decided to go elsewhere and sleep in isolation.  Actually, I left to have gas in isolation because let me tell you, there was precious little sleep that was had.  I had gas All.  Night.  Long.  That's right people.  I didn't sleep for the whole night.  My gas was loud.  It caused my body to move from the explosions.  I could feel it building in waves.  It was awful.  

The next morning, the only thing more awful than the gas itself, was my own breath as I was brushing my teeth.  It was garlic, and gas, and Indian food.  I wanted to kill myself.  No one who can create that smell, deserves to live.  I brushed for a looooong time.

Moral of the story - don't eat the garlic naan unless you plan to spend the next couple of days at home.  Alone.  With the windows open.  And the fan on.  And do yourself a favor.  Go buy some Gas-X.
author: Soo C.

description: I've been coming here for over 10 years!  The best place for Indian/Pakistani food.  Place is always packed and what would be called a whole in the wall!!!
author: Milad Y.

description:
Does Shalimar need another review? No. Does Shalimar need a review from me? Hardly. But it is going to get a review from me because I love this place. 

First off, I love the ambiance. Not "the place is impeccably clean and the wait service is natty good" ambiance, because that is on some other planet as compared to here. This is the "flickering fluorescent bulbs, dusty and nasty vent fans and scavenge and knee-cap for a table ambiance." And it's worth the potential assault charge to eat here. 

I have taken many an out of town guest here when they say they want to eat local. (Really?  Call and raise.) However, I have yet to get a complaint once I work past their suburban fears of the neighborhood and concern for board of health details. 

They relax once I shank someone for a table. 
They start to smile when they realize the guy behind the counter takes your order, gets it right, remembers who you are and the food is magically delivered to your table by a friendly dude who doesn't speak English, but is helpful nonetheless. 
They outright giggle as they open the fo'tys we picked up at the corner liquor store just north of the place (so we may have cheap booze while we dine; remember, ambiance?). 

They shut up and narf once the food arrives. 

They won't shut up as we leave. All they do is profusely thank me for a wonderful experience, interesting "casual atmosphere" and fantastic food (including the Lamb Kofta) for cheap! 

I'll give them the final star if they clean the dust off the afore mentioned fan and replace the flickering fluorescent bulb, but I am still afraid the place may lose some soul in doing so.   Maybe 4.5 stars are warranted...
author: Mark M.

description:
When Pakistanis go out to eat, they go for three things: chicken tikka, seekh kebabs, and naan. In Pakistan, the competition is way fierce as to who makes the best of each. Word of mouth spreads like wildfire, and can easily make or break any place.

When Shalimar opened up in the 'Loin an eon and a half ago, it was way dingier than how it is now (if you can imagine that). My dad was the first to discover it walking through there (why my dad was walking through the Tenderloin around the early 90's is beyond me). But with the food and the Punjabi bantering amongst the owners and cooking staff, along with the feel of a local dhaba from the homeland, my dad was hooked and soon he'd drive the entire family almost an hour into the city just to eat at Shalimar. And they had it all. The naan, the chicken, the kebabs were all excellent. And they were all spicy - just the way we liked it. So what if there were a couple cockroaches on the wall. Who cared? It felt like the homeland, yo.

That was then. A few years later, two upstarts called Pakwan and Taj Mahal joined in the fray, and soon the Tandoor-loin was in full effect, with each restaurant branching out into chains, each with its built-in fanbase. Pakwan may have won the battle in the Mission, but Shalimar has consistently held its own in the Tenderloin, regardless of the onslaught of Chutney, Naan N Curry, and countless other places. Each time I've gone in they've never disappointed. They don't skimp on their spices for anyone. You can either handle the heat or you can't. 

The Tenderloin institution definitely boosted Shalimar's name into the top echelon of Pakistani restaurants amongst the most loyal and hardcore community, Pakistanis themselves.  Hence, when Shalimar opened its Fremont location, it immediately became a massive success and every other Pakistani restaurant saw its sales plummet. Pakwan opened up in Fremont soon after in a red barn, but it stands empty. People only head there if Shalimar's too crowded.

But all the success in Fremont can be pointed back to this humble Jones St. restaurant, for that's where its reputation started building long ago. I enjoy all the non-grilled salaans (saucy dishes) as well, but it's the kebabs, naan, and chicken which had me coming back time and time again. Excellent. Wish there was a place like Shalimar in Phoenix, but this just means I'll have to travel back home a little more often...
author: Mr K.

description:
RATS DOING LAPS IN THE MASALA!!!!!

can't substantiate the claim.
however, my friend told me that her friends share the back of their apt with shalimar, and said there was a rat doin' laps in the masala sauce one day! funny but albeit disturbing. can't substantiate it. she told me this after I was completely craving Shalimar, so with this unfortunate story-it dissuaded me. I so confused. I love shalimar! but I guess you have to see the rat doin' laps in the masala before you make a move.
author: J A.

description:
If a gourmet dinner at the finest of Western restaurants is like a romantic kiss with the person you love, a meal at Shalimar is a no-holds-barred orgy with a bunch of pornstars.  Issues with griminess and seediness are all part of the Dionysian experience.

There are two very different ways that human endeavors can approach perfection.  One is classical moderation - finding just the right harmony between just the right things, putting every element in the best possible place and in the best proportions.  The other is just welcoming AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE of EVERYTHING that's remotely good.  You take some of this and some of that... and then more of this and more of that.  Shalimar is more in line with the latter school.

That's what this cuisine is all about.  It was invented when someone first said, "Hey, let's cook something in ghee AND oil AND butter AND cream, and we'll flavor it with onions AND garlic AND chillies AND cilantro!"  The ambiance is just being consistent with their approach to aesthetics.  The whole point is to feel like the animal that you are.  The wild orgy of your dreams has to be in a sleazy motel, not a church.

When you ask Shalimar to clean its bathrooms, you are asking Jackson Pollock to work on his shading.  You're asking punk rock to tune its strings.  You want Mozart?  Go to Chez Panisse or the French Laundry.  I'll be busy choking on seekh kabobs.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I used to ditch class regularly in college for Shalimar. This was mostly because we would run down there for lunch and then be unable to function in any afternoon classes, laid waste by the delicious food coma of spicy thick murgh masala, boti kebab, and garlic naan. It really used to be a special place, busting out all ethnic and pakistani when everyone else was doing the more royal indian vibe, and furthermore it was foiling the degradation of its surroundings with the shock value of quality.

But it's gone a bit downhill of late, and I'm informed by a source close to the community (I got friends, okay?) that the owner isn't around anymore and doesn't really care as much about the quality. This is probably because he has a neverending queue of wealthy white hipsters lined up to give him money, and he lives in some gated community in Fremont taking baths in dollar bills. Ain't nothing wrong with that; I am all about separating rich white kids from their money at every opportunity. But if I'm going to give any purveyor of delicious tandoori my money, it's going to be my badass friend Paracha over at Tasty Curry.
author: Megan W.

description:
they had the best chicken tikka masala.  it was great last year.  i went this year, and it seemed to have dropped a notch.  but i shall return and re-review if it goes back to my prior visits.

besides that i had the murgh korma shahi.  that actually tasted better than the CTM if you are into spicier food.  the naan was great as usual.  do not go here expecting ambience and black napkins.  it is a hole in the wall and run like a taqueira.  ultra casual with good food. 

 i would recommend eating at the restaurant rather than getting it to go. the naan tends to dry out if you wait too long.  they do not rub butter on their naan like other indian/pakistani places.  so it is pretty dry.  very similar to the bread you would get in pakistan, afghanistan, north india, etc.
author: Frances H.

description:
There should be two categories - food and ambiance! Food gets 5 stars. Wow, this food is good...finger licking good! Best Indian food, by far, in the city. Prices can't be beat either...

Ambiance: I haven't been for awhile - not that it makes a difference - but waiting 15 minutes out front while friends arrived certainly provided many unwanted visuals. Sorta curbs your appetite...
Advice - get in the door ASAP. ...better yet - order ahead with food to go!
author: Ron W.

description:
Everytime I come here I feel like I'm eating in some dirty cafeteria in some run down federal building with crappy lighting but the food makes it oh so worth it and I keep coming back. I always end up just ordering the Tikka Masala with Naan. If you are used to Naan N Curry this version's sauce is more of a red color and is not nearly as thick but has much better flavor.  I'm going to just take a guess here and say its probably better for you too since it doesn't seem to have as much cream as Nann n' Curry either. 

Honestly, until Amber opens up on Market street there really isn't very good Indian food in SF. Go to Sunnyvale or Fremont in the south bay and you'll see what I mean.  Unless I feel like driving for an hour though this hits the spot and the one on Polk is within walking distance. Bonus.
author: Morgan H.

description:
I always passed by this restaurant on my way to other places, and I finally had the right mind to go in and try some of the food.  I ordered my staple, Chicken Tikka Masala and it was good.  And the other reason why it was so good was because it was also AFFORDABLE!  

The portions were pretty hearty and you can help yourself to some of the complimentary tea.  Although the restaurant itself is a bit on the grungy side, it's definitely not a deterrent if you truly love affordable and good Indian food - especially if you're living in the tendernob area.
author: Shay F.

description: My favorite Indian/Pakistani fast casual place in the City.  As divy as this place looks, the food is second to none.  I just love the fact the yI can go to to liquor store next door and buy my favorite six pack to enjoy with my meal!
author: Honeya O.

description:
Awesome. The Jones St location is as good or even better than the other ones. The only thing is this is the smallest space of the 4 locations. But the cooking is awesome. We ordered my standard selections, bhuna gosht (lamb curry), kabli chana (chickpea curry), tandoori chicken, naan, and my friends threw in the chicken tikka masala. 

I never tried CTM here before and thought it was great, nice spicy and savory curry (w/o too much cream), I would order it again. My favorite lamb curry came with bone marrow, which was just orgasmic. The pieces of lamb were very tender too. The tandoori chicken we ordered was boneless, and a tad on the dry side. Nothin the mint chutney can't fix though. I'd go with bones though next time. Lastly, the fresh naan came to the table so piping hot, our fingers were practically burning.

I noticed the dishes were less greasy than ones I've tried in the other locations, and that seems to be the main complaint of Shalimar. Heed the sketchy neighborhood warning though.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I had some daal today from the Polk St. Shalimar today...I'm gonna stick with Jones St. from here on out.

The experience did inspire me to try and cook up an Indian meal of my own for dinner tonight, so they deserve some credit for that.

Daal was good, but the Naan was a little weak.
author: Jason R.

description: This was my third visit in two weeks ... Just floored by the quality of the food. Some may consider the place to be not of great hygiene but who cares as long as the food is awesome... And bonus is the price ..too less for such an awesome meal ...
author: Chetan M.

description: Excellent and I mean excellent nehari. I am addicted to nehari and have tried everywhere, this place is up there with some of the other restaurants
author: Bilal J.

description:
I love Shalimar. Seriously this is amazing Paki/Indian food. The dudes that run it are pretty nice too.

You must freaking get the Chicken Jalfrezi. It is the best food that has ever been made. I want to have a daughter JUST so I can name her Jing-Jing Jalfrezi (has a ring, don't it?) in honor of this dish.

It isn't the type of place you want to entertain business contacts (unless you can pull it off as an asset like I do -- see Larry C's review below, here's the magic line: "Times like these, you gotta be capital efficient. I'm getting an amazing dinner for $5 by trading off the non-essentials, like cleanliness.")

On a serious note, Mickey S I feel your pain about the Mumbai attacks, pure tragedy, I think it's also tragic that you would use that event to be even more divisive, let's not put another wedge between Indians and Pakistanis -- remember, an eye for an eye leaves the whole world blind.
author: Tyler W.

description:
Ok, so I'm comparing this place to the other Indian/Pakistani places in the neighborhood, mainly Lahore Karahi and Tikka Masala.
I ordered the same thing as the other places, which is a side of rice and the chicken tikka masala.  
Flavorwise, the food here was very good.  The tikka masala has a good amount of heat and the rice was very nicely flavored.
HOWEVER:  You had to spoon your way through a half inch of oil before you could get to it.
No good.
The portions are pretty meager too, ESPECIALLY when compared to Lahore Karahi.
I'd have to say that now, my favorites are in this order:
1.  Lahore Karahi BUT ONLY WHEN THE OWNER IS IN!
2.  Tikka Masala tied with Shalimar.
Next stop:  Chutney!
author: Meh M.

description:
Oh blessed Shiva, is this place good! But you have to wear an industrial HazMat suit and lead gloves to wade through the Tenderloin muck surrounding the place. 

The perfect way to cap a 'Loin pub crawl -- whether you're hanging with the dregs at Club 21 or with the swells at Bourbon & Branch. The CnH2n+1OH circulating in your bloodstream and liver has met its match in the Palaak Paneer and Chicken Tikka Masala, which will soak that alcohol right up with the absorbency to rival Charmin. Oops, am I allowed to use product placement in a review?
author: Suzanne R.

description:
A trip into the dark heart of the Tenderloin is sort of a rite of passage for the SF cuisine expeditionary, and I had heard Shalimar's name so many times that it seemed like the natural place to go (although I was surprised to find it's far from the only Indian dive in these parts).

As you'd expect, it's small, dingy, and hot inside (coming here during the heat wave was probably not the best idea).  You order from the friendly-but-frantically-busy guys at the counter, help yourself to some free chai, and wait for the heaping bowls of tasty, oily curry to come out.  In short, it's a lot like Naan 'n' Curry, only not as nice inside and a lot farther from home (for a westsider, anyway).  So I wouldn't make a special pilgrimage for it, but Tendernobbers (or as the Chronicle hails them, "urban pioneers") could do a lot worse for their Ol' Reliable.
author: Wes M.

description:
I love this place simply because the average yelper would probably cringe upon entering.

It is old San Francisco pre yuppie and pre yelp.

I love dirty ambiance and think it drives away people I don't care to eat near..namely yuppies.

I don't mind walking up to the restaurant and seeing a circle of people smoking crack on the sidewalk. I'm in the Tenderloin and that's how the Tenderloin rolls.

I walk in and meet my friend who guides me through their system.

You walk up to the unfriendly counter person (you'd be unfriendly too if you had to deal with crackheads followed by yuppies who expect everything done for them) and order off of the menu, pump your own chai, and wait for your out of control delicious indian food which you pay for at the counter when you are done with your meal.

The garlic naan is out of control good...the best i've ever eaten.

The food is so awesome and flavorful and yes greasy.

You know what?

Sometimes I like greasy food and I have say that I know I'm not alone out there.

I found myself getting really offended by the reviews I was reading that complained about that.

This place is a greasy dive treasure. 

Don't go to the greasy dive expecting healthy gourmet bistro food or service. It's not that kind of place, you know what kind of place it is.

Cheap, greasy, Indian, delicious, dirty.

Love it. Great people watching. Really sad I missed the massage of breast feeding mom with the exposed titty. 

Now that's a special sight while you are eating.
author: Deez N.

description:
"Biryani only on Fri." Oh no! Just when I was craving Biryani, that's not good. But ended up in having the chicken Boti (excellent) and the chicken kadhai (ehhhhhh) My husband swears by this place but I thought it was about average. Typical Pakistani joint like the one we used to frequent in Chicago Baba Palace. Shalimars boti was awesome... one of the best I have had ever. 
I was surprised at how clean I thought it was... until I read the yelp reviews about the roaches. The other thing that surprised me was that a lot of people seem to frequent this place. The area is kinda sketchy around there (understatement of the year) 

For the 3rd and last time.... mouth wateringly good boti.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Yeah, I know, this place looks like it was some 80's travel agent's office that got converted into an Indian restaurant...

... but don't be fooled, the food is delicious.

If you're thinking candle light and wine, look somewhere else.  It's questionable as a date joint.  It's in a crusty neighborhood and it doesn't get any nicer than the budget chairs and tables, but then again don't girls want something different than just your average nice restaurant?  

The food is stellar.  It's well spiced, delicious and ours came out fast.  The naan is fluffy and good.  I ate as much of my lamb and spinach as I could before realizing I was just way too full.  My mind said "eat that now you weak sauce &$%#$" but my body said "Noooo!  I Can't do it! I gotta have a few beers after this!"

Parking looks like a crap shoot, but if you don't mind walking a few blocks, the Powell Street Muni stop is like 4 blocks away.
author: Steven R.

description:
Yumm. Tyler Willis took me here

He is hot and Shalimar is good
author: Larry C.

description:
The food was just as good the second time around. But when my partner returned a mango lassi because she didn't like it, the guy behind the counter gave her lip (and I think he still charged us for it anyway).

AND on the way out, I noticed the health score. 66. Disgusting.
author: Stu M.

description:
I came to the Polk St. restaurant about a month ago and ordered Chicken Saag with rice.

I ended up waiting 30 minutes for my food. At least 2 other parties of 2 people that ordered 10 minutes after I did were served 10 minutes before I was served.

The chicken in my saag was rubbery - over-cooked. The saag was pretty unimpressive as well.

I've been coming to the Jones St. restaurant since 1997 - my boss at the time was Punjabi... I've liked the restaurant ever since.

Although the person who actually took money from me (for a meal that was outrageously late, a meal which I was served long after other patrons who ordered long after me,) apologized I'm outraged that he didn't offer my meal for free.

I was once in an Indian restaurant with my boss - that had incredibly bad and slow service - he said - 'We get up and leave'. I said: Don't we have to pay? He said 'No. They will understand.' We walked out after the first course and the restaurant staff understood why.

I SHOULD NOT have had to suffer through so insultingly slow service and I should not have been charged for a lousy and excessively late meal. As near as I can tell Shalimar doesn't care.

I'm sorry I chose Shalimar for dining.  You can be certain that I'll never eat there again.

Perhaps their reputation is better  than they deserve.
author: Lee D.

description:
Shalimar is a great place to grab lunch or dinner when you're craving rich, hot, spicy, incredibly flavorful Indian/Pakistani. I could live on their chicken tikka masala, palak paneer, daal masala and garlic naan for the rest of my life and be a happy woman.

It's cheap, poorly/barely decorated, almost always smoky inside and requires you to visit the Tenderloin but the food is excellent and the staff makes up for what they lack in the way of warmth and personal interaction with efficiency and consistency. I like that it's way casual and maybe even a little scary to some because that means there's less competition for food that I really want and suckers out there who have never had truly good garlic naan.

My Shalimar tips:

1) Call in your order and pick-up. Since walking around the TL isn't especially fun and street parking is almost impossible at night, getting someone to drop you off and go around the block while you pick up delish Shalimar is a great way to go. They put your curry dishes in paper take-out boxes and wrap them with plastic while the food is still so hot that it's almost like shrink wrap - and just as hard to remove later. This makes it easy to transport by car (or even Muni) without worrying about awful oil stains or spills.

2) For the least sketchy walk to Shalimar, go west on Geary from Union Square and make a left at Jones. This way you only have about 1.5 blocks of true Tenderloin to brave.

3) BYOB. Good thing there's so many liquor stores in the area to choose from.

4) Try the mango lassi. It's yummy and good for spice relief.
author: Kristina A.

description:
It's all been said before, but I would like to add my 2 cents worth for what it's worth.

Great food for a reasonable price, but come here for the side show.  If you like to people watch this is the place.  All sorts of very "interesting" people.

But hey we all have at least one thing in common, we all love Shalimar!

Oh and like other have said BYOB - to complete the feast!
author: A P.

description:
I came here on a date with a guy who said a friend had recommended this place.  So we stopped here and tried to sort out how to order and such.  I got the Saag Chicken with rice and he got some ... I dunno.  It had a bit of a kick to it, but it was beef and quite good.  As was the naan and rice.

They seem to do a lot of take out which is ideal as the space is a bit limited, especially during the dinner hour.  If I'm around in the neighborhood, I'd come here again ... it's worth a visit.
author: imelda j.

description:
My favorite Indian restaurant in the city, hands down. It's cheap, tasty, and a short walk from my house! 

Things to try: 

Garlic Naan- yes it is $2 more but well worth it
Lamb Curry- I can't recall the exact name of it.. but it is AMAZING!
Spinach/cheese dish- Once again.. not so good on the name but its a must have!
Any BBQ 

I also love the outdoor seating so I can watch the tenderloin nutsos walk by.
author: Sarah W.

description:
You have to rate the place based on what it is, not on what you would like it to be.

What it is: 
* a CASH-only joint
* dirty
* seat and order yourself
* good indian meat dishes

What it is NOT:
* a place to go on a first date
* going here if you are a vegetarian

I like this place a lot, usually for takeout. But you have to be picky about what you order. Their tandoori stuff is great, not so great on their veggie dishes. 

My favs:
- chicken tikka masala
- kebabs
- tandoori lambchops/chicken

P.S. My dad has had brains here(!), but it's not on the menu. (It's like in-n-out -- you just gotta KNOW).
author: Radha S.

description: I haven't explored the Indian food scene enough in SF, but this place certainly ranks high and they know what they're doing. You have to make sure you place your order and get any of the servers' attention because they're not going to wait on you hand-and-foot.
author: Marcus J.

description:
I went here once -- one time too many -- and I'd say the food was just okay (really oily).

But the reason for the single star is that this is, by a long shot, the FILTHIEST restaurant I've ever been to.  Buckets of raw chicken on the floor.  Nasty bathroom (which is where the kitchen staff presumably washes up, if they are so inclined).  And I've been to a lot of filthy restaurants, but this one takes the cake.  My friends laugh because whenever they mention Shalimar it reminds me that I keep meaning to report them to the Board of Health.
author: Mark T.

description:
This is some amazing food. Just like other SF classics such as Taqueria Cancun, it doesn't look like much, but the food is amazing.

Just spicy enough, without crying, and flavorful as all hell, the food is better than the other more expensive north Indian/Pakistani places within a mile or two. If you're looking for service, linens, nice paintings, well, go somewhere else. This is the closest thing I've found to what I experienced in India - amazing food, no fancy amenities (and no bugs, which is different from India).

Long story short, probably not a first date or wedding anniversary type place, but an excellent choice when looking for some really amazing north Indian/Pakistani food. Go there. Eat. Be happy, and full.
author: Ben K.

description: This was our original go to Indian place.  "Go to" meaning, we would go to it and take out and eat somewhere else.  When we would get to our destination the saag would be seeping oil through the take out box, which was knowingly and considerately wrapped with saran wrap.  We eagerly and happily ate away.  As the number of Indian restaurants across the city have grown, we have drifted from this location.  But we have found ourselves a few times at the Fremont location, which has a great beef shank and once again, saag with spinach that isn't overly chopped.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
The Pakistani embassy should just pack up in Washington and instead move into this location, cause there isn't anything else you're going to find in this country that is closer to Lahori food. Let me tell you: I'm from Pakistan, I've been going to Shalimar for the last 10 years (since they opened), and I yet have to find a Pakistani (or Indian) place in this city that is as authentic as Shalimar. They even have tubelights that flicker!
Yes, the neighbourhood might leave a lot to be desired, but one bite of the Chicken Koftas and you will feel like you're sitting in a Mughal emperor's lap. Yes, the place is noisy, but your ears will instead be ringing due to the spices in the Nihari. Yes, it's a hole-in-the-wall, but it's probably the best hole-in-the-wall you'll eat at this side of the Khyber Pass.
author: KebabKing ..

description:
One of the best deals in San Francisco.  A decent meal can be had at this place for under $8.  The neighborhood is very seedy and the restaurant is a little dirty, but the food is excellent.

The plain naan is excellent, properly doughy and charred.  The murgh tikka lahori is nicely char broiled, just a tad dry on the inside.  The same goes for the tandoori boti.  Side sauces or a curry dish, may help with the dryness.

The mango lassi drink was delicious and a great offset to the heavy flavors.

You must order at the counter and the food will be brought to your table.  The service there is rough around the edges, but tolerable for the cheap prices and excellent food.
author: Parris B.

description:
My favorite Indian food in the city.

I love the spices they use and the portions are generous. They have the best Naan and their Chicken Tika Masala I can't eat fast enough. My animalistic instincts come out in here because I try to devour the food as fast as possible once it hits the table.

If your looking for some classy place then go somewhere else. This is all about the food but does offer plenty of room to eat in. If you are like me and appreciate a place thats on the dive side and offers great food then you will love Shalimar on Jones.

I should also mention that the prices are CHEAP!
author: Patrick B.

description: I love naan and I love chicken tandoori.  They have both for a good price right near my house.  They round off one of the best blocks for food in the city.
author: Corey V.

description:
I'm torn with this place:

The waiter told us it was a "Pakistani / Indian" restaurant, as if the differences between the two cuisines was like comparing American to Canadian food (eh).

First and foremost, its cheap as hell, which is good. For 7 of us, i think it came to less then $10 per person.

Secondly, the look of the food, and the restaurant itself, isn't great. Of the 7 or 8 dishes we ordered, half of them looked identical, and as if it had all been plopped out of massive pots in the kitchen.

The food did taste pretty good though, and I left thinking that, yeah, I'd probably go back.

Then, it hit me - the familiar feeling that, for the next few hours anyway, my gastrointestinal tract would be dictating the rest of my night. So, sparing the gory details - lets just say, that $10 I spent at Shalimar, didn't seem like such a great investment anymore.

Will I go back? Probably...but only after a heavy night of drinking.
author: Lee M.

description:
Oh Shalimar.  How much do I love your food?  I love it in so many ways.  Despite the crappy neighborhood you are in, despite the crackheads hanging out outside, despite the feeling that I feel like my friends and I are going to be mugged around the corner, why do I feel like I need to go back to you so soon?

My favorite food that you have is your daal masala.  It is even better than the daal I get when I am eating at home.  Even though your building is very much a dive, your silverware and plates are clean, although I still wouldn't want to glance too much into the kitchen area.

I will have to come back to you, Shalimar.  Very soon.  I promise I will.
author: Kyle D.

description:
GO!! Period. if you like Indian/Pakistani food, this is pure heaven. They have other restuarants in the Bay Area as well. Their Fremont location is equally awesome with an identical menu. You will reek of the food after you leave because the place has poor ventilation. The bathroom will make you vomit (when it's clean) and make your skin peel when it's dirty. But I don't go there for the bathroom... I go for the BOMB ASS FOOD:

Kabobs - awesome with some chutney and yogurt wrapped inside their supreme naan. spicy as hell, but SO ADDICTING

Lamb Chops - If you like lamb, GET THEM!!! Period. Do it... don't ask.

Saag Gosht/Palak Gosht - Spinach, lamb, heaven. It's that good. 

Chicken Masala - authentic... none of that sweet sh!t you find at Naan & Curry

Rice and Naan - Supreme. Their Rice is good enough to convert Atkin's dieters to carb loaders. 

***I like Naan & Curry, just not as much as this place. Naan and Curry is for the masses, Shalimar is for the kings and queens. 

In short... GO!!!!!!!! GO TO SHALIMAR. IT'S THAT F*CKING GOOD!
author: Arick R.

description:
Don't be intimidated by the crazies on the street or the organized chaos of the restaurant. The food here is great. I've had the chicken tikka masala and bhuna gosht (lamb) a few different times. The only thing I don't like is they leave some of the spices (pepper and seeds) in the dishes and the rice. DON'T eat it!  Also, one disappointing thing is when you ask for 'spicy' they just thrown in a few chopped jalapenos - India is the country of a thousand spices, none are hot? meh. But these plates and the naan are delicious! Prices are great! 
Not sure how sanitary this place is but what doesn't kill you makes you stronger! Makes you feel like you're really in India! lol

Too bad they don't deliver!
author: Jenna P.

description:
Rats!!!  

Not what I want to see running under my table. All I can say is don't let them sit you in the back room.

The food was delicious but I had already lost my appetite.

And if you don't believe me, check out their health inspection scorecard on the SF Dept of Health Website:
 
http://dphwww.sfdph.org/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=2114
author: Rob G.

description: The menu's are physically gigantic. The restaurant is filthy. It's not horribly expensive, though for what they're offering as an eating area it's really a toss up. There were flies when we ate there, which I would suggest they just throw a screen door on there or something, because the last thing this place needs is another reason to not come here.
author: Sean W.

description:
This place is a dump.  It's got that usual stinky tranny hookers and crackhead Tenderloin ambiance.   You can go to the bodega next door and grab a sixpack of beer, seat yourself in a booth and wait for your food.

The food itself is fantastic. The saag gosht was the best I've ever had. The naan was good, the dal was good, everything was really good. And really fresh. And really cheap.  A feast for four cost us under $40.   Definitely worth the dodgy neighborhood.
author: Anthony R.

description:
So dumpy looking!!
But great indian food, easy to tell since it's always packed with idian families around meal time. 

Great touch is that the milk tea is free! Yay!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Rats.

That about sums it up.

On my way to the loo I stopped to look outside the open door at what a lovely clear night it was in SF. No fog, sweet. Pan down... are my eyes deceiving me? Am I suddenly in an Indiana Jones movie? Why, pray tell, is there an entire _colony_ of rats snacking oh-so-leisurely on the bags of garbage outside? Did you see Ratatouille? I am talking easily 40 rats all eating/drinking from the stream of wet that the holes in the garbage bag were leaking.

I was equally revolted and drawn to it. They were not afraid. But they looked healthy...

This occured after dinner, thank Vishnu.

I never made it to the loo. I heard it was not the best.
author: Kenna T.

description:
This is totally a Trash Monster kind of place--gross fluorescent lighting slightly dingy decor & a newspaper for a menu [um..hello? Newspapers are dying. Its all about blogging now!]

My two favorites are the Chicken Tikka Masala & Saag Paneer. This is the best CTM In the city. I've branched out before & gotten other things like some vegetable mush or two, but each time I curse myself for not having had ordered the CTM. After ordering some veggie mush I happen to sit down next to two nice Pakistani/Indian men who happened to be eating CTM [BTW, rule of thumb: if people of that ethnicity are eating the food in that establishment, you know its good] I told them how much I was mad at myself for venturing forth into other territory & they understood. Since i was practically drooling on them at their food, they gave me the rest of their CTM. 

Such yumminess! 

AND free tea! Take THAT Pakwan!
author: Rebekah K.

description:
Ok, so the place is a dump. what do you expect, given the location? The crackheads and prostitutes lingering outside the door make it look like the gateway to hell. but your dining experience won't be hell, if you just accept this place for what it is...

its a DHABA (24/7 highway truckstops located throughout india that specialize in oily, cheap-ass punjabi fare).
yes, shalimar is 100% dhaba. but it is completely, deliciously authentic. just don't come expecting an upscale dining experience.

the first time i came here i was 13 and on the road to becoming a self-hating indian... at least, i hated all indian food. with the exception of naan bread, because how can anyone (aside from those with gluten allergies) hate that stuff? but yeah i hated all those delicious homemade indian dishes that my parents would throw my way and only ate the naan. 
Then shalimar opened its first location in SF, and my relatives in the area dragged me here (against my will, of course) and wow... two words: TANDOORI CHICKEN LEG. ok that was three, but i really had to add the "leg" because the thigh and leg pieces are best. 

Hands down best tandoori dishes i've ever had - chicken, lamb chops, seekh kabab - order them all to get the true shalimar experience. the curries are really oily so i wouldn't go too crazy with those, though. the best ones are goat (no really - i know indians who drive 40 miles in the fog for it on the only day its available (thursdays)) and chicken kofta, which is a safe bet for mainstream palates as well.

5 stars for saving me from a self-hating fate. Thanks, shalimar!

oh and the naan is great as well, duh.

P.S. a word to the wise - the jones st original location is best, so yes you'll have to wade through the sea of crack addicts.
author: A K S.

description: Amazing Food...So Fresh and cheap with good quality meat. Chicken Sheesh kabob are to die for.
author: Kin Kin S.

description:
I like the fact that the menus are printed on newspapers. I would someday like to work for the Shalimar Menu (I could have the Naan Column).

I also like the BYOB, brilliant idea, so you can stuff your face and get loaded for cheap, word -- and the way they cook their ginger okra. Mutha fucka! Some good okra. Also, eating the chicken and goat harachi makes me feel like a savage, in the absolute best way possible. That's what happens when you crush bones to get at the marrow. 

Someone told me that in India the Indian food (redundant?) is "less like a big stewey gloppy motherfucking mess." I'll take my big sloppy mess, and sweating like a pig as I eat it. 

Thanks, Shalimar.
author: Chris R.

description: Absolutely authentic cuisine. Line was out the door. Everything I had from the Tandoori was delicious. May god bless Tandoori's everywhere!
author: Gregory H.

description:
Good food.

Really cheap.

You can bring your own alcohol.

Lines can be long and the place can be busy because of good food and alcohol policy (they also sell beer for cheap).

Not exactly a date kind of place, but good for take out or a quick dinner.
author: B K.

description: Ok so here's the truth about this place. When I first found Shalimaar I wanted to turn around and leave because its in a terrible location in SF. The place is definitely a hole in the wall but the food is AMAZING!! Best Indian food I've ever had for sure!!
author: nabil s.

description:
Fabio is Italian.  Fabio's second favorite cusine is Indian.  Interesting.  I know.

Well, Gaylord, Naan n Curry, and Tandoori Majal just doesn't do it for him.  He wanted Shalimar.  So we all go try Shalimar.  (for some reason, saruman just got stuck in my head when he said shalimar....)

Wow.  Shalimar is indeed flavor packed.  As if Indian food in general aren't flavor-packed enough.  Their dishes are just extra spicy (as in the spices), and extra flavorful.  They probably put crack in it....  Mighty tasty.  Mighty greesy.  Chicken Tikka masala is among the favorites no doubt.  The one with spinach and cheese was EXECELLENT.

We went in a Chinese, a Italian, an African, and came back out all Indians.  At least we smell like one....
author: Gigi T.

description:
It was our third date. On our second date I had taken him to some upscale Indian place, after which he told me with surprising assertiveness that he needed to take me to Shalimar. 

There was a drunk homeless person lying in front of the restaurant, and we were surrounded by neon massage parlor signs. I walked in thinking "this is probably our last date."

He knew the menu well, so he ordered for both of us. Chicken tikka masala, chicken saagwala, some rice dish, mango lassis, naan. OMG. I don't think I ever had real Indian food until Shalimar. I was blown away by the flavors and richness of the dishes. I walked out thinking "this guy is amazing." This was a long time ago, and we've since parted ways, but Shalimar still ranks in my top 3 places for Indian (the other two are in NY).
author: Deb I.

description:
I am not an Indian food fan but this place is amazing.

Total dive.  Paper menus.  Terrific food.

also pretty cheap.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I have a bone to pick with a lot of you fellow Yelpsters. First of all, this is not Indian food. This is Pakistani cuisine. Yes, similar dishes, similar flavors, but totally different culturally. It's like calling someone from Whales an Irish. Just isn't cool guys. Let's get a little more cultured here.

No point in reviewing the food here. Everyone already knows it's one of the original, and best Paki places in the Bay =).
author: Charles K.

description: Craving Shalimar at the moment so I figure the least I could do is put in a positive review. Was introduced to this place by a friend and I have paid it forward and introduced it to the majority of my other friends and family. Service could be better but the quality of the food gives it 5 stars.!
author: Jaz S.

description:
Um this place is a legend and the food lives up to it.

That is all.

Oh, and I am Pakistani.
author: Raza M.

description:
When you walk in, the food smells is so wonderful you forget all about the not-so-nice smells you had to encounter on your way there through the tenderloin.

The taste is even better than the smell.
author: lisa g.

description:
Seriously, the best, non-evasive Indian food I've had in a while. Meaning: no "Wrath of Naan" type stuff a few hours after your meal ;)

You can feed a table of 10 for only $60 if you really wanted to. 
Great garlic naan (even better for your date) and really scrumptious kebob. (Hopefully your date's is too, heh)

If you don't mind the colorful locale, the flies around your table or the influx of groups of 7 or more later on in the evening, than it's worth it. I've been twice  and I'll go back again!
author: Jessica P.

description: Great indian food, very filling and flavorful, with lots of spices. You order and pay up at the front, seat yourself, etc. I think the food is great here, but I always tend to pick Lahore Karahi around the corner, over this place. Dishes at Lahore are a bit more nutty/buttery and I smell alot better when I leave there than when I leave Shalimar. The tandoori smoke at Shalimar reminds me of the time I accidentally melted a plastic bag on the stove, and the fumes that resulted.  Dottie's is right next door, Bourbon & Branch is right across the street for some good drinks.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Oh snaps! Not the best location in the neighborhood, as long as you don't mind the homeless, drug dealers, and trannies on the street corners. If you drive a nice, semi-expensive looking car, you might want to park it at the local garages. (there's 1 right across the street from Shalimar and another down the street, around the corner) Unless you're a frugal cheapass and want street parking, just remember to hide your sh!t out of view and move them to your trunk. 

But daaaaaaaamn, the food is GOOD and worth the trip to a sh!tty neighborhood. Disclaimer: I'm generally not a fan of Indian food. However, I'm glad my friend dragged my butt over to Shalimar for a good time. *NOTE: CASH ONLY*  Remember to hit the ATM before coming here!

It's true what other yelpers have said, the Chicken Masala is a dish worth ordering. Especially the sauce off the dish is mouthwatering when you dip naan bread into it. Rice is a bit bland, but what do you expect? IT'S RICE. 

As for atmosphere, they definitely need to work on it. C'mon now, even the cheap Chinese slops in Chinatown have better decor!!
author: Camilla W.

description:
Really good, if you are in the neighborhood. My neighborhood Shalimar is on Polk, and both share the same unfortunate interior. Would it kill these folks to install some non-flourescent lighting?

Anyway, what we come here for is the food. When I think "Indian in SF," I think "Shalimar." These dishes are authentic Indian - the good stuff that you find at a side-of-the-road dhaba in some village with limited electricity. It's got street cred.
author: Sahra H.

description:
This place is fucking screamin'.  Don't be afraid of the neighborhood.  Don't be afraid of the dirty walls.  Don't be afraid of the roaches, flies or other dead insects invading your table.  Just concentrate on the food, and you'll be fine.   

Blind people love this place.
author: Larry A.

description:
Before entering this fine establishment please visit the corner liquor store, grab yourself a forty, throw it in a paper bag and then head on over to the restaurant.  Please note the bottle opener fastened to the door of the liquor store on your way out.  Convenient and classy.  

I don't really have much experience with this type of food.  My experience is actually limited to a buffet in Brighton, England and one late night in Pasadena, CA.  So I'm obviously not an expert.  That being said, I enjoyed the food.  I took suggestions from my date and ended up telling the server what combination of flavors, veggies and meat I would enjoy and he brought out something that looked like horse puke (green, leafy, grainy with chunks).  However, it was a bundle of garlic, chicken and spinach heaven with some other spices (a little spicy for me, but I'm a big wimp).  The rice and naan were fantabulous as well.  I recommend this place to anyone looking for a little culinary adventure in an interesting neighborhood.  A homeless man hailed us a cab as we left - again convenient and classy!
author: M J.

description:
Solid good. Not much bad to say as I got the masala, the most average indian food ever. The Naan was pretty amazing, as other reviewers have stated. Super greasy, which is good, just get a decent pile of napkins before.

Sitting there waiting for the food, I thought that this place is probably going to be one of those restaurants where you aren't impressed by decor or ambiance, but quality food, and I was spot on. This is the type of place you see everyone enjoying themselves and their mouths as the munch on quality food, regardless of how much they made that day.  

Also, walking in that place made my nose rejoice, which probably set me up with a good attitude from the get go.
author: Peter W.

description:
Five stars for the overall experience. I felt like I was in Karachi or Lahore or something. We came here on a tip from a friend who said we had to come here when we're in San Francisco because it's what he eats every other day when he's in the area.

He warned us it was a dirty joint and upon curious visual inspection of the kitchen (which is exposed), I could confirm that. But all of this didn't matter because I had heard such good things about the food. And if it's that good, I'm cool with a cash register sitting right next to the grill.

So when my wife and I walked in, all of the tables were full, but a table of two stood up almost immediately and left. We waited confused whether to wait to sit there or wait to be seated...? It's not clear how it works here but we stood there by the door for about 2 minutes anyway looking confused and presumably out of place, then we just sat at the dirty table; we didn't want to lose it!

Then this nice man who I thought I saw sitting at the table next to us walked back over and said, "here, let me get those for you" and he took this dishes away and then he used one of the soiled paper napkins left on the table to wipe it crumb free for us. Then he informed us: "You order at the counter. I'll bring you some menus." 

OK, so the service is pretty friendly...  We thanked him, then, as he started to walk toward the door, I asked him, "do you work here?" He said, "no, I just eat here. I just wanted to help you!" And he smiled and walked out wit his wife. Hmm...? That was nice. Without him, we probably would have been sitting there for a while.

So we have the menus and their 2 feet wide, printed like newspapers. The selection is huge and the prices are ridiculously cheap so we ordered tons of stuff.

Lamb brain masala - chopped lamb brain in a creamy, spicy masala sauce. Surprisingly delicious. Rich! Very rich... and sort of fatty tasting, at least the consistency was fatty like.

Garlic naan - a thick buttery, freshly baked round of naan bread stuffed with tons of fresh garlic and herbs. Great for dipping in the raita.

Raita - theirs was a thin one - yogurt with cucmber, chopped raisins. Perfect to cool the heat from the entrees.

Kofte kebab - a little on the dry side but full of spicy complexity.

Tandoori chicken leg - Delicious smokiness that penetrated the meat. Well marinated but not too sweet. And it was moist and hot. Very good!

Murgha chicken something... AKA "the king of curries" on their menu - pretty good but it didn't stand out from all of the other good stuff on the table. Bone-in chicken pieces in a reddish oily curry. Good but not wow.

The meal also came with a plate of sliced onions and jalapenos sprinkled with indian spices. They were good to throw in the naan with the kofte and wrap it up.

Yes, the kitchen was grimy and greasy but it lent to the experience. Definitely one of the best dining experiences as of recently!
author: Aa-Ron L.

description:
Deeeeeeeelicious.  Absolutely delicious.  I was at the Prescott Hotel and decided to boogie down the street in my leisure suit jivin to P-Funk (okay not really but it would have been cool, you must admit) and find something interesting to munch down.  I initially stopped at the Halal Chinese place up the block and wasn't impressed by their five-item buffet, so I stopped in here.  It is certainly a proliteriat-style joint.... not much going on in the way of decor.  Off-white walls, granite-topped tables (cheap ones, though), open kitchen that looks like it was installed a half-century ago.

The ordering process was a bit odd... go up to the counter, look at the menu (which is on newsprint, in newspaper format??  interesting...), choose your items, order, and then go sit and wait.  Don't pay till you've eaten.  I was a bit turned off by the lack of samosas and pakoras... samosas are one of the ways that I guage an Indian restaurant so I was crushed.  The prices are quite fair... $5.95 for a vegetarian entree, $1 per piece of naan, 2 papadoums, or a bit of raita... not bad at all.

I'd not heard of this place, or how it's been voted best restaurant in SF or in the top 50 restaurants in the US by various journals when I stopped in.  But when they brought my paneer masala to the table, I could certainly see why it's so storied.  It was absolutely wonderful; the sauce was rich without being so imposingly dense like so many other rich masalas are, and the paneer was perfect; firm without being squishy, flavorful without being too intrusive.  The fresh naan was fluffy and light, and the rice was quite flavorful as well.  Wow.  I'll certainly be back here.

The lack of samosas or pakoras is disheartening, and while what little service there was wasn't impolite, it was very blah and somewhat uninspiring.  Because of these things I can't feel truly right about five stars, but, don't get me wrong.... the food here is amazing.
author: Tristan S.

description:
The food in this place is effing good and I can see that many people here agree, assuming that they're people. BUT, BUT, BUT... I've been here when the door to the 'lot' on the other side was open and I saw chicken meat in open container on the ground with a bunch of pidgeon swarming around, just saying.
My reaction to my family was "if you guys look through that door there's chicken on the floor and birds flying about." (I thought I'd inform them while we're eating chicken). My family looked through the door and then we continue eating in silence. WTF!
I'd still go here, but a note to Shalimar that if they're going to have shit like that at least cover it a little bit.
Good brain curry! 
I usually leave this place with my stomach burning, oh so wonderful.
author: John L.

description:
Dingy, in the TL, and not a methadone clinic.

Goes to show the best food is at the hole in the wall establishments.

Food is greasy, cheap, but very tasty. And apparently is BYOB since there were plenty of paper bags and all kinds of beers at people's tables.

Parking can suck, but its definitely in a convenient location... convenient if you are craving Pakistani food and need to pick up some crack.
author: Rocky K.

description:
WARNING:  Yep... parking can be a (rhymes with "witch").  Don't let that deter you from giving your belly some GOOD LOVIN'!!!

WARNING 2:  This place is PACKED --- ALL THE TIME!!!  It's located in the heart of the Tenderloin --- don't expect anything more than a DIVE... with AMAZING Pakistani cuisine...

The food is VERY flavorful!  Just order everything --- and it's DIRT CHEAP!  The naan is made to order --- yummy with just the right amount of crispiness without losing it's flakiness.

If you're adventurous --- try EVERYTHING --- including the lamb brains... it's really delicious!
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
I always walked by this place on the wait to Dottie's True Blue and thought, who in the hell would eat here. For Indian food, it was only Naan'n'Curry, but then a little birdy of a cab driver whisper a sweet little word in my ear... Shalimar.

There's no gimmickry here, no flash, no bizarre international fusions or misguided attempts at modernization.
