Instead, the menu is full of brilliant and full-flavored versions of chaat, kebab, masala and more, a humble offering of honest, delicious dishes passed down through generations of a restaurant family who have long been the best at what they do. Oh and it's cheap too. Yummers.
author: Jacob S.

description: Went to SF from SoCal and saw the review. The tandoori wasn't tasty and brain curry could be  better. Would not recommend.
author: Amin K.

description: Solid food, not awesome, not bad. I'd go with the Nehari, that is what they are known for. The naan is really doughy and soft. It's not like some places where the naan feels like paper. They've done up the place too since I last visited so it looks like they are doing well.
author: Adnan Z.

description:
The currys are tasty, favorful and the location is TrendyLoin and to top it off they have Sheeps brains. So, why do I give you 3 stars? Its what happened after I ate here.

Such an experience needs a poem to do it justice:

Shailmar, Shalimar, I loved your chicken bits,
but within 10 mins I had the shits.
I didn't even order the goat or the brain,
but you left me with mad ass pain.
author: Tak H.

description:
There are so many excellent places to eat, but for the surreal-transport-to-another-world factor, whenever someone asks me what my favorite restaurant in San Francisco is, I always say Shalimar. Not once has anyone heard of it. Until last month, when for the hundredth time, over many years, I uttered the name once again. To my surprise, the new acquaintance replied, "I walk by that place every day! I live down the street! Now I'm gotta try it!" 

Finally, all the way from L.A., I made a new convert.

So glad to find today on Yelp that so many share my feelings. Wish I could find a place like it down here. Have an order of the chops for me!

(thanks to Mary for first taking me: hung over, chomping down our meals with our bare hands, in abject silence...good times...)
author: Lawrence F.

description:
So delicious. Super Yum. AND they even have Mukhwas!

(yeah, I didn't know the name of it either until now... but it's the stuff you love as you leave Indian restaurants. you know, that after-dinner "mint".)

from Wikipedia: 

"Mukhwas is a colorful Indian after-meal snack or digestive aid made primarily of fennel seeds, anise seeds, coconut, and sesame seeds. They are sweet in flavor and highly aromatic due to added sugar and the addition of various essential oils, including peppermint oil. The seeds are often also coated in sugar and brightly colored."

YUM.
author: Sally M.

description:
Some say this is the best Indian food in the city/state/country, and I'm not one to disagree.  Everything was spectacular: eggplant, chicken, lamb, okra, etc. etc. etc.  Very cheap, as well -- it's hard to find a restaurant this good for this little in SF.

I considered subtracting a star for the shoddy Tenderloin-esque decor and furniture, but I suppose that's just part of eating in the ghetto (and it keeps the price down).
author: Danny C.

description:
Went with 20 people from work and PIGGED OUT for under $300.  Food is amazing.  service and layout not conducive to such a large group, though.  I'd bring the boyz here and look like a master of the city.  I'd bring a date and look like a straight-up punk.

I hear there is another location on Polk more like a restaurant and less like a high-school cafeteria.  If the food is 1/2 as good I'd be 2x as willing to try it instead of 1/3 of the other Indian places of tried; which make up about 1/5 of the restaurants I've visited in SF.  Which is about 1/100 of the total for the city.
author: Anthony R.

description:
2006 has been the year that I learned more about Indian food.  I don't know what kicked it off but I think it was the night that I went to see 'Brick' with Melissa at the Embarcadero and the only place close was some Indian place... ANYWAY.

I heard that people who know go to Shalimar so my ace Dave "hustle" and I went here on some type of man date.

Ordering is like ordering at most 'casual' Indian places, you go to a counter and order some food that all sounds the same when you read the menu, then you order way too much nann, get weird looks because you have no clue what you are doing and then get a can of diet Pepsi... there is never booze at these places.  Why is that?

Anyway, the food was pretty good but I don't know if it is cheap... I guess I thought that everything at these places is supposed to be dirt cheap, what do I know?

Sorry everyone, this reads like shit.
author: Thadd L.

description:
This is clearly far from a new, undiscovered place, but tonight was my first time here, and I want to write about it.

The decor: Spartan. The atmosphere: Drab. The service: Courteous enough but brusque. The food: Delicious. We did take-out and had to wait a long time for our food (and we weren't even sure we had the right order when they gave us the plastic bag full of shrink-wrapped take-out boxes), but it was worth it.

Shalimar's naan was good but not different from that from any other Indian or Pakistani place. The multi-hued rice included dark orange grains in addition to the usual white and yellow (what creates those colors?). The chicken jalfrezi, pieces of meat sauteed in spices with onions, burned subtly in the mouth. The okra created similar heat, with its whole pieces of vegetable mixed up with onions, slices of ginger, and mysterious seasonings.

Would I eat here again? Absolutely -- I'll seek it out. The food is more than a cut above the outposts of Pakwan (Mission and Chinatown branches), Tasty Curry (Inner Sunset and formerly the Financial District), and Naan 'n' Curry (Inner Sunset and North Beach), that I've been to. Only Aslam's Rasoi is close, and it costs so much more.
author: Tara M.

description: It's my 2nd time eating here. The taste of each dish is astonishing. If u like strong flavored indian food that isnt buffet style, then this is it. The garlic naan bread is yummy. Their rice and dishes are done just right. If u get a chance, try out their boiling hott chai tea...must add sugar thou. Also, dont wear ur best clothes here because it gets really smoky and WILL stink up your clothes.
author: Ernie P.

description: Do I need to say it? Good indian food. Its a total and complete hole in the wall, but the first hole in the wall indian restaurant that I have tried in the TL. You need to go up to the counter to order your food and the bring it out in there plastic plates. Needless to say, its greasy, but oh so delicious, not to mention cheap!
author: Caroline C.

description:
As long as you don't mind dining with folks you don't know and grabbing your own food this is THE place to go late night downtown. It seems that no matter what time it is there is a line to wait short or long.

But its worth the wait. Don't expect it to be the cleanest place you've ever seen, its sort of the dive bar equivalent, but the food is tremendous and cheap.
author: Marz W.

description:
I love the 'mar. I also feel comfortable saying that anyone who feels differently isn't worth knowing (or resuscitating, or braking for, etc). So why not five stars? Variability. Sometimes they're so on that I think (and claim often) that I'll eat the chicken botti until incapacitated. Other times though, the naan has been sitting around too long, the bengan bharta isn't quite as perfectly spiced, or... well... let's say that even the Zagats decor rating doesn't reflect some of the things I've seen there and leave it at that.

Those guys at Shalimar know how to treat their regulars (so much so that I feel like an adulterer when I eat Indian/Pakistani elsewhere). You walk in, there's a line, you get the nod and you're in the back room while some marina chump is still figuring out how many garlic naan to get. I do miss the office table with the map of Pakistan in the back room, but I can't fault their (halting) efforts to class the place up.

To Shalimar neophytes: don't wait for a seat; don't wait for them to take your order. Get a table, walk up to the counter, and order. You pay when you're finished. Also, here's what you order: chicken botti, bengan, channa, naan, rice. Next time, you can try the chicken kofta, palak paneer, chicken corma, and lamb chop. Don't make me wait behind you while you scour the "Shalimar Times" (the menu) finding your precious garlic naan and chicken tikka masala. It's like standing between a mother bear and her cub, okay?
author: Adam L.

description:
Real.  Authentic.  Pakistani Cuisine.

Dining Checklist:

1. Cheap Eats?  Oh yeah.
2. Succulent Food?  Bingo.
3. Crack Heads Watching?  Check.
4. Cockroaches on Ground?  Got that too.

That about sums it up.  This place is legendary.  Expect to be offered crack and a BJ by the local denizens but the tradeoff is worth it (if you can't deal, the location on Polk and Pine is much cleaner and safer).  

Get the Chicken Tikka, Chicken Tikka Masala (yes, they are two separate dishes), the Chicken Kofta (hugely underrated), and the Bhengan Buhrtha (Eggplant).  If you are feeling really adventurous, order the Magaz Masala (not on the menu; don't ask why until after you finish the dish :-) ).  The Naan is good is pretty darn good when served hot and fresh (usually).
author: Naeem I.

description: Best GOAT!!! Best Indian food in San Francisco =)
author: Rachel L.

description: this place is the best i mean best when it comes to Pakistani or Indian food i came her with my family on a Sunday night and it was crazy line out the door and everything 30 min later we got a table and man its was worth the wait 5 stars all day!!!!!!
author: T t.

description: Chicken Tikka Marsala! I don't care if I might as well be screaming Sweet and Sour Pork! I know its probably the least authentic dish but I love it and Shalimar makes it good. The nan was off the chain. This place is no frills but its good, cheap and quick. If you're around the Polk st area and bar hopping this place is awesome. And you can bring your own booze in how cool is that.
author: Hyung L.

description: Probably one of the best indian/pakistani restaurants in the city in my opinion. Their naan is so damn good. I usually order the chicken tikka masala, haleem, nihari, and lamb saag. The dishes are all so good and I love how it's on the spicier side. Does  bland, overly creamy chicken tikka masala piss you off? Yeah, it pisses me off too.
author: Jane C.

description:
If you just got paid, come here and order the tandorri Lamb Chops. So good as well as everything else on the menu.

I especially like the other lamb dish with chunks of lamb on the bone. The marrow is easy to suck out and oh so tasty! I could have just sat there all night sucking lamb bones.

Any of the Briyani dishes are great. Nice and spicy.
author: Todd H.

description:
OMG. I'll never forget the time I was waiting for dinner with my SO and a pigeon came walking out of the back kitchen into the dining area. I felt like I was in Karachi.
The food, as always, to die for.
author: Food S.

description: I finally got around to trying this place and it was great.  It's nice inside and the block it's on isn't too heavy on the crack dealing which is a plus.  Got two chicken items (Murgh Boti Tandoori and on the special I think was called Chicken Jalfrezi), garlic naan, rice, and some chick pea thing and it was a lot of food for 2 people and was $15 per person after tip (though it's self-serve, so tipping ettiquite is in question).  It was the best Indian I've ever had, though I don't have it a lot.  I'd probably get plain naan next time because the garlic was too powerful for my taste, but I still loved all the parts of the meal in concert.  Wasn't too busy around 12:30 surprisingly; seemed like mostly a business person crowd on the Monday I was there.
author: Marc S.

description: While the food here is good and cheap, it's a little overrated. Shalimar is known for its meats which I only thought were okay here. You're better off going to Naan 'n Curry in the same neighb.
author: Kathleen M.

description: I think this location is very similar in quality to the other SF location.  The food is good and not horribly pricey.  The advantage to this location is that it is not as deep in the TL, has a little better parking access, and is much less smoky.  Check it out for good indian food - plus you can eat in the patio area if it's nice out.
author: Aaron W.

description: Delicious delicious food in a place that looks like an armpit and smells like a fast-food exhaust fan. Populated by cabbies and yuppies all in agreement about the Chicken Tikka Masala.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Where else, I ask you, can you stroll in with your own bottle of Moet and tuck in to some delightfully seasoned brains for brunch with no corkage!? I love me some greasy spoonage, and this one ranks up there with the best. Delish food, low key atmosphere, low as hell prices... only con is that there's no heat and in December I was trundling around in flip flops due to some serious lack of foresight. 

Another pro is that you can act as ridiculous as you like there and they don't bat an eye.
author: Julia K.

description:
3.5

Feels like I wandered into a bustling cafeteria.  Noisy, dirty, and pungent with spices - I love it!  Quick service (if not friendly - don't expect to chat it up with staff here).  I was a bit confused that their menu looked like a random fold-out in a newspaper.  

My garlic naan was about to explode with garlic pieces.  The chicken tikka masala was pretty good - thick/soupy sauce that curiously grew spicier the more I ate it.  My boyfriend and I also ordered the "king of curries" dish - tender chicken and savory sauce.

Not amazing enough for a long drive to the City, but definitely tasty.
author: Pauline L.

description:
I love the atmosphere and the lamb tandoori. I love that I get to take the good smell of Indian food with me on my clothes for the rest of the day.

If only their daal was makhani...
author: Elsa T.

description:
Pros: Greasy (the curries, in a good way), Spicy,  Flavorful, Cheap and you get free entertainment from the crackheads out front.

Cons: The place is a dump

There are items on their menu that scare me a little (brains.. literally, you can order brains here), but everything I've had here is so good that I would be willing to try even the brains.
author: Matt W.

description:
Cheap and Tashty! 

They make the most succulent and tender Tandoori Chicken Boti ever. The Kofta and Kebabs aren't bad either. Try them with the Mint and Plum Chutney's and don't forget to get some complimentary Chai on your way out.

Location: Sooty.
author: Seema H.

description:
If you love spicy Indian/Pakistani food, one that WILL make you feel heavy and lazy afterwards... then this is your place. Its cheap, but finger-licking delicious.

Its not the most hygenic place around, but I wouldn't say you would fall sick eating there. This particular location is not very crowded, unlike the locations in south bay.

Parking is easily available across the street for $5, which might be 20% of your check in Shalimar!!
author: Sumit C.

description:
Rather than rave about this place - which it deserves - i will give my perfect shalimar menu for 3-4 ( w/ leftovers).

Chicken Boti
Chicken Kofta
Seekh Kabab
Beef Jalfrezi or Haleem
2 regular Naan
1 order rice
1 order raita
2 mango lassis
1 order - Banarsi Kheer
author: D S.

description:
Given the neighborhood that this restaurant is, I can sort of see why it's dirty but this place REALLY gave me the creeps.  It was REALLY dirty, everything looked like there was a film of oil covering it.  Tried to find the cleanest table and seats.  Prices were okay, not even that cheap for Indian food.  Flies were flying around everywhere and it was REALLY warm inside the restaurant on a hot day outside.

We got our food, food was pretty good, not as good as Naan Curry or this Indian place we order from for work.

Overall...slightly disappointing, more so because of how dirty and dingy it was and not because of the food.
author: Winnie L.

description:
I live in West LA and my ex-roomate lived in SF for several years. He swore by this place. It had been 3 years since he had been back up to SF and to this joint. We went about a year ago and as we walked in, the guys behind the counter immediately recognized him as if he never left. 

No JOKE: the Chicken Tikka Masala and Garlic Naan are already worth a trip from LA.
author: Rollence P.

description:
So I went to India back in March and was talking it over with my Pakistani cab driver recently. I said the food in India was awesome, but nothing quite topped Shalimar. He lifted one hand and screamed: "SHALIMAR BETTER THAN ALL FOOD PAKISTAN INDIA COMBINED!"

He's right. I've never tasted such complexity in Indian food. Every bite is miraculous, spices that aren't just spicy but flavorful, helping me discover new corners of my palate. I'm guessing that having an all-Subcontinent cooking team helps with that. 

Last time I went, it was phenomenal and came out to $8 a person. I started laughing. My wife likes it so much we went for our anniversary last year. Far superior to any of the other joints in Little Bombay.

Shalimar can have off nights, it's located in a warzone, sometimes they do table service and sometimes they don't, they sometimes get the orders wrong, and the bathroom appears to have been transported from the worst place in the world, AKA the New Delhi airport. But when they're on (which is usually), Shalimar's food is among the best.
author: matt s.

description:
Best Indian food in the city. Hands down. Probably the best Nan I've ever had. 

Only bad side - they don't take credit cards.
author: Buster B.

description: This is your quintessential dumpy hole in the wall place but I absolutely LOVE it!  The food is amazing and you know it's pretty authentic when the whole place is filled with Indian and/or Pakistani folks!  Whenever we go, we get the chicken tikka masala, the naan, tandori chicken, beef kabobs, chana masala etc.....everything has been delicious!  Yes, the neighborhood is iffy, the servers are not the most friendly and the restaurant itself looks filthy but the food is delicious!  If you love Indian food, you have to give this place a try!
author: Clara A.

description: This restaurant has some of the best tasting Pakistani/Indian food in SF. If you don't need a 3 Star+ atmosphere, I highly recommend this place.
author: Michael W.

description:
very mediocre food! 
super oily, almost like little peices floating in a pool of oil!
it was served warm but it was not very flavourful or anything!
I'm not going to even comment on the service / waiting tim or the ambience (or lack thereof :p )
author: Malika S.

description:
um. this food is excellent. everything is super good. this is quality indian food that doesn't upset your tummy the next day.

one star less because it isn't very clean looking. 

this is definitely a hidden gem in nob hill especially compared to dottie's cafe next door which always has a line and isn't anything special...
author: Dilip R.

description:
My favorite Tandoori.  I always have to make it back after some time away.  The closet you get to authentic including the atmosphere

well I might even fo further 

I actually go to India quite a bit this Lahori/Rawalpindhi
is some of the best grilled stuff I have had

the tandoor really packs some heat 
and these guys get it right 

the nann is excellent 

the spice is just right 

Its a little heavy
author: AZAM A.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco. I've taken my parents here and they said its some of the best kebabs they've had outside of India. Its probably the best place of this style of cooking (What is considered "Pakistani") in the United States.

My favorite dishes are: 

Brain Curry - eat it with the rice its fantastic. The first time you'll be squeamish -- after that you'll be hooked.

Nihari - Just amazing. I ate here with my Pakistani friend and his parents. They agreed that it was some of the best they've had in the US as well.

Murgh Boti Tandoori - Chicken pieces perfectly cooked in the tandoor.

I had my birthday party at Shalimar. If you can try to get to the back room. Its a great experience. Half-working television playing old bollywood films, a fire detector hanging by its electrical wire from the ceiling. Shalimar is no-frills and authentic. Its a daba, and that is probably why the food is so good.
author: Ish H.

description: I'm not kidding when I say that the paneer masala  is blackout good. I experience lost time every time it's placed in front of me.
author: Ana F.

description: Went here on a date...and I'll keep the place, while the date didn't quite work out.  If you are ready for some good food and aren't worried about the ambiance, then this is a great place.  I absolutely loved the rich flavor of the Chicken Tikka Masala and while I'm writing this my mouth has started watering.  All in all, really yummy and family friendly!
author: Steph B.

description: I've gone here frequently over the years. I ordered, as usual, at the counter and then took a seat from whichever table was available. I had the chicken breast tandori, palak paneer rice and naan. The food came out tasty, spicey, and piping hot. I have been told that it is the most authentic of all the Indian restaurants in town.  I can't speak to authenticity but I can tell you that the food was delicious!  My only criticism is that the restaurant could be cleaner.
author: Mike L.

description:
Still one of my favorite places to go for Indian/Pakistani Food.  There are other places now that I like, but this place always seems to deliver the goods.  The service needs a little work, they are sometimes rude.  
A buddy of mine from out of town always wants to hit this place up no matter what.  I love just about everything here.  The Beef Nihara and the Goat Curry are my favorites along with their OKRA dish.
author: Demanding T.

description:
The first time I came here was with my brother, he had raved on about the Shalimar, and he knows his Pakistani food. When we walked into the restaurant, every head turned and I quickly saw that I was the only girl in the place. Along with that, the tin-ey Hindi music playing, the nastiness that is the bathroom, and the cheap and insanely tasty chicken tikka, I had the most satisfying Pakistani meal since moving to San Francisco. Besides isn't the it all about the experience? I would chose this place over one of those fancy fusion places any day. 
Just remember to use the loo before you go, and if you still must use it, hand sanitizer is always good to have, just in case.
author: Emily D.

description: A hole in the wall in a highly shady neighborhood dotted with homeless and drug addicts. As soon as you enter the place, you can smell meat and spices. But what the heck, I got yummy chicken tikka masala with naan and kheer for 10 bucks!
author: Ruchika I.

description: Chicken tikka masala, garlic naan, basmati rice, tandoori chicken plus we like to order some random different dishes to round everything out. May not be the flashiest of establishments but what they lack in appearance they make up in taste. Cheap as heck too!
author: Mila A.

description:
Walk into here and take a deep breath. If you have synesthesia, you may hear a Palestrina mass, the air is so redolent of roasted spices. Get everything/anything. It is ALL good. The beef haleem, the beef nihari, the tandoori, the goat karahi, the garlic naan... Even the rice (chawal) is worth writing about - with saffron and roasted cumin, pepper, cardamom and cloves. Yes, I would rather have lamb haleem and lamb nihari, but I will take what I can get.

I MISS Shan in Artesia, CA. Until I ate at Shalimar I whined about how much I missed Shan. Now I'm happy. My husband took me to Shalimar for lunch and to Fleur de Lys for dinner on our anniversary. Even with the linoleum floors and newspaper menus, Shalimar is the better value. 

The Shalimar on Polk and in Sunnyvale both have unbelievable tandoori, but their haleem and nihari aren't quite as good as the Shalimar on Jones.
author: Vena V.

description:
I had to try this one too, before i had to condemn all 'hole in the wall'  Indian / Pak food places in the neighbourhood. Decided to have my dinner on a Saturday night. Looked uninviting from the outside, with my bitter experiences in Naan N Curry and Chutney. But the braveheart decided to go for the kill. Surprisingly the "guy at the counter" invited me in and took down my orders. He even asked me to sit down and wait. The place was smokey with the open kitchen, i was soon smelling like the food itself. 

But the service was good. Deserved a 3. The guy served me food at the table and made sure i was okay.The food was tasting amazing and deserves a 4. I am definitely going again.
author: Sankar B.

description: I'm not sure if they still have that sign on the front door naming them one of the top 100 restaurants in the country.  That's quite a generous statement, and I'm not sure I'd go that far, or even close to it.  Anyway, if you expect too much from this place (e.g., if you believe that sign), you'll probably be disappointed.  What you get from Shalimar, however, is great tasting Indian fare for a decent price.  I love the garlic naan and the chicken tikka masala.  They probably have one of the best c. tickka masala's out there (there we go again with overly generous evaluations, this time from me).  Food is served fast and warm, meats are juicy and tender, the naan is soft and fluffy.  Good food for a decent price...always a combination I appreciate and one often missing in the FiDi.  It's a good thing that they don't mark up their prices as one of the tops in the country.  You'll probably wont like the location by the T-Loin, but it may be worth the mugging.
author: Angel S.

description:
the best food in the world !!!!!!!! i am not blow'n smoke !!!!!! it's not a luxurious ambiance however the food is too die for, truly amazing !!!!!!!!! again, i not blow'n smoke !!!!!!!    i despised lamb all my life until a friend took me here on a bet that i would try the lamb and if i didn't like it, that dinner was on her! contemptuously, i kept my ground! she insisted!!! so we checked it out a few days later!  ever since that moment, which happens to be 0ver 10 years ago!!! i have been to shalimar on jones & o'farrell probably over 800-900 times! if this restaurant traded over the market indexes i would certainly buy the stock :) must must must try! additionally, it is the last place i go when i leave frisco & the first on my return!!! i will make a bet with you! if you go and don't like the """food""" i will pay your bill! you must take before and after pics of plates for confirmation if you accept the challenge !!!!!!!!!!!!
i've been to india and i haven't found anything comparative to this joint! surprisingly my 2nd most favorite indian/pakistani joint would also be called shalimar in reykjavik iceland!!! however, 3 times more expensive  !!!!!!!
author: Has U.

description:
The food at Shalimar is addictive, especially: 
the okra (worth the trip alone when it's on the menu)
the lamb kebabs 
garlic naan
goat curry 

The ambiance couldn't be much worse but I don't go here for ambiance.  There was a rat inside briefly near the side door on my last visit but that didn't stop me from enjoying everything.  

The service often consists of them pointing and yelling at you to pick up your food from the counter, but again, I don't go here for refined service.
author: Jennifer W.

description: We must have been there on a bad night.  Surly staff and the food (nan excepted) was just not great - good, but not great.
author: dan m.

description:
An incredible find in the not so crazy part of the Tenderloin.

My friend Maggie and I wanted to order Seekh Kebabs of beef and chicken, but they were out of the chicken.  So the guy behind the counter suggested  Tikka Lahori, a butterflied chicken breast with lemon and spices, and it was INCREDIBLE!  For $4 to get a full chicken breast with the wing attached is insane, and also super tasty.  Great blend of spices, just hot enough to keep you interested.

The Beef Kebab was also a tasty delight...I'm guessing there was tamarind in this, because it had that distinctive slightly sour citrus flavor.

I am definitely adding this place to my regular haunts. Just wonderful.

Mind you, if you're looking for ambiance, go ahead to the pricey place around the corner on O'Farrell.  Their food would not touch the savory palate pleasers at Shalimar.
author: Audrey E.

description:
Went here on Friday and waited for several minutes at the counter until the fellow behind the counter started to help someone that walked up to the counter next to us.  That annoyed me enough that I had to remove myself from the counter and instead go back to the table that we had been waiting for them to clear for several minutes.  

The person clearing tables walked over to the dirty table next to us, not ours, and put a couple of items in the bin before going to another table for something, all the while taking his time while we were standing next to the dirty table we wanted to sit at.  He then resumed clearing the table next to us, ignoring our table.  The clincher was when he grabbed some silverware and instead of putting it in the dirty dishes bin, put it back with the self-serve silverware, making the call that it was clean silverware.  At that point we left and went to Pakwan, where the food was mediocre but the service passable.  I'm pretty flexible with the cleanliness of my cheap eats locations, but I don't want them going through a table of dirty dishes trying to pick out the clean ones.

I was here once before and recalled the food being unremarkable but the service passable.   They'll not get a third chance from me.
author: Mikey P.

description:
Not the kind of place for your first date but certainly a second or third. If your date wants to come here again with you then you got it made! 

This place doesn't have too much to offer vegetarians but plenty to bring you back. The atmosphere is jovial and even though the service is a bit slow, the waiter is very friendly. But then, good food and good company has to be enjoyed at leisure.  Their dal is excellent (and the least oily), but their palak-paneer is awesome. The naan is as authentic as it can get and quite yum. They also have a potato stuffed naan which is not bad either but I prefer the simpler plain naan.

If you miss eating at dhabas (cheap roadside restaurants) from your travels in India/Pakistan then this is THE place in San Francisco.
author: Doble V.

description: We went last week for date night, and it was rockin,  We had almost all veg, except for chicken tikka masala.  Um,  rock on is all I have to say.  Food was amazing and on point.  The atmosphere lacks, yet for cheap Indian, this is a-ok in my book.  Shalimar, I will be back
author: Nicole F.

description: Great food, great prices, hole in the wall spot, open late. I wish thewse great indian spot had better ventalation so I dont smell like a cab driver when I leave.
author: Yoli B.

description:
This place is the dirtiest restaurant,don't even try to use the bathroom.But,I know it's the  local people's favorite.Food is cheap and great.I got taken here when I was a visiter and not a local.I just have something about a restaurant that it should not be that dirty.Place to bring your buddies not a date.
Does San Francisco have a health inspector?This place would not pass in Houston,Tx.
author: Brandon M.

description:
Love it or hate it, there's no denying that a dinner of chicken boti, haleem, and beef jalfrezi at Shalimar will blow away any palate with even a passing knowledge of what good South Asian food is (look elsewhere for vegetable dishes though).

As for the rats -- they make the place authentic.
author: Zubair J.

description: Yes, I mustered enough courage and set foot upon the this place. The location is pretty cool and the atmosphere is pretty much: I come in peace and for the food. (Plain and simple) I was pretty surprised how many people were there all eying their table of choice like vultures. When we finally got a table, it was time to order from their newspaper menus. Neat! We ordered up our favorite dishes like paneer tikka masala and lots of naan. What we weren't brave enough for was the brain dish on the menu that night. The food was delicious at Shalimar's and I will be back and braver!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Shalimar is sooooooo dank.

all i do when i go here is point at a couple items on the menu and then ask the guy for some recomendations.  It's been bomb every time.

The service is pretty crappy but i think they realized that a long time ago.  Their ways aren't going to change.  They will bring you your food, dont worry.

I dont know how they do it.  If this place was a legitament restaurant with waiters and servers it would be one of the best restaurants in the City. 

Oh yah, bring your own beer- thats the only way to do it.
author: Chris C.

description:
Yet another diamond in the ruff, a true epicurist's jewel amongst the sea of crackheads that roam the TL.  Don't ask me why all the greatest food comes from the shabbiest parts of town.  I promise you won't get jumped during the daytime, JUST GO! 

Hmmm... first of, the mango lassi is just ORGASMIC.  I usually don't order sweetened beverages when I eat out because I think it takes away from the taste of the food. But this stuff is so rich, so creamy, but not overly heavy and has just the right amount of sweetness to tame the sourness of the mangoes and yogurt.  Absolutely fabulous.  And for $1.99, they give you a BIG ASS glass... seriously like the size of a Nalgene water bottle.  

My brother loves the Chicken Tikka Masala here.  I love their spinach and potatoes, spinach and paneer cheese, spinach with lentils, hell, spinach with ANYTHING.  Their naan and whole-wheat roti are very good too, soft and doughy on the inside, crisp on the out.  Why order boring old rice when you've got naan?  (hides from all the fellow Chinese people that want to lambast me for betraying rice).

Definitely a cheap, tasty spot to dine at as opposed to the often overpriced eats around touristy Union Square.  I think it's cute how they print their menu like it's a newspaper.  But this shouldn't be news to anyone - if you can stand a more... shall we say "different" neighborhood, this place won't let you down. Yum.
author: Catherine C.

description:
This is what I call down right dirty whole in the wall yummy Indian food. No frills. Who knows how they handled my curry and naan, since I've heard there's cockroaches there and such.. 

Hasn't deterred me from coming back. There is no Vindaloo though, and that makes me sad. 

I like Pakwan in the Mission a little better.. 

Food is cheap and comes out fast, the one on Jones is better than the one on Polk in my opinion.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description: Chicken tikimansala!!! Omg the best!!! However once you step out of here your going to smell like spice!!! Lol
author: Stephanie Cindy C.

description:
Ahh the traditional Indian restaurant with its TV going, its bright, bright lighting, its loudness, just what you want if you were looking for a meal after your coming down after being on meth!
I perfer a little more polish in my dining halls but the food was right the heck on.  The food came A-live in my mouth, very punchy.
author: Sean S.

description:
Ummmm if you're looking for cheap Indian-Pakistani food, why wouldn't you just eat at any one of the 5+ Naan N Curry locations in the city??

I had heard about Shalimar for awhile but finally went last night. I guess I am spoiled by Naan N Curry. First, Naan N Curry has better ambiance. They attempt to decorate their hole in the walls with cozy colors. They even play music. I almost passed Shalimar by because I thought it was a taqueria. The walls are plain white and there is no music.

It's the same self-service, get your own utensils and plates, style of dining as Naan N Curry except Naan N Curry gives you FREE all you can drink yummy chai tea. They also give you free water. We had to buy bottled water from Shalimar. When we finally got our meal, it was OK. The Palaak Paneer was way too salty--and I like salt! The Garlic Naan didn't taste garlicky and wasn't as good as Naan N Curry's (although I like Mehfil's Garlic Naan best). They had the windows open and even on a warm San Francisco night, I was freezing with the draft. 

I would come here if I lived right across the street but then again, Naan N Curry just opened a location on Van Ness nearby so maybe not. Oh yeah and Shalimar cost more than Naan N Curry. Two stars because it wasn't bad food for the price. They definitely have room for improvement though.
author: Cindy P.

description:
THE OG! Love this place for many reasons, but the greatest is the 40 oz for $2 you can buy up the street and sip inside with your chicken masala and naan.  gotta love that.  Everything is delicious although the portions are a bit tiny.  There's so much delicious grease in everything, though, that the small portions you've devoured instantly feel like you've eaten an entire slaughtered animal in 5 minutes. 

Little smokey in here from the cooking, but i wouldn't have it any other way. Read the Shalimar Times to catch up on your current events
author: Victor B.

description:
Awesome, awesome Pakistani food.  My first time there, we went with a friend who knew what to order as most of the things he ordered weren't on the menu.  Since then, those unknown favorites have earned regular spots on the menu.  I wish I could remember the names off hand, but all in all, this is a great place to eat.  

BTW - Leave your jackets in your car as you'll leave smelling of Pakistani food.
author: Brian L.

description:
My parents and most of our family friends are from Lahore, Pakistan where this place's eponymous Shalimar Gardens are located and this hole in the wall is the one reason they will brave the City and especially the T'Loin. My brothers and I still laugh at the time a trannie asked our relatively-conservative mother for "a light or a quarter" as we left the place. In any case, the food is pretty close to authentic and cannot be beat. It will be spicy and is a great way to clear the sinuses, especially in the winter months. They can tone it down if you want, but where's the fun/taste in that? 

The quality did dip for awhile at the SF location as the owners expanded into Fremont and Sunnyvale. Apparently they were sending the rockstar cooks to the other locations for a few months to get the other places up to snuff, and it definitely worked as the Sunnyvale location is packed every day for lunch. 

5 stars for the food, -1 star for pain-in-the-ass parking situation/shitty neighborhood.

Last piece of advice: do not go here before heading out for the night as the utter lack of ventilation will leave you reeking of chicken tikka.
author: Ahsan M.

description:
Ah Shalimar, how do I love thee? 

I love the weird secret room in the back with the TV playing Hindi film songs. I love the guys from Lahore who let me practice my Punjabi with them. I love the haleem and naan so much that I devour them only to remember - too late - why I stay away.

The stomach rumbles. It expands. It gurgles. 

And then it belches loudly and repeatedly. And I get to taste that haleem late into the night.

Nasty.

This was my weekly haunt for a long time & I will still go there once in a blue moon - with antacid in hand.
author: Sharand N.

description:
NOW THIS IS WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I loved this place! 
Went here for lunch with the wife. I knew where it was, and I knew it wasn't anything fancy. I heard they had good food....and I heard correctly on all accounts!

When you step over the homeless people to enter this fine establishment you instantly hit by the smell of strong spices and great food! It's very informal almost to the point you just kinda have to figure out what to do. You order at the counter and then seat yourself. We helped ourselves to silverware and all that, but imagine that someone would have brought it if we waited. The table wabled and wasn't that clean. The silverware was a little dirty, but napkins and water do wonders for both!

When the food came, the heavens opened and a single beam of sunlight shined right on my plate!
The food was incredible! Perfect blend of seasoning, spices and meat. We had a few different dishes, but something told me we couldn't go wrong with anything we ordered. We also had the Mango Lassi and that was killer!

Don't go here expecting a nice place or fancy atmosphere. Go for the food...and you will be happy you did!!!
author: JR H.

description:
I give this place 3 stars only b'c the food isn't half bad. However, here are the reasons I hate Shalimar and will wait years to go back:

1) It's very cafeteria and everything in the place seems unfriendly - including the guy at the front that takes your orders

2) It's dirty

And the reason I will not return:
3) Patrons should NOT breast feed with no blanket while your husband gives you a massage - ALL WHILE I AM TRYING TO EAT! 

I'm surprised I was even able to keep the tikka masala down. Maybe it's a cultural thing but I wasn't down with it!
author: Josephine H.

description: I went here to pick up some food about 2 weeks ago and it was not bad.  After looking at the other reviews, I guess it is a hit or miss.  I ordered chicken biryani, naan, and chicken kofta. Everything had a good amount of masala and spices.
author: Manhav B.

description:
I have been to Shalimar for a couple times at three of their locations. It is always busy, and has plenty of Indians there. I guess it's a good sign for authenticity.

I have had many of their popular items, like chicken tikka marsala, lamb curry, chicken boti. It's curry we are talking about and of course they are full of flavor. Their food is hotter than many other places. So I need more of their delicious naan to compensate that.

I like their food, but the area is a bit sketchy and I don't feel that the place is very clean. It is not a bad place for a quite bite or order to-go.
author: Jose K.

description:
Best...indian/pakistani....ever!  I love this place (they know me ;).  They used to be DIRT cheap back before all you pale-skinned folk found out about them.  But unfortunately, their prices have risen since then.   Its still worth it though.

favorites:
Favorites for me are chicken bhoti (dry), palak paneer, and garlic nan.  thats a solid meal.  All of the curries are great too.  Don't sleep on the mixed vegetable as well.  its all good.  Don't ask for less spicy or I may pop out from hiding under the table and smack you.

negatives:
As noted below, its spicy so leave your wimpy friends here. Note that you may see some crack smoking on the block (like chapelle says, ain't nothin tender about the 'loin).  Ladies, I wouldn't recommend wearing a mini-skirt like one of my dates I brought there wore (unless you're ok with crackhead catcalls).  Its kind of like a wu-tang concert out there but only if old dirty was every member, and he had even less teeth.  Also, don't bite those green things they bring you before the meal, they're jalapenos not beans (my dates have had a rough time at shalimar).
author: chadmalik ..

description:
Nann 'n' Curry is tikka masala crap compared to Shalimar. You know this because there is a rap out in the city about it, "... tika masala, make me wanna holla, at the Shalimar..."

that is all.
author: danny e.

description:
You know it's good when you walk in and the restaurant is filled with Indian people.

Highlight: Crackheads outside the restaurant making sexually explicit comments to customers / passersby.

Crackhead to the female customer: "Oh your face isn't too good, but your body is nice."
author: Po L.

description:
I totally loved their chicken tikka sauce.... oh man I want that again... beautiful naan too... mmmmm

Oh... really cheap too!!!
author: Aaron W.

description:
This is a worst Indian food joint I ever visited in the Bay Area.

We ordered paneer tikka masala and paneer was not good. The dish was very oily. I had better paneer dish than this elsewhere. Their Kabuli Chana was also very different in a strange way. It wasn't tasty. The third dish we ordered was Dal and it too was not at all tasty. It looked like they just boiled dal (lentils) with some chilli powder and turmeric added to it. 

Over all not a good place if you want to have something vegetarian.

I am giving 2 points for their Chai(Tea) and Tandoori roti, both were good.
author: Metal I.

description: I will take both my pretentious foodie friends and family, who think Chilis is "going out to dinner" to this little gem. The food is incredible. BYOB saves me about 60 percent of what a total bill would be on a Fri/Sat night dinner out.. Staff is soft-spoken but unbelievable friendly. I would have given it 5 stars, but my pretentious foodie friends wouldn't let me:). 23 Zagat score is objective proof that they rock.
author: Amber W.

description: Cheap, tasty, and, if I recall correctly, open late.  They have delicious free chai.  I've never had a dish here I didn't enjoy.  However, it's in kind of a sketchy location and there's no parking.
author: Katharine N.

description: This is your HOLE-IN-THE wall place. Yeah it might be dirty, and there might be junkies hanging out, outside on the streets. I had some walking zombie with the craziest look approach me and my friend when we were going into the restaurant. I was so hesitant to eat there, and was quite intimidated. I am picky when it comes to Indian food, but I must say: the first bite I put into my mouth, there was an explosion! The food was delicious, and I had the BEST Tikka Masala of my whole entire life. The flavors are bold, and what is even BOLDER is the dirt-cheap prices of their food. All you need is less than 10 bucks (for two people) for a satisfying meal, and you can carry on with your day.
author: T. C.

description: This place is decent and priced well. The food is a little too oily. The chai can be watery. I like their kofta and their keema is decent. It's no Lahore Karahi, but better than Naan N Curry.
author: Andrew K.

description: I love Shalimar.  Absolutely delicious vegetarian food.  BYOB.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
We love this place.
It's noisy, funky, with sordid character soutside, but the food is GREAT!
Puts many other Pakistani and Indian restaurants to shame.
The spices are authentic and plentiful.
Mmm good!
author: Mark S.

description: After many years of driving from the suburbs to eat at or pick up food from Shalimar - it is a treat to live walking distance of the Polk Street location!   It seems a little cleaner than the the Jones St location but barely so.  This is Pakistani/North Indian food at its best - no frills and reasonable.  To people who are surprised to see very little by way of veggies, well, this is a different type of cuisine from the ubiquitous 'Indian' food so much more commonly found. Heavy on the meats, light on vegetables and even rice to some extent.  Naan, parathas and kulchas are the way to go.  And daals are the best options for non meat eaters.
author: Ash A.

description:
i normally frequent the polk street shalimar, but before bourbon and branch -this was the one to hit.

i rate this place 4 stars.  since they allow you to BYOB, i gotta bump em up to 5, because yea.

this place can be a bit overwhelming if you don't know what you're doing, or don't have a guide.  you order the food, and then find a table to sit at. that sounds easy, but the place is packed and sometimes people will get a table first, t hen approach the window for their food.

while standing in line i noticed a group of 4-5 indian men with matching lanyard/name badges. they were obviously in town for a conference of some sort.  you know that their conference wasn't in the TL, thus they were either referred to shalimar, or they were just in the know!
author: Ameer N.

description:
Cheap, delicious, fast. And that's it!
Zero atmosphere but that isn't the point. Now that I don't live in the neighborhood I do miss it...and I noticed I have lost some poundage, hehee.
Need more ghee...
author: Jackie P.

description:
Ignore the crackheads outside, the vaporized grease smoke clinging to the walls, the chaos, the less than immaculate silverware.  This is the place for great Pakistani/Northern Indian food at good prices. 

The chicken tikka masala is thick, flavorful, and not an IBS-inducing creamy nightmare.  The spicy grilled chicken is perfection itself -- especially the Murgh Boti Tandoori (little grilled pieces of chicken).  The fresh naan is wondrously soft and crunchy, and the garlic naan will make you cry with happiness. Even (normally boring old) daal is good here.  The only complaint is that the lamb tends to be mostly bones.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Company is key!
I did well today, beware some days might make you run to the nearest restroom... or so I heard.
Their Chai tea is so so good!
The key is to eat in moderation!
Yummers!
author: Cristina R.

description:
I went here with some friends and didn't order anything.
We were escorted into the seediest back room EVER, so I wasn't feeling it at first. Waiter was very nice. 
Loved the newspaper menus and enjoyed the world cup playing on the TV. 
Friends ordered and food was served QUICK and smelled DELICIOUS!
They scarfed, then passed the remains to me and my boy. Man, the chicken tikka masala was very very good, and the naan was substantial and fluffy at the same time. 
Prices were cheap (Around 5/6.00 for an entree, 1.00 for plain naan, 2 dollars for a hearty plate of rice, etc) and I know I will go back again for some late night grub. 
Some of the dishes were a bit too spicy for me, but I managed. Good to know you can ask for them "toned down" if you so desire.
author: Amy J.

description:
Good food.  Tasty food.  Maybe too intense for my wife.  Crappy Ambiance.  The restroom is a bio-hazard.  The kitchen doesn't look to great either.  

I prefer the food and the vibe across the street at Chutney's.
author: James G.

description:
In my opinion, its the best Indian food in the city.  They have another location in Fremont, but its not as good.

Cons:
*not the cleanest place in the world
*in the tenderloin-but the crackheads do add character
*you and your clothes will smell when you leave-don't plan on going anywhere nice immedietly afteward..haha.

Pros:
*My husband loves the chicken tikka masala and the lamb curry
*I love the okra and the aloo naan
*you can bring your own booze since they don't sell it there.
*The spices are just right in all of their dishes

Love this place!
author: Jodi S.

description:
After years of eating here, Im finally writing a review.  Not that they need any help from me.  Everyone knows about this place and loves it.  

OK so this place is a bit dodgy...  it is in the Tenderloin and ecstatically speaking, its not the prettiest.  Its a bare bones no nonsense indo-pakistani place thats pretty much a self service place.  They have great bollywood music blasting in the background.  If youre looking for white table cloth, with cloth napkins and matching cutlery, go to Amber India.  Its delicious.  But if you you want DELICIOUS curry for $7 then dont look anywhere else.  My fav is their lamb curry with aloo naan.  My mouths getting watery just thinking about it.
author: Marcia B.

description: Food was good, price was average. The eating area had a dirty charm with the hanging empty frames and proudly displayed 74 health score.
author: Mantas V.

description:
WARNING:This ain't your Valentine date candlelight dinner restaurant.
But if you want some damn good food than this is the place. I dare say that this hole in the wall could actually be the most famous restaurant in the world. I know people who fly in all the way from Pakistan, so they can come to Shalimar and eat authentic Pakistani cuisine. The food is delicious and anything better  than the Tikkas, Sikh Kababs, Boti , Nihari and Karhai would be a sin. They even have a BYOB policy. But I must warn you, alcohol and spicy Paki food don't mix well. Too bad they don't serve Pakola here. But the chai Paki style makes up for it. I could live off Shalimar. This is the must eat at restaurant in SF.
author: Imran M.

description:
Ok ok. I have bitched and moaned about how I dislike Indian food for so long.  I do admit that it is some tasty stuff, but it is so unhealthy that I cant make my peace with it.  Also, the Jones street Shalimar is filthy.  
Well yesterday, I caved in and we had lunch here at Shalimar on Polk street.  Again, the food was supremely tasty.  Yes it was greasy and fatty and salty, but we had worked out for a couple of hours and I felt like I could handle it.
The place gets 3 stars from me because it is lacking in any ambiance whatsoever.  It is bare and ugly.  Also, since we were already inside and waiting for food, I did not (I was afraid!)  go to the bathroom, lest I witness a scene like the other Shalimar's bathroom.  
 
Admittedly though, we had a good lunch.  I did not come down with any food-born illnesses (yet) and I didn't smell excessively like curry.  Still you cant eat this food all the time...think of the clogged arteries, think of the widening girth...maybe in a couple of years, I will eat at Shalimar again.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I loved this place. It ain't pretty to look at- the actual restaurant or the food but it tastes awesome! We walked in, the place was filled with smoke and I was tempted to turn around and leave, but I didn't and I'm glad I didn't!

The food was reasonably fast, mega cheap and wicked tasty. Yum! I'll be heading back there again soon :)
author: Bridey J.

description:
Delicious, cheap food!  We had a party of 13 and ate family style.  Everything we tried was tasty and good.  
Luckily their kitchen is in plain sight.  

Do not go in the bathroom!! I went in to wash my hands and was horrified.  The walk to our table was also an experience.
author: sara e.

description: Shalimar was A-OK. The food was kinda cheap but not super cheap, and the service was fine but not great, and the meal itself was good but not great. Definitely right down the line what you're expecting when you walk in off on Jones Street to an order at the counter type Indian place.
author: Robert K.

description:
Indeed, it was very tasty. It took quite a long time to get our food but once it arrived everyone was pleased. It was nice to have multiple people in order to eat family style because it'd suck to just eat naan and tandori chicken all by itself. But really, the food was much tastier than most of the indian food that I've ever had. 

The interior is pretty dirty, very much a hole in the wall type of place. You order at the counter from the greasy paper menus.
author: Jack O.

description:
Now I'm the first person to overlook the service and the atmosphere so long as neither are offensive for good food (I am zushi puzzle's biggest fan people!).

But when the food is good but nothing to write home about, the utter lack of anything else to bring you back can rear it's ugly head and pull the ratings down a star or two.

The food.  Was good.  I like picking out the spices from my Indian food.  The naan was piping hot.  But it wasn't great, by any means. 

The service.  What service?  They brought us our food.  We asked for menus, had to go to the counter to order, had to get up to ask for water (then had to pour it ourselves), and had to get up *again* to get our check and pay.  That's right -- there's no one to even flag down when you're being ignored - you have to GET UP.  They also served our water in paper cups, and they didn't give us knives.  Ever eaten a lamb chop without a knife?  Good times.

The room, let's face it, is a bit of an embarrassment.  It wouldn't take much at all to at least look like some effort was made.  Instead near bare yellowish dirty looking walls, linoleum floors, and cheap tables.  

Won't be back.
author: Jenny S.

description:
I was first introduced to this Shalimar  back in the summer of 2004 while on a day date of partaking in all of the Pride festivities and while things didn't work out with my date past the second date,  it was love at first smell of all things Shalimar. 

Lately, it's become a love-hate relationship. I say love-hate because my boyfriend practically needs a Shalimar IV and it's hard to find any other Indian-Pakistani place near my house, let alone one as good, so we end up there a lot (like at least once a week a lot). 

The conversation generally goes like this: 

Dee: "What do you want to eat, babe?"
Bf: "um...."
Dee: "Okay, what do you want other than Shalimar?" 
Bf "um..."
Dee: "That's all you want  to eat? Nothing else?!?!"
Bf: "We can stop at the Jug Shop and get a bottle of whatever you like to pair..." 

Damn. Well played significant other. Well played. You got me. 

It's a nice walk from my house in Cow Hollow, so my boyfriend and I generally walk and stop into The Jug Shop on the way there and pick up something already chilled. 

The BYOB is my favorite part. There's nothing better than opening a bottle of something and pouring it into the paper cups to drink with our meal. Cava, Rose, Brut, Gewrztraminer, Riesling, Sauvignon Blanc, even Chardonnay. They've all met their match at Shalimar. 

On sunny weekends or in the summer time we'll ride our bikes there (perhaps just to assuage a little of  the guilt of partaking in so much delicious clarified butter fried goodness). Plus, it's also always fun to watch the Billy Ray Cyrus look alike in  his cut-off plaid flannel shirt, jorts (that's jean shorts for those of you foos who don't know the lingo) and mullet roller blading up and down Polk St.
author: Dee I.

description:
Good. Cheap. Fast. What more can you ask for?!? 

You can really tell when you're experiencing really really good food. You forget about the sticky table, the stinky guy sitting 2 inches away from you, the baby picking his booger at the next table, the warm diet coke, the dingy feel, your ugly date with nose hair sticking out, or the people waiting for their table that keep bumping into your chair with his huge ass. All you think about is "Dang, this is good food!!". Even though I get constipated every time I eat here, I still come back again and again.
author: Kwan H.

description:
Amazing homemade paneer. The best alu naan I've ever had. Sticks to the "hole in the wall, but well worth the visit" formula.  

Side note: if the only reason you went to Shalimar is to brag about how you dared to set foot in the Tenderloin, spare us your review.  It just skews the average for people who actually want to know about the food and service.
author: Janna M.

description:
So much delicious.  The mango lassi was delicious, the saag gosht was rich and yummy, the naan was hot and fresh.

The best part: it's only two blocks from the massive Hilton convention center.  The secret's out, though - I went here during a conference, and I saw tons of other name tags all around me.
author: Jena B.

description: Hands down the best Indian food in SF.  I come here right after a nice joint of bomb bud.
author: Christina S.

description: I don't know what it is - I have recollections of this place as being exceptional, authentic, and a bit of a hole in the wall. On this last visit, I found the food visibly oily and poor in taste. Eek!
author: Jon A.

description:
I THOUGHT YOU KNEW!

This place is ridiculous. I decided to check it out when some of my co-workers said they take their families here when they visit from India. I don't always like "authentic" food, so that's not the reason the rating is so high. It's because IT IS RIDICULOUSLY GOOD. The prices are reasonable; actually low. So you have to try the chicken tandoori and the bengan bhujia (terrible spelling I know). If the palak paneer ever comes back, try that too. And the spinach dish- fuggetaboutit. Can't remember it's name, but fuggetaboutit.

If your idea of Indian food is ordering beer (I'm not sure where that one started--probably in the UK) and chilling out, this is probably not the place. You can do that, but this isn't a sit for two hours place and it is a bit grimy. But how cares?! The food is phenomenal and has never made me sick.

I eat here for brunch, lunch, dinner, whenever. If you find yourself facing a long line at Dottie's and this place is open, MAKE THE RIGHT MOVE.
author: Mark T.

description: Love the TIkka Masala! Love the Spinich and Potatoes! Love the Naan!
author: Helen C.

description: I work in a nearby  hotel and once in a while order out.  I understand that this is the place that started the Indian fast food trend.  And they are most excellent.  I usually order the Calf Brain Masala which sounds awful but is actually quite flavorful and has an interesting texture going down.  Shalimar chefs take great care with their curries and I can identify specific spices and herbs: cinnamon sticks green peppers; corriander and onion.  I also order the potato stuffed bread called Aloo Paratha which is filling and great for dipping into the Masala.  I'm confident you will enjoy!
author: Tony C.

description:
This is supposedly the "nicer" version of Shalimar than the one on Polk street.  Personally I think this one is a bit more bland, albeit the bathroom is a magnitude cleaner.  Still, if you're in the mood for Indian food you must try it.  But also give their Polk one a go as that one tends to have more bold spice taste.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Yeah, the neighborhood sucks.  Yeah, the atmosphere leaves a lot to be desired.  Yeah, the menu's are stain splattered and tattered.  Yeah, you have to counter order and practically buss your own table.  But, I'm sorry, a better late night dinner there is not.  The vegetarian dishes are wonderful, especially the Palak Paneer and Bengun Bhujia.  All of the tandoori options are good (my persoanl fave is the lamb) and there are a myriad of naan choices.  And, don't forge the Biryani....Mmmmmm.

Best of all, it's BYOB.  Brings me back to the good ol' days at Sam Woh's....but so much tastier
author: Shannon M.

description:
Juxtaposition = Bourbon & Branch, followed by Shalimar.  Dark, sexy, ultrastylish bar specializing in super-premium booze, featuring "mixologists", velvet wallpaper, and requiring a password to enter.  Bright, stark, dirty, Indian/Pakistani feeding station specializing in greasy, spicy, delicious, authentic food.   4 drinks at B&B: $46.  Tikka Masala, Saag Gosht, 2 Naan and some rice: $19. 

There was a guy literally pissing on the front wall of Shalimar after we tripped over a few bums at the crackhead zoo outside.  It's approximately 78 steps from door-to-door, each one of which should be made carefully, with much trepidation.  Don't wear your blue suede shoes.

OK, the food.  I've been a Pakwan (on 16th) devotee for years, and had needed a good excuse to venture into the 'loin and try out Shalimar.  It was well worth it.  Authentic and greasy as can be, and it brings some nice heat.  I think the Naan and Tikka Masala at Pakwan are better, but the Saag was amazing here.  

It was actually much cleaner than I expected, and the guys behind the counter were friendly!  Maybe I have a different view of "friendly", growing up in NYC.  As in, "he made eye contact, we're BFF now."

Yum.
author: Jon B.

description:
4.5 stars 

If you brave the tenderloin and seek out this hole in the wall you will be rewarded with pretty amazing Pakistan food. The Tika Lahori is especially noteworthy and I also enjoyed my chicken masala, even if it was slightly greasy. The naan is also great, and I liked the jasmin rice. If you order take out, get lots of napkins, as it can be a little messy .
I know the outside isn't much to look at and the neighborhood can be a little dicey, but the food makes it all worthwhile.
author: Russ C.

description:
The king of exotic dive eateries, Shalimar serves up Indian / Pakistani cuisine that you'd gladly eat as your last meal on earth (and, given the sketchy surroundings, you just might end up eating it here!). 

I can't say anything more accurate than the Indian cab driver in Matt S.'s review ... the place is king.  Even the SF cab drivers will tell you -- catch a cab anywhere in the city, ask them to take you to Shalimar near Union Square and they'll all smile and rave. Eat where hard working people on late shifts eat -- they don't suffer foolish food gladly. 

Some random thoughts:

I came here with a couple of buddies in the midst of a minor bender once. We were as hungry as only late night drunks can be, and so ordered gluttonously, expansively, with wild gestures and lust for tandoori in our hearts.  We filled the table with curried lamb and skewered chicken and garlic naan. We ate okra.  364 days a year, I am not an okra kind of guy, but we ordered it here and I ate it ravenously.  At some point we came down off our beer high and noticed that we'd embarrassed ourselves. I mean -- I think I had to give the shrt I was wearing away when the dry cleaner failed to defeat the curry stains I nailed myself with that night.  We literally filled the table with food and stared at the unconquerable leftovers with shame. The bill?  I think maybe $30 (including tip).  

I fed a table full of engineers like kings for $200 during the 2007 Game Developers Conference here. My beer bill from the liquor store at the corner was more expensive than the dinner tab.   

As other have mentioned, this is a cheerfully BYOB establishment. You'll want to buy some booze (I recommend the Redhook ESB or a standard Sam Adams) from the liquor store at Geary & Jones before heading in, then ask around for the bottle opener. Someone somewhere at some table will have it.  If you're on the wagon that night, you will have a religious experience with their thai tea.
author: Sean F.

description:
This is another of those "Indian/Pakistani" places dotting the 'loin. 

I had heard of this place a few times, but this was my first trip. The rumor is that this place has the most authentic "dhaba" (roadside diner) food in the City. Well, I can tell you that the rumor is true. I haven't found a more authentic Indian greasy-spoon around these parts.

I ordered a bunch of chicken seekh kebab. At $2.50 a pop, they were quite inexpensive and good appetizers (try these piping hot with some Kingfisher or Taj Mahal beer. yum! Unfortunately, Shalimar don't do no alcohol, so BYOB). I requested that they be well-done (a recurring theme in my restaurant visits) , and they didn't disappoint.

We also ordered the standard fare of palak paneer and chicken tikka masala. I only had the PP and it was decent.

This is a grimy, hole-in-the-wall restaurant with reasonably authentic food. It's open till 11:30 on weekend nights at least, so it's good for late eats.
author: A J.

description: Had not been in a while, did not really enjoy my food as it was very bland.   The staff were very nice though.    I did not have the eggplant dish which is what I think they are known for.
author: Rekha P.

description: Amazing food with so much flavor, so much so that there's a party in my tummy! yummy yummy yummy! (Learned this song on Yo Gabba Gabba)
author: Wakako U.

description: Best Indian food I've ever had. The chicken tikka masala and garlic naan were fantastic! We got the gulag Jaman taj mahal and banarsi kheer for dessert and they were a great finish to this wonderful meal. The place was packed, they provided great service, and the aromas were stimulating.
author: Janet M.

description:
Convoluted combination of self- and table-service made eating here (my first time) a little bit nerve-racking. Counter help was not exactly patient or helpful.

Food is okay. All the menu items are a la carte (no sides or combinations) so ordering a meal for one person can be expensive & too much food. Naan was good, but in a doughy, pizza-crusty, patently non-Indian kind of way.
author: matt k.

description:
Awesome food for the dollar. The paneer was even a little spicy, and our jalfrezi (a.k.a. naan fajita). The garlic naan is really puffy and there's lots of garlic embedded on the *insides*, not just sprinkled on top of burnt naan like lots of other dives.

Missing a star because the food is a tad greasy.
author: Rob T.

description: Came for some lunch before a matinee show at the Curran. Gasp, I was a bit put off by the unkempt condition of the place. Then there's a sticker near the door that says it's Zagat Rated. ?!. But where yelpers were right is about the quality of the food. And you know you're getting authentic when practically everyone else who comes in is Indian. I couldn't fault any of the flavors of our tandoori, curry, beef and veggie dishes. Plus rice and naan and masala tea for 3, plenty of food for under $40. For the food and the attentive service, I'd come back.
author: Geigy S.

description: Occasionally, incandescent thoughts of Shalimar's garlic naan keep me up at night.  That is all you really need to know.
author: Brendan M.

description:
At this point you've seen all the reviews, and you've probably gathered something along the lines of - good food, bad area, no alcohol, yadda yadda.  Well, here's what I can add to that.

As far as each dish is concerned, the chicken kofta is smothered in an oily masala (and frequently not as rich on the inside as I'd like), the veggie dishes aren't really that great (though it's hard to screw up saag gosht), and the (beef) seekh kabob is a bit to mealy.  Those are the lowlights though.  What these people do right, in my opinion, is operate the tandoor.  The the karahi chicken, the seekh kabob muglai (chicken), and generally most of their other tandoori dishes are excellent.

In the end, the tandoor is the reason to go here.  If you're looking for vegetable dishes, or masalas, that might resemble a Pakistani home, you should venture down the street to Lahore Karahi.
author: Omar S.

description:
This place is great!  Doesn't sound appetizing, but they have goat on Thursdays...my FAVE!  Also, they let you bring it yer own booze (they don't sell any).  It's hard to get a table at times, but just be patient!  

p.s.  it's so cheap that you can afford to try a bunch of different dishes!
author: Charlene E.

description:
I have no idea how we ended up here.  This would only have been possible if we'd intended to go to Dottie's, waited in line for a while, and then realized that there was a time crunch being that we had a subsequent engagement that we wouldn't make if we dallied any longer (how's that for constructive memory?).

I ordered the Chicken tikka masala, which wasn't wholly disgusting--just a bit.  The only advantage to eating here is that all the meat is Halal--which doesn't benefit me in the least.  I'd prefer for it to be organic as well.  An organic Indo-Pak restaurant?  Right--I'll continue to dream on.
author: Momo R.

description:
Very cool place. Don't expect nice seating or fancy waiters. This is the grunge of the grunge. Don't deter yourself yet, because that's all thats a little off about this place. 

The food here is amazingly authentic. They offers some pretty damn good pakistani foods, hands down. The menu is awesome because its like a newspaper. Haha. 

Once you sit down, most likely some dude who ate at the table before may have thrown one or two down already so no worries. 

Oh and for this place, don't expect to be served. Seriously. Everything you want you definitely have to speak up. Want a cup of water? Ask for it. That's the way it goes around here. Its a fantastic in and out place. Pop in for lunch or dinner, it doesn't matter. The food is great and that makes up entirely for the service. Mmmm....GOAT BRAINS.
author: Dzu N.

description:
So incredibly tasty.  You come out reeking of spice, and it pours out of your skin later as you sweat.  It's almost like getting a cleanse of your entire self via cardamom.

Another plus is that you can stay in San Francisco but feel like you just went somewhere else exotic (like Pakistan), but without fear of getting blown up or eating something that will make you sick.  Dirt cheap, too.  They only take cash.
author: F. K.

description:
These folks are the pioneers of Pakistani food in the Bay Area. Definitely the best around! Dirty as hell but the food is amazing!!!

I have been going there since it opened while I lived in the Bay, and also now every time I visit. 

A must try if you are in the SF area.
author: R J.

description:
(exerpt from my food blog munchmunchmunch.com)

word

So in an old episode of Seinfeld, (I guess they are all old now) Jerry goes to a place that sells the best soup in Manhattan. The place is run by a disdainful man lovingly referred to as the 'Soup Nazi.' He's called this because he is very specific about how customers can get the soup and he doesn't care what you think or say about his establishment or methods because he knows in the end you do what he wants because he has the best soup in town. 

Shalimar is like the beloved 'Soup Nazi' in that it has horrendous settings and terrible customer service, but at the same time the best Indian food in the city leaving you helpless to shun the place.

Let's get the negatives out first. Shalimar is possibly the dirtest restaurant I've ever been in. I think I've been to food stalls in third world countries that are cleaner than this place. If you want an extra fork, good luck with that. They keep a few up front, but they are in no hurry to
refill them once they're gone. The glasses and plates have more spots on them a junkie's arm. 

In terms of customer service remember that patience is a virtue. My wife and I waited 45 minutes for our food until I had to remind them of our order. You can also plan on standing at the counter for a while until someone helps you.

However, with all of that being said..... Shalimar is the best Indian food in San Francisco. There goat gosht is mouth-watering, and the seekh kabab is spiced well and lip-smacking. Their naan is fresh and doughy. Shalimar's food is a little oily, but I've never been one to shy away from oily food. 

All in all Shalimar is the best Indian food in the city. However, if you are a clean freak you may find yourself at a loss

yups,
author: david h.

description:
I love this place. I go there mostly late Saturday night I eat then I go home.
Food are spicy but great.
author: rajeef M.

description: You can't beat the price, but its becoming more of a you get what you pay for place. The bathrooms are usable but you'll never be the same. The chicken was not really as juicy or flavorful as I've remembered it to be. The kabobs are good, and nans are generously proportioned (though should be buttered). I still enjoy shalimar but its kind of overhyped.
author: stanley o.

description: Horrible neighborhood, horrible decor, great food. Wouldn't feel safe with a date here but a night out with the guys, this spot has got the goods. Was authentic as far as my friends could tell and I thought the food was great. Had a little of everything family-style served with naan and rice. Free chai tea!
author: Andrew C.

description: Holy F*ing Delisciousness!!!!!! This place is amazingly authentic, extremely reasonably priced & BYOB....Jones St. certainly has some excellent people watching & flava goin for it as well....I highly suggest trying the Tikka Masala w/the naan & garbanzo bean curry? Sooooooooo delicious, fed 3 of us for lunch---they also serve free chai tea =) *Get'R'Done*
author: Alexis G.

description: Y'all are trippin', this place is DIRTY, and not in a good way.   Food is good, but not worth getting hepatitis A through C.  And on top of it all, there's hardly any place to sit.  Check out how many times the word "dirty" comes up in the reviews. This is not a charming quality. If you're lucky, maybe you'll get stabbed by a crackhead on your way out.
author: Tina L.

description:
This is a sure place to find good Indian/Parkistani food near Union Square because I don't think they ever close their doors. Nothing fancy, just formica tables, hard working guys that were shocked when a single woman came in to order an item to be eaten there ...where was her dog protector? Oh well, just throw some samosas to the wolves, should they approach too unfavorably. Unlikely to happen, but there are some Tenderloin prowlers that sniff about.

Great Tikka Masala!
author: miriam b.

description:
Oh I love the food here! I would eat salad all week to go binge here. Their chicken tikka masala and the chicken kofta, and the naaans, yumm yumm! I am salivating, no drooling while writing this review. By far the best non vegetarian masala dishes in the whole freaking bay area. 

Thank God for this place! Its just divine! Cant rave enough about this place, you gotta check this one out. Its a hole in the wall though, and food is a bit oily and spicy. But your taste buds wouldnt mind that. worth a try.
author: Kumar S.

description:
This is my favorite Indian in the city, although I haven't had a big sampling.

I always go for the chicken tikka masala and naan, which are always good. The ordering process can be a little confusing. Just to up to the counter where the chefs are, someone will take your order. Then go sit, they will bring you the food, then go pay at the counter when done.

Remember, when you leave and go shopping around Union Square or Nob Hill, you will smell like Indian food.
author: Nathan M.

description:
This is like hot hot hot on my cheap eats list.  A few things come to mind:
1) fire pit chicken I want to go to bed with you
2) this place is a little nast
3) VALUE VALUE VALUE - think walmart's gallon sized pickle jar for 2.99
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Love the food. High quality, big taste.
Chutney across the street has been slipping in quality and service lately, so I've been going to Shalimar lately, 100% upgrade.
author: Chuck D.

description:
This is probably as good as Pakistani food gets. Probably the best hole-in-the-wall place for Indian food. It's kind of out of the way to drive here for lunch, but when we do, we never get disappointed. The best flavor and spices in every dish. Highly recommended!

Quick Tips:
- Cash Only
- free Chai Milk Tea (next to the counter)
- Get a pitcher of water from the fridge if you want water
- Metered parking around the area
- Sketchy neighborhood, but it's good in the day time
- bring friends so you can order more dishes to try!
author: Kao S.

description: My absolute favorite Indian restaurant. I lived in NYC for two years and I couldn't find anything that lived up to Shalimar. I particularly like the Chicken Karahi and the Palak Paneer. Its not fine dining, but its by far the best tasting, greasiest, indian food available. Oh yea, and don't wear anything too nice to the restaurant... you come out smelling like tandoori smoke
author: Jordan M.

description:
The curry here is phenomenal. Full of flavor and spice. There is no better curry in the city. We've been going here for years and are never, ever disappointed.  Last year when we were living on the East coast we missed this place the most.

If you are squeamish of establishments that aren't the cleanest or the best decorated, go to the one on Polk. Otherwise, this place is great. You walk up and tell them what you want, you clear a table, you grab your drinks. Don't expect any high end service, it's silly to even expect it considering where you are.
