Just take control when you walk in and they will bring the food to the table when it's ready. If you can't handle any of that there is always take out. 

And if you're still turned off...the Pakwan down the street is better than that Chutney place. That place has mediocre curries for people who really aren't curry fans in the first place.
author: Jen D.

description: I'm not proud of giving this restaurant a bad review since they're my own peeps (I'm Indian); the food is good, but you'll pay for it later :(  I'd order the vegeterian entrees - and stay away from the meat dishes.  Shalimar has been around for a long time nationally so - still a plus in that sense but...yeah, not all the food there is what it seems. Be careful.
author: Puneeta S.

description: I love this place. Its Desi food and since my wife is Pescatarian, we both can find plenty of things to eat here. I love the tandoori chicken leg and channa. This place is a hole in the wall, but that's why the food is so good.
author: Jamaal M.

description: Shalimar has fantastic indian food. I highly recommend the Saag Chicken, Chicken Tikka Masala, Bhuna Ghosht. The Garlic Naan is also very good. The only draw back is they only take cash.
author: Colin C.

description: Food is pretty good but this place is so dirty that it makes me gag and feel guilty for eating here.  food is pretty good though although a bit greasy.
author: Bayarea K.

description:
Review something for what it is people 

"Maybe I'm being a snob, but it would be nice to have water delivered." You grab the water from the fridge here. 

"Make sure your bill is correct because it happened again."
Yes, make sure yourself, because the crazy guys at the counter will fix it if you say there's a problem. 

Would you review a '67 Chevy as if it were a new Audi? I guess some of you probably would. But it would be a stupid review. 

Shalimar rules. Get beer across the street. A 40. Bring it in a bag.
author: Adam R.

description:
I almost cried when I came here at 10am and they weren't open.

Shalimar food is synonymous with Indian food in my house. I don't know where else to get this kind of authentic, spiced food. I tried naan n curry before....Shalimar blows them out of the water.
author: anocha s.

description:
My favorite Indian restaurant in the city. Don't go there if you are looking for "ambiance" or to see and be seen. Go there because you love northern Indian, rich, spicy, extremely flavorful food. The spices and the freshness is amazing and the food comes out fast.

Some people complain the food is oily, it is not oil people, but ghee (delicious clarified butter). There is a BIG difference.

I have tried numerous other indian restaurants (dozens and dozens) and they never compare. They just leave me wishing I was at Shalimar instead. I've been there so often in the past 7 years that I even get a smile from the staff (who is generally insanely busy and no nonsense).

We love the tikki masala, chicken boti (the most moist and flavorful ever), spinach and potatoes, potato nan (also the best i've ever had), and rice.

Free chai. Don't accept watered down versions like the places on lower haight, get some real flavor!!!!

Hands down the best Indian Food EVER!!!
author: Little B.

description:
This was the first paki/indian restaurant I ever went to when I was 12. And I fell in love with this place. My whole family loves indian food now because of this place. I would have to say this is one of the top 3 indi/paki restaurants in the city. Great strong smell of great food and the PRICE IS RIGHT!
A MUST try.
I recommend the spinach dish, garlic naan, lamb, and any briyani dish.

btw It is tradition to serve yourself so do not be offended if you dont get your food and utensils. You pick it up yourself!
author: Daniel X.

description: So perhaps I was primed to much for that (under promise - over deliver?) but bottom line - a disappointment. The dirty venue, self-service, long wait would all make this a 'charming' and maybe even (a stretch...) semi-authentic experience if the food was actually amazing. It wasn't. felt like going to a cheap, unremarkable hole in the wall in Karachi. This could have been great but wasn't so.
author: Assaf H.

description:
Fingernail in food!

Not sure how this happened (hanging fingernail, clipping right over the beef tandoori), but there it was!  Really bummed because I brought back this great take-out from this place and my gf discovered a fingernail in her food half-way during the meal.  She tried not to ruin my dinner by mentioning it, but when I found out I had to throw out the rest.  And I wanted to keep it for left-overs tomorrow!  Bummer!  Was good except for that.
author: Matt S.

description: Cheap. Quick. Greasy-tasty. Total dive. 3 stars.
author: Leena K.

description: When I die, I hope I wind up here.
author: Burt F.

description: Not a chance.  I know good Indian food, like Indian oven and Naan& Curry 10 years ago before they closed the one in the heart of the Tenderloin.  Bros, clean you store, wtf. Our Chiken Tika was soupy and felt like the place gave me food poisoning.  I know many Indian restaurants can be dives but man, I wouldn't bring a girl here unless I never wanted to see her again.
author: Frank F.

description:
the kabli channa and the palak aloo methi are very good.  they ran out of mutter paneer last night when we came and got the okra.  

it was packed on a sunday night, so we got the order to go.  i would suggest that anyway, since the dining room isn't the cleanest.
author: Helen T.

description: Good cheap Indo/Pak food. The kebabs are good I don't think the biryani was all that. The lamb curries are usually fantastic.
author: Pranav C.

description:
This is THE place for good Pakistani food ~ from the tandoor. I would recommend getting the simple tandoori roti and any of their curries or dals. Round it off with a cup of chai ~ ask for it since its not on the menu. 
Ordering food is always chaos, and you are never quite sure when to start talking, or whether anyone is actually listening to you. If you don't make eye-contact at the right moment - you might just lose the guy :) The food is always right though, and it finds it's way to your table ~
I love to eat in this hole in the wall, but it's a good take-out place if you don't want to deal with the atmosphere (or the lack of it) ~
author: Shipra K.

description:
If you care about ambiance, then this is not the place for you.  However, Shalimar serves up the best Indian food in SF - hands down!
 
My favorites include chicken tikka masala, tandoori boti and plak paneer....yummmm!!!

Parking is horrible and you have to get past a slew of bums to get in.  Otherwise, this place is the bomb!
author: DJ N.

description:
Two words: TANDOORI CHOPS

(and your jacket will smell like them for days)
author: Major M.

description:
If you can get by the (lack of) decor, Shalimar is fantastic. The food is delicious and very, very reasonable. Expect to walk out stuffed for no more than 11 or 12 dollars a person.

The standard such as Chiken Tiki Masala and the fresh naan are great, and the Tandooris are not to be missed. In general the curries, although a bit greasy, are quite rich and tasty, with very well balanced spices. Don't miss out on their various goat dishes as well, although they're not always available.

Just avoid the bathroom.
author: Joel W.

description:
Every place pretends like they have something similar to Shalimar but they don't.

The tandoori stuff is always delicious (including the naan), and the curries are all delicious.
author: R E.

description: Best hole in the wall. Makes you remember road trips through North India. It is a cheap place so don't expect anything remotely fancy. But if u crave true and tasty Indian food this is the place to go.
author: Kanu P.

description: Halal meat is served here.  Unfortunately the owners allow people to bring alcohol in and many of San Francisco's "single club scene" frequent this location and thus many bottles of wine and beer are left on the tables.  Not very good environment for Muslim families.  But the food of course is pretty good.  Try the BBQ items such as chicken tikka breast or leg pieces, the chicken boti, seekh kabab and the CTM and Nihari are very good as well.  Definitely try the Garlic Naan and Mango Lassi.  They take cash only.  For better "family atmosphere" try the Fremont or Sunnyvale locations instead of Polk or Jones St. Shalimar.
author: Irfan R.

description: This restaurant is affordable, great quality and unpretentious. I LUV the chicken tikka masala. Tried a few items, but the tikka was my fave. The naan is also very good. It is crispy, not greasy nor dough-y. We had 2 types of curry, one tandory 1/4 chicken and 3 naans for 22 dollars. Some reviews talk about how "greasy" the tikka masala was; sure it has a thin later of oil over the curry compared to other indian curries, but for me it's fine. I can't wait to return!
author: José C.

description: I normally don't care about service and only care about the food but once in awhile THIS happens and I realize that service is important. I ordered and sat down. After 30 minutes and seeing people who ordered after me FINISH their meal I follow up on where the fuck is my food? I left after that.
author: Christopher L.

description: I woke up one morning craving their Tikka Masala. It was a weird craving (especially at 7 am), but apparently the food made a lasting impression. Divey, hole-in-the-wall place in the TL. BYOB. Favorite dishes are the Kabli chana (chickpeas in butter), Bengun bhujia (eggplant with onion and tomatoes), Naan-A-Akbar and, of course, the Tikka. Don't wear your Sunday's best to dine here. Unless you plan on smelling like curry all day. Dirt cheap. Go. Now. Eat.
author: Alex H.

description:
I've only had takeout from here, but have ordered here multiple times.
Good food; reasonable prices.
Try the Kuchumber Salad!
author: Dora t.

description: Have been dining here off and on for nearly ten years. This restaurant was originally recommended to my father by a friend of his who is from India as the most authentic food from India/Pakistan in the Bay Area (and this guy lives in Fremont). So...we tried it. And keep coming back. In the old days you could bring in a 6-pack of beer to drink, but now they're getting a license, so that's all good for them. A bit on the "florescent light and linoleum" side, the experience and the food in unparalleled. If you want a more comfy experience, try their place on Polk.
author: Eric H.

description: This is the best Indian food in the city. I think I would sell my ovaries to have a plate of Saag Paneer in front of me, and I'm not even a vegetarian. What's nuts is how cheap it is - you can get the sultan's tandoori chicken and naan for like five bucks and I swear it will fill you up. I would marry one of those guys if they cooked like that at home...if they would have me. Anyway, Shalimar rules.
author: April Y.

description:
ROUND UP: 4 and 1/2 stars

9:30pm on a Monday night, Shalimar is crowded. You're really hungry, you see that Pakwan is a block away, there's another Indian restaurant across the street. You think to yourself, is it really worth the wait? Yes, it is!

The naan is fluffy, and when with garlic, it's really jam packed with garlic. The curries are off the wall. I really liked the eggplant one, the bengan bhuija. It has a nice hint of cinnamon. The chicken tikka masala and the chicken kofta was tasty too (though I wish the kofta serving had more than three meatballs!)

 Reasonable prices. It might take awhile to be able to order and get a seat, but afterward the food comes out fairly quickly.
author: Anh-Thu N.

description:
We had high expectations for this restaurant after our close friends highly praised and recommended it for us. After getting lost through the winding streets of San Francisco, we finally reached it, parking the car in the parking lot adjacent to the restaurant. The restaurant didn't make a very good first appearance; a shabby building and extremely long, packed lines.
Of course, all this wouldn't matter if the inside of the restaurant and food was good. Sadly, it wasn't any better than it looked from the outside. Because of the packed building, the waiter said we'd have to wait for 2 hours before a table cleared. Instead, he led us out of the back door, and into the other, empty room. As we sat down, the first thing we noticed was the intense stench. In front of the room was a muddy field and vacant, empty home. It reeked of rotten meat and wet dirt; we quickly closed the door.
Unfortunately, the stench wasn't lessened too much. In the room was a totally soiled bathroom, and the door leading to it didn't close. We moved to the tables farthest away from the bathroom, but that was when we noticed yet another problem; pests. Yup, the room was infested with various insects; cockroaches were on the ceiling lamp and scuttling across the floor, flies were buzzing continually around the room, and spiderwebs hung in the corners of the room. The tables were sticky, and felt like some toddler had spilled orange juice all over it. 
Even this wasn't enough to deter us from the promise of amazing food, though. The waiter finally trudged over to our room and took our orders. We tried to ignore the 'scenery' outside and the stench, and waited...and waited...and waited. I realize that this waiting business is common in almost every single Indian restaurant, but the combined stench and dirtiness prolonged that 40 minutes into 40 hours. Finally, the waiter once again appeared and set down the plates, cups, and utensils, and went back to bring the food. One look at the dirty spoon was enough; we decided to eat with our own hands instead.
After using a napkin to turn on the faucet in order to wash our hands, the food FINALLY arrived. Eager to try the oft-praised and seemingly legendary food of Shalimar, I dug in, pouring Tikki Boti Masala, piling Tandoori Kabab and Chicken, and finally, the famed Garlic Naan. When I finally ate I realized...the food wasn't so great. It wasn't BAD - the Kabab had a slight onion-y flavor to it, the Tandoori was average (even though about half were burned), and the Masala was good (if very greasy)...but it wasn't GREAT either. After I finally finished my dinner, I realized only one thing was amazing - the Naan. Excuse me, but I hadn't come all this way, in this filthy restaurant, waited the better part of an hour to taste NAAN. 
As I left the building I made a vow to never come back again. This was by far the worst Indian restaurant I've ever been in. The neighborhood and outside appearance was unwelcoming, the lines were long, the other room reeked of stenches, the restaurant was practically infested with pests, the wait was long, the waiter service was unsatisfactory, and the food was, at best, sub-par.
author: Adnan P.

description:
Most authentic Pakistani Restaurant in SF, that I have come across yet. Absolutely love the atmosphere, to get the whole experience you must dine-in and make use of all the facilities.

The food is also the best and the price is as cheap as it comes, best nan and chai too.

Alcoholic beverages can be brought in from the liquor store + !
author: Isaac D.

description:
I love the food at this place! They are serving the BEST garlic naan that I have ever had at any Indian/Pakistani restaurant. The Tandoori and Tikka Masala chicken are excellent. The staff is friendly and you do get lots of food for the low price 

Yes, the place is not fancy, restroom is not clean, parking sucks and the area is crappy at night. When I went there last time, there were a couple of crazy people hanging out nearby but I just ignored them. However, if you really want to eat great food, you should stop by.
author: MS K.

description:
Wonderful food!  

The tandoori chicken was delicious and inexpensive.  It was very moist and flavorful.  The tandoori lamb was also tasty.  The lamb curry was decent.  Not the best tasting I've had, but it did have huge chunks of lamb, which I've never seen before.  The nan bread was also very warm and fresh.

The quality of the food and price is excellent.  However, there are a few concerns.  The first time you go in there, you are not quite sure if you're supposed to wait to be seated or help yourself.  We ended up standing around for a couple of minutes trying to figure it out, and no one came to greet us or anything.  We also could not find a menu, until someone pointed to a stack of menus that looked like newspapers.  This in itself is okay, except some had a lot of oil stains on them so it was kind of hard to read.  After ordering, we picked up our own plates and utensils, which looked like they were washed but a little wet.  One of the plates still had a little bit of caked on food on it, so we had to get another one.

Also, the area is not the best.  We walked over to the restaurant after visiting the SF Center, and there were several panhandlers and people sleeping or lounging on the street.

But overall, the food and price is great.  If you can look past some of the issues I just mentioned, it is a great place to go.
author: Sydney B.

description: This has got to be one of the sketchiest places I've ever dined at.  My boyfriend at the time never even dared take me here until a year after we started dating.  Why you might ask?  Well the minute I stepped inside the restaurant, all I could think of was, "Omg, this place is so dirty.  He wants me to eat here?!?!  -_- "  It didn't help that before we even got to the place, we passed by a bunch of shady looking people.  Albeit, we did go at night but hey, it's still the Tenderloin.  I wasn't sure how to order but the boyfriend took care of that.  We ended up eating at the restaurant and although it felt dirty to be there, the food was actually pretty good.  I did see quite a bit of oil sitting in the curry but it's not like anyone comes here to eat healthy.  Perhaps my rating is skewed because the food surpassed my expectations, but it is a good place to try if you want a true hole in the wall experience.
author: Sophia N.

description: My god, this place is a dump, but I keep coming back for the mighty fine Indian-Pakistani vittles!  The dumpiness turns to quaintness, once you've taken a few bites of their flavorful food.  Just don't drink too much of the chai, or you might need to use their stupefyingly scary bathroom - enough to make even the tiniest bladdered person a commodophobe!
author: Loretta G.

description:
i love the diversity of San Fran. 

Unlike the close-minded LA where all ethnicity cluster around one little small area with extreme territorial syndrome, you find Shalimar filled with chinese families eating around the table while scolding their kids, indian businessmen shamelessly flirting with every blondie walks by, drunk red necks digging into their beer bottle while patiently waiting for their food, and high schoolers holding onto a piece of naan with the same hand they have used to squeeze the zit . Quite lovely. 

BBQ chicken cost $3.50 per leg or a piece of breast, meat is juicy and tender with slight burnt taste. you might wanna order two.   Jasmine rice is cooked with "ghee" to have a more rich and smooth flavour (not sure what ghee is? try wikipedia, u imbeciles!). 

a hole in the wall in the tenderloin area. but again, what restaurants in this area can run business with glamour? this is a serious shattered gem.

Be prepared to: 
1. look for your own seats with eagle eyes, once landed, grab it right away! You snooze, You lose. 
2. shamelessly asking random people to share tables and invite yourself to sit down after being rejected. 
3. expect no service WHATSOEVER 
4. share your fortune involuntarily with the homeless and street walkers on your way home. 

last but not least, if you happen to be like Kat who "accidently explored" the tenderloin area at night on your own, bring a pepper spray just in case.
author: Kat S.

description: The tandoori chicken here is the best - juicy with lots of flavor, and not dry whatsoever!  This place is a complete hole-in-the-wall and homeless people stand outside by the windows watching you eat (I suggest you sit away from the windows).  But just because the place is filled with smoke and you basically have to bus your own tables, don't turn away from it!  The food is delicious and authentic, not to mention, very affordable.  Again, just don't sit by the windows.
author: Claire H.

description:
hole in the wall but verrry good!

naan was fresh and hot out of the oven.  the tandori chicken was well cooked seasoned very well, but add some of the green sauce and its just enough kick to spice ur mouth but not too crazy where you'll go ulping for air... decent portion here so you'll want it as a staple

The Murgh Korma Shah was very good, kind of like a chicken meatball with a nice curry sauce, 3 pieces...and the chicken marsala very good but also only 3 pieces.

overall two thumbs up.  food didn't leave me feeling heavy and i would definitely come back.  i wouldn't recommend coming with nice clothes though, you will stink..but oh is it worth it
author: Arthur T.

description:
Best indian food, every time i eat at shalimar I am never disapointed with the food.
 Food is Consistently tasty. 
The best Chicken tikki masala 
best nan in town.
Tandori chicken is delicious
Fast and decent prices.
author: R A.

description:
5 star indian food but -1 star for not having adequate ventilation...

the food is GREAT!  I think it is some of the best indian I have had in a while...  the kababs are tasty the Chicken Tikka Massalla is delicious and when you ask for it spicy it is really spicy!

I just can't stand how smokey and smelly it is in here... its as if they cook with the vents closed and fans blow the smoke into the dining area... whats up with that.  When you eat here you leave smelling like you were bathed in indian food just because the smoke is all over you... ill only order take out or delivery from now on.
author: Shawn A.

description: While the atmosphere in the restaurant is pretty shady and the employees aren't the friendliest, this is definitely some great indian food and its pretty darn affordable. I'm only in town for 2 months, but I'll be back here quick a few times I imagine. It isn't a pretty place, but grab some for takeout and you'll have one happy belly by the end of your meal.
author: Michael P.

description: This was by far the worst Indian food I have ever had. Let's put it this way I went there 9 months ago and made myself a promise to write a review since I would never forget how terrible my experience was. Food is very oily and the quality if not good. I read the reviews before going there and have no idea why people like this place. This place is so run down and dirty that I don't understand how they get a pass for even being open. My friend and I almost walked out before even ordering anything. We tried to convince ourselves to eat there just because of the great reviews. Just have to say what a big mistake. I was getting so grossed out once the food arrived just by looking at it. It was just like they emptied half of a bottle of oil, some nasty tasting chicken with all the fatty parts and some Indian spices. I also have to make myself clear and tell you that I'm not a health freak eater, but this was just something totally different. We felt so nauseous after leaving Shalimar for a couple of hours. If you think this is good Indian food that means you haven't had a real tasting Indian meal.
author: Silver D.

description: Food is delicious and authentic. Price is real cheap and staff is ok. The pros of Shalimar ends here. Coming to the negative side, the place is unhygienic and and food is unhealthy. The rest room and the kitchen are very close to one another. Rest room is a nightmare. I had chicken tikka masala which was plunged in oil. The location is sketchy. Overall, you can definitely go and try the food if you just care for the taste.
author: Nishanth D.

description:
Damn good for the price.  In town for a conference near Union Square, last night we went looking for food before heading to the bars. Naan and Curry was across from our hotel, but I'd been there before (quite bad) so I asked the coat checker for another suggestion. He pointed us toward Shalimar, saying "it's not nice looking, but it's very good."   Not realizing we were heading to the Tenderloin, we took off. 

Even more of a hole in the wall than I anticipated. And yeah, it was greasy and I wouldn't order the okra again (soggy.)  My friends said the mango lassis were lukewarm (but it was freakishly hot weather...)

But most of it was really tasty.  CTM and spinach/potato dishes were good and the lamb was very good. The $1 raita was better than most I've had, anywhere. I've paid double these prices for worse Indian food in the North Bay, and paid slightly more at two other places in SF that I thought were not nearly as good. 

Five of us stuffed ourselves for $46 and had food left over. If we were  overcharged on the total bill by a few bucks, I wouldn't care. The guy actually took our order from the table and brought us water pitchers and cups, which I'm reading isn't typical.

I went to the site another reviewer posted about health violations...  014 (CFR) Rodents/Roaches/Flies/Other Animals
High Risk  given on 2/4/2008  "abated" 3/26/2008

So hopefully those rats are gone now... I didn't see any.
author: Jami R.

description:
Solid Indian food for sure.

Top notch naan and curries... Tikka Masala quite good, as was the Sikh Kebab, and decent Chana Masala.
author: David G.

description:
This place has some of the best and most authentic Indian/Pakistani food in San Francisco. With all of the new Indian/Pakistani restaurants opening up over the past several years, this one is going stronger than ever. 

Don't expect good service or a nice atmosphere. The service has gotten better over the years, but it is still well below average. Don't let that share you off though, it's still worth it because the food is so good. Oh, the neighborhood is also a bit frightening.

You will leave smelling like tandoori smoke and a happy grin on your face.
author: Adam C.

description: The goat itself garners a perfect score. Add the garlic naan to boot and I'm sold. Cheap, delicious, and satisfying. Now if this place were a bit closer..
author: Joe L.

description: This is one of the two restaurants in the city that serves Halim on a regular basis - and it is always mouth wateringly wonderful. Once I start with their Halim, I just cannot stop. That's usually all I eat when I go there, though on occasion I've tried other dishes those are pretty good too.
author: Nick K.

description: Really nothing special. Not very clean, so I wouldn't take a girl here. Just go with your guy friends and pig out on a bunch of (standard fare) desi food.
author: Vilas P.

description: Go here, don't go to the Shalimar on Polk. This is the real deal, the one on Polk is like the nice and clean one, this is the sawdust on the floor roaches in the walls pakistanian/north indian restaurant you've been dreaming of in your kaiber pass somnambulist sojourns. Yes, imagine yourself wearing the gear of a traveller, trekking through the hindu kush with sherpas and stopping at some local eatery that serves up a steaming plate of goat, aromatic eggplant and damn fine tandoori. This is probably my favorite "Indian" in the city with lahore, just a couple blocks away, 2nd. The loin is rich in fantastic Pakistani and Indian restaurants but this must be one of the finest. Be prepared to jump on tables, be ruthless, be cutthroat, take no prisoners, as none will be taken... ;-)
author: Len S.

description: It's 11 pm. You went to a dinner at an academic conference that was pathetically bad (a shame in SF...), and you are starving because you barely touched the food. Suddenly you think: I'm staying in the Tenderloin. The Tandoorloin. I want NIHARI. I called Shalimar to ask if they had it, and they did, so I placed an order for that and a couple naan. The naan was fine but nothing to write home about, however, the nihari was great! I told all my Pakistani friends and family about this place, I think it outshines the place in Chicago that we treat as the gold standard. Call ahead if you are set on nihari, as I understand that they only make it certain days.
author: Lydia M.

description:
please go somewhere else !
these people are very unhygienic.

i admit there dishes are good, but not at the cost of your health.
also too much oil.

and please dont mistake it for indian food, its nowhere near the 
taste of real indian food.
these people just dont care , they there to make money.

big turn offs  smell.. cash only.... staff (rude)....... hygiene.
author: Bunty P.

description:
Dear Yelp,

Thank you for endowing me with all of the great friends, exciting experiences, valuable entertainment, and exquisite information that you have provided over the years.  I am delighted to tell you that I shared a lovely dinner at Shalimar Restaurant last evening with several of my Yelp friends.  As much as I would like to acknowledge my compadres as an expression of gratitude in my letter to you, their names will remain anonymous.   

Dinner itself was quite the experience. Although utterly lacking in decor, and possibly even verging on the filthy, Shalimar's dumpiness and Tenderloin backdrop provide an abundance of character.  When I spotted an ideal parking spot on Jones Street directly fronting the restaurant, one of the Tenderloin's many characters (this one happening to be lacking teeth) accommodated me, reserving the spot for me and then, carefully directing me in my parallel parking effort with his indispensable valet services.  Upon exiting my vehicle I was more than surprised to find that he fancied payment for this service, which I had understood was complimentary.  When I told the toothless valet that I did not have any cash on me, I was utterly flabbergasted to hear the two words that would next fall from his dentally-challenged orifice:  "fuck you",  two words which sent me on the scoot to the restaurant's front door to await the others.

As I waited, I went into the Shalimar for my first peek: it is stark, austere even.  I ask if they take credit, but its cash only.  By this time, one of my cohorts has shown up, so we go down to the corner store to get some cash, passing by the toothless valet and several of his friends.  

We come back and are joined by our other Yelp companions.  We go inside and order lavishly.  We order all kinds of dishes. So many dishes. Chicken dishes, lamb dishes, vegetable dishes, saffron rice, naan.  Here was a south Asian feast and it was all really good.  We had gotten some beer from the corner store as well and were just having a jovial time of it.

As the evening progressed and the beer flowed, stories began to trickle forth.  Stories of Yelp.  First gossip.  And then, not just gossip, but full-blown stories rich with colorful detail.  As I listened intently to the stories unfolding, my jaw just dropped lower and lower.  These stories were about sexual relations.  You know, hooking up.  "FTF's" (Friends That Fuck). "Fuck buddies." Three-ways. Copulation. Fornication.  "DYL" tours.  *Borderline orgies*.  For those of you who don't know or get what I'm talking about, TOTAL DEBAUCHERY IS WHAT IS BEING DESCRIBED TO ME.  My eyeballs boggled and nearly popped out of my skull as I watched the words fall whimsically from my Yelp companions' moistened lips.  My earballs burned and throbbed as I listened to these stories, gasping at some of the particularly detailed anecdotes.  Neighboring patrons glared at our table as the volume rose with every boisterous hoot, every raucous holler and every haughty, self-satisfied belly laugh.  The stories even inspired me to add a new character to my "Cast of Yelp Characters, Act Two" (please see "Yelp Slut" http://www.yelp.com/biz/lsu5qhNB1NEFWn4bApeHOA?hrid=xbkIxSTqkRuDVnKgB6-UQg).

It was 10 pm when we finally finished.  I must admit that, by the end of the night, I was a bit queasy from all the dizzying and shocking tales of Yelp depravity.  This wasn't helped by the insistence of two members of our party that we order "jalebees" for dessert, which turned out to be India's version of deep fried cheetos and tasted like they had been marinated overnight in the Ganges River (the south part). 

The point of my letter, Yelp, is this...

PLEASE COPY ME ON THE MEMO NEXT TIME YOU ARE PLANNING TO HAVE WILD WANTON DEBAUCHEROUS CARNAL LUDE ROMAN EMPIRE-STYLE ANIMAL SEX. 

Thank you for your attention in this matter.  Good day.

Sincerely,



Rick Hirsch
author: Rick H.

description:
Not the best place if you're looking for fine dining but perfect if you just want really great Indian/Pakistani food in a highly casual environment.

My favourite was the eggplant curry. We also had the garlic naan bread, tandoori chicken and bryani rice.

Highly recommended.
author: Jason K.

description:
sometimes when you go to dine out, the experience surpasses the actual meal.  in the case of shalimar, the experience is like a mushroom trip where you traipse through fields of curried meats and dance amongst the technicolor stew.  the food is right wicked awesome and the ambience only amplifies your gustatory headtrip.  

first you get to approach through the Tenderloin.  heaven forbid you are trying to park because you'll be doing SF laps for 30 minutes at a minimum.  i actually found a secret parking garage that only charges $4 per hour after 7pm.  then you make your way past every crackhead, junkie and meth tweaker in the lower 48.  mix in the local shopping cart gang and panhandlers with trash and strange fluids in the gutters and you are living the Tenderloin dream!  once, as my friend and i made our way in we saw a fellow doing a hotfoot dance, throwing his head around and grimacing a lot.  as we got closer we realized that he was YANKING HIS JUNK UNDERNEATH HIS BLANKET right there on the street.  10 kinds of awesome!

anyway, after entering the "restaurant" things only get better.  like a 12-ring circus and nobody knows what is going on.  you go and order your food before you have a table to sit at, then you look around and the whole place is packed.  if you are lucky you get escorted out the side door, past the mop buckets and the trash dumpsters to the secret VIP room in back.  we got seated at a table that was still covered in dirty dishes and leavings|drippings from the prior occupant.  BYOB and crack a freshie while you await ecstasy on porcelain.  if you need to use the bathroom, feel free to step into the full suite, complete with shower stall cum paint storage closet.  

after you gut down on the tastiest indian food in san francisco, you roll yourself out of there and start to notice the extended list of health code violations.  and you do it with a huge smile of satisfaction.

if you are under the influence of intoxicants, don't forget to pay because they ain't bringing you a check.
author: W G.

description:
I just laugh when I see people at Shalimar who have obviously decided to be adventurous on their lunch hour, try an Indo-Paki "hole-in-the-wall" and get taken aback when they realize it truly is a hole-in-the-wall place that is about as no-frills as you can get and requires you to get your own tableware and drinks (soda, water, or the kick-ass free tea).  If anything, this Shalimar is slightly better than the Fremont location, in that the "waiter" does show sympathy to those poor souls waiting at their tables for water and a menu and actually bring those items to them, rather than making them go up to the counter and order like everyone else.  Believe me, there is no such sympathy in Fremont.

In any case, onward to my meal, which was great...not as great as that of the Fremont location, but good nonetheless.  We ordered the usual- plain naan, chicken tikka masala, lamb curry, tandoori chicken legs, chicken kofta and a new one for us- the bangun bhurjia (eggplant).  The naan is super-fresh so no complaints there- its great to eat alone or with the curry.  The tandoori chicken leg- also super-fresh- comes slightly charred and smokey, with a delicious spice rub on the outside that has you licking your fingers.  The chicken tikka masala- definitely spicy, definitely tasty, but perhaps with a touch too much ghee.  The chicken kofta- one of my favorites- is a milder curry, so it gives you a break from the spiciness of the chicken tikka masala and the lamb curry.  The chicken meatballs are tender and full of flavor.  The eggplant was fabulous- almost like the Indo-Paki version of baba ghanouj.  Lots of great flavor and spices, though you do have to be careful not to bite into one of the whole cloves or cardamon seeds.  The only disappointment was the lamb curry which was mostly all bone. 

4 stars for the meal and the freakishly good free chai tea, which is so freakishly good because they don't use too much cardamon.  Even after being completely stuffed by the meal, we'll manage to put away two to three cups each.  I'm subtracting one star just because my stomach didn't agree with that much ghee.  I'd definitely recommend going, but for a better experience overall, head over to their location in Fremont.
author: Angela H.

description: Orgasmically good Indian! This is THE kind of hole-in-the-wall place that you hope to find in any city. Cheap and simple, and so awesomely spicy that it's sure to give you an endorphin rush. Do brace yourself for the actual restaurant - though it's not unsanitary, it's pretty dirty. The walls have random pictures and cracks, there is cardboard in the window [what's weird is that it's neither a sign nor a cover for a hole, it's just there], the menus are greasy, and occasionally unpleasant SF characters wander in... but in a way it's all part of the hole-in-the-wall aesthetic.
author: Liza P.

description: Look at the crowds here, versus the many almost empty Pakistani and Indian restaurants around it in the Tenderloin. Shalimar for its devotees is extraordinary, and we and friends always leave immensely happy. The naans outclass most of the other places around, I have friends who bring dozens of orders of bhuna ghosh back across country with them whenever they visit, we love the kebabs, the goat curry and chicken ginger and the haleem.  The Tenderloin at night is dodgy, the walls dingy, the place crowded: walk with friends and consider it a pilgrimage.
author: Lawrence C.

description: No complaints. I've yet to have a bad experience at either Shalimar location. I ate here for lunch and didn't eat again until lunchtime the following day. Know that your clothes are going to smell like tandoori even if the place is empty. Unlike the Tenderloin location there's outdoor seating for when the weather's nice out.
author: alejandro p.

description: tandori chicken was better here....good....not so bitterly charred as i have experienced at the jones location...but sadly...the chicken meatballs in curry sauce seemed a bit rubbery today....but the sauce was still great for dippin' and munchin' the nan (warm toasty flat bread)......the front patio area is nice for a lazy lunch on a nice cool sunny day....while the buzzin' flies above was a bit annoying.....shalimar is always a cheap good eats joint in the city.....and the polk street location is a little "nicer" when compared to the jones street location....
author: Hen A.

description: The Tandoori chicken was really good! Everything was so cheap and the service was fast even though the place was totally packed. Surely the crown jewel of downtown. I can't wait to go again.
author: Sharee R.

description: Best Chicken Tikka Masala in the Tenderloin but not the best in the city. Last Saturday a small group of friends and me went to three different Indian places in the Loin to see which had the best Tikka. Shalimar edged out Chutney and the place actually called Tikka Masala. The naan was stuffed with garlic shavings rather than dusted with garlic crumbs like most Indian places. The ambiance is pretty bad (thus 3 stars instead of 4) and of the three we visited that night, this one had the most tandori smoke floating around.  At this point I've tried the Tikka Masala at over 10 Indian places in SF and Mehfil on 2nd and Folsom is head and shoulders above the rest.
author: Kris N.

description: I had the Murgh Tikka Lahori with some rice and naan. The chicken in it was soft and tasty but the sauce it was in was just mediocre. Felt a bit greasey but this is the first time I had this dish. I also had a taste of Chicken Tikka Masala. That dish was lacking a bit of flavor. I most likely need to go back again to have another go to get a better reading of the food. Price was reasonable though.
author: Louis T.

description:
"Mary had a little sheep,
with whom she went to sleep,
the sheep turned out to be a Ram
and Mary had a little lamb"

From Elvis crooning "Love me tender" to wife swapping in Scott Fitzgerald's Tender is the Night, our society has a soft corner for Tenderness.
I have strong Tenderness towards Shalimar Restaurant in the Tenderloin especially for the Bhuna Lamb.  I sink my teeth into the tender meat and my heart gets filled with gratitude to the Ram who went out of his way to don the disguise of a sheep and make tender love to Mary so that I could get my piece of meat.
author: Kaustav C.

description: Delicious Indian in a dive. Plus one star for the BYOB policy and liquor store on the corner. Minus one star for the very authentic Indian bathroom.
author: Sara B.

description: This place is great! Its dirty, super sketchy,  and everything you might ask for when indian restaurants come to mind! You can see the whole kitchen preparing the delicious homestyle curry and it is one big hot steaming mess in there! I've only been here once but from my first experience I really liked it. Although the service was lacking (which they don't really have anyways)... everything else was fine. I ended up only trying three different vegetarian plates and have yet to try the chicken tikka marsala. One of my friends was vegeterian and another was a health freak so I had to put a hold on my chicken dish. Next time though I will and most definitely order that dish as I heard good things. Oh yeah don't mind the flies as they add extra flavor...jk. Just wave your hand and push em away. They are only there cause the food is that damn tasty and aromatic. Oh and the salt is very interesting. They have some stuff in there like peppercorn and bits and pieces of random junk...which I think was accidental. Its cool though cause its like a treasure hunt inside a salt shaker!
author: Jonathon C.

description: cheap and quick and easy and delish, but the grease factor and the decor and fluorescent lighting factor and  the "its been sitting in the pot all day" factor always keeps me from fully enjoying the undeniable good spice at shalimar, but what can I say? I'll be back nonetheless.
author: Liz S.

description:
I know people who will drive three hours for Shalimar's seekh kebabs, which are the real reason to go.  Shalimar is, and it's pretty well established, the best Pakistani food spot in the Bay Area.  The, uh, ambiance isn't for everyone.  Or, really, anyone except those nostalgic for their favorite corner dive in Karachi (when it was bombed out by India during the last war).  I sympathize with the people who never want to set foot in Shalimar.  I've got a pretty strong stomach but "the rag"...  the orange, crusty, tikka towel that is overdue for its annual cleaning is enough to make me get take out 9 out of 10 times.  

But for those who want the experience here is my best advice:

1. There is no line.  There are only polite people waiting in a line that doesn't exist.  Just walk up to the counter, say "ayar" -- means buddy in urdu -- and place your order.

2. Fire to plate.  I only order stuff that I can see go from the sanitizing influence of a the fire straight onto my plate.  E.g., naan, tikka, kebabs, etc.  I don't do saag.  The only exception I allow is for the basmati.  Break this rule more than three times at your own peril.

3. Cash only.  You won't want to walk around the neighborhood looking for an ATM. 

4. Bring your own drinks.  If you like beer feel free to bring your own.  You won't be judged.  Even though, strictly speaking, you're going to hell.

5. Free chai.  Cups of tea are free.  Don't forget to pour in about three tablespoons of sugar.  I think that's sweetened and condensed milk in there, which would explain why we all like it so much.

6. Time the naan.  Wait until the naan is fresh.  This may require a little hovering.  But, if the naan stack is down to 2-3, there's a fresh one coming.  Pretend you're studying the menu.

7. Enough has been written about the bathroom.
author: Sharif E.

description: Don't let anyone tell you different, this is the best Indian/Pakistani restaurant in SF. Not only do I think it's great but all of my Pakistani friends confirm that it's the best place around. You must try the Chicken Tikka Masala. There's also one in Fremont with the same menu for all you South Bay peeps.
author: Aaron V.

description: addictive and delicious, like indian crack my companion exclaimed as we devoured the goat and the beef and the chicken tikka massala. I'm still having daydreams about the naan.  Be sure to bring your own beer, and to drink lots of water before bedtime.
author: Stellah D.

description:
Oh, I finally know your name so that when i'm in san fran I can eat your wonderful naan and curry chicken. Yes I have to drink my own drink but I don't care, you are my favorite.

I ate there in 2001...I still dream about it. often... Is it still good???
author: Mochi K.

description:
I came here for the first time with some of my guys from college. We'd been wandering around the city all day and, after spending more time debating where to get dinner then it would actually take us to eat it, we were ravenous by the time we settled on and arrived at Shalimar.

We ordered half the menu and then waited. Now, let me say one thing: my family eats really slowly. I was the "fastest eater" but I guess that's not saying much as my family, until fairly recently, consisted only of myself and my parents. So, in general, no matter how hard I try, usually everyone else at the table has had their plate cleared except me and I've still got half the entree to go. I have heard kids from larger families describe the face-stuffing-races they and their siblings engaged in to make sure they got their share of the food. Well, once the food arrived at our table, I got to experience that first hand.  In under 15 minutes, possibly less, all the spicy savory food did an amazing disappearing act! In those 15 minutes the conversation was limited to comments like "mmm, this chicken is awesome," "pass me the nann," "did you try the tandori boti?," "is there any more aloo keema? "you want the last potato? I'll split it with you."  Once we realized that, short of licking the dishes, there wasn't anything left on the table to eat we took a breather. And debated getting more food. The light and fluffy nan? Another aloo keema? should we try something else?

But after letting what we'd eaten settled for a few moments we decided more food could wait for another night and so we move on to the  grand finale, an order of the Gulab Jaman, warm gooey syrupy spheres of heaven. 

I'm looking forward to going back, especially now that I know it's BOYB. Maybe next time I'll take my girlfriends so I won't have to eat Cookie Monster style.
author: Camille H.

description: While it wasn't the absolute best Indian food I've ever had, it was quite tasty and the price was right!  After having some rather flat and non-fluffy naan from a place in the Mission, the fluffy naan here was a breath of fresh air.  I didn't realize that they had lamb brain masala until after I left, so I'll have to try it next time.
author: Mike G.

description: Not much for ambiance but then I'm not ordering that from the menu.  Shalimar was amazing.  The perfect marriage of spice to every dish and for anything too spicy they had that super yummy yogurt to cool your palate.  Good stuff.  Highly recommended.
author: Chard M.

description: This location and the one near Sunnyvale are my favorite places for some great Indian food! I always go here with my family because I think my aunt is the landlord for the Jones location. We seriously order everything on the menu and it's all packed full of flavor and really satisfying. I like all their different kinds of naan, like potato, and onion naan, dipped in the chicken curry. Tandoori chicken is always cooked just right and even their tea is good! Definitely check out this place! It is undeniably the best Indian food in the city! Hearty portions too!
author: Kamie P.

description: By far the BEST BEST pakistani restaurant I've been to in a while! I could have their food all month if ONLYY i lived closer! I had them three times this weekend and I couldnt regret it at all. As a student, not only are their prices perfect but their food is amazing! I missed my moms cooking so much that going to Shalimar made me feel like I was back home.Plus their food is so balanced not too spicy or bland. Just perfect!
author: On The G.

description:
I've been coming to this place since '99 when..believe it or not..the ambiance was even WORSE (and the food even better and cheaper). Back then I was the only white boy in the place but now it's pretty popular and well known.

My friends and I wonder if the cooks buy some crack outside the door and put it in the food.. cuz this stuff is so addictive!

Favorite dish is Bengan Bharti. I'm not usually an eggplant fan but this dish is the BOMB! Also their shishkabob dishes (most of the meat dishes) are great.
author: T.J. K.

description: What a wonderful Polk Street dining experience.  The food is great, the atmosphere is somewhat like a cafeteria and the experience of ordering and paying for your food is quirky and somewhat confusing...in a good way, though.
author: Will W.

description: This place was my favorite pakistani dive in the city.  No longer...I took a good friend there and he insisted on the lamb chops which i always thought were too expensive to order....Since i love lamb, i agreed....i asked specifically for rare and was given over the top well done with fat and was as chewey as possible....like leather....I pointed this out to the waiter who merely shrugged his shoulders and turned away.  Such a disappointment and for the price (highest on the menu), one would think they might just take a return....hahahahahaha....the bathroom is definitely always third world and the owner or manager physically tossed out a customer after a huge shouting match and then threw his backpack out onto the street after him....I decided not to make such a big deal over the lamb chops (possibly the worst i have ever eaten) and ordered the chicken.
author: bruce g.

description: INCREDIBLY GOOD. Open letter to all chefs especially in the Bay Area: Why can't you all cook like this for $8?INCREDIBLY GOOD.
author: armand d.

description:
Shalimar used to be my favorite Indian/ Pakistani restaurant in the Tenderloin.  I apparently need to find a new favorite.  We ordered some very standard dishes- chicken tikka masala and saag paneer.  The chicken tikka masala had about 1/2" of grease pooled on top- literally.  We were able to spoon it off at least...  The chicken was tough and overcooked, and the curry itself too greasy.  The saag paneer was clumpy, greasy, and the cheese was also dry and hard. 

The only positive was that the staff was really friendly, which was appreciated given that you wouldn't really expect good service.

I may have to give Lahore Karahi another try, though in the past I've rated it below Shalimar.  Or maybe we have to try the East Bay or peninsula...
author: C.S. K.

description: Charlene say's it's the best. I thought is was okay. It's one of those places where you get your food cheap, therefore you get what you pay for. The Naan was raw in the center. The meat dishes were awesome, but they had too many pepper corns in them. Shalimar is the place to go after you get drunk in Tendernob and you only have $8.43 and some lint left in your pockets. It's good but not amazing like Charlene says it is. Of course coming from Lathrop everything is better than the local Long John Silver's. Just kidding Charlene. And yes, you were right about heating up the food in the microwave late at night and eating leftovers. Shalimar leftovers are the best couch food in the world. Thanks for treating us to Shalimar Charlene. We luv you.
author: Glenn C.

description: This place is legit!  Its not the cleanest restaurant you'll visit but that's probably because they're putting that much more effort on the food.  If you like indian food, this is a must-try.
author: Alex P.

description: its okay, i think little delhi is better and less greasy
author: James V.

description: This is most authentic food I have tasted. Plan to go there again and see it is always as tasty.
author: roger j.

description:
the shalimar gardens built in the 17th century near lahore, pakistan, were known for impeccable design and beautiful flora. unlike its namesake, our lovely shalimar was not given stars for the decor, service, ambiance or cleanliness, its for the food and its food is honestly meritable. even better: the entire newsprinted menu is really inexpensive.

they have perfected mellowing of the indian spices for the american palate. when you are picking out pieces of spices you know you're in a good place. i've tried a bunch of eateries in the polk gultch and few of them exceed mediocre. shalimar however, makes me happy its in the neighborhood.
author: Ligaya T.

description: I'm 1/2 Pakistani and this is close as I've ever gotten to my grandmother's cooking which is out of this world.  Treat yourself for cheap!  While having the Tikka Masala all I could think of was a line from Sophia on the Golden Girls "If this sauce were a person, I'd get naked and make love to it."  Yeah, it's that fantastic.
author: Sean M.

description: I dont understand what all the hype is for.  I was really disappointed and swore never to go back there!  The place looks like its ready to fall apart any minute.  It was dirty and disgusting.  The food comes nowhere near Kabab & Curry or Shan in San Jose.  Even by my desi standards, their maghaz masala was crawling with lil peppercorns(garam masala in abundance) and their haleem was all daal with any meat whatsoever missing in action.  I can probably make better garlic naans at home!
author: Seher H.

description: One of my favorite restaurants that I go to regularly.  They gots an awesome menu of super-good choices of Indian cuisine at rock-bottom prices.  You can have dinner for two people here and get super-stuffed for under $13.  Really good place to eat right after a workout at the gym.  Don't let this place's location fool you (it's in the ghetto), it's damn good food at hella cheap prices.
author: Minh V.

description: I'd give Chutney across the street 3 stars. This is one notch below. Seriously, anybody who gives this place over 3 stars doesn't know squat about decent Indian/Pakistani food. Shalimar is a dirty hole in the wall that serves very greasy/oily food. I ordered 6 dishes here. The only half-way decent stuff was the rice and garlic naan. Do not get any goat or lamb meat dishes here. Chicken is so-so.
author: Rich B.

description: Yes, it's cheap, and the food is pretty good.  But I would hardly say it's the best Indian/Pakistani food in the city (or even the neighborhood).  The surly staff and miserable interior just don't make up for it.  I'd say this is one of the most consistently overrated restaurants in SF.
author: nick w.

description:
5 Stars all the way!

the food absolutely rocks at Shalimar - sure, the place has it's drawbacks, the toothless woman sitting on the sidewalk outside, the dirty silverware, the pools of oil on top of some of the dishes,(j/k it's not that bad.. But if you can get past the sheer grossness of the place, you're in for a treat.. Everything on the menu is worth trying, though certain dishes will bring you closer to Nirvana than others. One of my favorites is the Chicken Kofta, the ambrosial balls of minced chicken in a piquant curry, quite unlike anything else I've come across ..They even have a BYOB policy.hehehe
author: tramy n.

description: Located in a very bad neighborhood. Don't let this place scare you. Great pakistani food.
author: Dee N.

description: This is the original of the Pakistani restaurants that have surfaced over the last couple of years, and still one of the better ones. Kebobs and tikka dishes are worth trying.
author: Nish N.

description: Best Pakistani/Indian Food ever! A great hole in a wall place. My husband first brought me here bout 10 yrs ago. I was really hesitant to go because of the area, but one night we (I) braved it n it was delicious passionate spiced up food. A definite downtown SF experience. We always order the same food which only costs us $23 including tip. He orders chicken boti, chana masala,potato bread, basmati rice. Sometimes we add the chicken Tika masala, cuz we luv it. U may have to wait from time to time, but it's so worth it. We visit Shalimar( this location) bout once a month at least!
author: Flora K.

description: There are many indian restaurants whose food is spicy, but not packed with much flavor.  This restaurant's food is full of flavor and spice. The service is terrible (mostly do-it-yourself) and the restaurant itself isn't the cleanest. You go to the counter to order and grab your own drinks. They got our order wrong and also forgot to bring us our okra which we had to ask for. The temperature in the place is really warm, not to mention eating indian/pakistani food makes you even warmer so i don't recommend wearing anything heavy you can't take off. Area isn't the greatest but it IS the TL. Basically, if you don't care about ambiance and being catered to hand and foot, then this is your place because the food here is awesome.
author: Jen Y.

description: Hot hot hot! The food here is really hot! It's kind of crappy on the inside but the food is pretty good.
author: Carson H.

description:
wow, Shalimar is a great place:

good portions (providing you remember to order rice & naan) of good food at good prices.

here is some advice for people visiting for the first time:

remember to order rice & naan (try the garlic naan).

when they're busy, you may need to use your elbows or make friends with some new people to get a table. better yet, bring a friend and have them hold the table while you order.

if you're put off by dingy dining rooms and curt service, try walking through the homeless jungle on Ellis between Taylor and Jones on your way to the restaurant. Shalimar will seem like heaven.

if you're put off by eating to Pakistani techno, get your food to go.
author: adam b.

description: This place is great! It's cheap, low key, and you can bring your own beer.  I love going there and find the food very tasty.  I wouldn't go on a date there, but if you're out on polk street and hungry it's a fun place to go.
author: Sarah C.

description: Super cheap, very tasty food. I shared a chicken tikka masala and a lamb stew, as well as rice and naan. Highly recommended, I will definitely return to this place.
author: Joshua S.

description:
5 Stars for the food!  You can't come to a place like this and base your rating on their service, location...or the newspaper menu.

Excellent food, great prices I haven't got anything here that I didn't absolutely love, even disregarding the price this place is amazing.  I always have to give a little bit more respect to a place when you have Indian/Pakistani people bringing you there for the food.  

No alcohol? They've let me have a beer from the liquor store on the corner before, and a different time said I couldn't.  So ask and see what they say if you want a beer with dinner...couldn't hurt.
author: Check I.

description: Awesome Pakistani food. I'm British and know my curry. This is excellent and not pretentious. Karahi is beautiful.
author: james j.

description:
Disgustingly dirty (stains on the walls, filthy plates/waiters, the counter guy was eating with his hands and handling food/cash).
Food was sorta okay
I WILL NOT go there again
BTW... Department of Public Health gave it a cleanliness score of 66 (WAY WAY BELOW average)
author: T S.

description: Eh, it's alright but I think that Chutney across the street is better fare, personally.  I was disappointed that they didn't have my staple, Aloo Gobhi and I had to make do with an Aloo with mixed vegetables instead.  Not as good.  I also didn't like their Palaak Paneer at all.  OIly, lumpy and with little discernable flavor.  Raita was good but that's hard to screw up and the chicken tikka masala was decent.  The beef khabobs were kind of over spiced and oily but they were still okay.  Prices are the usual cheap, TL fare but I still will go to Chutney over Shalimar hands down.
author: Jill D.

description:
OK i used to love this place, but the past two times I have went my clothes reeked beyond belief afterward: get some ventilation guys. In that way the Shalimar on Polk is nicer because its breezy and has an outdoor option.

The other star off is because they stopped allowing BYO!! I don't know if the same is true for Polk st, but that really bummed me out.

The food is still great...but there are other equally good options where I won't smell and can drink a beer.
author: Sam H.

description: The food is greasy, but quite tasty and you can't complain about the prices.  I could have done without the flies, though.  I have to admit, the last time I was there, there were quite a few flies buzzing around, and it didn't really enhance the dining experience.  Unfortunately, it seems that there is no longer a BYOB policy.  Geez, if I could drink, maybe I could forget about the flies!
author: Susan S.

description: Simply the best Pakistani place west of, well, Pakistan! The tandoori chicken, chicken tikka masala, sag gosht ... totally fabulous. As for the ambiance, it is total chaos, and the smoke coming from the kitcfhen totally envelopes the diners -- just like it should be! :)  Enjoy!
author: Marc K.

description: Every bit as good as Naan n Curry, but slightly more expensive.  The Polk St location is a little cleaner and less scuzzy-feeling than the slew of Indian places over in the 'Loin.
author: Andrew E.

description: This is a 5 star hole-in-the-wall if such a thing exist.  Why even mention the ambience?  Unless you're date tells you hole-in-the-wall is so their thing, take them elsewhere.  But if you want cheap, great tasting food, this is it.  I have not a clue what part of India this food is from, but it sure as hell was spicy whatever chicken I ordered that was sittin' in some yummy sauce.  However, not all their food is spicy or oily as other reviews suggest cause my bf ordered another chicken dish (sorry I'm not very helpful here) that was actually a bit dry but still very tasty.  It's true that their naan is nothing to rave about.
author: Mabel L.

description: Wow-took advice here on Yelp and tried the chicken tikka marsala. Sooo good!  The naan was right up there too. The place is a dump but I'm ok with that.
author: Dave M.

description: Wow, this place is good. I thought naan & curry was IT for this category of indian (cheap, quick and easy) but this place is the real deal. The interior has something to be desired but the food is soo damn good. I'd say branch out from the tikka massala here (i personally like naan&currys better) and try something new...come-on people...lets be a little adventurous!
author: Lindonesia S.

description: I admit it, i'm ghetto by heart! This dive totally calls to me. You definitely have to mentally prepare yourself for the ghetto factor - inside & out of this establishment. Sometimes I think its the grit factor that makes the food that much more bona fide. It can be hard to snag a seat... but certainly better than standing outside. That is, if you're willing to stay to grub.  I'm not even going to try naming recommendations off the myriad of choices on their huge, newspaper-big menus - i'd butcher it anyway. My fave is the chiken tikka masala, tho I've loved everything i've eaten here... it's as close to Pakistan that this girl can get to for under 10 bucks easy.
author: Ikeb I.

description: 4 stars definitely for the awesome food...the curry beef, curry muttom (which I thought definitely tasted better than the beef, it seemed more juicy), the okra though mushy was really tasty but it is not for the health concious as it was swimming in a lot of oil. Haha...I guess most of the veges here are not that healthy but it is darn tasty. The chicken tandoori is by far my absolute fave, it was tender and full of flavor...hmmmm....and definitely order the chicken masala cos the sauce is the best for dunking your naan into. The food prices here are sooo reasonable that I will come back again. The restaurant isnt exactly the cleanest but heck, for the good food I will still return!
author: Topazskye L.

description: The kids in SF seem to really like this one.  It feels and tastes like a cafeteria.  Naan-n-curry is better.
author: A V.

description: Good, cheap, quick, cash-only, nice and spicy Indian food. Good for sopping up drunkenness before the really late night hits. I am always really happy when I eat here with friends and we all manage to stuff ourselves and send the leftovers home with the poorest of us (usually that's me).
author: Anna S.

description: I get dragged here all the time by a few friends who are nuts about this place. It's very cheap, it's charming as far as holes in the wall go, and I guess it's fun to take your own alcohol places, but the food just ain't so great.
author: Max M.

description: Great food. Spicy! Cheap. No service, and you sometimes have to be aggressive to get your order in.  I discovered the hard way that their raita is spicy, so don't try to use it to cool your mouth down.
author: Beetle B.

description:
Probably the best Indian/Pakistani food in the city. Yes, the place is alittle dirty, yes the service is non-existent, but the food completely makes up for that. And it's cheap and fast to boot - I love it when the place can manage that without sacrificing the food quality. The only downside is that vegetarian options are a bit limited. 

Try murgh boti tandoori - it is tender and spicy and perfect. The naan is always fresh out of tandoor. Saag chicken is moist and delicios. In short - a perfect Punjabi experience!
author: Slav F.

description: The curries are unimpressive but the kebab and tandoori are quite tasty.  When you add everything up like rice, naan, and papadams it becomes a bit pricey for what it is.  I think it has declined in quality over the past 3 or 4 years as I remember my Indian friends driving all the way from Fremont for a late night Shalimar fix back in the day.
author: matthew w.

description:
Having been a regular at the restaurant for the past 7 years should speak for itself. Shalimar is the best Indian-Pakistani food in America, perhaps North America. 

If you go there and don't order the Chicken Boti you don't know what you're missing out on. 

While the ambiance is lack luster, who cares? You're there for the food right? If you're not, this probably isn't the place for you.
author: Faisal G.

description:
You walk into Shalimar and through the haze of smoke you see it, the command center, the kitchen, crowded with men, shoving and screaming as if they were on the floor of the New York stock exchange. There are no less than 25 people behind the counter, using all sorts of methods to prepare the delicious food - I swear I saw someone using a blowtorch on the Tandoori chicken. Cooks and dishwashers seem to trade places with each other regularly and periodically half the crew walks out of the back door as more come to replace them without missing a beat. There is only one constant behind that counter, a tall dominating figure, who seems to tower over the others, causing them to cower as they pass by on their way for more Naan. I'll call him the Alpha Man - he says nothing, just points and stares at the others who seem to understand his silent orders - watching this makes me anxious and afraid, I feel like at any minute he is going to point at me and I will have to run back there and mop the floor or something - he definitely runs this place. 

The small army that runs Shalimar is only concerned with one thing - making great tasting, authentic food - they don't care if you're comfortable, they don't even care if you come back - they know they're good at what they do. Swagger.  I go there for the swagger just as much as I go there for the food.

If you haven't been to Shalimar yet, stop what ever you're doing and go there right now - it's delicious Indian Soul Food for next to nothing. Go, now!!
author: Max T.

description:
Consistent, cheap, open late and as authentic as it is going to get in S.F.  You know it's a good sign when other restaurants are recommending that you go to Shalimar to get an authentic Byriani.  

My favs are the Chicken Korma, Chicken Byriani, Chicken Tika Masala - oh goodness forget it, it's ALL GOOD!!!
author: Nerrd G.

description: My favorite (well tied with Naan-N-Curry) Pakistani/Indian place in the city. The food is excellent and the atmosphere is exactly what I look for in a cheap joint, vintage hole-in-the-wall. You have to be assertive and just start ordering food even if the guy in the kitchen doesn't look like he's paying any attention. You get your own silverware and whatever else you need, but for the price, who can complain?
author: Jordan M.

description: Simply the best Indian food in San Francisco. Cheap and good, thus always a dinner option.
author: Eugenel E.

description: I had heard great things about this place.  I was in the neighborhood around lunchtime with some friends and family one afternoon, so we decided to get lunch here.  The place is pretty bare bones.  You order the food at the counter and it feels a bit like a run down cafeteria.  Normally, I don't mind this if the food is good.  However, it was ehhh.  Not nearly as good as I had heard the food would be.  Maybe I would have liked it better if i hadn't had any expectations, but it completely failed to impress.  The food was edible, but not much more than that.
author: Kate B.

description: So friggin good, and so friggin cheap.  Just the way I likes it.
author: Helen C.

description: Shalimar is great place for CHEAP indian food late at night. They are also great because for those of us that cant handle really spicy, they can make food mild. I love their Chana Masala.   If you like incredibly spicy authentic food, then go around the corner to Naan & Curry, their food is hands down THE BEST in the city. However, I eat at Shalimar because N&C is too hot for my sensitive tastebuds and at N&C there is no such thing as mild.
author: K B.

description:
everyone raves about this place, but it didn't do much for me...

when i order tikka masala, i expect it to have the taste of yummy creamy tomato sauce w/those wonderful indian spices...  not oily, creamy tomato sauce.  the other dishes we ordered were sub-par.

expect to smell when you leave.

i'll be across the street @ chutney's.
author: Sheri N.

description: The location is far from the best (a part of the city I do my best to avoid), the service is nonexistent, and they only take cash.  Still, I willingly wade through the homeless and the junkies to get my fill at Shalimar, which remains one of the very best Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the city.  If you care about high quality Indian food, then you need to visit.
author: Ty D.

description: They're trying to call or label this part of town "Little India." Hello people in the real estate biz...DO YOU KNOW HOW BIG INDIA IS??"  If you've been to this hood you know that it's more like a Hieronymus Bosch painting. But amongst the rough of the LOIN is a diamond in Shalimar. After a night of carousing with the crew, there is no better stop than Shalimar. Gotta brown bag your beer...(Hey everybody else in this hood is doing it). Love the naan, chicken masala....yumfabulous... and saag paneer. But I must only provide 3 duckets to ye ol' Shalimar, because Pakwan is my favorite for  Pakistani-Indian food. Yes they're paying me to say this!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
i've heard so much about this place and finally went last night. i've found a new FAV indian restaurant in sf!! i've been looking for a place like this- fast service, cheap eats, and GREAT food. i might not know how authentic indian/pakistani food should taste like but Shalimar makes it just the way i like it. 

the thick and tangy raita was awesome! i like to eat it with everything (in fact I can drink it) so it has to be just right! all the dishes were very spicy, flavorful, and saucy (perfect for dipping my naan). the complimentary raw onions and chili pepper topped it off for me. it's so delicious!

it's worth the trek through The Loins, the inhaling of urine, and passing of the drug exchanges. don't stop, just walk straight to the restaurant.........but be sure to go straight back home after too. the smell of the curry will stick to you=P

i'm looking forward to my next meal there!
author: Irene T.

description: My favorite Tenderloin destination, Shalimar serves delicious Pakistani food at cheap prices.  The Tandoori chicken and Chicken Tikka Masala are my favorites. While the food is good and cheap, the decor follows suit, so don't bring a hot date with you and expect to impress; you'll probably wreak of onions and spices for the rest of the night.
author: Peter C.

description: As a hole in the wall connoisseur, this is definitely one of my favourites.  The best Pakistani food I've ever had.  Spices to tingle the senses, and authentic to the bone.  Great value but sort of tucked away in a ghetto part of town.  Make sure you negotiate the pimps and their crack whores carefully to get in the door safely.
author: Chris C.

description: I came here on Friday night with a group of people after happy hour at Swig. My companian was very amped up about how great it is, but I have to say that I was rather disappointed. The food was decent, but not spectacular. The only thing that really stood out was the naan. Maybe we didn't order the right dishes. I almost gave this place 2 stars because of the atmosphere. It has crummy florescent lighting and just seems dirty. Maybe I'm being a snob, but it would be nice to have water delivered to your table along with the meal, especially if you're eating spicy as hell Indian food. The staff neglected to do this, we had to seek out our own water after eating a few bites. The restroom was absolutely atrocious. The atomsphere is the factor that knocked my review down to 2 stars. Otherwise I would have given it 3.
author: Jenny R.

description: Despite my companions recommendations, I was a little disappointed by the food.  It's a bit greasy, and not the best combination of spices I've had in Indian food.
author: Elaine U.

description: Five stars all around. Mostly because they made us "Roti". The Shalimar on Polk is just as good, but they didn't make me special Roti. The restaurant is packed and crammed, it's not fancy, but the food is amazing. Three of us ate extremely well for 20 bucks. 3 entrees, 2 pieces roti and a mango lassi. Love it. I might make the extra walk to this Shalimar just because they do "Roti".
author: Maren P.

description: I've been to many Indian resturants in the city, and by far this is one of the best! But make sure you arrive early, this place is always packed. I love this place because you can BYOB!
author: timothy h.

description:
best indy in the city
crazy on christmas

the dirty
author: nate l.

description: Food is amazing - try the chicken koftas. Location is sketchy - would not wander there by myself. Place is very basic so dont expect any fancy service and atmosphere - go there for the food!
author: Mitali D.

description:
Their dishes are just wonderful.  If you just compare taste, it beats Nan'n'Curry and Chutney Restaurant in this neighbourhood.  

I love their food.  Great pricing.  And now I have come to think that the curries here taste better than the ones at Shalimar at Polk Street.  It's true.  You should compare the same curries if you doubt it.  

Before I used to give 4 stars but now it's 5 stars...  I got used to the flies around my insanely delicious curries...  Especially their MURGHI KORMA SHAHI (ah I hope I wrote it right...) is one of the curry master piece.  For some reason I don't really like Shalimar's lamb curries.  But their SAAG is also great as well.  

Just to note though, there are dishes which are not the best of course.  Their tandooris are not great and Chutney Restaurant makes them better.  The ones here are kinda dry and especially beef tandoori was just not good.  Also BIRYANI is not their expertise either - also Chutney Restaurant makes it better than here.
author: T T.

description: As i was driving with my friends on a sunday night looking for something to do or eat, my friend. who is pakistani, said we should check out some places that he likes to eat in the tenderloin.  We head there and park.  Although not in the best neighborhood when you walk in its very homey.  Only a handful of tables, the kitchen is right there and you see the food getting made right infront of you.  The menu is like a newspaper and you circle what you want and bring it to the back where the kitchen is and they bring you your drinks and plates.  When the food is served you are served almost family style with diffrent plates with food and everyone shares.  You eat the food all with your hands using the bread named "Naan" which is almost like peta bread only a bit more sour.  The food is awesome and cheap.  Go and eat here you wont regret it.
author: Morgan H.

description:
be prepared.

... for awesome, delicious food... a place with a line out the door in san francisco is bound to be delicious

... to look at a greasy menu and not know half the things that are on there (unless you're an expert) -- be ready to point and hope you got it right!

... for terrible service in a craptastic neighborhood

i'll definitely go back, but i've got to be in the mood... still, the taste is tough to beat!
author: Selina W.

description: Excellent food! Great prices! Not a pretty place (its a dive) but the food is totally worth the walk from Union Sq.
author: Andahs A.

description:
By far the best Indian/Pakistani food in SF. As authentic as it can get, full of spices. 
If you enjoy white washed, white linen type restraunts, this is not the place for you. Indians actually eat here. Sorry Naan N' Curry Fans!
author: Joanna W.

description: This is the best Indian I've had in the city.  Minus a couple of imperfections the food was great.  Best dish: palak paneer.  I tried the kabli channa, daal, paneer masala and palak paneer.  Cons: The texture of the paneer wasn't perfect; it was a little bit tough and tasteless.  One batch of the naan was perfectly flaky and warm but the other was a bit tough and chewy.  I had a great meal overall and will sure be back!
author: Erin F.
