description: Like a fiend who embarks in a hopeless quest to reenact that first, primitive and brutal high on the drug, I have travelled the world in search of the taste of Shalimar. Needless to say, without success.
author: S R.

description:
the food quality is not as good -the Fremont & So Bay location have much better standards.
i wanted to knock this down to 2 stars, but since i have been going here for over 10 years, im sticking to 3 for now. the chicken curry is still very tasty, and the goat special is delish! the tandoori is hit or miss. the biggest disappointment has been the nihari, and not to mention the naan -they are terrible. their nihari was so good back in the day. now its warmed up on a microwave (@Polk) and just to watery. Shalimar is not doing it right anymore. the naan is thick like pizza dough. obviously, they do not let the yeast to rise, otherwise it would be light & fluffy -way it needs to be ALL the time.
we have to many Pakistani food options in the city, or just head down to their Eastbay location.
author: dha A.

description: The treacherous journey walking through Crackhead row from our car to Shalimar was well worth it, don't judge a book by its cover because if you do you probably wont enter this spot. This is another hidden treasure located in the TL. We ordered Garlic Naan, saag chicken curry, saag gosht, and Tandoori chops and let me tell you the food was amazing.
author: Joshua N.

description: Shalimar had some of the best chicken tika i've had in a long time, succulent, jucy, and perfectly cooked. All the dishes we had there were excellent, and they have some adventurous menu items we didn't try like brains masala. These guys do lose a star for the naan bread, it wasn't bad, but it certainly wasn't the heavenly experience that a good naan should be. Cheap, cheerful, a little grubby, and full of people of Indian and Pakistani decent, added up to a very enjoyable and tasty lunch.
author: Karl L.

description: Delicious Pakistani food - great prices! Don't come if you are expecting a clean bathroom and romantic stroll in the neighborhood!
author: Alexis D.

description:
yes there are cockroaches on the wall, but the food is good
the owners are pleasant
have had my order messed up before, but they remembered us and the next time we were there, they hooked us up with extra food and a big discount
chicken tikka masala is a little greasy for my taste, but they have wonderful garlic naan, chana masala, and vegetarian options
author: Deka M.

description:
Aaron V has been telling me about Shalimar for a long time now. When I lived in SJC I did make the trek up to their Fremont location a couple of times for take-out and it was pretty good. Finally on Friday me and a friend hit up the Tenderloin location for some good eats and the inevitably good people-watching that always comes with being in the Tenderloin. They have 2 other locations as well - 1 in SF and 1 in Santa Clara (though their website still claims coming soon eventhough I see it has reviews up already). This one I'd qualify as a pseudo-hole-in-the-wall . . . not super concerned with decor but with cool wall designs and great aromas wafting about.

We had no luck with street parking so decided to fork up $7 to park just across the street. My friend needed cash, so we hit up the ATM that's to the left of Shalimar . . . only to wait we listened to it dial-out once, tell him there was a "dispensing error", then try dialing-out again only to return with the same message. Meanwhile, I enjoyed watching the yocals pacing up and down the street, muttering to themselves or possibly anyone close enough to them that were listening & also happened to be fluent in crazy.

On to the food. It was fantastic. I have to withhold one star because they couldn't keep up with the demand for their chai so everyone had to keep going back up when a fresh pot was put out. This does support the fact that the chai was smooth and delicious. We almost ordered more that could fit on our table: lamb chops which were brilliantly spiced and tender, chicken tikka masala which very good & not  too rich, curried garbanzo beans in an attempt to have something kind of healthy, palak paneer which I love but have to watch out for pieces of some spice seed they don't grind up that I don't really care for, we also ended up with some grilled chicken breasts that I don't recall ordering, and of course some fresh garlic nann. It was definitely too much food so we ended up boxing the leftovers to go. I highly recommend this place to Indian food lovers and will no doubt be returning, next time with more consciousness to how many items to pick off the menu.
author: Todd F.

description: I won't say much about the food as it seems everyone has already done it justice.  The location is in the tenderloin and is a bit sketchy but well worth the risk of possibly being mugged or witnessing a drug deal.  The restaurant itself is definitely nothing fancy.  :D
author: Delilah B.

description: A relatively new outpost of this Pakistani / Indian dive mini-chain.  Somehow it doesn't feel quite as special as the location on Jones but still worth a visit.  Amazing how quickly this place went from brand squeeky new to looking like it's been around a lot longer than it has.  Must be the clouds of smoke and grease.  Outdoor seating just off the sidewalk is nice if sometimes chilly.
author: Gil S.

description: Not quite good enough for 4 stars, but the curries were very, very tasty, just a little too much ghee for my taste.  The chicken tikka masala was swimming in the stuff.  Now, that meant it was crazy buttery delicious, but just sorta disgusting when you looked at it.  Fairly cheap, though, which makes up for a lot.
author: Don H.

description:
Excellent food, thats it nothing else!!  Thats the only reason we go there
since they are open we go other places to have Pakistani food  but no
you cannot get any better then Shalimar
author: Gul M.

description: By far the best Indian food but smacked right in the middle of Tenderloin area. Love the tandoori chicken, saag chicken and their garlic naan are heavenly to name a few. Definitely a cheap eats place.
author: Yan M.

description: For months, I've been asking myself the age old question "Do I stick with Chutneys or try Shalimar."  Tonight, I took the plunge.  The person I was with said "yea it's kinda dirty, but people go here cuz it's cheap."  My meal (chicken tikka masala, rice, aloo nann) was "ok," but nothing fantastic, and the price was $12.  That's a pretty cheap dinner, but across the street, I can use my credit card, it's clean...er, the food is better, and the prices are the same if not cheaper!!!  I won't be going back because Chutneys is right across the street.
author: Jared F.

description: 4 for the food, 5 for the short-order style and the crowded/fun environment.  Anything Saag is great.
author: Josh M.

description: Yummy, yummy chicken tikka masala. Was staying at the Hilton a couple blocks away and went & tried this place. Loved it. Went back two nights later.
author: Matt M.

description: I love Shalimar- so yummy in my tummy! make my nose run with your spices please.....love it- don't go to the rest room here, it's nasty! I have had the privelege of eating in the back room....back room? you say- yes, there is back room......................the back room is for the special people, the regulars, or the ones who speak urdu-
author: Ricquel N.

description: I really like being near restaurants like this. Its not perfect, but when I go here, Fremont or Sunnyvale (with the SF one being the best) I wonder why I don't come more often. I think its because I walk away stuffed every time. Very very good, I don't think it will disappoint.
author: Mick R.

description: So good and so cheap!  My only complaint would be the ventilation. I always leave there with the smell of tandoori in my hair but I bare it because the food is so good. I think i have tried almost everything they have except the brains b/c I just can't go there. The tandoori is always succulent, the naan is nice & fluffy (I prefer the garlic one), but my favorite dish is Mili juli subzi. I love spicy food and that dish takes the cake. They never over do it and I am always left satisfied and a few pounds heavier! I always go with my family and we never spend that much. My toddler niece and nephew like this place so you should too. This is my favorite pakistani place in SF!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Oh Shalimar, how I love you so!

My husband and I regularly sit at a 4-top and fill it with endless plates of yummy and delicious goodness. Their naan is absolutely fabulous, piping hot and the perfect tool for scraping clean the plates.

If you're a fan of lamb, try the nihari. It is to die for. Tender, falling-apart lamb in a complex, smoky and spicy sauce. Pour the sauce over their rice and you are good to go. Their chicken tikka is perfect every time. Their kabob is phenomenal. Oh, I could go on and on and on...

When an ethnic restaurant is filled by its own countrymen, then you know it's good fare. 

I am a die hard Shalimar fan.
author: d b.

description: This is the best Indian/Pakistani spot in the city. The food is just amazing! The flavors are mouth watering and the taste is very authentic. Keep in mind this place is  a hole in the wall, not very nice..but you have to pay the price to eat great food like this. The actual prices are very cheap. Must try!
author: Azizi A.

description: Love it!  They also have a location in Fremont and a new one in Sunnyvale (which is not as good).  Let's give the newcomer some time to settle into the new place.  Although I don't recommend the Byriani (Like Kabab & Curry's), the currys here are yummy.  I recommend the chicken kofta, butter chicken, and lamb curry.   This is by far one of my favorite comfort food places.  They open later than most restaurants in the city which is nice after a night of drinking.  Also, since the currys have time to simmer all day and night, they are even tastier late in the evening.
author: M S.

description: Oh my goodness..it was very yummy all over...it was my second time there and i went my brother, his girl and our friend after a daytime of drinking...very satisfying to the fullest...i just want to take a nice nap now =) this is what makes hole in the wall restaurants the best!
author: Jenny G.

description: Yummy! One of the cheapest and most authentic spots for curry in the city. Definitely a great late night spot.
author: Sara W.

description: I don't get all the good reviews on this place.  My girlfriend said this place was no good and that we should go to Chutney instead but the other couple insisted so we wussed out and went.. what a mistake.  Three of us got sick and it is very smokey.  Make a wise choice and go across the street if you're looking for good Indian food.
author: phil k.

description: I really love this kind of food and picked this place for dinner with my parents due to the high rating.  The reason I give it 5 stars was also the biggest problem for my mom: the food is deliciously spicy!  In particular, I have had masala and tandoori at other restaurants and - although very flavorful - they have never been spicy.  I hope I am able to return the next time I am in the city.
author: Randy S.

description:
Beer from the corner liquor store - Check 
Panhandlers aplenty - Check 
The Best Indian/Pakistani food in the city - Check 
Stuffed to the gills - Check 
$17 bucks per person - unbeatable. 

We had the typical Shalimar experience, no frills fricken awesome food and low dollars. Where else in the city can you get the quality of food for the prices that Shalimar offers. 

We started with the Daal Masala - lentils in masala sauce, tender and perfect for dipping the Garlic and Onion Naan. The other starter was the Palak Paneer, which is cooked spinach with a Tofu like cheese, it is the least appealing looking dish on the menu but somehow it is fantastic. Then we moved onto the rest of the feast. We were adventurous and tried the Goat dish which comes with bones and all. The meat is tender and spices are perfect. I know it sounds gross but the marrow in the bones is fantastic. We also had the Murgh Bot Tandoor - Tender Spicy roasted chicken, the Saag Gosht, which is lamb in curry sauce probably our favorite dish. The Beef Jalfrezi is also very good. 

So be brave and hit the Tenderloin, hold your nose in the bathroom and enjoy some great food at a reasonable price.
author: Brad G.

description: I love Shalimar.  Shalimar offers the best dining experience in the City.  And when I say "dining experience" I mean smoke-filled, loud and festive kind of dinning experience.  It's a help-yourself kinda place; don't expect people to come by to fill your styrofoam cup.  If you're lucky and the front room is too crowded, you may ask to be seated in the backroom.  The "Mafia Room" is part of the San Francisco dinning lore.  The back room is much smaller, quieter, and more quant than the main room; plus, you get served.
author: Rick K.

description: Who knew Pakistani food could be sooo dayam good.  Sketchy interior but the service was pleasant and the BYO with no corkage was right up my alley.  There's something strangely classy about drinking a $25 Merlot from styrofoam cups.
author: Allison K.

description: Love this place.  Great Pakistani food and it's cheap too!  I've been going for the past 7 years and it never disappoints.  If you need to eat in a hurry this is the place to go.
author: Monica H.

description: While there are a lot of Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the Tenderlion, this one is among the best. Great food that is affordable.
author: Devon A.

description: by far the best desi restaurant in california (and i've been to ALOT)... at least food-wise.  the place is a complete hole in the wall, which i guess adds to its charm.  also, its in the tenderloin, so you'll always see a bunch of crackheads walking around.  but seriously, the food is amazing. CTM, sikh kebab, chicken jalfrezi, everythinng is amazing.  and don't forget the chai after your meal (its free!)
author: Aasim J.

description: The food here is good, and the tandoori chicken especially is moist and delicious. But beyond this, the atmosphere is usually very smoky with no ventilation, and the service is relatively slow and not very friendly, even on slow days with not a lot of customers...go for the food, but I recommend to go.
author: Heleena H.

description: My Indian ex-boss brought us all here.  Dude is a tech Daddy Warbucks but he insists this is the best place for simple Indian food.  The tandoori chicken is so juicy and flavorful
author: Kevin S.

description: As excellent value as my fave, Naan n curry, though rather more spacious so you don't feel like you are actually sitting in the kitchen with the cooks. Saag paneer was great, nice and fresh and not gloopy. Naan were as excellent as everyone reports. But the chicken Jalfrezi was so-so, far from the best I have ever had, and the daal, well maybe I am just not a big daal fan.  Will definitely be back to try the rest of the menu and hopefully bump it up another star.
author: Stuart J.

description: I finally got to try the famous Shalimar of the tenderloin...it's better than the Polk street one and is always bustling.  The naan was oh so good and made to perfection.  No fuss dining that will leave you satisfied.
author: Debbie Y.

description: The naan is great here.  There are so many places to get Indian food in this vicinity.  It isn't the best but it isn't the worst either.
author: Tracy A.

description: Great for groups - there's a hidden room in the back. The meat dishes here are tasty and juicy. The naan is a bit to soggy for me.
author: Judy L.

description: A Pakistani cab driver once told me, 'it is the best.'  I have found it to be hit or miss.  But the Naan is amazing.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Agree with T-Bone - hit or miss but the naan is always good. Get something simple. It is telling I don't know any Indian people who actually like this place.
author: patrick g.

description: This place should be good. If Lahore Karahi didn't exist, it would probably merit another star. The food is good, and fairly priced. It's just not perfection.
author: Dana L.

description: Hmmm...I don't know about spectacular, but the lamb chops were very tasty. The garlic naan was okay. And the service is weird: there's a waiter (who I swear said "yes" if they take plastic, only to find it's cashola only), but you have to order at the counter. The cleanliness is a bit suspect as well.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Seriously, not the cleanest place in the world...honestly, seems very sketchy...but the food is AWESOME. If you like Indian food then you will LOVE this place. You must try it. It's def. worth it. It's cheap and yummy. Such a good combo! =)
author: danae k.

description: There's a lot of good Pakistani/Indian food in town, but this place gets a nod from me for being delicious (most dishes) and stocked with cute 'loin boys. It's no frills good eats.
author: Colleen B.

description: The food has been okay both times I've been to Shalimar.  I've sat in the back room and last time I was there, was pretty disgusted by the filth in the restaurant and the bathroom.  Since I've found cheap Indian I like more (Pakwan), I have no plans to go back.
author: Susannah R.

description: 4-stars for the food, 0-stars for the atmosphere, service, or the bathrooms! But the food is terrific if you know what you are ordering, and the prices are cheap, cheap, cheap! Very authentic too (according to my Indian colleagues).
author: Mi M.

description: Great mango lassis and all the food I've had here was totally awesome. There is a lot to choose from on the menu so it's best to visit this place with a group of people so you can try a lot more. This place is almost always packed so you most likely will have to wait around till someone leaves in order to grab a table. It's worth the wait for sure. The food, the people, and the prices are outstanding!! When eating here I feel like I'm in an extended dinning room, it's a very family style restaurant. Yes, the place could be 100 times cleaner but that won't stop me from coming here and enjoying their delicious offerings.
author: Ericka A.

description: The first time I went there, after walking through the Tenderloin, there was a haze of kitchen smoke inside, some lights were flickering, and the menus were printed on cheap newsprint. In other words, this is not a fancy restaurant. But for those of us who don't mind a no-frills experience, the cheap prices, the tasty food (if a bit too much ghee), and the wonderful naan make it well worth it.
author: John C.

description: The one, the only, the original of all Shalimars.  This is a true hole in the wall that I keep going back to.  The secret room in the back is also an experience if you can secure it.  Their expertise is good Pakistani food.  There is no customer service hotline.  Don't look at the floors of the kitchen...simply order from their menu and try and find a seat in this usually crowded place.  Their chicken & beef dishes are really good.  Good naan.  I'll pass on their nehari.  Be advised that this restaurant is not in the best part of town...but then which good hole in the wall would be?
author: Atif Q.

description:
shalimar is BOMB.
i work on union square and it is just a hop skip and a jump away. the food is amazing and extremely cheap. i do not mind the sticky atmosphere or their cash only policy!  my coworkers and i grub the chicken tikki marsala, mili juli sabzi, and garlic naan. we are all about the garlic naan!!! if you are fretting the tenderloin, i suggest their polk street location (it is little bit nicer, and when i say 'little bit', i mean just that).
author: Maureen P.

description: Open late... quick and friendly service.. Warm and toasty naan... I had some ground chicken dish (aloo ?) with ginger and other herbs, and it had wonderful, sumptuous flavors. I liked the food at this location better than the one in the Tenderloin, but perhaps I just ordered the wrong thing there. I would definitely come to this one again. Only suggestion is that they paint the walls a more vibrant color (red? orange? mahogany?)
author: O K.

description: i prefer the shalimar on jones.  had the lamb here and it was overcooked.  still a good option for indian on polk.
author: Helen T.

description: I ate here awhile ago and it is really tasty. However, I think they do the simpler Indian dishes the best (like the saag paneer or the tikka masala), while the more pakistani type dishes, like the karahi, do not stand out as much. But their naan is good and their tandoori is tasty. If you have issues with cleanliness then you probably do not want to eat here, but otherwise it is really casual and great for groups.
author: Gina R.

description:
I actually joined Yelp just to voice my adoration of Shalimar...

I am in love. 

It is the most incredible food, at the most incredible prices. You will be hard pressed to find better. 

To address the negative reviews: it is true what they say, it is not the cleanest, prettiest or most romantic spot ever (although I have never seen roaches or had GI issues, and I get takeout there at least twice a week). If you want ambiance, head to Dosa on Fillmore, although the food pales in comparison (but is still quite good) and you'll spend 5x as much if you're lucky. And if you're deterred by the neighborhood, you need to get out more. No, I probably wouldn't come here for an anniversary, romantic dinner or other special occasion, but for an average evening, it's no big deal. Get over it, Tenderloin happens. 

But if not, grab a friend or two, a 6-pack from the corner store, and have some of the most amazing food this foodie has had in this foodie city. 

Clap clap Shalimar, keep it up.
author: kristen s.

description: Great restaurant. Be sure to bring a group of friends and share items. I would not recommend this to people who don't like hole in the wall places. It is BYOB, so if you want to drink then bring your own.
author: Raymond M.

description: Love the food.  Everything was nice & spicy but, not to the point where I couldn't breathe.  My friends and I went last Friday.  Nice and close to Union Square (if you like to walk).  Food was fast and sooooooooooooooooo good.  We had lamb, chicken, beef and garlic naan.  All very enjoyable.  Savory, saucy, and deeeeeeeeeeeeelish!  A must for all Indian food lovers.  But be warned, this place isn't very fancy and if you sit by the window, try not to smile at any of the people standing outside (even if you are a genuinely nice person) because you are in the T-loin.  Strangers might get the wrong idea and stare at you while you sit there with your friends.   And your clothes will probably smell but, it's totally worth it.  The prices are very affordable, too.
author: Christie X.

description: I was recommended to try this restaurant by some Indian friends who rave that their food is as authetic as you can find in the States. They use REAL spices and the degree of spiciness is perfect. I recommend the chicken tikka masala and other popular dishes. This is the place to go to get the BEST Indian food in SF! Their budget prices are only icing on the cake.
author: Helen L.

description: There are lots of things I don't like about Shalimar.  The cashier is surly, the place isn't good for eat-in (noisy, crowded, bad lighting), they only do cash, the prices are okay.  But the food, the food is damn good, and it deserves five stars.  Authenticity is hard to beat.  Good spicing, good selection, good stuff.  Visit their website for a full menu.
author: Green T.

description:
Shalimar, my Indian friends tell me you are the best Indian food, but I'd have to disagree.  Don't get me wrong, you're pretty good, but your quality can vary (avoid the Lamb!).

You're very charming.  Some people don't appreciate the crack-whore and baseball bat wielding thugs (saw four of them on one night) and let me not forget the availability of crack in the neighborhood.   But don't let that scare you off, there is a cheap (~$5 garage right across the street).  Also, there is bodega on the corner that will supply you with cheap alcohol and they carry a quite varied inventory of malt-liquor.
author: JH K.

description: Good, not great.  the meats are what you come here for.  Try going across the street to Lahore Karahi.
author: Rohit G.

description: One of my all time favorite restaurants. It's earned the nickname "Stinky's" amongst my friends because you walk out smelling a bit like BBQ. Delicious food, cheap and casual!
author: Amanda B.

description: BYOB, and the most amazing flavors i have ever had. Even in 2 years living in London I did not find such tasty Indian comestibles. Superb. And so convenient - right off the 38 Scary line...
author: Juan C.

description: Hands down the best Indian/Pakistani food in the City, maybe Bay Area. Hands down dumpiest place. Rocking place, noisy, lots of yelling and scolding, good luck finding a readable menu, and no, this isn't a neighborhood you'll want to linger around. But wait until the ultra cheap and exquisite food comes out: puffy, toothsome Naan, the chickpeas, samosas, the tikka masala, tandoori meats. I've been here a few times now when I have managed to snag a parking space on Jones (not a small feat) and have never been disappointed. Flavors are intense as this is not a place for bland, warmed-over buffet crap; you're getting food literally cooked to order. I could also swear that the spice quotient is hiked up just a little. Did I say how cheap this place was? Also, don't be offended if you don't get perky service when you walk in and order at the counter.
author: Alfonso L.

description: Yummers... I love the naan. Great food.
author: Joy C.

description:
typically i enjoy this place, but last night was shockingly disappointing.  

when we showed up i wasn't that hungry.  by the time we got our food i was famished.  we didn't order anything too complicated and it was only really two dishes and some naan and rice.  

come on people!!  let's get with the program.  

i could understand that they were busy, but a lot of people who ordered after us were served their food before us.  that just doesn't seem right.  it seemed like our food took forever.  i would have thought that by the time the food came i would eat anything and love it.  i did eat it, but i didn't love it.  it wasn't up to its usuall goodness.  it was super oily and the vegetable korma was just weird.   i really wanted to give it one or two stars, but that would only be based on this one experience.  so for now it has 3.  maybe after a few more decent trips to shalimar it'll get a boost.  we'll see...
author: jen b.

description: Probably the most authentic Pakistani food in town.
author: Chaz N.

description: No chicken vindaloo, no good.  The food's actually pretty good, but I need chicken vindaloo on the menu.
author: Tinou B.

description: Wow, the food was really good! Tucked away in the TL amidst liquor stores and massage parlors, you may feel a little apprehension, but if you're brave enough to venture over here, you won't be sorry! We ordered the chicken tikka masala, beef kabobs, basmati rice, naan , and garlic naan. The bill came out under $20 (without tip) for two people--not bad! The service was meh (fast, but not friendly at all), but really, that's not what I'm looking for when I come to a place like this. This place was crowded on a weeknight, so that's a pretty good indication it's good food. I'll definitely be coming here again!
author: J. L.

description: indeed it is NOT the most sanitary place but it is the best tasting indian food i have yet! i have tried chutneys, um those two on eddy...and a lot more but its pretty yummy!!
author: H H.

description: Best Indian food in SF. I'd give it 5 stars if it were a little cleaner and more polished. The food is sensational. Never had a dish I didn't like. They let you bring in your own drinks and don't charge you. Their prices are very fair. The Naan is always fresh, so is the rice. These guys blow away those "Naan n' Curry" buffet places closer to Union Square. I'm a fan.
author: Greg B.

description: Two words: chicken kofta. These meatballs blow my mind. Love the atmosphere of the place, and even the confusion of how to order has its charm.
author: Calvin L.

description: Pretty good Indian food, cheap, nice people, fast, byob, outside seating is great and low key.  Not a date place, but good for a couple of buddies who care about the food.
author: Eric W.

description: Hands down the best North Indian/Pakistani food I have ever had, anywhere. It's so delicious! The neighborhood leaves something to be desired, the ambiance is, well, authentic and down to earth, and the service is, umm, not there. But, the food, yes! No better Pakistani food has entered my mouth. Better, in my opinion, than Naan and Curry, also this location is much better than the one on Polk St.
author: Eater S.

description: This is one of the best Indian/Pakistani restaurants in the city. However, having said that, it's also has the worst service I've ever seen. If I didn't know better, I would think that they did it on purpose. Avoided this place for years, but I can't beat the taste. So every once in a while, when I'm feeling indiscriminate, I will stop by here.
author: Adrian J.

description: I am still waiting for the perfect Indian meal.  I still have not yet found it.  Shalimar was very tasty though.  There is nothing fancy about the place but I will be back due to the convenience and the price.
author: Rise G.

description: This is by far my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco. I was tempted to detract a star due to the seedy neighborhood I have to endure to eat here, but the food is so amazingly delicious I will leave them with 5 stars.  Their assortment of chicken and lamb curries are all amazing, and they make some of the best vegetable dishes I have ever had at an Indian restaurant--- my particular favorites being the Okrah and Mixed Vegetable.  Just writing this review is making me hungry..... mmmmm
author: James M.

description: Absolutely amazing indian food at a great price. COME! The atmosphere is so downscale it becomes great in a reverse psychology way.
author: Gregorio A.

description: the food is too greasy, and the restaurant is gross combined with crackheaded (outside).  go to pakwan (in the mission).
author: eshwar k.

description: wow this place is not in the greatest location but it very authentic food an me an my wife love it here so if ur in the tenderloins then this is a place to go to get some indian food
author: DRASTIK P.

description:
SHALIMAR SHALIMAR!

This is most def my favorite restraunt. It's a hole in the wall, its not the cleanest spot, it's in the TL so of course there's crackheads and prostitutes, BUT I can care less. I eat at Shalimar probably once a week if i can. Its the best Pakastani food i've had. I always get the chicken boti (tandoori chicken), chicken kofta curry, spinach and potatoe, rice, and naan and siekh kabab. And i love it. my mouth waters thinking about the aromas and flavor you get from this food. 
If you cant stand the area then get over it. Shalimar beats any indian/pakastani restraunt ever.
everyone should try it!
author: yasmeen b.

description: very low class service and stinky ppl work there.sorry but you are presenting your country really bad and you should be ashamed of that.well you are from third world country but now you are in America so pls respect America cause you are charging ppl American dollar's.when I was there I almost asked a crackhead  for order.
author: Ordinary G.

description: Dirty place, ok food. That's all that's needed to know about this place.
author: Sajjad S.

description: Best Indian food in town if you don't want to spend a ton of money.
author: Paul H.

description: Food is good.  Menus are cool on that newspaper stuff.  Great hole in the wall feel.  But I always seem to be burping for four hours after I eat it.  Nevertheless, some solid Indian food.
author: Mr. G.

description:
I've never been to a hole in the wall in Pakistan, but I imagine that this place is a passable imitation. The restaurant is located in a greasy crucible of curry, sweat, and roasting meat. Inside are the hungry, teaming hoardes and a few yuppies -- this is after all, San Francisco.  The food is good although more than a little salty and greasy. Good naan and rice, generous portions of aromatic brown slop. I don't know what the Health Department score for this place is and I'm afraid to find out.

Go there and savor the third world experience.
author: Peter B.

description: I live walking distance from Shalimar and before trying the food, I would look at the place and think "no way". When my friend suggested we go there I was hesitant, but he suggested to look beyond that; and sure enough the food here is fabulous!! All my out of town guests get to come here because the food is SO good. My suggestion is to look beyond the apearance because it is really good food.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
3.5 stars

A couple nights ago my friend Matt and his wife Karla took me out for some delicious Indian and Pakistani cuisine on Indian row in the 'loin. I had heard high praise for Shalimar, as well as some cautionary tales (greasy, do not use the bathrooms, etc). It is definitely a no frills greasy spoon without any pretensions; I found the place to be clean, if sparsely and simply decorated. But it's not about the ambience, or for that matter the service here (we were given dishes we did not order twice, you need to pay attention and be vigilant as the plates start arriving!) It's about greedily eating some of the most authentic, perfectly seasoned Indian and Pakistani food around. Each place setting is provided with a 'Shalimar Times,' basically a four page tabloid printout explaining what Shalimar is about, with a menu on the inside. An excerpt states, "SHALIMAR'S CULINARY PHILOSOPHY: 'No substituions to fit the local tastes, no frills or nuevo cuisine, but sensible, genuine, tasty hearty and wholesome food.' In each guest we look forward to 'many happy returns.' " The interesting word usage and liberal smattering of quote marks makes for entertaining pre-meal reading.

On to the food. We ordered 3 types of flavored naan (onion, garlic, and spicy potato). All were flavorful and properly moist and chewy. Okra and tomatoes was delicious - rich and velvety fresh okra, piquant from the simmered tomatoes, and very savory and authentic from a liberal use of hing. Pureed eggplant (bengen bhujia) was tasty, with a good amount of onion and a strong cardamom seasoning which was the dominant flavor of this dish. Even better was the tandoori chicken (murgh boti tandoori), crisp and well seasoned with spices and vinegar. The standout dish, however, was saag gosht - a combination of tender braised lamb and spinach, with ginger, coriander, and a more mild blend of spices.

No wine to wash this food down. It's a BYOB and I was caught unprepared, no riesling on me and neighborhood shops are fine for tall boys of beer but that's about it. So it was all washed down with a Bass ale. Which was fine, even Riesling would have a tough time handling much of this food. I wholeheartedly reccommend Shalimar for folks who can deal with a slightly sketchy neighborhood, poor service and a slightly louder than usual blend of hip-hop and Bhangra. At Shalimar, it's all about the food.
author: joe m.

description: So after eating expensive meals over and over, I start to crave good cheap food.  Well, this place has it. My wife and I took a bus from the Marina all the way to Union Square, had dinner, and returned home for $19.50.  We were so psyched that we could do it all for under twenty bucks that we've added this to our list of places to frequent.  Keep in mind that this place is on the outskirts of the Tenderloin, so I wouldn't suggest it for someone that can't handle a brush with panhandlers.
author: Will H.

description: Orgasmically good Indian! This is THE kind of hole-in-the-wall place that you hope to find in any city. Cheap and simple, and so awesomely spicy that it's sure to give you an endorphin rush. Do brace yourself for the actual restaurant - though it's not unsanitary, it's pretty dirty. The walls have random pictures and cracks, there is cardboard in the window [what's weird is that it's neither a sign nor a cover for a hole, it's just there], the menus are greasy, and occasionally unpleasant SF characters wander in but in a way it's all part of the hole-in-the-wall aesthetic.
author: lizok

description:
i'll agree.  it probably is the best indian/pakistani place in the city, and i know a few indian/pakistani people who can vouch for that too.  everything here is drenched in spice, and woe be to the people who (like me) have the condition where things are as spicy going out as they were going in.

tikka masala 4tw
author: Jon Y.

description: Been coming here for years. I have to come here at least once a week for my Indian weekly fix since I live in the city now. The food is great. The first time I came here, I did not think too highly of the place until I tasted the food and been hooked ever since.
author: Mohammad M.

description: As if I needed a reason to visit the Tenderloin!!?!  This was the first place I had Indian food and as with all "firsts", nothing else can quite live up to it.  Their chana masala is spicy, chicken saag is savory, and the naan makes me so very, very happy.
author: P-Rock F.

description: Can't beat them.. Thats all I have to say. Number #1 in the bay area
author: shoel s.

description: So a couple of us asked co-worker Shekar to guide us to a good Indian restaurant- he takes us to the Tandoriloin district and to Shalimar. If he says it's a good as S.F. Indian gets, it's as good as S.F. Indian gets.  It is great.
author: William G.

description: It was okay Chicken Tikka Masala.  Spicier than I expected, messy container. Good naan. I'll go back.
author: Heidi P.

description: This is supremely good Pakistani / Indian food in one of the dumpiest joints on earth. Their curries are spicy and flavorful, but the food from the tandoor is the real secret. Maybe it's never been cleaned and that adds flavor... Who knows, but it's good. Just don't take a clean freak there.
author: Randall K.

description: Pretty dirty. Food very oily and nothing special. Mango Lassi way too sweet. Mutter paneer was a sea of oil with a few peas. There are so many better places around. The garlic naan was very weird. Felt more like a pizza that was not fully done. And almost no flavor.
author: life l.

description: Tikki was TOUGH.  Must've been an off night.  Cheap eats in the tenderloin.  Would have given them another star except for the WORSE bathroom I've ever seen.  Yikes.  I can't imagine the cooks leaving the restroom and saying oh yeah, I'd better go back and wash my hands.  I imagine them saying I'd rather plunge my hands in the vat of boiling ghee rather than endure that experience again.  Dudes, cooking is hard.  Cleaning bathrooms is not.  Hire a swamper wandering the streets for Gods sake.  For $5.00 and all the naan he/she could eat you'd get a 3 star rating.
author: Ken D.

description: Treat for those who love authentic indian food. Close to Dhaba's in India interms of food and ambience.
author: Hash K.

description:
Update ! Shalimar awarded the coveted SIXTH STAR !!
Officially the standard by which all other sources of sustenance are judged !

When you come in, don't sit down.
You go up to the counter and order first.
If you come in and sit at a table and wait for service, you'll be waiting a really long time (and people will laugh at you).
Let me interrupt this diatribe to mention that the food absolutely rocks at Shalimar - sure, the place has it's drawbacks, the toothless woman sitting on the sidewalk outside, the dirty silverware, the pools of oil on top of some of the dishes, etc. But if you can get past the sheer grossness of the place, you're in for a treat. Some hints: Murgh Boti Tandoori (chunks of white meat chicken flash-cooked in the Mesquite Tandoor - top pick. Chicken Tikka Masala - if your heart can handle the cholesterol of the heavy cream that's used in it (check out the refrigerator shelves crammed with the stuff), it doesn't get any better than this. The Lamb Boti (Tandoori Lamb Chops) is supposed to be awesome as well, but I don't eat mammals. Don't miss out on the mint sauce (remember to wipe off the tip of the container before squirting the stuff directly into your mouth), the traditional rice, or any of the Naan. Another fun tip is to take a pool with your companions on what the tab is going to be - you can order the exact same dishes on every visit, and your check will always be different. I could go on and on, but the bottom line on Shalimar is that it can be a life changing experience if you give it a chance.
author: Fattfreddie F.

description: As far as authenticity - this is the real deal.  Location is Tenderloin and restaurant reflects that.  Maybe best to take out.  Daal and a naan are great.  Tikka mssala and paag paneer were perfect.  Go for the food but don't hang around too long.
author: Josh W.

description: Great indian food.  I've tried a bunch in the area and don't waste your time and money anywhere else.  Shalimar rocks.
author: Drew I.

description: Shalimar is too legit to quit! Cheap,  SPICY (mmmm), BYOB. What more could you ask for. Definitely on the greasy side, which makes it extra delicious. Great place to go with friends, grab some wine and beer from the liquor store next door. If you're going for good service, dont. But if you're going for the best Indian food ever, definitely do. Beware--cash only!
author: Vanessa J.

description: This place is awesome.  You can't go wrong!  Yesterday, I had the Chicken Kabob and Chickent Tikka Masala, with Naan and Rice.  I thoroughly enjoyed the aroma of the charred tandori oven as well as the blends of spicies in the kabob and curry.  The Naan is perfect for complimenting the richness and flavors.  This place is, as you say, "Off the hook!!!!"  Can't wait to be back!
author: ron c.

description:
ahhhhhhh, 10 more for the big #800!!!

***

not bad not bad ..... ordered a variety from one of each...

i'm definitely a huge fan for hole in the walls, and this place, is prolly one notch above a hole in the wall... and you may very well so agree that you can't get better food than this...

i was pleasantly surprised on how delish this place was ...

first of all, the menu! super creative. it comes in a newspaper form with plenty to offer.

a major perk: SUPER CHEAP! i dont think i spent anything over $10/dish. curries go from $7 and their veggies were $6 and up.

pix uploaded

now, you MUST try the MURGH BOTI TANDOORI. it IS THEE QUEEN OF TANDOOR... the boneless chicken breast that marinates in a blend of vinegar and spices, gently skewered over charcoal ..... talk about the TENDERNESS... YUM! =P

the BHUNA GOSHT which is a curry was like no other. def had this spicy thing going on. one thing for sure, im def not the typical korean who sweats when they eat spicy food, but i was literally sweating... shalimar, you got me GOOD.. make sure to get it with a $1 naan... or you can order with rice, which we got...  they have 4 diff types of naan bread and yes, it was worth it!

the veggies were quite an interesting twist. the PALAK ALOO METHI stir fried with perfection. the menu advertises it "seductively tantalizing" lol... well, not THAT seductive. HAHAHA.

anyhow, the guys were super friendly and easy to please...

shalimar is the only restaurant in the bay area, i swear, that specializes in AUTHENTIC indian & pakistani food!!! the tandoori dishes were cooked fresh in a traditional clay oven, and their famous curries, i swear, it was a wondrous adventure taking your mouth on these excotic journey of spices, veggies, naan and more... 

im coming back, back, back!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Excellent value for money.  The aroma of naans envelopes you immediately when walking in the door.   Take-out is convenient and well augmented with paper plates, plastic silverware. This is a real eating place with no pretense and simply great food.
author: Marco P.

description: Not exactly the fanciest interior but certainly authentic Pakistani. My favorite of all time. This is as good as it gets to the real stuff from Pakistan. Definitely try their spice chicken and saag chicken topped off with their naan. Though the guy look like the soup Nazi from Seinfeld, he's actually a nice guy, i think.
author: benjamin c.

description:
I've been to the Jones St. Shalimar in SF and the one in Fremont 4-5 times each, and was elated when they *finally* opened one in Sunnyvale!!  However, it was the absolute worst Indian restaurant experience I've ever had...Shalimar, how could you!!?  Imagine the usual Shalimar decor complaints (which are usually strangely endearing to me...) times 10!!, coupled with the worst Chicken Tikka Masala ever produced...ratty meat, tons of bones....arghh...

Well, today I made the walk down Crack Addict Row on Jones St. and restored my faith in Shalimar with some Dal Masala (1st time...I had no idea that boring yellow lentils could be *so* good) and Chicken Tikka Masala so good I almost cried...no bones, no fat, no grisly dark meet, just good white meat...mouth burning...flavors exploding...ahhhh.

Shalimar SF, please go down to your wayward child in Sunnyvale and whip that disgrace into shape...
author: Daniel F.

description:
mmmmmmmmm.... u gotta try this place.  this little restaurant attracts people from all over the neighborhood during lunch, and now i know why!

it's a bit of a hole-in-the-wall, but that only attracts me more!  we were kinda confused when we first walked in.  the tables were awkwardly located.  you order at the counter toward the rear of the restaurant.  when the food is ready, they put it on the counter and a waiter will bring it to you.  you may pay at the counter after you have feasted.

the food here is a far cry from the monstrosities they serve at Chutney (for which i opine in http://www.yelp.com/biz/chutney-san-francisco#hrid:6T5gU4NDcnOTVS52-HwrKA) across the street.  the curry is denser and they put generous amounts of meat in the orders.  their naan is thicker and they serve this orange rice i've never had before.  absolutely deeeelish!!  and can't forget the mango lassi's - - 2 bucks for a sinfully sweet, thick, mangoey experience?  you just can't beat that!

this is my go-to place for indian in the tenderloin for sure!  lahore, i must admit, was pretty good.... but my experience there was... umm.... (http://www.yelp.com/biz/lahore-karahi-san-francisco#hrid:IB8IKncmbgtKSJpQ71nsAA)

oh!  the menus were really cute!!!  not to mention the low low prices on them!

to sum up, if its good and cheap, it will keep me coming back.  shalimar is good and cheap.  therefore, i'll be back.  Recommended!!!
author: Christina L.

description: This place is the bomb! Delicious, homey and oil heavy, heart dishes make me wanna cum! the counter staff is courteous and supah friendly. the chicken korma is amazing, tender pieces of dark meat on the bone with delicious gravy.
author: Jodi B.

description:
Going to shalimar has become a tradition for my family. I can't go a week without the Tikka Massala and Palak Paneer. Affordable and delicious food makes it even better! It's the best indian and pakistani food in the city! You can't go wrong with Shalimar. 

I suggest going to the Polk resturant if you want to avoid the "streets" of the Tenderloin. Food is generally the same and still has the shalimar atmosphere! 5 stars!
author: Nathan M.

description: Cheap and reasonable.   I've been going here for years.  On a flight back from Seoul 3 years ago, I overheard a fellow traveller, recommend this place to his seat mate.  He raved about it, quite excitedly to his poor seatmate.   I laughed, smiled and agreed with him, and daydreamed about my next visit there.   The one on Jones is the best.  The one on Polk is ok.
author: Steve Y.

description:
Food - same as Pakwan and but better than Chutney
Service - good
author: Phi N.

description:
Keep in mind this place is cash only...  A couple of years ago, my friend and I were $1 short and had to go out on the street and ask people for change (very embarassing), but now I come prepared.

Good food, good prices, but you leave smelling like the restaurant.  Don't be surprised if there are a few flies joining you for your meal.
author: Sarah K.

description: damn, that was some good-ass food. we ordered some kind of baked chicken, chicken tikka masala(mmmm), garlic naan, and rice. they were all awesome. the garlic naan had full chunks of garlic in it, which i loved. the portions were very generous(i was STUFFED) and the price was very cheap. apparently you can also bring your own booze here. i loved the menu too, it looked like a newspaper. minus 1 star for the ghetto location and the rude server. i orderd a mango lassi and instead of handing it to me, he went out of his way to place it across the table. i was told he's always like that...next time i'll take it to go
author: Andrew T.

description: love it, been going for years, inexpensive good food.
author: Dyl H.

description: good and cheap. will return. best indian food in my neighbourhood. it kicks naan & curry's ass so hard!
author: James J.

description: I can't tell you how amazing this little whole in the wall restaurant is.  After trekking through the Tenderloin w/ my roomie and cousin (short 10 min walk since we live in Nob Hill), we walk in and are definitely not impressed with the decor/atmosphere, but it smelled fabulous, the place was hopping w/ people, and the food looked great! You walk up to the counter to order and I was very disappointed to learn they don't serve Vindaloo curry and that Vindaloo's not even a traditional Indian dish.  I ended up going with Tikka Masala (indian HOT) and it was wonderful. SO SPICY, just how I like it.  They even brought me out a medium dish b/c they didn't think I could handle, but I could :) It's also BYO, so we brought our own bottle of wine (WITH NO CORKAGE FEE).  They only have paper cups, so it looked a little ghetto, but whatever.  We ended up getting out of there for $30 (including tip) for 3 people. Talk about my new favorite Indian place in the city!!!
author: Jenny W.

description: Their chicken tikka masala and garlic naan are quite tasty.  So far that's all I've eaten there.
author: Xander H.

description: my husband & i LOVE shalimar!  authentic, affordable & the best tasting chicken curry, chicken tikka masala, rice, naan for two for under 20 bucks!!  and we feel like stuff pigs afterward every time we go there!  the place is definitely a hole in the wall, but it's the food that counts i tell ya!  long lines on the weekend, but it's press your luck each time though, sometimes you get seats quickly sometimes you have to wait for 20 minutes.  but it's so worth the wait, because when you get the food in your stomach, it'll thank you very much!!  can't wait until the next time we go back to shalimar, i am salivating just thinking about it!!
author: Teresa C.

description: There has to be something fairly exceptional waiting for me if I'm going to wade through the dregs of the Tenderloin in quest of a meal, and this place usually delivers the goods. The naan alone is worth zigzagging past winos and dodging drug dealers . . . it's impeccable, with a light crisp bottom, big, soft bubbles on top, and not the slightest bit doughy. Ordering - which is done at the counter - can be a challenge, and you might be stranded there watching the counterman chop massive piles of chicken if you don't assert yourself and shout out your order. It helps to know what the different dishes are in advance. Palak paneer had a clean, spinach taste and tender chunks of cheese. Chicken tikka masala was nice, but lacked character; chicken saag had more kick and was a better choice. The lamb chops, unfortunately, were cooked almost past medium-well, and were dry as a result, but the aromatic rice was flavorful enough to make amends. Portions are large and prices are reasonable. The place is overlit and overloud, but mixed with the smell of grilled meat was a mild scent of disinfectant, which I oddly found reassuring.
author: Gourmet G.

description: GREASY  FOOD ;dirty place full of roaches ;that was my last vist ; i tried new tikka masala@ellis and jones one block down exellent food very clean best PRATHAS  i ever had. AND 5STARSFOR VERY cleanrestrooms  comparing to most of them.
author: ASH Q.

description: the best indian and pakistani food in the city. i honestly love the decor, atmosphere. bring a 40oz, enjoy your meal.
author: vincent m.

description: mmmm super tastey. best garlic naan I've ever had. masala was super oily but great tasting. you know you came to the right authenic place when you're the only non pakistani or indian in the joint. yes I did get the shits right after I ate but that's what the bathroom is for. love this place.
author: Dave R.

description: Have been a fan for years. We did take out last night along with some friends - had tandoori chicken, naan, palak paneer and chicken tikka masala. The palak paneer was ok with feew pieces of paneer but the other dishes were excellent. The place itself is a hole in the wall and there is no customer service but the food more than makes up for it. Love coming here.
author: P From CA C.

description: Food seriously tiny pieces of meat drowning in sauces.  Kebab-lamb, chicken, beef...terribly dry.  For those that manage to get past the homelessness of the area, there is no respite.  Disappointingly not homey or fresh tasting.  As to ambience...please:  a hybrid cheap asian restaurant -sticky table, fluorescent light...dirty vibes.  Their fremont sista does a better job fulfilling their company's fresh homemade meal vision and mission statement.
author: Quynh P.

description: While I'll admit the food was decent, it could not overcome the other issues I had with the place, and wasn't any better than the run of the mill places in the city.  First, the bathroom might have been the worst I've ever had to use in the U.S. and worse than 98% of the restrooms I used when I went to India.  (I'm talking about the bathroom outside to the left.)  I don't think the bathroom has ever been cleaned and looks like people have just peed all over the walls for the past 20 years without anyone doing anything about it.  Second, on the way back into the restaurant after the bathroom experience, I saw large buckets of chicken and meat sitting outside in the alley.  That's right, buckets of raw meat, hanging outside not on ice or anything, probably about to go into the kitchen and onto diners' plates.  To be fair, I have no proof of what actually happened with that meat, but I'm just saying... kind of gross.
author: Rebecca S.

description: like others reviewed, HOLE IN THE WALL!  but this place has rreally GOOD food and was packed with asians.  :O  no service other than bring you your plates and food.  self service and smells of BBQ.
author: Pickle R.

description: Consistently great food, cheap prices, however no decor, no service, a little dirty at times AND DO NOT USE THEIR BATHROOM, you might catch a disease . . . . .
author: M Y.

description: how could you not luv a place that zagats gives a 23 for food, and a 3 for ambiance?  with techno southern asian vibes resonating through the smoke filled room?  with the self serve chai and the brusk proprietor taking your order at the counter?  i feel at home when im at shalimar, and the bonus thing is that shalimar kinda goes home with you as well, and to bed with you..... and to work with you the next day......
author: Curtis Y.

description: You know this is a good Indian/Pakistani restaurant when you see the cab drivers double parked getting their dinner. The okra is the bomb.
author: Lucie F.

description: My faves are always the hole in the wall joints.  From Manhattan to San Francisco, London, Paris etc.  Yea you can go for ambiance and high prices but a whole in the wall with it's own ambiance and good food is the best.
author: Misti L.

description: In the one block walk it took to get here, I made about 30 minutes worth of gnarly stories. I love the TL. No, really love this place. I'm gonna have shirts made up. If anyone has a room in the TL for rent, hit me up. I wanna be closer to this place. I'm super upset my friend is moving out. Which brings me to my story. We were hanging out here, having a house cooling party, and I got a powerful hunger. I had read "The Namesake" that day (super easy but engrossing read), and was feeling Indian subcontinental. So I asked for some decent Indian food close by. Shalimar was thrown out, mostly cause it was close. And good. So I trekked the one whole block. Crazies leaping out of trees, over exposed breasts heading to the Ambassador, the whole nine yards. Of course, Shalimar was just as hectic indoors as it was outdoors. And cash only. And kinda took a second to figure out. And then find a menu. And I for sure wanted take out. I don't think I would ever eat sitting at a table. But maybe drunk. Cause curries and beers is like cigarettes and coffee. Anyway, the food was delish, even eating off a laptop desk in a tiny Tenderloin studio.
author: Matt L.

description: i still think this place is good, you elitist swine! yeah, lahore is better. this place has excellent things to offer though. the dal is a major contender, and the spices they use on the tandoori and the nihari (When i ate meat) will do you freakin' right, i assure you. gets kinda pricey, oddly enough. and they never make it spicy enough, they decide that diablo blanco's arent prepared for the en fuego assault, and then i get livid. oh well, easier on them i suppose.
author: Christopher J.

description: Having been to several Pakistani restaurants in the Bay Area, I didn't think Shalimar would have anything out of the ordinary.  Sure, I expected to have a delicious meal but I didn't realize how much I'd enjoy the various dishes we ordered.  We ordered some of their lentil and chick peas dishes and those were very good.  The lamb curry was cooked perfectly with just the right amount of spice.  The tikka masala was the best I've ever had!!!  Shalimar also had potato naan, onion naan and garlic naan,  all of which were soft and had a slight sweet taste.  The portions were very generous and I appreciate the free chai and low key atmosphere.  I am sure to be back soon.
author: Mika S.

description: This place is like walking into Lahore.  Seriously, the decorations are hilarious.  The food was really good and the prices were SUPER reasonable.  The naan is not as amazing as other reviewers mention, but it was good.  The tandoor meat dishes are really well prepared, the food is relatively fresh and the spices are well proportioned.  Highly recommend it and would go back.  Very diverse crowd and pretty busy.  And yes, that blind dude that hangs out down the street (I think by O'farrell) totally recommends this place to everyone.  Very funny.  Give him a dollar.
author: Sanjiv B.

description: ive been to all the other naan with curry type places, and i thought they were good. not until i found out that they all opend on the same street as shalimar cuz shalimar is one of the best! yeah, its kind of ghetto around here, but the food is great. the naan were so thick and warm, not like th eother burnt to a crisp type naan. i give it a 4 jus b/c i walked to the bathroom and saw a bucket full of raw chicken breast bones with some meat still on it, blech
author: Janelle H.

description: guys, i love this place for the simple fact that where else can you go late at night and get a good meal in the city. the people alway serve us amazingly well for the dive it looks like. they have even gotten other people to get up when we arrive so we have a place to eat. guys dont order chicken tikka masala its just not the specialty. go with the chicken tikka boti, brain masala, palak paneer or chops. yum! and totally cheap. its pakistani food so dont look to compare it to the indian restaurants that serve all the food made with the exact same curry. bring hand sanitizer with you and wet wipes, dont bother with the bathroom.
author: Naureen H.

description: The best phrase I can use to describe this place is "bare bones".  It's cheap, the menus are printed on newspaper, and there's not much atmosphere.  Saag Paneer tends to be my go-to indian dish, and I wasn't particularly impressed by it here.  However, one of my indian friends swears by this place, so maybe it depends what you get.  No liquor license, so it's the always exciting go-to-the-corner-store-BYOB experience.  Not crazy about it, but if you're short on cash, this place might come in handy.
author: Patrick P.

description: Good food, inexpensive, and the place looks cleaner than a lot of other Indian eateries. And, Chai doesn't cost extra!! I would recommend this place to a friend!
author: J J.

description: I LOVE Shalimar!  The food is delicious, it's all very reasonably-priced, and we BYOB, which was nice.  It's very bare bones and no frills, but the food is unbeatable.  Okra dish is delicious, naan is yummy, I'm getting hungry thinking about it!
author: Jesha C.

description: Naan and Curry, N'n'Chutney, Tasty Curry, Indian Oven, Rotee... i could go on and on naming off the various Indian/Pakistani joints i've been to, and the only one that matters today is Shalimar. Located in the heart of the 'loin its a bit of an adventure, but hey its part of the fun (who doesn't like goth strippers...). When your on your journey be sure to stop for refreshments at the liquor store on the corner as its BYOB. Much like most people I cant help but order the Chicken Tikka Masala... oh the excellence. Unlike all the other places I mentioned above the Masala curry at shalimar is *alot* spicier than most places, instead of the cream light orange/tan color found at most places you get a rich and spicy deep dark orange curry. I've tried several other dishes and all are at or above par to other places i've been, the eggplant is especially good.  Anyway, stop reading this get your butt on MUNI, bring a couple friends, and be prepared to have a great time contemplating how the Buddha fasted with such great food around.
author: Chris F.

description: 3.5 Stars. I like Shalimar, it's cheap, convenient (relative to where I live), and it has good Chicken Tikka Masala. One of the great complaints I have (the 0.25 stars it is missing) is that the Naan is just mediocre. Its neighbors have better Naan (Naan N Curry / Lahore Kirahi).  Beware, if you walk in for more than one second, you WILL smell like it even if you leave right after. So don't check it out until you're ready to order. Oh one more thing the Saag Paneer was great the first time I had it, but the second time it tasted "stemmy".
author: Jeannette L.

description: OK, I'm a big fan of Indian food, and I've tried quite a few Indian restaurants around the bay area. This one, gets my 5-star rating for sure! The naan is THE best I've ever had - so puffy and so fresh. The beef curry is my favorite - very special taste, and very tender. We definitely will go back many times. :)
author: Kerry R.

description: Awesome Indian Paki food. My Pakistani friend brought me here giving it rave reviews and it did not disappoint. The service isn't the most umm.. friendly you will get at a restaurant. It falls in line with my theory of the more authentic and tasty the restaurant, the crappier the service. I still definitely recommend this location.
author: Chris M.

description: ghetto as hell but i love it! my my college roomate who has just move to the states from bombay tried every single indian place he could to find those comfort foods that he loves and when he found shalimar he was so excited he took me there the next day and like he said it was the best place i have indiian food wayyyy better than pakwan and naan n curry cant compare the them to shalimar they arent even in the same hemisphere. got to love shalimar.
author: Jared V.

description: Excellent food and really fast service. Have had several things here and everything I ate was wonderful. Thumbs up for the outdoor seating and the convenience store next door so you can grab your booze and bring it on over it a paper bag. I'm giving Shalimar 3 stars because of 1) its sketchy hood and 2) there can be a pretty long wait for a table if you go at a busy time.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
my review of shalimar requires a background to yesterday afternoon when I was a grouch.


as I was marcus the grouch yesterday afternoon. It started as I was tired which is always a good way to get going. Then toiling went south. 
after opposite of fred toiling I went to force freding practice but I was the only one in attendance.
I then called Urban Diversion about the location of happy hour and was told jones and geary. I was angrily looking for the joint cursing google and ud when I saw that I had made a mistake and that I was on O farrel. 
once I was at the joint I decided to hit shalimar. I called them on the phone and asked about their credit card status. I did not understand their answer so I assumed they were part of the 21st century movement away from cash.
When I got there they said cash only and pointed me to one of those no name atms which charge $4. As I am not a fool I freded down to union square and withdrew $20. I hate carrying cash. I returned to shalimar where they gave me three $5 which was good because I hate presumptive tips. After all of this the chana masala was good. As they are in a dodgy neighborhood they need to accept credit cards. I would pay a surcharge if that would help but as a business do not whine.
author: Marcus R.

description: at first glance it seems a little grungy and sorta a hole in the wall place, which are usually the best i must say. and this place definately earns that hole in the wall yum factor. they have huge nan, and the chefs are cool and will explain to you what they put in the dishes. the chai is ready to drink, and the condiments plentiful. get the garlic nan, they put like fifty cloves in that thing! good food fo sho.
author: Kay L.

description: The nastiest Indian Food in the Country. Very bad food, service, decor, and atmosphere. Chutney's is much better, which is located right across the street.
author: Saleem C.

description: Food was okay.  They definitely have geat naan.  But I didn't think the food was all that special.
author: noman a.

description: i've had a lot of indian food in sf and this place def. does it in terms of flavor.  the ambience isnt great and the parking in the area sucks.  but it's all about the food.  nice people too.
author: Daniele S.

description: I've only been here late at night, mostly drunk, and this place has never dissapointed me. I love the food, the prices, the atmosphere, the FREE CHAI. The wait for a table can be annoying, but its so so so worth it. It's great for a post-bar meal, or for a sober post-theater meal, or for any meal at all. Everyone in my family adores this place. I try to go here every time I am back in San Francisco.
author: Emily S.

description: The best indian food in the city, its just a waste sometimes to go anywhere else for indian food. Their tandoori chicken, specifically the boneless is not from this planet. The rice and the naan are melt-in-your-mouth fresh, bla bla bla, why are you even reading this, go there now (and go alone and preferably with clothes you can throw away, its a nasty little restaurant :) )
author: Ron F.

description: Shalimar is hands down the best Indian Indian food I have had anywhere in the world, including New York, all over the United Kingdom and even Bombay. The No. 17 "King of Curries" is to die for.
author: Anne B.

description: the food is pretty good sure beats naan n curry but boy is it greasy.
author: Art N.

description: food is typical dhaba ( roadside ) food.it's rich & by saying that I mean it's oily,spicy.I loved the chicken keema though I think I can make better than that.The best stuff was the free chai ( tea).Once in a while it's ok.today I am heading to Dosas.wait for my review.
author: Yelp F.

description: great indian food in the TL...cheap...and it is best if you go outside to the secret back room...that is quiet
author: Kate R.

description: i came here for the first time awhile ago. was a little scared because it is a divey place. but the prices were so cheap and the food was actually really good. i had the Saag Gosht for $6 - very good. the only thing was that i'm a huge fan of biryani and it's only served on certain days.
author: Miss O.

description: i have no idea why i come here...maybe because both times my brother and sister have insisted! well today the food was okay but i still think the whole time i was worried if my car would still be outside when we were done. even though my car was parked in the front of the restaurant. also, the two guys staring and looking for something on the side walk made me a little uneasy - as well as the guy that sold my son a bloody soldier  with it's hand cut off. yeah...pretty intense experience. okay the brain masala was not bad and the chai is pretty good. the last bad thing is that you will come out smelling like the food and hours later the smell is still lingering. as i am typing my review my brother complains he has heart burn right now. =) i have to say that if you have any type of stomach problems please don't eat here. it's morning and all of us are still feeling the food in our stomachs. my brother says we need plungers to get the digestion process started. =(
author: Z A.
